Case of the Arrogant Ebayer

Part I

Sandy constantly struggled with her PC. Working for a small repair company was a lot of fun, but dealing with the constant loss of network connectivity, software crashes and freezes was just too much.

"Bob, this is Sandy" she said into her cellphone. "Can you come up here and look at my PC again? It's frozen!"

"Um, did you CTRL-ALT-DEL a few times? Maybe try recycling the power? Ya know, reboot?" Bob responded in his best I-hate-being-the-admin-of-this-small-company-network voice.

"Nevermind Bob!" Sandy responded as she slammed her cellphone shut. She often wondered what the point was of paying a sysadmin that didn't administer any systems, her workstation included....After her PC boot, Sandy logged back into the network only to find that her primary application, Quicken, was nowhere to be found on her desktop or in her program directory.

"DARNIT! How did that happen? Well, I guess I had better reinstall - of course I'll need to visit Bob now and get the CD. Lucky me!" Sandy told herself.

Sandy decide to wait until lunch time - a time when she knew Bob would be out of the office. Bob was known to take two hour lunch breaks, so she had plenty of time to get the CD, perform the install and return the CD before he returned to the office.

A quick jog downstairs and some creative pathfinding found Sandy in Bob's small, poorly-lit and extremely warm office.

"How does he survive down here?" Sandy thought.

Sandy rummaged through all the file cabinets, Bob's desk drawers, the supply cabinets.... the Quicken CD was no where to be found.

As a matter of fact, Sandy couldn't find ANY software CD's.

Sandy noticed a large gym bag under Bob's desk. Upon closer inspection, Sandy found that it contained Bob's workout clothes and some balled-up papers.

"EWWWWW!" Sandy exclaimed as she dropped a stained pair of socks. Before she could zip the bag up, a familiar logo on one of the balled-up papers caught her eye.

It was the eBay logo - and Sandy had a feedback count of 312. She was an eBay expert.

Unwrapping the paper, Sandy was surprised to find that the paper was a printout of a successful auction.

"Maybe Bob is selling his car on eBay?" Sandy wondered. As she examined the paper closely, she noticed that Bob was the seller... his ID was a dead give-away... "BobWeaverAZ".

But what really caught her eye was the item being sold.

A piece of software in the box, including CD, manuals, and the EULA (end user license agreement).

It was a copy of Quicken.

Part II

"No flavored creamer? What the hell?" I thought as I ravaged the company coffee stand. This cup of pure Peruvian Organic delight was going to taste rather bland without some hazelnut goodness added. Oh well. I had to remember that this was a small company and people pretty much brought whatever they wanted to drink with them from home.

"Hey Chief, you made it!" a familiar voice yelled my direction. It was Sandy, a former coworker of mine from way back. Sandy had called me to her new digs, a small electronics repair company, to investigate some missing software. "Some software SHOULD go missing" I mused to myself, remembering Microsoft Bob. *shudder*

"Come into my office, we have a lot to talk about." Sandy said as she bounced around the corner into her office. "I need some professional help."

"I've been telling you that for years." I sassed back, wedging myself into a strange metal chair that just needed a power source and some wires for a lively game of capital punishment..."Here's the scoop." Sandy began. "Our Sysadmin, Bob, is the resident... oh what did you used to call them?"

"BOFH?" I replied. "Bastard Operator From Hell?"

"Yes! That's him. He can't stand to be bothered when we need help, we're not quite sure what he does on the servers, and he never seems to be 'around' when you need him. "

"Tell me something new Sandy." I said matter-o-factly. "BOFH's have been around a long time. They're like luggage, and just as hard to get rid of sometimes."

"Well, we think we've found a way. The president of the company and I suspect that Bob is selling company assets on eBay." Sandy said with a scowl. "I found these printouts of auctions in his gym bag under his desk. You'll notice that he is the seller on all the auctions, and the items in the pictures we've traced as being assets. Look at the serial numbers of the software in the pictures! We're registered to the serial number! Unreal!"

"Fascinating." I blurted out in the middle of examining the papers. "Have you confronted Bob about this yet? "

"Yes, this morning." Sandy said. "However, he claims that someone used his ID to sell the items on eBay. He was upset, so we let him go home for the rest of the day. It's not like we're not used to seeing his chair empty in his office."

"Has he been back into his office since you sent him home?" I asked.

"No." she responded.

"Does he have remote access to the network from home?" I asked her, raising an eyebrow.

"No. At least I don't think so." Sandy replied in a hushed voice.

I rose from my chair, and made a bee-line for Bob's office.

"Where are you going?" Sandy yelled from behind her desk.

"To catch a thief." I replied.

I only hoped I wasn't too late.


Part III

"What a mess!" I thought to myself, pouring over the contents of Bob's "desk". Desk would be a misnomer - more like "place to throw all my stuff, food wrappers, empty soda cans and used tissues". I haven't been this nauseated since the time I accidentally watched the Rosie O'Donnell show... or was that Oprah.

A folder in one of the desk drawers contained a network diagram that had actually been updated in the past year. I was impressed.

Glancing over the document, it appeared that the office had a single outside network connection. It was a fractional T-1 connected via a large national provider. There appeared to be a firewall in place between the internal network and the border router.

A wireless scan for rogue access points produced nothing. Hmmm.

"Sandy - do you have any POTS lines into this building?" I yelled down the hall. My voice trailed off as I noticed a phone cord running behind the bookcase to my left and heading towards the PC computer on the floor...."Why does he have a phone cord plugged into his PC?" Sandy asked me. "I thought we only had one POTS line - and that went to the fax machine in the next room."

"Looks like he split the line" I said. "Sandy, I'm going to need to do a forensic analysis of his workstation to prove anything. Has anyone touched his machine since he left?"

"No - are you kidding? Nobody WANTS to come in here. It's like a sauna!" Sandy joked.

Twenty minutes later I had retrieved "Roscoe" from the trunk of my car. Roscoe is a portable forensic analysis workstation that I carry with me for just this type of occasion.
"All I need now is a laptop named Enos" I mused.

I took several pictures of Bob's workstation, showing it's location, cords, serial number and asset tag number. I then unplugged the power cord from the back of the PC, and heard the workstation die in protest.

"Chief, what are you doing? Doesn't that hurt the computer?" Sandy exclaimed.

"It's the best way to preserve the state of the machine, especially since it's running a Windows operating system." I responded. I continued to amuse Sandy with tales of how the Windows swap file is a treasure trove of information, and I didn't want to take the chance of modifying anything on the drive.

I proceeded to take pictures of the inside of the machine, noting serial numbers, brands of equipment, etc.

Instead of removing the hard drive from it's restraining bracket, I simply placed the 'leech' IDE cable from Roscoe onto the drive with a write-blocker in place. I powered up Roscoe and proceeded to make an image of the disk drive using Encase, my tool of choice.

"Time to find a good sandwich shop" I announced to Sandy. The drive copy was going to take about an hour to complete.

"What are expecting to find on the drive, Chief?" Sandy kept asking me.

"Fingerprints" I responded.

Part IV

"I sure am glad this guy only had a 9GB harddrive in this machine." I thought to myself while watching my forensic toolkit application load the captured image of Bob's workstation into memory.
The thought of having to look through another 100GB image of files was a recent painful memory from another case I had worked on.

Beep!

The image had finished loading. Now was the time to start scanning through the contents of the drive....
(quick aside)
I like to make lots of notes during a forensic analysis - that way I can always backtrack to a certain file should the need arise.

One of the first notes I had made for this casefile was that Bob's PC has a system clock that was off by 10 minutes. Apparently Bob never paid attention to what time it was, or he liked to be late to everything. Developing a time delta is important, because it's typically your best reference point in reconstructing events between the PC and the world.
(/quick aside)

"Need some coffee Chief?" Sandy asked about 10 seconds before she appeared at the doorway to Bob's office.

"Yes please - and find some flavored creamer, will ya?" I rattled back.

I was making great time going through hundreds of web page fragments that I had found in cache files, temp files, swap space and slack space on the drive.

"I guess he likes Russian women and viagra." I joked to myself as I made some notes on Bob's internet usage habits.

"Here ya go!" Sandy proudliy announced as she placed a hot mug of joe on the desk in front of me.

"Sandy, do you know who your company attorney is? I asked as I burned my upper lip on the fresh coffee.

"Sure - Peter Nelson. Why?" Sandy asked - obviously puzzled by my request.

Doing a quick stretch of my arms in an effort to release the building tension on my shoulders, I slipped the glasses off my nose and placed them on the desk.

"Get him on the phone. This is way beyond eBay."

Part V

To the common Joe, cigar smoke is categorized into two flavors. The first is "full-bodied, rich and melodic" - the second being "oh my God! Someone is smoking a cigar! Oh I'm going to puke!".

Peter Nelson's office was like stepping into a humidor in a fine cigar shop. Cool, humid and reeking of tobacco leaves. Sixty seconds after walking in the door I was addicted to nicotine.

"So this is the great Gatsby! What does Sandy call you... Chief?" Peter bellowed behind his large mahogony desk.

"I've been called worse." I thought, remembering an angry ex. "I have a picture show for you Peter, and you may want to add a scotch to go with that Cigar."

The befuddled look on Peter's face amused me in a strange, primal way. Almost like I had called his mother an ambulance-chaser.

The lits dimmed, the LCD on my linux laptop released a glowing shower of illuminating pixels, and I slammed the last of my flavored coffee down...."Your company is harboring illegal activity." I announced.

Peter fidgeted in his seat. "Excuse me?" Peter asked.

I switched to a different slide in OpenOffice's Impress (powerpoint for all you Windows folk) and began the tale.

"Your system administrator, Bob, has been selling company assets such as software licenses, software media and hardware on eBay and a number of other online marketplaces." I said.

"Yes, I'm aware of THAT!" Peter snapped back. "So we scare him, let him go, hire somebody else. Big deal. What is this illegal activity crap?"

"Peter, do you understand the term 'minimum necessary access'? " I asked.

"Hey, I wasn't born yesterday! Yes - employees only have access to information that is required of their job description - any good attorney nowadays has heard of it." Peter replied.

"Well, Bob has access to everything witin this company - including e-mail, financial data, payroll, your website, your databases..."

"YES! Ok, but he's the only one that knows how to access the systems. We're not that big of a company and it's normal for him to access all of that stuff." Bob said, clearly becoming agitated with me. "He makes sure the orders get into the database via the website, updates the website pages with data from our files, blah blah blah."

"Or his files?" I inquired.

*click*

The next slide appeared on the laptop.

Peter was stone faced. So much so that I was tempted to check his vitals for any sign of life.

"What... the... what the hell is that?" Peter stammered, pointing at the slide.

"It's an eight-year old girl." I replied.

Part VI

You could hear a pin drop. The boardroom of the company was cold and stocked to the hilt in mahogony furniture.

"If only I were a termite!" I thought.

My attention was diverted to the CEO as he spoke to the other members at the table: the CFO, Peter, Sandy, and the human resources manager.

"We've all sat through the Chief's presentation, and we're aware of what one of our employees has been doing over the past year. I'd like for the Chief to walk us through how he found this information and what we should do next." said the CEO in his best "oh my God we're all doomed if this gets out to the public" voice.

Coffee in hand, I walked to the front of the boardroom, hooked my linux laptop to the LCD projector and began discussing the notes of my investigation...(aside)
As you've probably noticed, a good part of my time is spent giving presentations and discussing procedures and facts. This is the hard part - explaining forensic evidence to people who are not necessarily technical folks, and not losing them in legal jargon or FUD [fear, uncertainy & doubt].
(/aside)

"Ladies and Gentleman, you've read my prepared case notes surrounding this incident, and I'd like to elaborate on several points.

I was called to investigate the apparent theft of company property by Bob.

I surmised through a forensic investigation of Bob's workstation that he was, in fact, advertising for sale company assets, collecting funds for the assets via Paypal and shipping the items using the company fedex account.

During the course of this investigation, I discovered traces of images on Bob's workstation that were clearly nude pictures of children. The pictures were downloaded using Internet Explorer, and were part of several webpages - webpages that originated from this company's web server.

I discovered traces of IRC and ICQ conversations between Bob and other people regarding the acquisition, trading, storage and distribution of these types of images.

A snippet of one conversation detailed Bob's plans to allocate 5GB of drive space on the company's web server for the safe distribution of these images. The directory structure of the site was well hidden under a virtual directory called 'test'. Below this directory were web pages that contained thumb-nail galleries of the pictures.

I also recovered FTP logs on Bob's workstation and the web server that clearly show when and where the images were put. Examination of these logs showed that the time the images were uploaded from the workstation and received by the server were off by exactly 10 minutes. Bob's workstation is 10 minutes off from the webserver's clock which is sync'd like the rest of the network using an NTP (Network Time Protocol) device.

According to the webserver logs, there have been over 30000 hits to this protected directory from approximately 400 different hosts around the world in the past year alone. " I said, pausing to drink some coffee.

"I have prepared a formal report which has been provided to you in hardcopy and electronic format. I have given Peter a forensically-sterile copy of all of the electronic evidence I have collected, along with the chain-of-custody documents. It is my understanding that Peter will be contacting the Crimes Against Children task force of the FBI. Correct Peter?"

"Yes. The board has voted to hand over all evidence to the FBI. This is not something we want to brush under the rug, so to speak." Peter responded.

I closed my laptop, threw my styro coffee cup in the garbage and headed out of the boardroom to the elevator.

I wondered to myself how many companies (especially large companies) brush this stuff 'under the rug'? How many of these crimes go unpunished? How may of these types of crimes are not investigated using proper procedures and are torn apart in court?

As I pressed the 'lobby' button on the elevator, I thought about the kids in those pictures. I wondered to myself "who is THEIR voice in all of this? Who fights for the children?"

I approached the glass door of the lobby, bumping it with my laptop bag. I caught a reflection of myself as I opened the door.

"Oh yeah" I thought.

Case of the Talkative Terrorist

Part I

"Chief, you want anything from the Coffee Shop? We're making a run!" Mike announced in the doorway of my office.

"Do you have to ask? Coffee of the day - hazelnut flavoring - and make sure you get a cup condom - I don't want to burn my hands on their cups." I replied, half laughing at myself for using the word 'condom' in regards to coffee.

The mood in the office had been quite somber in the past week. The date? September 18, 2001.

Fear. Anger. Outrage. These feelings raced through my system like a bad burrito with sour cream. Only a week had passed since the worst terror attack the United States had ever witnessed.

The glow of the Sun CRT on my desk lit up my spectacles as I browsed through CNN.COM.

"Bad news.... bad news... bad news... oh look, someone rescued a kitty from a well. How refreshing!" I said to myself, waiting for that cup of coffee that was taking way too long to get to my desk.

*ring*

Glancing at my office phone, I saw that one of the fraud investigators was calling. Being the ISO at a small telecom was an interesting experience to say the least.

"I hope this isn't about my last expense report." I mused as I picked up the phone.

"Chief? It's John. Can I run something by you? " he asked.

"Sure, as long as you bring me coffee." I replied...."Okay, I've been working fraud for five years, and I can't make heads or tails of this!" John exclaimed as he slammed two large binders of dead tree on my desk.

"We have a user of our teleconferencing service who ran up $4000US in charges. His credit card was denied. I called the user, they pleaded ignorance and gave me another card number. That was denied as well, and now the user has disappeared! We can't contact him at the numbers he provided us." John said.

"You called the card issuers, right?" I said, cutting him off. "Stolen cards?"

"Good guess. So I had services flag the account for non-payment and it's been deactivated." John said as he took a sip out of MY coffee that he had brought ME.

"I'm not hearing anything new here John. What's got your goat?" I asked, watching him drink more of MY coffee.

"Oh yeah... sorry. Well I had my two junior analysts start cross-referencing all the teleconference connections, and... well... we can't find them." John replied nervously. "It's like they never existed, yet they ended up in billing!"

"What? The system doesn't allow that to happen." I spouted back. "Are you sure your monkeys aren't eating fermented bananas over there?"

"Checked it myself. Help!" John pleaded as he went back to his desk.

"Hmmmm. Missing references in the calls database. Stolen credit cards. Disappearing users. Guess I'd better order in lunch today." I remarked to myself as a I poured over the thousands of pages of information now occupying my desk.

I was intrigued. Our system was designed to record every call into our distribution system, and every call from an outside system that joined our teleconferencing system. The calls were referenced by a CID (Caller Identification Number) that is composed of the calling phone number, network id, etc. It's essentially a big long string of characters like a VIN (Vehicle Identification Number) where every letter and number means something. Yet, these teleconferences had 'ghost' connections - no CID.

"Where are the ghostbusters when you need them?" I muttered angrily, wondering where the hell my Coffee Shop coffee was.

A few hours had gone by, no coffee, but lunch showed up in the form of a delicious sliced beef sandwich with au jous. Then I saw it.

"Holy crap!" I said to myself as my sandwich fell out of my mouth. I grabbed my phone and hit the 'quick-dial' button for telecom operations.

After two quick rings I was greeted with "TELOPS. Frank speaking."

"Frank, Chief here. I need you to assemble the system developers, the database guy and anyone else that knows how the routing system works NOW. Conference room 2 in 30 minutes." I barked into the phone.

"10-4" Frank replied.

Part II

"Why is it so cold in here?" I muttered, looking around Conference Room #2 for a thermostat. I was half-tempted to start cutting a hole in the floor and start ice fishing.

One by one the critical members of the TELOPS development team scampered into the conference room. Nobody likes to be ushered away from real work to an impromptu meeting, but these guys expect last-minute meetings from me - the evil security guy.

"Uh-oh. Chief has a live one." joked Pitre, noticing the stacks and stacks of dead tree surrounding my position at the head of the conference table. "And me without my PDA!"

"Quiet you!" I joked back while motioning for Mr. SmartySwede to close the door behind him.

I dimmed the lights in the conference room, unlocked the screensaver on my linux presentation laptop, and welcomed the team with slide #1:

"The system is haunted"...I quickly brought the team up to speed on my phantom records.

"The real kicker isn't what you're seeing on the paper, but what's NOT on the paper. If you'll examine the teleconference logs, you'll notice that not only is the CID missing, but the OCN (Originating Connection Network) is zero." I said.

"Chief, we don't have an OCN with an ID of zero - that must be a table-level error in the database." Pitre speculated.

"Wrong - I'm querying the database now, and the rows for these records do indeed have zeros in them." announced Andre, our resident DBA lord as he glanced over the scrolling text on his laptop.

"Then there's an error in the population application - we're not reading the OCN correctly at the point of hand-shake." spouted Phil, one of the application developers.

"Can you verify your code?" I asked Phil while generously offering Phil the laptop of Andre.

"I'm only one SSH session away from answering that question." joked Phil as he typed fevorishly on the laptop.

A few minutes of pondering and questions had gone by when Phil announced "Well, there goes that theory - CVS shows no changes to the production code in 3 weeks, and I just walked a connection through the entire application - flawless."

"Let's look at where we're at here. The record of the teleconference IS hitting billing, so we know that process is working. Billing is reporting what it's handed - so something is amiss in the telops infrastructure." said Andre as he clawed at Phil to return his prized notebook.

I sat for what seemed an eternity listening to the team volley ideas, speculations and accusations around the table. In between two sips of cold coffee, I turned to Phil and injected my thoughts into his conversation.
"Phil - in the code snippet that you walked me through, you're more or less doing a case-by-case ID assignment based on OCN, correct?"

"Yep." Phil replied. "Why?"

"And those OCN's are fed by the provider.." I trailed off.

"Yes, yes..." Phil nodded his head.

"But we're counting on the provider to do some homework while making the connections - and if they fell down while doing their accounting..." I trailed off yet again, lost in thought.

"We'd still see the handoff phone number!" Phil said, glancing around the table at befuddled team members.

"Not if the connection is another... teleconference!" I blurted out in mid-thought.

"Huh?" Phil asked. "You're saying..."

I stood up in front of the table and rolled a fifty-page diagnostic from one of the calls out onto the conference room table.

"The bastards are conference jumping - and they've just found a hole in our system that didn't show up because nobody is looking for this sort of thing - until the next billing cycle comes up - and then it takes 30 days for fraud to be notified. Sixty days of anonymous connections with the system!" I exclaimed while shuffling around more dead trees, trying to find the phone number of the ISO at one of our largest providers.

As I hit the speakerphone button on the phone on the table and dialed his number, my heart was racing because I already knew what he was going to tell me.

Part III

Spending all day on the phone can have some strange psychological effects on a person. For instance, you sit down at a restaurant afterwards and give your order to the little shiny box in the center of the table. Then you realize "Hey, that's a napkin holder! Not a speakerphone!" The glaring eyes of the people sitting around you is rather amusing though. Like THEY have never talked to a napkin holder before.

Our conversations with our providers' ISOs (Information Security Officers) were very productive. It would seem that all of the providing networks which feed teleconference callers into our system had the same 'ghost' records in their billing systems. Most weren't aware of the problem until our phone call.

One particular provider was especially helpful, and I had worked with their ISO on a number of occasions relating to inter-network security. AJ was an all-around cool guy, former black hat-turned-white hat and pretty darn funny. We decided that we'd work together as a team on this investigation.

We started off backtracking connections to the teleconference systems call by call. It was a very slow, painful process that took several hours. The clock was flirting with midnight when AJ called my office.

"Chief - you'll never guess what I did." AJ asked.

"Fell asleep at your desk and were woken up by that annoying beep that the spacebar makes when your head slams into it?" I replied in my most groggy kermit-the-frog sounding voice.

"Nice try, but no. I found an originating phone number into a teleconference that started on my network and jumped to yours!"

I almost dropped the phone.AJ and I were both exhausted, so we agreed to call it a night and start again in the morning.

One pot of coffee and 6 hours later I was back in the office and my mind was racing. Almost on cue my phone rang - it was AJ.

"We ran a records trace on this number last night." AJ said. "You asked me for the last three months of call data, and boy do I have a present for you!"

"How much data are we talking?" I asked apprehensively.

"I just dropped you a PGP-encrypted email with a document attached. This guy was BUSY!" AJ laughed.

"What do you mean?" I queried as I popped the passphrase into my mail client. "Busy as in ordering undies from Macy's or what?"

"Busy as in calling all over the damn world!" AJ said in a now-increasing southern accent.

I examined the document AJ sent, and made notations on countries, times, dates... trying to wrap my mind around what this guy was doing with our systems.
The caller was dialing locations in England, India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iraq, Kuwait, Germany... but the calls were short - under a minute. And then the same teleconference network received inbound calls from those same countries within minutes.

"And Chief, it gets even more interesting. Flip to the last page of the report." AJ said.

I quickly flipped to the back page marked "Reverse Number Lookup".

"Ah, cool. You found the location that this number belongs to!" I exclaimed.

As I read through the detail dump, the report almost fell out of my hands.

"AJ, this address is 2 blocks from where the world trade center stood! " I blurted out.

The coincidence was astounding.

Part IV

"Um, I'm new to this region - how do I get to your office again?" asked Special Agent Jones. He had called me on my office number from a pay phone.

After giving SA Jones driving directions in excruciating detail, I hung up the phone and alerted my secretary that we'd be having a visitor shortly.

"No wonder they never found Jimmy Hoffa" I cackled as I placed the finishing touches on the three-ring-binder holding all of the information that SA Jones requested. I burned a copy of all documents, reports, and files to a cd-rom for their convenience. I imagined that the FBI would have an easier time grepping through a million lines of information in digital form than paper.

I carried the binder and CD into the office of the company Attorney, alerting him that the FBI was going to present us with a warrant for the information. The look of relief on his face was a sight to behold - if you were into bulldogs I guess.

*buzz*

The intercom in my office crackled loudly.

"Chief, you have a visitor from the FBI waiting in the lobby." announced the receptionist.

"On my way." I said to myself as I broke into a quick trot down the hallway.SA Jones looked a little frazzled sitting in the lobby. He was outfitted in the standard "look at me I'm a federal agent" outfit. Short-sleeved dress shirt, 'outback' vest, and tan SWAT pants. His badge and gun clung to his waistline like a couple of Krisy Kreme doughnuts.

We settled down in a conference room close to the entrance, and I presented SA Jones with a fresh cup of coffee.

"Any flavored creamer?" he asked.

"I like this guy already!" I mused.

SA Jones presented me with a warrant for the information, which I glanced over and gave to the receptionist. She walked the warrant to the Company Attorney's office.

"I have to say Chief, this is impressive" SA Jones said as he flipped through the book. "You wouldn't believe the type of evidence that people give us - we usually need a team of SA's just to organize it into something understandable."

"We aim to please." I joked.

"We'll contact you if we need more information or clarification of what you've given us. You might want to give me your SSN just in case you move on to another company. We have ways of finding you." SA Jones said with a half-smile on his face.

I escorted SA Jones out of the building, and returned to my desk. I knew that I should be feeling happy that I was able to assist the FBI in an investigation, but I was frustrated... frustrated that my contribution ended with me passing SA Jones the book.

Two weeks later, I was contacted by SA Jones. They had some 'hits' on some of the phone numbers that were in our notes, but that was all that he could tell me.

(fast forward to today)

Sitting in my living room at home and watching CNN I see that more suspected terrorists were found around the world.

I always sit and wonder... did the information that I helped discover have anything to do with their capture? Did a phone number lead them to a person who knew something about somebody's half-sister that was involved with a brother of someone who likes to blow up innocent people?

The great thing about information security is that you never know what you'll find while looking for the truth... like finding out an employee is selling confidential information to the black market for extra spending cash.

Special Agent Monkey is on the case.

Mysteriously Missing Records

Part I

Speed. I could not believe the speed of the computer that was in front of me. I had just received a Sun Ultra 60 dual-processor workstation, and I was carefully performing a stage1 install of Gentoo Linux on it. My office was alive with the magical hum that only a Sun powersupply can provide.

"Sweet Gina! Look at the compiler go!" I blathered as my eyeballs followed the code scrolling accross the console.

*ring* The phone rang impatiently.

"I hope this isn't that gal I spilled beer on last night in the bar!" I thought to myself as I pressed the phone to my ear.

"Chief? Hi, my name is Debbie. I'm the receptionist at your Doctor's office!" came a perky voice over the phone wire.

"Oh my God! You goofed on my test results!" I shrieked, clutching my chest in perhaps the best Fred Sanford impersonation ever performed by a white man.

"No, no silly! I still have your business card from the last time you came in and asked me out. Remember? I turned you down?" She said as I managed to stand back up.

"Uh, yeah sure! Hey I didn't spill beer on you last night did I?" I asked

"Huh?" She replied.

"Nevermind." I said in a sigh of relief. "What can I do for you, since we obviously aren't going out on a date?"

"The Doctor would like to talk to you... about a theft in the office." Debbie said, taking a much too serious tone.

"Tounge depressors?" I quipped.

"No - Patient Records." Debbie shot back..."I'll be right there." I said as I looked around for my car keys.

The Gentoo compile would have to wait.

An hour later I was seated in the waiting room of my doctor's office. Reading material was in abundance, but the quality was questionable... unless you like Oprah magazine and The New England Journal Of Medicine.

"Chief? The Doc will see you now." Debbie said, opening the mysterious door-of-wonders that led from the waiting room to the "hallway of examinations", commonly referred to as the "freezing meatlocker from hell" by most patients.

I seated myself on what appeared to be a vinyl chair wrapped in wax paper, and Debbie closed the door behind her as she returned to the reception area.

"I hope this appointment doesn't involve me dropping trou" I mused.

"Chief! How are ya!" the Doc said as he bounced (literally) into the examination room. This guy has more energy than a roomful of third graders during a snack break.

"Good. I hear you're missing some patient records?" I asked.

"Yes, I'm afraid I am. " He replied as he sat next to me on the finely-wrapped vinyl table.

"How did this happen?" I asked.

"Well, we just started using this document imaging software. We're moving the paper records to electronic you know... and we noticed that a few days this week we were missing records from the database. Scans that we know we put in, but they don't show up!" the doc said.

"And you're sure you're using this thing right?" I joked, getting the 'duh' look back from the doc.

"Yes, we're using it the right way. Can you take a look?" he pleaded as we left the examination room and entered the office area.

The Dell PC was on, running Windows XP.

"Gag me." I muttered.

I ran through a quick cursory examination of the operating system, settings and the application.

"Doc, are you working your staff late, or what?" I said, flipping through the application logs.

"Hey, this is a doctor's office. Everybody goes home at ... " he began.

"3:10am?" I asked.

Someone was performing an invasive procedure on this system.

Part II

"Doc, you really need to get a better quality of coffee bean in here." I muttered as I emptied the coffee pot into my road-worn styro cup.

I had been in the office all afternoon and most of the evening, pouring over system and application logs.

At first glance, it appeared to me that a user was logging into the application around 3:00am over the past week and searching for records. Once the target records were found, they were removed from the system.

The application stored all the documents in PDF format. The scanning engine did a great job - I was astounded at the quality of the scans.

Turning back to the system log files, I spied an unknown ip address...I had attached my laptop to the network earlier and made a nice nmap scan history of the entire network. There were just a few nodes.

192.168.1.1 - Netgear router to the internet w/firewall rules in place.
192.168.1.10 - Officemanager's computer (the one I was on)
192.168.1.20 - JetDirect Printer
192.168.1.11 - Doc's PC in his private office
192.168.1.254 - My laptop (I chose 254 because it was free, and was clearly different than the other devices)

The unknown ip address was 192.168.1.100. Hmmm.

I verified that no other portable devices were ever brought in or attached to the network.

I performed a wireless network audit using Kismet ... no access points, no traffic at all. Hmmm.

I verified the location of all POTS phone lines. Only one for the fax machine.

"Me thinks we have a phantom machine on the network." I thought to myself.

After downing the last of my coffee, I got down on my hands and knees and started tracing CAT5 network cable.

I traced the machine I was on to the wall jack, and the same for the printer and doc's computer.

"I wonder what's down the rabbit hole?" I mused as I unlocked the phone room door to the office.

I quickly located the patch panel for doc's office, and traced each connection back to the netgear switch.

One cable to the internet...
One cable to the office manager PC...
One cable to the printer...
One cable to doc's PC...
One cable to the spare CAT5 jack in the office...
One cable...

One more cable? What?

The cable ran behind the Netgear device, down to the floor, and then snaked back up the wall into a removable ceiling tile.

Doc's network was tapped.

Part III

"MY EYES! MY EYES! DEAR GOD MY EYES!" I cried to myself as I happened to notice that the Sup had a severe case of plumber-crackitis.

"Alrighty, there ya go. You mess anything up and you gotta pay for it!!!" the Sup said as he staggered down the staircase.
I climbed the ladder, and stuck my head into the crawlspace. Reaching for my trusty maglite , I noticed the smell.

Garbage. Ewwwww.
Crawling about twenty feet, I located the CAT5 cable snaking up from the doc's phone room. Using my maglite to follow the cable's path, I noticed something most peculiar...A small 4-port hub. The doc's cable was inserted into a port, and another cable was running from the small hub to a hole about 3 feet away.

Rolling onto my back, I looked at the floorplan that Mr. CheekCracks gave me, and stared in disbelief.

"Why would a cable be running to an empty suite?" I pondered.

The hub was powered on, so obviously that suite has electricity still.

I crawled out of the crawlspace and made my way back down the stairs and headed towards the sup's office.

"Hey Sup, who was the last tenant of 110?" I asked loud enough to be heard over his radio-broadcast baseball game.

"Nobody. Nobody has ever been in that suite. I use it to store stuff." the Sup yelled back, fixated on the tiny talking box.

"Can I look around in there?" I asked again in an even louder voice.

"Who are you, Magnum PI? Ah, whatever." the Sup responded as he threw a keycard my way.

I left the Sup's office in a hurry and made my way to suite 110. The door was locked. I used the keycard to unlock the door, and clicked the light switch.

Flourescent lights lit up the room, and I was greeted with about 30 large boxes of... crap. As I made my way around the boxes, I located a storage room . At the top of the storage room I saw the mystery CAT5 cable and a power cord running down the wall to a makeshift shelf.

Out of the corner of my eye, I noticed a 5-gallon bucket with a piece of canvas thrown over the top. The canvas wasn't dusty like everything else. Hmmm.

I lifted the canvas slowly, remembering a recent encounter with a midget and a jack-in-the box, and flipped on my maglite.

"Nice laptop." I mused.

Part IV

"Thank heavens for Starbucks!" I stammered as I downed the last of my calorie-heavy coffee creation. I had been sitting in my car for about four hours. A quick check of my watch showed that it was 2:55AM and counting.

I flipped open my trusty linux laptop and finished up my case notes. I had more questions that answers at this point. Why a hub in the crawlspace? Why not just run a cable? I was just organizing a list of geek toys that I was going to buy with the fat investigative bill I was going to present to the doc next week when a flash of headlights caught my attention.

In what seemed like a total retro-moment in time, a VW station wagon pulled into a parking spot about 4 spots south of suite 110. Out stepped a young male, early 20's, ponytail, ballcap and a smoldering cigarette. He was carrying a small nylon overnight bag over his shoulder.

I observed the subject entering the suite with a keycard. The lights were not turned on. Hmmm.

I pulled my car on the side of the building, and crept back up the stairs and into the crawlspace.

The journey through the crawlspace took a bit more time than yesterday, but moving quietly can be a challenge sometimes.

I made my way to the hole in the ceiling above suite 110, and peered down into the storage room.

The subject had removed the laptop from the bucket, and plugged the CAT5 cable into the ethernet port. While the laptop was booting, the subject lit up another cigarette and proceeded to remove a cellular phone from his bag.

I couldn't make out the conversation, but I could see that the laptop was booting into Windows 2000 Professional. While talking on the phone, the subject proceeded to visit several adult-oriented sites, dating sites, and was using instant-messaging software.

Twenty minutes later the subject picked up his cellular phone again, quickly closed all the windows open on the laptop, and proceeded to perform some commands at a command prompt. Within seconds I recognized a familiar window on his screen.

It was the document imaging software that the doc was using.

The subject proceeded to use the system for approximately twenty more minutes, made a phone call, removed what appeared to be a mini-USB hard drive from the back of the laptop, shutdown the laptop and left the area.

"Fascinating." I thought to myself. "I need to examine that laptop."

I made my way back down the stairs and crept slowly to my car. A quick glance around the parking lot showed that the subject had left.

I opened my trunk, removed Rosco (my portable forensic workstation) from my trunk and entered Suite 110.

I walked to the storage room, and noticed that the subject had returned everything to their normal places.

"Well, he's a tidy little freak, isn't he?" I joked.

I set Rosco up on a box that I removed from the corner of the room. I took several pictures of the area, the bucket, the laptop, and made some notes in my journal.

I put a pair of surgical gloves on and removed the laptop from the bucket. As I turned the laptop over so that I could take a picture of the serial #, I saw something that I couldn't believe.

"Property of Newman Investigations. Reward if found."

Part V

Things were getting more confusing by the second. I now had entirely too many questions and not enough answers.

Why was a private investigator pigeon-holed in a suite next to my doctor?

Why was this private investigator manipulating electronic records on the doc's system?

Why not just pick the lock on the suite, bypass the alarm and do everything at the console? Or just steal the workstation? Or just steal the paper documents?

I was one confused monkey.

Two hours later, I had the laptop hard drive imaged. This was no easy task - the hard drive wasn't easily removable. I had to take most of the laptop apart and use an adapter on the laptop drive so it would talk nicely to my ide ribbon cable.

I put the laptop back together, left everything as I found it, and called it a day.

Curiosity was killing me though, and I knew as soon as I returned home I'd be analyzing my recent hard drive capture...

After a fresh pot of coffee I began my examination of the encase drive image using FTK (Forensic Toolkit).

Aside from the usual porn site visits and some meaningless bantering in yahoo messenger, I wasn't finding a lot... aside from a directory full of PGP-encrypted files that had sequential date filenames -- and that's what made my brain go *click*.

I picked up the phone and dialed the number I had copied off of the bottom of the laptop.

"I wonder if anyone has lost a laptop recently?" I mused.

The voice on the other end of the phone was James Newman, the owner of Newman investigations. I had never met James before, but I had read about his involvement in high profile investigations in the local metropolitan area.

As I suspected, James was missing a laptop - his laptop. It was stolen from his vehicle about three weeks ago.

James and I quickly agreed to meet for lunch to compare notes.

Perhaps things weren't as complex as I was making them.

Or were they?

I met James at a burger joint twenty minutes from the doc's office. James was nothing like I imagined - about five feet, five inches tall and a very portly fellow. Juding from how James demolished two gutbuster burgers and finished them off with cheese fries and two diet sodas, I could see why.

I brought James up to speed on what I was doing, the missing records, the mysterious pony-tailed man, the laptop, and the half-ass network tap that I found. James looked more perplexed the more I talked. He immediately asked me if I had attempted to open the PGP-encrypted files that I found.

I replied that I had not.

James looked relieved, took a deep breath, and began a long tale going back almost a year. My suspicions were correct - those PGP-encrypted files were James's case notes from a current case he was working on.
Apparently he was knee-deep in a PI's paradise: a nasty divorce case. A wealthy husband was trying to divorce his wife. Wife hires newman to tail husband, suspecting infideliy. Newman finds out that the husband was indeed cheating on the wife, with an eighteen year old girl, about thirty years his junior. The girl was also three months pregnant.

Bells and whistles were going off in my head. I decided the best course of action was to work with James. James wanted to find out who the pony-tailed man was and how he came in possesion of James's laptop.

"Wonderful." I grumbled.

Conclusion

Three days had gone by. James and I were learning things about each other that only two people cramped up in a car on a stakeout could learn. For instance, I learned never to let James eat any dairy products before beginning a stakeout. Evidently he is intollerant of all things cow.

On the fourth day, we struck gold. It was early in the morning, somewhere around 2am when the familiar VW bug pulled into the parking lot. James had his binoculars out, and in between creating his own cumulous clouds in the car and trying to drink MY coffee, he was humming some rediculous tune that sounded like a song from 'Cats'.

As the subject exited the VW Bug, James focused his binoculars with an intensity I had only seen him have once before, and that was trying to get the top off of a pringles can.

"Unreal!" James gasped.

"What?" I asked him.

"Let's move!" James said, pounding his hand on my dash.

I drove back to the side of the building, and parked my car as far out of sight as possible. James wanted to take this guy down commando style, judging from the weird gleam in his eyes.

I slid my keycard through the door access console, and James opened the door to the suite.
I let James go ahead of me, following the lesser-known survival theory of "put the bigger guy in front of you".

Peering over a pile of stinky moving boxes, we spied the subject hooking the laptop up the network and lighting a cigarette at the same time.

"This boy has talent" I joked to myself.

"Ready?" James mouthed as he gave me some weird hand signal that I had never seen before.

"Ok." I mouthed back.

James approached the subject quietly, and after he was about 5 feet from the subject, announced in a booming voice "Hello Sergio!"

I froze. "James knows this guy? I can't take any more surprises!" I screamed silently into the back of my teeth.

"Uh, what's up Jim?" Sergio said as he sat down slowly, apparently forgetting that he had just sat the laptop on the same bucket ten seconds ago.

"Get off my laptop, fool. What the hell are you doing here, why did you take my laptop, and how the heck did you get in here?" James demanded.

Sergio sighed in contempt. "Dude, you KNOW why I took it, and I'm sure you KNOW why I'm here, so let's stop playing games."

"Pardon me, but what the (expletive) is going on here?" I asked. I felt like I was being dragged down a mountain slope head-first by man-eating elves.

"Sergio here is Beth's ex-boyfriend." James snapped back.

"Beth?" I asked.

"Beth is my client's husband's fling. The pregnant 18 year old girl." James said.

My head was pounding. My specialty was computer crime, and this seemed more like a bad detective novel in a girly magazine (ed: not that I've ever read a girly magazine, mind you. Just what I've heard. *grin*)

Sergio proceeded to fill in the blanks under a brow-beating by James.

Sergio is a computer science student and amateur 'hacker' from the local university. Sergio and Beth had been together since they were 15 years old. Beth left Sergio for Newman's client's husband, which enraged Sergio. When Sergio found out that Beth was pregnant, he suspected that the baby might actually be his.

Apparently Sergio had a private meeting with Newman's client and Newman's client spilled the beans on Newman, asking Sergio to stay out of the investigation and let Newman do his job. Apparently Newman was taking too much time, hence Sergio's theft of Newman's laptop.

Sergio was frustrated that he couldn't read the PGP-encrypted files on Newman's laptop, so he decided to go right to the source: the doctor's office. Through some cleaver social engineering, Sergio passed himself off as a telecommunications worker with the local phone company and acquired a master door card to the facility. (ed: Note that the facility did not program their cards correctly. The facility should have had a 'vendor' card to give Sergio which could have prevented him from using the card outside of business hours) He then performed the poor man's network tap on the doc's office. When I asked him about the network tap, he said it was a spur-of-the-moment thing, and he used the tools he had available to commit long-term surveillance of the computers.

I started my round of questioning. Sergio had gained access to the doc's records system using the tap, however the application was password-protected. Good thing for Sergio that the doc's office manager kept ALL the system passwords in a plain text file on her desktop! Sergio simply copied this file via windows file sharing. (ed: I later checked the file sharing settings on the XP machine in the doc's office, and she did have full file sharing turned on with no permissions!)

I asked Sergio what he was doing in the records system. Sergio replied that he was searching for the medical records of Beth relating to her pregnancy, sexually transmitted diseases, etc.
When I asked Sergio about the deleted records that the doc had told me about, he replied that the deletions were an accident, and the results of him learning the ins and outs of the system.

Conclusion:

Sergio was charged with several crimes relating to this incident, but later plea-bargained his way out of most of them in exchange for testimony relating to another crime.

Beth was indeed pregnant with Sergio's baby. (per a paternity test)

Newman's client divorced her husband and received a large sum of money in the divorce decree.

Newman received a hefty fee from his client. I never saw a penny of it.

The doc was so thankful for my help that he paid for my very first golf lesson.

Case of the Careless Whisper

Part I

"Jeezus, I'm going to be deaf before I'm 40!" I said to myself as the mesmerizing hum of the datacenter breezed into my ears. I was touring the 'datacenter of the future' thanks to a vendor that wanted my company's business bad.

The datacenter had great physical security, including reinforced doors, magnetic card readers, biometric palm and finger readers, not to mention sound sensors in all areas outside of the datacenter.

"Wow, I hope the rats don't get gas here." I mused, imagining a bite of a Big Mac by a few rats causing widespread panic amongst the datacenter security folk.

I was busy wedging myself in between two large Sun E10k's when my cell phone rang.

"Chief? You busy?" a familiar voice asked. It was the CTO of a company I had done a few jobs for in the past.

"I should hope so. You seen my coffee bill this month?" I joked back.

"We need you to help us with.... a little problem..." the CTO said in a hushed voice.
After a quick lunch I headed over to "Simply Software Stuff". The CTO, Joe, met me at the door.

I was ushered into a conference room where a fresh cup of Seattle's finest coffee greeted me with a loving aroma.

"I *LOVE* you guys!" I said as I sipped the hot coffee goodness, complete with hazelnut flavoring.

"Chief, I'll be frank with you. Things are grim. We're less than 30 days away from launching our newest product, and some sources have told us that a competing company is releasing practically the same product in 2 weeks!" Joe exclaimed.

"Ah, perhaps a little birdy told them?" I mused as I studied Joe's face. He was serious.

"Alright Joe, so what do you know? Where do I start?" I asked, halfway through my coffee.

"I have reason to believe that someone here is sharing code with XOR Corporation. I want you to prove it." Joe said with a stern look on his face.

"XOR Corporation? Aren't those the guys that are always 3 steps ahead of you? Are you thinking this has been going on for some time?" I asked.

"I'm afraid so." Joe responded. "And it gets better. I believe the leaks are originating from within the office network while everyone is here... we're talking communication with XOR minutes after crucial meetings."

"How's that?" I asked.

But before Joe could respond, I read his eyes plain as day.

Part II

"Well, I certainly didn't enter information security for the glamor." I mumbled under my breath as I poked my head through a few ceiling tiles at the offices of SSS.

The challenge that Joe presented me with was going to be lots of fun. The majority of the staff members of SSS were hard-core techies, and they knew their stuff cold. The development team was first-rate, the network team consisted of a few published authors on network topology and design, and the sales people were... well, ok they were sales people. But I digress...

The time was 0100 hours, and the only other living soul in the building was a rather annoying cricket. I was looking in the ceiling of one of the conference rooms for an ideal place to drop my 'package'. The package consisted of a freeBSD laptop with an extended-range 802.11b antenna (ed: 128-bit wep, etc) and a built-in ethernet adapter. The conference room I was in was perfect, because there was already a piece of conduit running down the wall to the network jack plate. I simply added another CAT5 cable of the same color (green) to the bundle, plugged in to an empty jack, and jury-rigged the power from an existing light receptacle.

This was getting to be rather fun...I then entered the network patch-panel room, and conveniently jacked my conference room jack into a port of the core network switch. Joe was nice enough to provide me with the appropriate passwords, so configuring a spanning port was a piece of cake. This little port was going to be busy!

After I dropped my 'package' into the ceiling of the conference room and patched myself into the core, I exited the same way that I came (the front door) and key-carded myself out as Joe. The alarm was automatically set and the lights dimmed in the building. Very cool.

I made myself comfortable in the front seat of my car, turn my ignition key to 'auxillary', and turned on my linux laptop. I had equipped my laptop with a custom-made RF antenna made from a coffee can, some coax cable and some glue. There are commercial solutions that look prettier, but none offered the reception that my home-brewed coffee antenna did. And the aroma... the aroma! Sweet, sweet columbian bliss!

Linux booted rather quickly on my laptop, and before I knew it I was sniffing and recording packets to disk thanks to ethereal, my tool of choice. After verifying that I had a working wireless sniffer setup, I shut my equipment down and dialed Joe on my cell phone.

"Yo." Joe responded.

"It's in." I said.

"Excellent. You have three days, the guys in question work 10am to 7pm every day. Please prove me wrong Chief." Joe pleaded.

"I'd like nothing better." I said as I closed my cell phone.

Nothing better indeed.

Part III

No more pastrami for me. My stomach was doing the leap-frog olympics as I sat in my car the next morning, watching network traffic scroll by on my screen.

"Wow, ten more seconds and Linda has won a perfectly good used VCR on ebay for $5!" I marveled.

A quick glance on my watch showed that the 1100 developer meeting was almost over... 1155 and counting.

Good thing this was a relatively small network, because I'm sure that my freeBSD laptop in the ceiling was going bonkers sniffing all of this traffic...
My setup was pretty sweet. The freeBSD laptop had it's ethernet interface in promiscuous mode. I was using a console-based sniffer app to slice the traffic from the wire and make some attractive looking packet dumps.

The wireless connection via another ethernet interface offered me an effortless ssh tunnel to the laptop from my linux laptop in the car where console and X-based apps were a snap to run remotely.

My cell phone rang.

"Chief, we're out. Heads up. *click*"

Joe's shortest conversation with me ever!

I added a few custom filters to ethereal and dug in for some fun.

Two minutes after Joe's call, my custom filter for AIM (AOL Instant Messenger) was slapping red-colored fonts all over my laptop screen.

"Excellent." I thought to myself.

My freeBSD laptop was running a slimmed-down mysql database, apache webserver, and a little app called 'aimsniff'. Aimsniff was plucking the AIM messages from the network traffic and inserting them into a mysql database, recording userid's, messages, date/time stamps, the whole shabang.

"God I love free software!" I said as I brought up Mozilla and connected to the web server on my freeBSD laptop.

Aimsniff was scrawling out a conversation at lightening speed:

dotnetd00d: the design changes are staying in. looks like it won't hurt anything.
t1g3r666: cool. so how did you guys get around the software activation problem that came up in UAT?
dotnetd00d: i dunno. jack handled that - he just recoded it. i'll get the changes for you tonight before I leave
t1g3r666: alright. save me time on doing it haha
dotnetd00d: are you still on for 2 fridays?
t1g3r666: yeah we are launching on schedule. bonus check in the mail like promised
dotnetd00d:k
dotnetd00d: i want the other half soon. i owe $$ to the x
t1g3r666: ok i c what i can do
t1g3r666: dont' forget the changes on p.a.
dotnetd00d:not to worry - gotcha covered
t1g3r666:k - l8tr


A quick cut-n-paste from Mozilla into openoffice saved conversation 1.

Now to zero in on dotnetd00d. And fast.

Part IV

Samba is my friend. Not only does it allow windows and unix boxes the ability to share files and resources, but it comes with a lot of great tools like nmblookup .
Aimsniff is smart enough to be able to use samba to gather the windows workstation name of any chatters on the network segment being sniffed. It would appear that dotnetd00d was using a windows workstation called 'dev07'.

"Surely it couldn't be this simple." I muttered under my breath. That's as smart as prank-calling 911 from your home phone.

A quick nmblookup -A dev07 showed a user logged in named tester04 .

"Dagnabit!" I hissed. As I suspected, the machine had a generic userid logged in.

I had to wonder if that id was assigned to a particular user or group of users, and who knew the passwords...
I buzzed Joe on the cell phone.

*ring*

"Chief!" Joe exclaimed in my ear.

I gave Joe the low down.

"Give me some time to lookup that information on the accounts and I'll get right back to you." Joe said as he closed the phone connection.

I spent the next few hours nursing a splendid house blend of coffee at a local eatery reading the news on my linux laptop and complimentary 802.11 connection. My gut was churning, and I knew it wasn't from the heavenly brewed bliss that I was sipping. Something about this SSS case didn't feel right.

I've busted a lot of stupid computer criminals, but none gave me this feeling. I had to ask myself a lot of hard questions.

Why would a mole choose to communicate with a competitor via an insecure protocol like AIM?
Why not just pick up the phone?
Why not wait and meet after work?
Why take the chance of being monitored at work?

*ring* My cellphone was performing a wonderful melodic rendition of a Mozart composition.

"Chief. " I announced into my phone.

"It's Joe. Here's the deal on the accounts. That machine is in our development lab - the same lab that we develop all our software on. That lab has no outbound firewall restrictions on any machines in that subnet. The userid's are generic and are written on sticky pads stuck to the monitors. Anyone that walks into the lab can sit down and login."

The sound of my hand slapping my forehead was so loud that the eatery customers around me thought I was having a seizure. I was stunned!

"Joe, this is going to add a layer of complexity to the investigation." I said.

"I know, not the most secure practice in the world, but we didn't feel there were a lot of risks in a testing environment." Joe responded.

"Can I get physical access to your building again?" I asked.

"When?" Joe queried.

"Tonight." I said.

I confirmed with Joe that my keycard would still work in the SSS building and told him that I'd update him later.

As quick as I hung up on Joe, I speed-dialed another number on my phone.

"Larry here. How can I help you?" echoed a voice from the receiver.

"Larry? Chief here. I need some toys." I said.

"Hey Chief! Cool! What kind of toys are we talking? Microphones? Infrared sensors? What?"

"Mini-cams. And lots of them." I said.

Time to kick things up a notch.

Part V

My watch read 0430 hours. I was out of coffee.

*ACHOO!*

I was sneezing my head off placing (sample product, not the one used in this case file: mini-cams ) into the ceiling tiles of a few rooms in SSS. I was drilling small holes into the ceiling tiles so that the mini-cam lenses would have an adequate view of the room being monitored. The dust from the tiles was clogging my nose and making quite the mess on the floor. Lucky for me SSS had a well-stocked cleaning cabinet.

I installed cameras in the main conference room, the development lab, and above the developer cube farm. The camera power supplies were patched into power using the same method as the laptop - creative use of light fixture power.

I then proceeded to an empty storage room towards the back of the building that was to be my home for a while...
The cameras worked by broadcasting an image using radio frequency over various channels.
The receivers for these cameras had RCA Video Outputs, which I then plugged into 3 VHS VCR's which were recording the image. The VCR's provided RCA Video Out as well, which I fed into three monitors. Next to the three monitors sat my loyal companion... my wireless linux laptop.

A critical product development meeting was about to take place in five hours. My goal was to correlate visual images and locations of individuals with the conversations streaming accross my aimsniff session monitor.

I buzzed Joe on his cell phone.

"This is Joe. " he announced.

"Joe, Chief here. I'm ready to go." I said.

"Are you recording everything?" he asked.

"I will be once that front door gets unlocked at 7AM" I responded.

"I'm nervous man. Good luck. I guess you'll be 'seeing' me around 8AM at the meeting." Joe blurted as he ended our discussion.

HE'S NERVOUS? I'm the one in a storage room monitoring hidden cameras, internet connections and I have no coffee. I'M NERVOUS.

0700 hours rolled around and I started my recording sessions. Surprisingly, almost all of the employees were in the office and working at 0730 hours.

"Now that's loyalty to getting a product out the door." I mused as I tried to drink from my empty coffee cup.

0800 hours appeared and all of the key staff members that Joe mentioned were in attendance in the conference room. I had a great 'God' shot of the room, and the only face I couldn't see on camera was Joe's, since he decided to sit directly underneath where I planted my camera. Dumb luck I suppose.


The internet connection at the office was virtually silent aside from some SPAM mail and a receptionist that was going hog-wild on eBay.

The meeting broke around 0945 hours, and the only person remaining in the conference room was Joe. All of the developers returned to their cubes after quick trips to the restroom, and the lab was empty.

1015 hours and dotnetd00d makes his appearance on AIM. t1g3r666 showed up as the only buddy in dotnetd00d's buddy list again, and was immediately responsive to dotnetd00d's messages.

Strange.

The conference room was empty. The cubes were full of developers. The lab was empty.

What the...

Then it hit me. I had made an amateur mistake right out of the barn door. I returned to my friend Ethereal the network traffic analyzer and there I saw it... activity on port 58000.

Someone was using VNC to run AIM on a lab machine.

I had their IP address. And nmblookup -A xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx gave me their real username.

Joe was never going to believe this.

Conclusion

An eternity seemed to pass between the time that I buzzed Joe on his cell phone again and the moment that he appeared in my hideaway of a storeroom.

"No way." Joe said as he closed the door behind him.

"No, no way." Joe repeated as he sat down next to me.

I turned my laptop slightly to the right so that Joe could see the console window I had open, and the output from the nmblookup command glowed in a soft green font on a dark black background.

jhayword

"Janice Hayword!" Joe said, pounding his fist on the table. "My personal assistant of three years is a mole?"Joe and I poured over hours of network traffic, and the rest of the traffic was consistent with Janice being logged on to her workstation.

Joe left the storeroom in a huff, and headed straight for Janice's cubicle.

He approached Janice's cubicle quietly, and peered over the 5-foot wall of the cubicle so that he could catch a glimpse of her monitor screen. Sure enough, she had VNC loaded, and was chatting in AIM.

Summary:

Remember earlier in this case file when I said that everyone at SSS was technically proficient? Janice was no exception. She was studying computer science at the local technical school, and was continuing to stay employed as Joe's personal assistant to pay the bills.

Janice was recently divorced and owed her ex-husband a large amount of money due to the arrangements of their divorce decree.

Janice knew a few key people at XOR Corporation from trade shows. She had been approached by a VP of Engineering at XOR during one such tradeshow after overhearing Janice and her ex-husband having a conversation on Janice's cell phone. The VP offered a sizable amount of money for information regarding SSS's products, development cycle, release dates, features... even source code.

Janice had physical and technical access to almost all of the systems at SSS. Due to poor security in SSS's lab environment, she was able to copy and burn CDR's of information at will and use a tool like VNC to connect to the internet via AIM.

Janice was summarily fired from SSS. Litigation is still pending on this case.

SSS was hit with the clue banana pretty hard in this case. They have since taken a much stronger interest in the security of their people, systems and intellectual property.

Case of the CFO CD

Part I

"Texas? You want me to fly to Texas?" I chimed into my cell phone. "It's frick'in humid in Texas!!"

I had been called in the late afternoon on a Friday by a 'friend of a friend' -- industry talk for a confidential referral that involved a large retainer fee. The case was hush-hush, and nobody was giving any details.

I hopped the next available plane to Texas, which happened to be at 0400 hours.

"Nice." I whined to myself, not looking forward to the body cavity search at the airport security checkpoint.

Before I knew it, the pain of the cavity search had subsided and I was wheeling a rental car down a Texas freeway headed toward Mechanical Inc.'s headquarters building...
The building was a large high-rise covered in glass panels, and came conveniently with Valet parking.

"Try not to scratch it." I joked to the Valet as I tossed him the keys to the rental.

Apparently someone had warned the receptionist in the building to be on the lookout for a chimp-like human that had an appointment with the C-level executives. I was rushed into an elevator and tens of stories later I was escorted by plain-clothes security guards into a lavish boardroom, complete with a wetbar and two pots of fresh, hot coffee.

"Jamaican Beans!" I exclaimed as I inhaled the mighty putrid aroma eminating from the pots.

"You know your coffee." said a voice from behind the large mahogany conference room table. "But do you know anything about finding a needle in a haystack?"

"You could say that." I replied, remembering the last time I searched for a shred of compassion while waiting in line at the Motor Vehicles Division.

"Chief, my name is Samuel Johanson. I am the CEO of Mechanical. To my right is our CIO, Michael Dickens, and to my left is Terry Gaim, Corporate General Counsel."

Nods were exchanged around the room.

"So," I began. "What's the needle, and where's your haystack?"

"I can answer that." Terry announced after removing her glasses and letting them drape around her neck from a bright blue cord.

"Three months ago during a Corporate Compliance Audit, we discovered that our CFO at the time, Janice Wheatherly, was moonlighting as a financial advisor for a subsidiary of one of our competitors - NutsAndBolts, Inc. We confronted Janice about it, and she denied any involvement with the company. Our sources indicated that Janice was collecting fees from NAB, and was attending meetings at restaurants with NAB executives until the early hours of the morning. Corporate Security followed Janice and validated the information. We terminated Janice the very next day."

"And the needle?" I begged.

"Ah, yes. Our human resources department and corporate security department had a miscommunication, and Janice was able to reenter the building, copy files to her laptop, burn them to CD, clean the laptop and then leave the building with the CD media before we knew what was going on." Terry said.

"Ok, so I have to ask. How do you know that she burned files to CD media?" I asked.

Michael shuffled in his seat and said "All of our executive offices are monitored by CCTV (closed circuit television). We played the tape back and observed Janice placing CDR media into her laptop. Data Security has already confirmed that her network account accessed very sensitive files on the network at that time."

"So you want me to prove that the files were actually copied to CDR media, thus substantiating your claim that she removed confidential records from the company after being terminated." I deduced.

"Bingo." Samuel said. "Our Data Security guys have been all over her laptop, and they can't find any proof."

"Samuel, do you have a lot of those Jamaican coffee beans?" I asked.

"Uh, sure?" he replied.

"I'll need another pot of coffee and someone to show me Janice's office." I demanded.

Part II

"I love efficiency!" I announced as I examined the accumulated digital evidence that Mechanical's Data Security department provided me. They had really done their homework all the way around.

Bill, the Chief Investigator , had provided me with an enCase image of Janice's laptop drive, a listing of all directories and files (with attributes preserved) on the file server that Janice supposedly accessed, and a copy of the digital video from the CCTV system.

"Bill, you're telling me that your team has gone over this image with a fine tooth comb and there's no trail to the CD burning?" I asked.

"Yep, the trail ran cold during the last examination of the enCase image. We have enough evidence through the usual places in the windows file system to prove that she logged in and copied some files around, but nothing that proves that she burned the files to a CDR." Bill said, taking an almost embarrassed tone with me.

Bill left me to my work in a very comfortable office on the executive floor. I cracked my knuckles and turned Roscoe (my portable forensic workstation) on. Roscoe booted up rather swiftly, almost like he was eager to get on with the investigation...For nearly twenty hours I combed the contents of Janice's hard drive in the enCase image. I was looking so hard for that needle that my vision was becoming a little blurry - although that could have been from the instant coffee that I was forced to drink a few times thanks to the coffee room auto-locking at 2000 hours. That's a crime in itself.

I was beat. I was spent. I wasn't finding anything. The CD burner software was there, and the FAT32 partition of this Windows 2000 laptop wasn't telling me anything.

One of the duties of a forensic investigator is to be completely impartial through all investigations, and my gut was telling me that the needle didn't exist.

"Too bad I'm not looking for a spoon. Maybe Keanu Reeves could help me out." I mused, having a flashback from The Matrix.

The C-level executives were expecting a briefing tomorrow morning, and I had a feeling I wasn't going to give them the answer that they wanted.

Conclusion

The morning came fast. I had barely cracked open an eye in my hotel room when I noticed that I was going to be late for my meeting with Mechanical's executive team unless I skipped one part of my morning routine.

I chose shaving. I certainly wasn't going to be missing my cup of coffee at the nearby Starbucks. Pashaw.

I made record time in traffic, and appeared in front of Mechanical's receptionist with two minutes to spare.

Plainclothes security escorted me again into the elevator. It was like being a movie star, only without the movies, the money or the star status.

I couldn't stop thinking about my investigation, about Janice, and about the briefing I was about to give the Mechanical team. The CCTV clearly showed Janice inserting what appeared to be a blank CD-R into her laptop - but I had to PROVE that she transferred files onto the CD-R. By the results of my findings, I could not tell them that Janice burned the files onto a CD-R.

And then suddenly, it hit me...
Years of working with linux and command-line CD-burning software flashed before my eyes as an idea smashed its way into my cranial cavity.

I apologized to the Corporate Security personnel and asked if I could return to the reception level. I then informed the receptionist that my meeting would need to be delayed until after lunch time.

I quickly drove back to my hotel, whipped Roscoe out from the trunk and entered my room. After a few minutes, Roscoe was up and running and I was examining the file system of the laptop one more time.

What was I looking for? Application swap. Almost all CD-burning applications write the destination CD image to a swap image (most of these are ISO files) before burning to a CD-R to prevent problems with the burn. I had looked the application directory and subdirectories up and down, but hadn't found anything interesting - but we're talking Windows here. Time to bet some money that the application developer had decided to use the system 'temp' directory. Most of the time, I'd be looking in C:\WINDOWS\TEMP, however the laptop image notes that Mechanical's Data Security folks had given me showed that the system temporary directory was set to C:\TMP.

Glancing through C:\TMP, there were lots of files - and a quick sort by date showed me three files that still retained the mystery date that Janice had supposedly burned the CD-R. I had seen these files before during my intial investigations, but I couldn't make sense of the file structure - it looked like one large binary file.

Taking a gamble, I exported the file from the image and burned it onto a CDR. Throwing the CD-R into my linux laptop, I mounted the file using the loopback device to /mnt/image. My pulse quickened as I changed into the /mnt/image directory and issued the standard 'ls -la' command.

Paydirt.

The 'binary file' was actually an ISO image that was created by the application shortly before the burn process. All of the filenames and filesizes that Mechanical had provided me matched the directory listing to a proverbial ' T '.

My meeting with the Mechanical management team was going to be quite different than initially anticipated.

Management team mangled by clue banana. News at 11.

Case of the Drive-By-Spammer

Part I

Saturday mornings are one of the true pleasures in life. There's nothing like waking up, making a fresh pot of coffee from ground organic Peruvian coffee beans, mixing in a creamy stream of Hazelnut flavoring and a dash of skim milk for texture, and then sitting in front of my beloved Powermac and catching up on e-mail, news and a little bit of work.

Minutes after loading up MailApp and connecting via imap/ssl to my mail server, one particular e-mail caught my eye - it was from the owner of a local ISP that I had befriended at a technology expo many years ago.

The e-mail was quite enthralling:

Chief,

Sorry this isn't a howdy-do e-mail. I have a problem that I think you may be able to help me with. I've lost your cell phone number, so sorry about the long e-mail.

As you know, we host a very large mail cluster that hosts approximately 3000 domains. On average, we receive about 12000 spam e-mails a day. Over the past two weeks, this number has jumped to 110,000. Our servers are so busy receiving all of this spam mail and pushing it through spam filters that we're contemplating adding more machines to the cluster to help lessen the load. Unfortuantely, the number of spam e-mails is growing every day. This morning we received almost 150,000!!

Our security analysts have examined a lot of the e-mails, but they haven't come up with much.

This is where you come in.

Help me obi-monkey, you're my only hope!

Call me at XXX-XXX-XXXX asap.

Dick H.


"Sure" I thought to myself. "Right after I have my second cup of coffee goodness." I mused.

SecurityMonkey is on the case.

Part II

Lucky for me, the drive to Cranial-Link (CL) was less than an hour in Saturday traffic. Their office was located close to a local university, so needless to say coffee shops were in abundance.

I entered the lobby of CL with a 16oz cup of joe in one hand and my laptop bag in the other.

No receptionist to be found.

"Oh yeah..." I thought. "It's saturday - where the heck is Dick?" I pondered.

The lobby had three doors - one to the outside (that I just came in), one to what looked to be a restroom, and the last being a high-security door with a badge and palm reader attached to the wall.

*BEEP*!

A loud chirp caught my attention as Dick entered the lobby from the datacenter security door.

"Hey stranger!" he yelled as he helped me with my laptop bag. "This way..." he trailed off as he escorted me into the datacenter...

"Nice flypaper." I joked as I walked through two feet of anti-static/dust matting on the floor. These guys were serious about a clean datacenter.

We were seated in a medium-sized conference room for a few minutes catching up on recent events when we were joined by Mark & Mike, the security analysts for CL.

"Mark, Mike... bring Chief up to speed on where we're at." Dick said as he attempted to drink out of my Starbucks cup.

"Get your own!" I screamed as I snatched the cup from his hand. Why is it that people want to drink MY coffee?
