One of the most common tricks that warez kiddies use is to create a directory called "...". It's meant to be easily overlooked by the other listings in an empty directory - namely the current directory (" . ") and the parent directory (" .. ").

Nick had utilized this trick here. But why?


#cd ...

# ls -la

rwxrwxr-x 5 root root 4096 Dec 7 11:01 .
drwx------ 63 root root 4096 Dec 7 11:34 ..
-rwx------ 63 root root 13444096 Dec 7 11:59 master.mdb


Paydirt.

I burned the master.mdb file onto a CDR disc, and examined it using one of the forensic workstations running Windows 2000. I opened the master.mdb file with Access.

"Holy Mary of Magnolia" Soandso whispered. "He grabbed the entire database. He had access to every arrest we've made in the past year!"

My watch showed that it was 30 minutes past coffee time, so I excused myself to the local Starbucks for a relaxing cup of java and some quiet time to enter my case notes into my laptop.

Ah, the glories of information security work. I was one tired monkey.

(Summary)

What have we learned from this casefile?

Nick was a young, brash, reckless haX0r that knew a few tricks, but he was lazy. He tried way too hard to hide something that he knew any law enforcement agency would want - their own data. He went to an awful lot of trouble to protect this data, but he made a series of mistakes. What were those mistakes?

It was later learned by the HP that Nick was intending on selling the information that he had gathered to anyone that wanted it. Nice business model there, eh? What would some hurdles be to Nick successfully selling this information?

Nick was convicted and placed on probation. Big surprise.

(/Summary)

New casefile next thursday - stay tuned.

~ Chief

When things go bad

Part I

(Intro)

Perry Mason was known for only losing one case in his history of practicing law. I have not been so lucky in the world of information security investigations.

Things are rarely what they seem, people lie, computers malfunction, and the curve balls fly faster than an angry spider monkey hopped up on Starbuck's finest ground beans. I've often been asked about a case that didn't pan out as I intended - my first reaction is to always respond with "All of them."

The case file you're about to read has been compiled from my memory and the case notes of another securitymonkey-type that worked with me. Like all the case files on this site, the events actually happened - but the details have been heavily modified to protect the identities of those involved. (And to protect my monkey butt.)

(/Intro)

When Things Go Bad - Part I
All I wanted was a day off. It was a beautiful day outside, the pool was a very comfortable 80 degrees, and the grocery store down the street had ribeye steaks on sale. I had just cleaned the coffee grinder and was preparing a nice half/half Jamaican/Columbian blend when my cell phone rang.

*ring*

It was a fellow investigator that I periodically handed off work to.

"Chief." I said into the squawking silver-colored box.

"Chief! Dave here. Busy?" Dave asked.

"CURSES!" I screamed into the phone. I had just spilled a pound of beautiful Jamaican coffee beans all over the kitchen floor. Thoughts of also spilling a pot of hot water, some milk and sugar, and skating around the floor with a straw in my mouth ran through my mind. I needed a cup of coffee bad.

"Alrighty then. I have a live one here that I need an assist on." Dave said, calmly ignoring the coffee emergency on my end of the phone.

"Whatcha got?" I asked, carefully picking up the beans one by one.

"Fredrick VonHeffer called my office today and left me a nonsensical voice mail. I didn't quite understand his message, but he's on his way to the Rainforest Cafe to have lunch with me in an hour." Dave relayed.

"Fredrick VonHeffer? The guy that just took his little CRM software company public?" I asked.

"The very one." Dave responded. "And you're not going to believe this, but he's accusing TouchThemSoft of information theft and wants me to prove it. We're talking a serious lawsuit here."

"Information theft? We talking another intellectual property theft case, or a patent infringement case?" I asked as I poured the recently picked-up beans back into the grinder. Sure they came off the floor, but they would still make good coffee.

"Not sure. But I'm meeting him in an hour. Have plans? Care to join?" Dave asked.

"Rainforest Cafe you said? Lots of monkeys there. Count me in." I said as I deafened Dave with jet-engine blast of noise from the coffee grinder.

"Chief - one more thing. I think this is a little beyond what we normally work on - he's convinced that his company is under some sort of surveillance too." Dave yelled into the phone. Obviously Dave wasn't respecting my coffee grinder right now.

"Aren't we all?" I joked. "I'll meet you in an hour. Bring your gear. If this case is legit, we might need to do some after-hours recon at their office."

"Roger that." Dave said as he hung up.

So much for enjoying my beautiful day.

Part II

"Eeeek! Eeeek!"

The screams of monkeys filled the air as Dave and I walked into the Rainforest Cafe.

"Feels just like home." I said to myself, fighting back a few tears. Monkeys are family-oriented, you know.

"So where are we meeting Mr. VonHoover?" I joked.

"Chief, it's VonHEFFER. He said he'd be on the south side of the restaurant." Dave replied.

A quick examination of the south side of the restaurant produced no VonHeffer. I glanced at my watch... we were a few minutes late.

"Time for some coffee." I said as I walked towards the bar.

"I'll get us a table on the south side of the restaurant." Dave said as he flagged down the hostess.

I had just been served a fine smelling blend of java happiness when I felt a tap on my shoulder. I turned around, grumpy that my coffee was being interrupted..."You Chief?" a clean-cut businessman-looking chap asked me.

"Uh, sure. And you are?" I queried.

"VonHeffer - Dave over there said to invite you to our table." he said.

I scurried over to the table, tailing behind VonHeffer. He glanced around the room several times and sat facing the entrance.

Dave introduced me to VonHeffer, brief personal histories were discussed, and then VonHeffer went into the details of our meeting.

"Here's my situation in a nutshell gentleman: I just took my company HefferSoft public. A lot of this was made possible by how well my company is managed, how great our product is, and how happy our customers are.

Well, our chief competitor in our little neck of the CRM woods is TouchThemSoft. I was just made aware that a former developer of ours is breaking his non-compete agreement with us and is secretly helping TouchThemSoft develop a product that is using some patented technologies that we've spent years developing.

If TouchThemSoft beats us to market with this product, we could be screwed." VonHeffer said, taking a drink from his now empty beer.

"Ok, this is nothing new. Dave mentioned that you're under some kind of surveillance?" I asked.

"Yes, well - sort of. My attorney has begun legal proceedings against the former developer. Shortly after we filed on the former developer, we started noticing strange things. I am followed home almost every night. I will sometimes spot the same person at three different restaurants in four nights..." VonHeffer said in a nervous voice.

"Maybe they like a wide variety of food AND coffee." I thought to myself.

"Anyone else under surveillance? Anything else going on?" Dave asked VonHeffer.

"Yes - our offices have been broken into twice, yet nothing was stolen. We have three security guards that patrol the interior of the building now. My home has been broken into as well, but like my office - nothing was stolen. My executive assistant's home was burglarized two days ago - and they did steal something." VonHeffer said, now sweating profusely.

"What did they steal?" I asked.

"Some money, some jewelry, her office keys ... and her laptop." VonHeffer said.

Part III

Out of pure instinct I reached for my sidearm, the trusty clue banana... but alas, I had left it on the dash of my car.

VonHeffer sat at the table, a nervous twitch ran through his neck every few minutes. A coffee lover I see. Excellent.

"Well, let's break this down." I began. "We have a rogue ex-employee, a stolen laptop, stolen keys, and you are possibly under some kind of surveillance?"

"Yes." VonHeffer said in between nervous twitches.

"Dave, let's go for a walk." I said as I grabbed Dave by the arm.

We excused ourselves and walked outside.

"What's up?" Dave asked.

"This doesn't feel right." I said."What do you mean?" Dave questioned me as he sat down on a bench outside the restaurant.

"Well, he's either leaving something out, or making some of this up. Who throws surveillance on a previous employer like this? The ex-employee has all the cards. The non-compete is going to be hard to win in court, we both know that. If TouchThemSoft is responsible for the break-ins, what were they after besides the keys and the laptop? What do the keys go to? What's on the laptop?" I asked.

"You want to do this by the numbers and see what happens? We're talking some serious billable hours here Chief." Dave said, dollar signs blazing in his eyes.

"You read my mind. Let's sign the agreements and roll over to their HQ. We need to talk to their legal folks and find out if they have ever done any type of risk assessments. And I want to know what was on that laptop." I said.

"Sounds good - but what do you want to do about this little surveillance issue?" Dave asked me as he lit up a cigarette.

"We can ghost chase. Call Mikey - put him on VonHeffer for a few days, take some pictures, you know... by the numbers. Have him do a covert on him though... if someone close to VonHeffer is 'in' on something I don't want Mikey compromised. We'll see if someone is really following VonHeffer." I replied.

"Done deal Chief." Dave said as he put out his cigarette under his shoe.

'One last thing." I began.

"Yeah Chief?" Dave responded.

"Until we know this whole thing isn't rotten, mum is the word on operational plans. We discuss nothing with the client." I demanded.

"Your gut really bothering you on this one Chief?" Dave asked.

"Something besides the coffee? Yes."

(Aside)

Pick out the holes in VonHeffer's story. What was bothering my gut? Coffee is not an allowed answer.

Part IV

"Fancy Digs." I thought to myself as I entered HefferSoft's spacious lobby. I checked in with the receptionist and decided to warm up one of the leather chairs nearby. Dave was still outside, cellphone in one hand and a Newport in the other.

"Chief?" the receptionist said as she leaned over the marble counter.

"Yo!" I responded, eager to put down the People Magazine I had been browsing.

"Mr. Jones in legal will see you now - down the hallway, last door on your left." the receptionist squeaked.

I motioned for Dave to speed things up outside and started walking down the hallway. Dave and I entered Mr. Jones' office and took our seats quickly.

I asked Mr. Jones some very basic questions regarding HefferSoft and the situation that Mr. VonHeffer described.
"When you get right down to it, there's a lot going on around here." Mr Jones began. "We had a key employee defect to the one competitor that is on the verge of putting us out of business. This is, of course, confidential."

"Understood." I said. "So what's the risk? I take it your legal team has done some sort of risk analysis. What were the results? What are your big risks here besides a possible violation of a non-compete agreement?"

"Well, yes - there's that. You see, the employee we're talking about here is Mick Thomas - he's basically the programmer that wrote the first version of our software in his apartment years ago. Mick always wanted a larger portion of the company. Taking the company public didn't sit too well with Mick, even though he was given a very generous stock option plan." Mr. Jones said. "Mick had it out with VonHeffer one afternoon, and we haven't seen him since. We had some information leak into this office that Mick might be working at TouchThemSoft - turns out the information was good. "

"I'm trying to follow you here." I said as I imagined how good a cup of coffee would be during this discussion. "What are the RISKS here? What does Mick bring to the table at TouchThemSoft besides his experience with VonHeffer and possible access to proprietary source code?"

Dave moved forward in his seat. "And better yet - what information was on the assistant's laptop that was stolen? Was this information collected? I'd like to see this as soon as possible."

"Yes Dave, I'll have that information to you shortly. To answer your question Chief, we do have a list of concerns with Thomas' defection - and there are more risks than those that you mentioned. " Mr. Jones said as he became suddenly tight-lipped.

"Yes? And?" I asked.

Mr. Jones shifted in his chair, covered his eyes with his left hand and inhaled deeply. This is never a good sign from a client.

"Thomas had access to... documents." Mr. Jones said under his breath.

"What kind of documents?" Dave asked, practically falling out of his chair at this point.

"Damaging ones." Mr. Jones said.

(Aside)

Looks like my gut instinct was right on this one. I smelled a smokescreen quick by observing VonHeffer's body language and listening to him spill the beans.

What kind of documents does Thomas really have?

Why is Jones so uncomfortable right now?

What else was VonHeffer lying about? Why?

What kind of coffee will I be drinking next?

Is the surveillance claim a red herring? Why? Why Not?

(/Aside)

Part V

"This is the best tuna sandwich I've ever had!" Dave exclaimed as he dripped tuna salad out of his sandwich all over the table.

"Dude, I'm trying to eat here." I said staring at my grilled chicken breast and a side of fruit. You know you're getting old when you make a serious effort to eat healthy every day. "Takes the guilt away from this double-espresso powered white chocolate caramel cup of coffee happiness." I thought as I felt the caffeine rush to my brain.

We were both pretty exhausted from spending a marathon three hours in Jones' office.

I wanted to establish a few things with Jones. What did he really know about what was going on? Did he trust VonHeffer? Did he have external motivators? How well did he know Mick Thomas?

Jones stated that he was oblivious to anything besides what we had already talked about - he had no reason to not trust VonHeffer - and he barely knew Thomas aside from their conversations in board meetings. Jones also refused to elaborate on the "damaging documents".

"Hey Chief - you're staring off into monkeyland again - what's up?" Dave asked, waving his monkey paw in front of my face."Have you heard from Mikey?" I asked Dave, refering to the tail-for-hire that was supposed to be shadowing VonHeffer and looking for the surveillance teams that VonHeffer described.

"Nope." Dave replied. "But let's see how he's doing?"

Dave picked up his cell phone and dialed Mikey's number. Apparently Dave was more interested in his Tuna sandwich than talking to Mikey, because he handed his cell phone to me.

"Mikey." I heard on the phone.

"Mikey - it's Chief. What's up?" I asked.

"Not a damned thing. I've been tailing this guy all day. We went from his house, to the gas station, to the book store, to the clothing store, to a restaurant for lunch, back to the mall, up north to a bar..."

"Ok - and no contacts?" I asked Mikey.

"Not one. Nobody is following this guy - and if they are, they are better than I am. I swept his car for locaters and he's clean. I think he's seen one too many James Bond movies." Mikey joked.

"Alright - let's go two more days and see what happens." I said as I hung up.

Dave's eyes widened. "Hey Chief, do you realize that this is the first time that we've followed the CLIENT?"

"When's the last time we had a client that gave you the heebie-jeebie's like VonHeffer? Did you get the profile of that stolen laptop?" I asked.

"I'm looking at it now." Dave said, lifting a folder of documents from his lap.

"Please don't get Tuna on that man." I said.

"Well, I'm not the techie of the team - so help me figure this out. The listing is from a backup server that automatically backs up portables when they plug into the corporate LAN." Dave said as he turned a few pages. "And this is where it gets REAL confusing. I'm looking through the directory listings of the C: drive and I'm not seeing anything even remotely interesting. There's a total of maybe 20 word documents and a few spreadsheets, but nothing with file names that sound interesting."

"That means nothing - anything could be in those files - or any other file." I said wishing I had remembered to ask Jones for a contact to pull the backup tapes.

"Ok, ok... but here's the best part... the backup software is configured to only backup drive C:!" Dave exclaimed.

"Yeah, what's your point? Most laptops nowadays only have one big ass C: drive anyway." I countered.

"Chief - there's a drive D: on this listing.... and it's stuffed with word documents and spreadsheets." said Dave.

"Where are you going with this Dave?" I demanded.

"It's a CD-ROM! Now I wonder if the CD-ROM was in the laptop when it was 'stolen'?" Dave asked.

A CD-ROM huntin' we are about to go....


Part VI

(Aside)

Time to back up for a second.

Through some keen observations by Dave, we've established that at the last time the executive assistant's laptop was backed up (ie, last time it was plugged into the corporate LAN), there was a mystery CD in the laptop. This is the same laptop that was supposedly stolen from her home. The CD looks interesting, but how do we find the CD? How do we find out what was on the CD? Why was the CD made? Does the whole case revolve around this one CD?

One thing to keep in mind during this case file - the NAME of the case file. :-)


(/Aside)

Our story continues...

Paper as far as the monkey eye could see - scattered all over the table at the local Starbucks. Dave and I were entrenched doing some background work on the executive assistant, Mick Thomas, VonHeffer, and multiple binders of company policies and procedures.

Lots of interesting facts were added to our case notes:

* The Executive Assistant (EA) did indeed report the break-in and theft to the police, however no homeowners claim was filed on her possessions. Not uncommon - a homeowner's claim is a death blow to ever getting homeowner's insurance within three years. Don't you love how the insurance racket works?

* Interviews with other staff members revealed that the EA and Mick Thomas were known to eat lunch together and socialize on numerous occasions.

* Mick Thomas not only had full access to the company's CVS (source code) servers, but administrator and root access to all other machines. This was in violation of the company's network security policy, but no violation reports were ever filed.

* A risk analysis was done by the legal department about six months before Mick Thomas left the company. All five stages of a RA were completed, and one of the largest financial risks mentioned was the theft of intellectual property (the source code) of their product line.

* The company CFO, Izzy Landers, has been on vacation since the theft of the EA's laptop and unreachable by cell phone.

* Izzy and VonHeffer were college roommates.

* Izzy used to work for TouchThemSoft about one year before the EA's laptop was stolen. No non-compete suit was ever filed by TouchThemSoft over this move. Interesting.

"You know what I'm thinking?" I said to Dave as I took a swig of a most caffeinated house blend.

"This was a bad week to stop smoking crack?" Dave joked.

"If I was going to burn a CD with a bunch of potentially damaging (and we're assuming damaging) documents on it, what machine would I use at my company?" I asked.

"Hmmm. Well, for starters you wouldn't want to use your own machine - so let's assume that the EA burnt the CD but she didn't use her laptop." Dave said.

"Yep, ok - now she needs to find another machine with a burner in it - whose machine is she going to use?" I pondered.

"One that she has access to? But with her login, she could login to any Windows 2000 workstation on that top-floor network." Dave pointed out.

"Yes - but how many machines had a burner installed!" I expounded.

"Well, according to the hardware inventory... only two." Dave replied. "One belonged to the VP of Graphic Services who used..... a powermac G4. And the other was in... oh this is nice!!!"

"Uh?" I replied.

Dave lowered the paper and smiled, spouting off "The only other machine with a burner belonged to...

Mick Thomas!!!

Let's hope that the IT department didn't follow it's machine scrubbing procedures on that machine, Chief."

Yes, indeed.


(Aside)

Ok sleuths... what is going on?

What are your theories so far?

Hint: Remember this case file ?

And why the heck was I drinking a house blend instead of an imported bean?

Part VII


Memo from the Chief

Hello out there? You all have been very quiet lately. Is everyone on summer vacation BUT me? Or have you all gotten lost in the multiple layers of details surrounding this case file? Understandable. And remember, you're reading a 'summarized' version of what happened. Icky.

Our story continues...

Tracking down Mick Thomas's machine was not hard. One phone call to the hardware monkeys and they knew exactly which machine I was talking about.

"So where is this workstation?" I asked the first monkey.

"(sound of him scratching his head) It's the pretty blue tower machine sitting next to my supervisor's desk." said the first monkey.

"Put your Sup on the phone please." I asked.

"Yes?" said the second monkey.

"You have workstation #WS000002 in your office, yes?" I asked the second monkey.

"(sound of him scratching some place I didn't want to know about). Yes - it's sitting right here next to my desk." said the second monkey. "I use it every day!"

My heart sunk.

"Did you erase the contents of that workstation before you started using it?" I asked the second monkey.

"Nope. I just created a new profile. This baby has a mega awesome video card and Mick had everything tuned just right!" chirped the second monkey.

Dave and I just had a lucky break.

We headed to the hardware support area in the IT department and located the workstation. It was a bright blue tower - one that someone would use if they were a professional gamer perhaps.

"We're going to need to borrow this machine for a while." I told the second monkey.

He started to give me some grief about needing his machine, but I'm sure the sight of my trusty clue banana dangling from my belt made him change his mind. Fear the banana!

I pulled the power cord from the back of the machine and heard the fans go silent. We took some pictures, packed the machine in some anti-scratch wrapping and placed the machine on our trusty cart, leaving the screaming monkeys in the hardware support department to their daily grind of swinging from one cube to the next.

A few hours later I was combing an Encase image of the hard drive from the big bad blue workstation. It didn't take me long to locate a series of CDR project files and disc images. Whoever was using Mick's profile was not concerned about these files laying about in broad daylight.

There were ten images total on the drive. I proceeded to start burning CDR images one by one and labeling them accordingly by the image filename, date and time.

As the CDR's were labeled, I handed them to Dave for examination. One by one, disc by disc, the procedure was rather slow.

I decided that the room temperature decaf I was drinking wasn't cutting it anymore, so I volunteered to venture out to the coffee shop to acquire some good bean juice while Dave continued to examine the CDR's.

I was in line at the coffee shop trying to decide between the columbian medium roast and the espresso of the day when my cell phone rang.

"Chief." I responded.

"I see files." Dave said on the other end.

"No kidding genius boy. Anything that interests us?" I asked.

"A couple of things actually." Dave said.

"Do tell." I joked as I placed my order for our coffees.

"Well, I found a complete dump of their accounting system - everything. A/P, A/R, income statements, balance sheets, you name it." Dave announced.

"Really? And what's the other thing you found?" I asked instinctively.

"Another dump of their accounting system - same time period according to some of the plain-text report files - but with one slight difference." Dave said.

"Oh, I can feel this one coming!" I thought.

"The numbers are all different. They have two sets of books." Dave almost whispered into the phone.

I almost dropped my coffee.

(Aside)

So, we have some things going on here. For whatever reason, Mick had a CDR image on his hard drive of a dump of the accounting system (which he had access to). Did Mick make the image? Did the EA? Why? Why not?

Discuss.

(/Aside)

Part VIII- It ends badly

Things were bad, and were getting worse the further we dug. Dave and I could have worn signs around our necks that said "Designated tools of due diligence". You can make the joke.

Here we were being brought into an organization because of some missing data, some employees being followed, and key members of staff possibly jumping ship to a competitor. What could it all mean?

I took a gamble with my next move. This game is all instict, and I've never found my gut to be wrong on matters like this. I grabbed my case notes and walked to Mr. Jones' office in legal.

Time to apply pressure to this gaping chest wound of a case.I spread page after page after page of case notes out in front of me on Jones' desk. I asked some rather pointed questions, but my gut was telling me that Jones really didn't have a clue. It looked like I'd have to show my hand in this card game.

"Mr. Jones, are you aware that VonHeffer and certain other executives in this company have been defrauding your investors from the very beginning?" I asked.

"What do you mean?" Jones asked, looking like I was pusing bamboo chutes down under his fingernails.

"I have two sets of accounting records here. One set is the set that you used to file all of your financial reports. The information I gathered from these reports matches your public disclosures." I said. "However, this other set of records tells a very different story. It would appear that VonHeffer and crew have been treating themselves to large cash bonuses, personal perks that were written off as expenses, and let's not even talk about the company's stock option plan." I said as I placed the documents in front of Jones.

"How did you... find... where... what the..." Jones sputtered off.

I spent the next hour briefing Jones on what Dave and I had uncovered. I was going to throw the matter into his hands, collect our check and run away from this case as fast as my shoes could take me.

Mick Thomas caught on to the "questionable" accounting practices that VonHeffer and several other officers of the company practiced. The CFO was a personal friend of VonHeffer and disappeared on vacation. Thomas found the records, burned them to CDR media and escaped to TouchThemSoft as fast as he could. The CDR's were his insurance against VonHeffer suing him from jumping ship.

Thomas and the EA were indeed having an at-work affair. Thomas had given the EA a copy of the CDR as insurance. When Thomas found out that VonHeffer was on to him, Thomas and the EA staged the break-in at her place to explain the laptop (and the CDR) just "disappearing". It was later discovered that the EA had saved hundreds of incriminating e-mails from VonHeffer as her own "insurance".

VonHeffer's plan on bringing in an outside security investigation firm backfired in the worst way. The forensic evidence that we were able to find, label, preserve and present aided an attorney that represented some of VonHeffer's largest investors. Needless to say that VonHeffer and his cronies wound up with some jail time. VonHeffer's company was bought by a much larger company and it's technology used in a much larger, more popular CRM solution.

Not every case goes smooth or even makes sense in the end - especially when things go badly.

(Aside)
How did VonHeffer completely shoot himself in the foot?

Anyone want to take a guess at describing the entire scam that VonHeffer put together? This casefile only highlights the very basics.

(/Aside)

Next time, new case file - and it's a weird one.

Case of the Determined Debutant

Part I

New Format Announcement From The Chief:

I have decided to do smaller, more frequent updates to the case files. You've all been very vocal about this, so I'll do my best to comply. Enjoy!
~ Chief


I hate planes. I hate flying. Unfortunately, it's required to get around in today's world. The worst part has to be the coffee.

"Where do they find this stuff, the back shelf at Wal Mart?" I joked to myself.

It was a long flight back home after a well deserved vacation, and I was looking forward to sleeping in my own bed and the familiar aroma of quality java beans being ground at exactly 05:00 hours. Yum.

I was off the plane a mere three minutes when I turned my cell phone on to check my messages.

"Twenty Nine new voice mails? UGH." I moaned as I began the daunting process of listen-and-delete. The last voice mail was left a few hours before, and caught my interest.

It was a referral call from a large financial clearinghouse in town. They had a confidential matter to discuss with me.

"God help me if these people just want to refinance my house." I said as I closed my phone.

I would return their call first thing in the morning. Five o'clock came way too fast the next day. I had to spend the next few hours getting caught up on e-mails and snail mail. The coffee went down smooth and I could feel it activating every neuron in my monkey-like brain.

"Time to give BigHouse Financial a call back." I thought. I pounded their number into my cell phone.

"BigHouse Financial, how may I direct your call?" said the perky voice on the other end of the phone.

"Michael Cash, please." I said with a straight face. This receptionist was straight out of the movie "Valley Girl".

"This is Michael." a familiar-sounding voice said.

"Michael, it's Chief - returning your call. What's up?" I asked.

"Thanks for calling back Chief - I have a sensitive issue brewing here at BigHouse and I'm not quite sure how to handle it." Michael said slowly. He was thinking about each word he said so loudly that my ears were bleeding.

"What kind of 'issue'?" I asked.

"It's best that we don't discuss this on the... phone. When can you come in?" Michael asked.

"I'm jumping into the car as we speak." I replied back.

Part II

BigHouse Financial occupied a large glass-faced building in the ritzier part of town. The building was less than a year old, and hosted one of the most technically innovative physical security systems around. I had read about this building while it was in the planning, building, and completion phases in a lot of trade magazines.

"Now's my chance to see the goods." I thought as I checked in with the guard at the parking garage. He took my driver's license, scanned it into a machine, printed and laminated an id badge for me and my vehicle and assigned me a parking space - next to the elevators even!

I exited my vehicle and looked around the parking garage - I was being watched by numerous cameras mounted around the ceiling. As I scanned my new badge to enter the elevator, I was surprised to see *tah dah*... yet another camera in the elevator.

"This is right out of movie." I said outloud. I hadn't seen security this tight since touring a few casinos in Las Vegas.

I walked accross a bridge that extended from the second floor of the parking garage to the BigHouse Financial office building. I scanned my badge again at the door to the building and walked into a large reception area, complete with perky receptionist...

"Hello! How may I help you?" the receptionist said without blinking an eye.

"I have an appointment with Mike Cash." I said looking around the reception area. A camera was overhead, and one on the ceiling overtop each of the intersecting hallways nearby.

"Please have a seat, Mike will be right with you." she said as she motioned me to sit on a very comfy brown leather sofa.

I was reading a fascinating article about Michael Jackson and his fascination with monkeys when Mike approached me.

"Chief! Good to see you... let's take a walk to a conference room." Mike said as badged us into one of the nearby rooms.

Mike closed the door behind us, asked me to sit down and proceeded to pour me a cup of coffee from a nearby coffee pot.

"What's up Mike? I talked to the person that referred you to me, and he didn't have a clue about your 'issue'." I said as I sipped the hot coffee slowly.

"Chief, we spent a lot of money making this one of the most secure buildings around. We process thousands upon thousands of sensitive financial transactions a day. We keep several terabytes of financial documents online and accessible to our service staff. We have a large security staff, and we pass every security audit that we go through. That's what makes this especially difficult." Mike lamented.

"I don't understand, makes what difficult?" I asked, sipping more coffee.

"We have a mole." Mike said, folding his arms in front of him.

"This mole has somehow figured out how to..."

To Be Continued...

Part III

"To what?" I asked, annoyed that Mike wasn't completing his sentences properly.

Mike smiled. "Well, someone has figured out how to get a large amount of our customers' data out of this building."

"Fill me in." I said, intrigued.

"Well, this has been going on for about two months now. You need to understand that there is no external access to this network, aside from private network connections to clearinghouses. No internet access, no analog phone lines laying about... none of the obvious electronic stuff. Everyone is searched coming and going from this building. We're stumped." Mike said, offering me a warmup on my coffee.

"I have to say I particularly enjoyed the brief search that the guard gave me." I joked. I was wanded for metal objects - that was about it. Of course, I brought nothing into the office aside from my trusty pen and notepad...

"You have this place under pretty heavy CCT surveillance man - cameras are everywhere." I said. "And I'm guessing that you have an adequate internal audit department that is analyzing employee access to systems? Nothing out of the ordinary?"

"You are correct - and no, we've found nothing. We first caught on to the information leakage when ten people over a four week period were the victims of identity theft. The only thing these people really had in common was that their identities were used around the same time, and they all had a major financial transaction go through our shop at some point." Mike pointed out as he flipped through some drink coasters on the conference room table.

I raised a finger to my bottom lip, thought for a moment and said "So your assumption is that you have someone lifting documents in some form or fashion from your company and using the information themselves..."

"Or selling the information to someone else perhaps." Mike responded, a smile crossing his face.

"That's quite common nowadays." I commented, taking a few moments to collect my thoughts. "I think I need to sign those NDA's you talked about, and then pour over these ten individuals' transactions."

"Let's go to my office - I have everything ready." Mike said as he ushered me out of the conference room and into an elevator.

A few minutes later, I was signing my John Hancock to some legalese and glancing over what appeared to be papers associated with home mortgages.

"Woah." I said out loud as I dropped my pen.

"Whoa what?" Mike asked.

"Mike, all of these people have yearly incomes that exceed half a million dollars." I said.

"Yes, that too is quite common - we see them all the time." Mike pointed out as he flipped through the papers.

"Yeah, but are all your customers self-employed?" I asked.

"What?" Mike spouted as he took the pile of papers from my hands.

"Someone is profiling your customers... looking for specific characteristics... something that works to their advantage." I said as I sat up in my chair.

"Well, we somehow missed that... but how does this help us? Where are you going with this?" Mike inquired as he stared at me in disbelief.

"Honeynuts." I responded.

Time to bait the line and see what bites.

Part IV

"Breakfast cereal?" Mike asked as he stared at me with disbelief. Mike looked more like a 'Wheaties' kind of guy, so I'm sure that I had just offended him.

"No - think of it like this. What happens when you go out to the park and leave a trail of breadcrumbs from the bottom of a tree to the bench you're sitting on?" I asked Mike with a grin.

"You're arrested for littering?" Mike said sarcastically.

"The pigeons flock to the breadcrumbs, and eat every one... working their way up to the last breadcrumb which is right in front of your feet." I said, downing the last of my cold coffee..."So you propose a trap - ok, what are the breadcrumbs? How do we pull this off?" Mike said with a raised eyebrow. Spock would have been proud.

"I'm going with the assumption that your thief is doing customized searches against certain fields in these records. We're going to plant some fake records out there that nobody would ever access in their normal course of work." I spouted as I tapped Mike's desk with my pen.

"Ah, and since we don't trap searches - but we DO trap record access - the pigeon would be walking right to our feet?" Mike asked, blinding me with the lightbulb that suddenly appeared over his head.

"Exactly. I need you to hand pick a small team of people with skills in these areas." I said as I scribbled some monkey jibberish on a piece of paper. "We're going to have a briefing in the morning at 0600 hours before most of your staff arrives. Stealth is the key here - and you want to make sure that these are people that you would trust with your life. We're not going to get too many shots at this." I said as I stood up to adjust the clue banana hanging proudly from my belt.

"You got it Chief - so when do you think we'll see the pigeon - or possibly pigeons?" Mike asked as he shook my outstretched hand.

"Soon." I said.

Part V

The clock on the wall read 06:05 hours. The conference room was a bit stuffy from the air conditioning being turned off over night for maintenance. I was sipping the last of a beautiful french roast, waiting for Mike to assemble the crew I asked for.

"So much for starting on time." I mumbled as I released a rather loud yawn.

Monkey business is tiring business, no two ways about it.

A few minutes later Mike entered the conference room with three individuals. Database guy was the architect of the system suspected of being used to steal the information. Data security guy was third in charge of security and a former network monkey - very clued individual. Systems specialist girl was an expert in the applications used in house to access the database in question. But why these three people?
Some explanation is necessary. First, I wanted someone who was a key individual and very low-level to the database. We'd need knowledge of how the database was composed and what low-level solutions were available in a pinch.

Data security guy was a grunt that had access to the security infrastructure, but also had a networking background to help us with our search endeavors.

System specialist girl was going to help us in figuring out each nook and cranny of the document-retrieval system that the users had access to.

The plan was simple. Plant the nuts, post a sentry and set some alarms. When the alarms were triggered, we wanted to do a capture-and-trace of the network traffic between the workstation and the application server, and perform as much physical surveillance as possible in the shortest amount of time. This is where data security guy was going to come in real handy - he had access to the entire security infrastructure - net-powered cameras and all.

I discussed the plan in great lengths and received some feedback from the team. As usual, there were surprises involved.

"Capture record access? Hell yes we can do that. Who told you we can't do that?" database guy asked Mike. Database guy was also an old Unix hack, and had some great tricks up his sleeve.

"I recommend we modify my debug scripts that I use for testing to look for database requests containing the bait names." database guy said. "One script in particular would be perfect - and it runs in real time. We can setup an email alert too."

"That's great, but all the transaction requests come from the application server - they all appear to be from the application server. We need a way to correlate when the search happens against the database with the user logged into the application and executing the search. Unfortunately, there is no such facility in the software." systems specialist said with a frown. "The best we could do would be to catch the alarm from the database, and then immediately perform a manual search on the application server for the request - which could take a while."

"And what about the network traffic capture? This is all web-based, and it's not SSL-encrypted for whatever reason." data security dude pointed out with a grin.
"If we want hard proof of the request, we'll need to setup an http sniffer box to monitor the switch port that the application server is plugged into."

I was grinning from ear to ear - I was making them think!

"Ok, let's talk about surveillance. Once we identify the ip of the workstation, we'll need to know where the workstation is located. We have a network map showing each workstation, right?" I asked.

"Well, we'd need to query the IP for the hostname since we're running DHCP here - but once we have the hostname it's a snap!" data security guy proudly announced.

"Database guy, let's get those records in the system and that script running." I suggested as I stood up from the table.

The game was on.

Part VI

Fish are a real pain in the arse. You're sitting there in a boat with your fishing pole extended, bait in the water... waiting... waiting... and those little suckers ignore you - almost as if they can smell you.

"Well, they wouldn't get near me right now - I smell like I want to be alone." I joked to myself.

Three days had gone by since our tiger team had jumped into action, and not even a nibble.

This isn't entirely unusual. In data collection cases such as this, the offender typically works in two fashions:

Slow and easy - records are accessed and copied one at a time over a very long period of time.
Fast and quick - records are accessed and copied in bulk using the fastest method available, hoping to ride in between security checks and not get caught.

My stomach was grumbling - it was getting very close to lunch time - I couldn't fathom another day in the company cafeteria....
One half an hour later, I was enjoying an amazing bowl of japanese food with green tea.

Note: I should tell you all now that the Chief's doctor had advised him to cut back on coffee consumption and switch to tea. Yes, it was a sad day.

*ring*

"Chief." I said holding my cell phone with one hand and my chopsticks with the other.

"Chief, it's database guy. I have a hit! Actually, I have three hits! We're rolling up the incident now... you should probably get back here asap."

I almost choked on my rice bowl. What's that saying, "a watched pot never boils?"

I drove back to the building and breezed through the security checkpoints. I entered an office with a swipe of my badge - an office that we converted into a makeshift "watch room".

"Ok, I got the queries right here... see.. right here!" database guy was almost screaming with glee. I really just wanted to slap him at this point.

"Have we run through the application logs yet, anything?" I asked systems specialist girl.

"I'm rolling through them now... I have several hundreds of thousands of lines of logs to search through. Shouldn't be much more than a few minutes longer." she said, her eyes not leaving her laptop screen.

The tension in the room was mounting, and data security guy looked like he was about to explode - foot tapping, nervously sipping a Coke. It wasn't warm in the room, yet he was sweating profusely. I hope he remembered to be "sure" this morning.

"Got it! I got it!" systems specialist girl said as she swung around in her chair. "Data security dude, bring up a camera on workstation 5B003."

"5B003? Where's that?" I asked.

"You wouldn't believe me if I told you." data security dude said as he manipulated the security cameras on the workstation in front of him.

"Try me." I said.

"That's on the fifth floor, section Bravo (north wing) in cube #3. That cube belongs to my partner Maria." data security dude said, more flustered than five minutes ago.

Data security dude brought up the camera, engaged the zoom mode and found the workstation.

"There's only one problem here, Chief." data security dude said.

"Eh?" I asked.

"That's not Maria at the computer." data security dude replied.

The room was dead silent.

Part VII

"Somebody want to tell me who this person is?" I asked as the camera zoomed in closer to the woman sitting at Maria's workstation.

"Darla Dominique." Data Security Dude replied, lost in a blank stare as he moved the camera around.

"Darla used to work in Data Security, but was moved to an analyst position within the IT department because of a political issue with the Director of our department." Data Security Dude said.

"What issue would that be?" I asked as I stepped closer to the LCD screen, watching her every movement.

"He actually expected Darla to be at work and do her job. Darla is in the middle of a nasty love triangle from the last information I heard, and wasn't making her job a priority. The Director didn't want her in a sensitive position, so he gave her a lateral promotion to somewhere else in IT." Data Security Dude elaborated as he began to stand up.

"What's the plan, Chief?" Systems Specialist Girl asked as she closed the lid on a nearby laptop.

"We watch and learn." I said as I sat down in Data Security Dude's chair.
The next ten minutes went by very slowly as we tracked and documented Darla's moves. I was most curious about how she was getting the information in such large quantities out of the building.

"She doing her criteria queries, getting the output through the document application, then what is she doing after that? It's hard to see." Database Guy said as he nudged closer to the LCD screen.

"The document images that she's seeing - what format do they appear as in the browser?" I asked Systems Specialist Girl.

"They are converted on the fly from PDF to JPG - they show up in the browser as a JPG." she said, holding her chin in one hand and scratching her head with the other.

"She's dragging and dropping something... look at that... one window into another window... see that? And the image moved up, then down..." I pointed out. My eyes were really beginning to hurt.

"She's getting up!" Data Security Dude said as he tried to find the ID of the camera she was approaching.

By the time the other camera was located and adjusted, Darla was already walking towards the elevator.

"Where does she normally sit?" I asked.

"She's on... the third floor... in the corner.. cube 12 it looks like. Let me find the camera..." Data Security Dude said as flipped through the camera software.

"Got it!" he said as he zoomed in. Darla had made it back to her desk and appeared busy with some menial task.

"What the hell is that - a three hole punch? What the hell is she doing?" Database Guy asked.

I started laughing - hard. I had to sit down.

"What's so funny Chief?" Data Security Dude asked.

"Get your facilities security team on the phone - and get Mike up here now. We need to grab her before she heads home."

"But why are you laughing?" Systems Specialist Girl asked.

"Because, folks, the joke is on us." I said.

I needed coffee.

Part VIII

"Medium-roasted beans, oh the pleasure...." I thought as I leisurely sipped 24 ounces of the creamy concoction in Mike's office. "I'm craving Oatmeal Cookies. That's weird." I thought to myself.

"Uh, Chief?" Mike asked, garnering for my attention.

"Huh?" I replied, snapping back to my senses.

"Sorry, you were lost there - tired?" Mike asked.

"You could say that - what time is Darla's shift over?" I inquired, glancing at my monkey watch.

"About 30 minutes to go. We should probably head down to the security desk." Mike suggested as he stood up behind his desk.

"Let's do it." I said, slamming the rest of my coffee in a gulp. It's a talent, I tell you.
A quick ride down the "secure" elevator and we were at the security desk,watching the clock tick.

A few minutes later, emloyees started to pour down the elevators and stairs, heading past the security desk and badging out the exit doors.

"There she is." Mike said, walking towards Darla - security guards in tow.

"Darla, could we have a few minutes?" Mike asked as he motioned towards the door of the security office.

"Uh, ok I guess. Is something wrong?" Darla asked, looking around nervously.

"We just need to ask you a few questions." Mike said, spouting out a line that has been in way too many detective movies.

Mike, Darla, and a security guard joined me in the security office. It was a bit crampt, but adequate.

"Darla, as you know we have a company policy on inspecting items leaving the company for security purposes.' Mike said.

"Uh, yes. I know that." Darla said, staring at her feet.

"Mind if I take a look at your binder?" I asked, reaching for the 1-inch thick blue plastic book.

"Uh, ok." Darla reluctantly agreed.

Mike peered over my shoulder as I opened the binder.

We weren't looking at meeting notes, recipes, or software instructions.

On each formatted page was a neatly printed graphic image of a document - the first page of what appeared to be some type of financial application. I could clearly see fields for name, address, phone number, date of birth, social security number, etc.

I flipped through the binder and realized there were approximately 30 different prints.

Darla was staring at the floor.

Under questioning, the following information was established:

- Darla had become angry at her Director for 'banishing' her from the data security department.
- Shortly before she left data security, she had installed a key-logging application on a few workstations.
- Darla knew the value of the information that was in the binder.
- Darla was selling the information to a 'buyer' that she met online. $100 per usable identity. Darla was making an extra $3000-5000 a month in cash!

Based on this information, I made several recommendations to Mike & crew:

1) They spent a lot of money on facility and data security - however they had their 'clocks cleaned' by that one random element: the user. Policies were examined and changed.
2) They needed to tighten up their user access to systems and applications - there is no reason that data security personnel needed administrator access to all systems. Minimum necessary access is the key.
3) They needed to monitor for keylogging software better, especially on 'secure' workstations. We also located about 280 workstations that had some nasty malware/adware/spyware infections. Windows, windows, windows... *sigh*
4) They needed to monitor print server logs. I found that they only kept about 24 hours of print logs before the log files were erased. Not good.
5) They needed better due diligence when it came to employee hires/transfers/terminations. After auditing about three months of HR activity, I found terminated/transfered users that still had access to sensitive systems.
6) Password policies were not consistent accross systems and applications. Some sensitive applications would accept a one character password! Eek!

Mike followed up with me several weeks later regarding Darla. Apparently Darla's case was referred to a federal agency who sought her cooperation in nailing her buyer.

Let's hope they got him.

Case of the Agitated Ad Peddler

Part I

Two O'clock in the morning, and I wasn't even close to falling asleep. My eyes were peeled, aimed towards the LCD screen of my trusty Apple Powerbook laptop...

"Ten seconds... 7 seconds... *CLICK*!" I screamed as I mashed the mouse button down in a fit of pent-up jealousy.

"High Bidder: MadClown007? NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO" I howled. I had been outbid on the mother of all coffee bean grinders by a frick'in clown.

"It just wasn't meant to be." I said as I closed the lid of the powerbook, and watched it instantly go to 'sleep' mode.

All of the eBay excitement prompted me to brew up a fresh pot of Starbucks house roast and pretty much write off sleep for the night. I sat down in the living room and stared at the TV screen, longing for sleep to take it's toll on my over-caffeinated brain.

I gave up on the Discovery channel and cracked open the Powerbook, this time wandering around through email.

"Now that's interesting..." I said to myself. "Why would this guy be emailing ME?...."It was an e-mail from a sysadmin-type that I had worked with at a company a few years ago. He apparently had escaped from that company unscathed and was pimping himself out as a Unix systems administrator for a local company that was known for selling ad circulation services to various websites - most of them "adult entertainment" sites.

The interesting parts of the e-mail consisted of:


...I just don't get it Chief, somehow someone is changing the destinations of our ad-clicks. There's only about 90 of us here at the office, and very few of us have access to the database. I've checked every log file I could find, and I just don't see it...

...This is costing us several thousands of dollars a week in lost revenue. Whoever is doing this is sending all our would-be clickers to other sites...

... essentially they are stealing our potentional customers - the eyeballs and mouse clicks that help us pay our bills...



"Fascinating" I said to myself. Glancing through iCal, I noticed that I didn't have a gig lined up for another week.

The Chief is exhausted, but he's on the case.

Part II

(Aside)
Helping companies whose sole purpose in existing is to throw advertising in our faces is a moral dilemma. I thought long and hard before agreeing to accept this case, even though in 'Part I' I seemed to have no reservations.

Staying impartial is hard sometimes, especially if you want to keep a steady caseload. Imagine if you were asked by a SPAM-spewing company to come assist them with a security issue. Would you accept the case? For your usual fee? For an increased fee to ease your moral pains?

These type of philosophical arguments aren't thrown around by many security professionals these days. It would appear that the almighty dollar cures most people of their hesitations.

So why did I accept this case? As a favor to an individual that you're about to meet.
(/Aside)

Read on...I was wiping sleep from my eyes as I drove down the freeway, heading towards my new gig. The sun had been up for a while, but not as long as me. My car was filled with the aroma of freshly brewed Peruvian beans, and my head was full of curiosity - just who decides to redirect ad clicks on the fly? What's the motive? What's the method? I had lots of questions (as usual) and little answers.

AddaBill Systems didn't look like much from the parking lot, but the face of the building was quite deceiving. As I opened the wooden double doors and stepped inside, I was immediately struck by the innovative architecture and technical prowess of the reception area. Large LCD panels occupied the walls. Their screens displayed various web pages, all marred by banner advertising - even flash animations that begged the viewer to "click and win!"

I inhaled deeply as I approached the receptionist, and was immediately struck by an all too familiar aroma. Suits. The placed reeked of corporate Americana.

"Hello! How can I help you?" asked the receptionist as she put three callers on hold with the familiar "Can you hold? Thank you. Can you hold? Thank you"

"I'm here to see Scrappy." I said.

"Excuse me? Scrappy?" she said with a blink of heavily-mascara-applied eyes.

"Oh, sorry - Fred. Fred Stoneflint." I replied and feeling rather embarrassed. "Scrappy" was Fred's nickname and online moniker.

"One moment please and I'll page him. Have a seat." She said as she motioned me to sit down on a very swank purple couch.

I whipped open my PDA and made some notes while waiting for Fred. I briefly brought up Ministumbler to see if any wireless networking goodness was available. One network appeared, with the token 128-bit WEP encryption.

"Bedrock" I mumbled, noticing the ESSID. "How quaint."

"Yo, Chief!" yelled a familiar voice in my direction.

"Hey Scrappy, I hear you have a small security issue." I joked as I shook his hand.

"Yeah, you could say that. Let's go back to my cave and I'll fill you in." Scrappy said as he escorted me through a maze of hallways that were all perfectly curved like the letter "S".

Scrappy's "cave" was a small office about ten feet from the datacenter door. The datacenter appeared to be badge-access only, along with a palm scanner. Scrappy was up to his usual tricks it would seem.

"This whole situation is just complete dino-poop man." Scrappy said as he sat down and lit up a cigarette. Apparently AddaBill bucked a lot of trends, including the local building codes.

"As you know, we are an ad-injection service. We keep an inventory of ad products like banners, flash clickers, even those little deceptive ads that look like window popups. All of these ads are stored on ad servers which are basically just web servers. We also have 'destination databases' that contain URLs of where certain ads should take the viewers. We can, in some cases, sell the same ad to several different companies or page owners. " Scrappy disclosed as he took another hit off of his cigarette.

"And judging through the webpage source code I looked through before I came over here, you're simply pointing the click to an ad server, feeding it an ID number of some sort, and the webserver sends the viewer on their way to advertisement for Viagra or adult escort services." I joked, longing for a cup of joe.

"Exactly. Our business viability relies on the accuracy of our ad redirects, and lately we've had some 'problems'." Scrappy said, making little quotation marks with his fingers.

"And what exactly are these 'problems'?" I replied, also making little quotation marks with my fingers.

"Somehow, somebody is modifying the destination databases here at random and sending our viewers to websites in China, Russia, Taiwan the list is pretty long." Scrappy moaned as he rubbed his eyes.

Scrappy put out his cigarette, sat up in his chair and looked me directly in the eyes.

"Chief, I got special permission to let you poke around here and try to figure this out. I'll go over everything that I've already tried, and you can take it from there." Scrappy said as he removed an envelope from his desk drawer and slid it across the table towards me.

"What's this?" I asked as I picked up the envelope.

"A retainer." Scrappy spouted with a grin on his face.

The number of zeroes on the check brought a smile to my face.

Part III

One thing about Scrappy that I always admired was his attention to detail. I spent the past few hours listening to him describe the infrastructure of AddaBill's network resources, the steps he had followed after the first instance of database modification had occurred, and how he wished that AddaBill would use whole beans in coffee preparation. The mere thought of Scrappy having to drink a strange Kona ground product early in the morning sent shivers down my spine.To recap, AddaBill had a pretty decent internet presence. A master set of servers resided at headquarters that replicated changes out to a farm of web/ad/database servers on both coasts of the United States. Scrappy had planned for disaster recovery and availability from the get-go.

The headquarters network was fed via four T1 connections, each connected to a Cisco router, and then barricaded with a simple linux firewall that Scrappy had hand-crafted himself. What a perfectionist.
The ad, web, and database servers were all isolated into their own DMZ segments - separated by another series of linux firewalls.

The remote networks had a very similar configuration - Cisco router and linux firewall between the internet and the segmented DMZ networks.

I wanted to start my investigation at the master database server, and then work my way to the two remote database servers - very similar to what Scrappy had done with his investigation.

AddaBill had a nice out-of-band management network that talked to the servers via a serial terminal server. After authenticating to the terminal server via a SSH session using a key and a password, I was then authorized to initiate a terminal session with the database server.

The database server was running a slightly modified MySQL server daemon - which shocked me, as I remembered Scrappy being a PostgrSQL guy. Hey, it's open source - what the hell.

I stepped through Scrappy's list of steps, and verified his findings.

The integrity of the server itself was intact, according to Tripwire. Key binaries matched MD5 signatures, logs were intact, no unauthorized user accounts, etc.

Scrappy took over, and initiated an interactive session with the MySQL daemon. He gave me an idea of how the database was structured, a look at the tables, etc. What I was most interested in was the MySQL configuration files and the user table. A quick glance through the config files revealed nothing interesting. Hmmm. Back to the interactive MySQL session - and stepping through the table row by row.

"Dude, we change passwords every thirty days on the user accounts that the system uses to do queries, inserts, etc. You can see the hashes there in the table I just don't get it man." Scrappy said, his neck twitching a bit - maybe he needed a smoke.

"Um, Scrappy - not to bust your marbles - but is there a reason that your maintenance user "dbmaint" can connect directly from the inside interface of the DMZ firewall?

"Huh?" Scrappy said, pushing me out of the way.

"WHAT THE HELL MAN!!!!" Scrappy yelled, his fists clenched.

Looks like Scrappy missed something.

(Aside)

Scrappy has egg on his face. What did Scrappy do wrong here?
How did he miss that?
And what is the signifigance of what I found in the MySQL user table?

Drink Coffee.

Discuss.

Part IV

Talk about a long silence.

Scrappy stared at the MySQL prompt like he was waiting for it to do a trick.

"Chief, I swear on a fresh pack of Newports that I looked this table over row by row. No way I could have missed that!" Scrappy whined, placing his forehead on the keyboard.

BEEP! BEEP! BEEP!

"Scrap, get your head off the keyboard man. Look, whether you missed it or not is irrelevant at this point in time. We have a lead, so let's follow it. Let's log into that firewall and have a look around." I said, giving Scrappy a gentle elbow in the side."I'm guessing you want me to copy this table out somewhere so we can look at it again?" Scrappy asked.

"You read my mind, Scrap." I said with a smile. A few keystrokes later, Scrappy had the table copied. He spent the next few minutes engulfed in self-pity as he changed the password of the dbmaint user, changed the permissions, and exited the session. Apparently that user was supposed to be used by administrators for maintenance.

A few moments later we were logged into the linux firewall, having a look around. Nothing out of the ordinary was noted. No strange user accounts, nothing of consequence in the logs, shell history files were intact. Strange.

"This makes no sense man - no sense at all." Scrappy said angrily. "There's nothing here Chief!"

"How many other admins have access to these boxes again?" I asked, flipping through my notepad.

"Just the other two admins, and I'd trust them with my life man." Scrappy replied.

"Well, if you're sure of their integrity, give them a call real quick and make sure they didn't change that table." I suggested as I handed Scrappy the phone off of his desk.

While Scrappy was making his phone calls, I continued to poke around on the firewall. Something didn't feel right - similar to how one feels after a bad meal of Chinese take-out.

"Scrap, I'm going to do further analysis on this firewall - why don't you log into your web farms and make sure the database servers there haven't been modified in the same way?" I asked Scrap as he cupped the mouthpiece on his phone.

"Cool - I'm on it." Scrap said with a renewed sense of purpose. He quickly cleared some papers and empty Coke cans off of a nearby laptop and went to work.

Time passed. I was still poking around in the firewall when I got a confirmation from Scrappy that the web farm didn't have the same type of modification we had seen here on the HQ network.

"Hmmm, either our gremlin knew he only had to modify this server to get his changes replicated out, or he was completely unaware that the web farm existed." I thought to myself. Well, it was more of an assumption actually.

The firewall was very basic, and as stated before, could only be managed through a serial connection directly to the box. This would suggest someone with physical access to the box was using it as a jumping off point perhaps?

I was busy talking myself into several different scenarios when a lightbulb suddenly appeared over my monkey-like head.

"I need to plug in to that DMZ switch." I yelled over to Scrappy.

"You do? Uh, ok - I'll badge you in." Scrappy said as we walked to the datacenter door. A quick swipe of his badge and a scan of his hand and Scrappy pushed me through the datacenter door.

"Port 12" Scrappy said as he pointed to the switch.

I quickly plugged my trusty Powerbook into the switch, configured my Ethernet port with a floater management IP provided by Scrappy, and brought up a terminal.app. A few key clicks later and I was performing an nmap scan of the outside interface of the firewall.

Scrappy was on the phone with his girlfriend when I rushed into his cave.

"Dude, what service is listening on port 2929 on that firewall?" I asked.

"Huh? Nothing! That thing firewalls connections, and that's it. No services are running on that box." Scrappy responded as he hung up on his girlfriend.

"Any reason that when I telnet to that port I'm greeted with a shell prompt?" I asked.

Scrappy sat motionless.

(Aside)

Uh-oh. Scrappy gets caught with his pants down again.

How am I getting a shell prompt on that port?

What am I really talking to?

Drink more coffee, discuss.

(/Aside)

Part V

"What in the wide world of sports is going on here?" blared the TV in Scrappy's office. He had a DVD of "Blazing Saddles" in the DVD player, and it was quite ironic that I was thinking the exact same thing as I shifted my eyes back to the Apple Powerbook in my lap.

I felt bad for Scrappy - he was a top-notch Unix admin, so this was a big hit to his ego. If I had to hamper a guess, I'd say he was spending too much time with his newly-acquired girlfriend that he met at DefCon a while back. She was very cute, and very smart, but very demanding of Scrap's time.
Can you say "Lack of focus?"

Scrappy was busy in the datacenter running nmap scans of every network device, every server, and every workstation. He was a man on a mission.Back to my investigation, and a wonderful venti white chocolate mocha from Starbucks.

Scrap had done some quick network-jack patching in the datacenter and the phone room so that I could work in the DMZ by plugging my Apple Powerbook into the spare network jack in his office. How convenient.

The mysterious firewall service was bizarre to say the least. No running daemons on the box (verified by running MD5-verified copies of 'ps', 'netstat' to name a few), no logged in users but myself nothing. But here I was, having a conversation on TCP port 2929.

MonkeyBook:~ chief$ telnet firewall.internal 2929
Trying 10.1.1.1
Connected to firewall.internal.
Escape character is '^]'.

My keystrokes weren't being echoed back to me.

No output.

What could this be? It almost looks like a a webserver?

GET filename HTTP/1.0

HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 17:37:53 GMT
Connection: r00t3d
Content-Type: text/html

Fascinating! There's a webserver running on port 2929 on this firewall?

Not quite. Examining the banner, I got quite a chuckle out of the "Connection" screen. Someone was going to a lot of trouble to make this LOOK like a webserver.

"Scrap?" I yelled out the door, hoping he could hear me in the datacenter.

"Yo - almost done man. Looks like we're clean!" Scrappy replied back.

Scrap walked in the room and planted himself in his chair and reached for a smoke. "Did you find anything?"

"Dude, someone has"

(Aside)

What has someone done? Explain the output I saw above.

Part VI

(Aside)

First of all, hats off to reader "ut-admin" for nailing the breach. It is indeed, adore - well, adore is half the problem.
Second, hats off to UcantBeSerious for finding a very serious clue in the last posting.
You all amaze me! Great work.

(/Aside)

And our story continues...


"Dude, someone has left you a present on your firewall." I said as I kept punching keystrokes into my GLterm window."What do you mean present?" Scrap said, almost dropping his lit cigarette on his desk.

"This is a smooth backdoor. Whatever application I'm talking to, it's configured to spew this HTTP response header no matter what. I wonder what happens when I issue a shell command." I wondered.

My monkey paws quickly hammered in "pwd" , the UNIX command that displays the working directory name.


/root


"Holy moldy French roasted beans!" I thought to myself. I then entered a bunch of garbage commands and received not to my surprise that same HTTP banner.

"Let's try something obvious." I thought to myself, a slight grin spreading over my face.


# mysql -u dbmaint -p -h 10.1.1.100
Enter password:
Welcome to the MySQL monitor. Commands end with ; or \g.
Your MySQL connection id is 2933 to server version: x.0.20

Type 'help;' or '\h' for help. Type '\c' to clear the buffer.

mysql>


"Chief, what are you thinking man? WTF? Where is this thing?" Scrappy pleaded with me, putting his cigarette out on the floor.
[ed: floor was carpeted. The next two minutes were spent finding glasses of water to put the fire out.].

"LKM Backdoor." I said as I massaged my temples. "I'd bet a Starbuck's giftcard on it - and I'm thinking netcat on port 2929 is our doorway."

"Linux Kernel Module? Netcat? You have to be kidding me. Well, let's kick it's ass, get my firewall rebuilt and we can still make it to dinner before 9pm! You can meet my girlfriend!!" Scrap said as he reached for his laptop.

"Wait." I said.

"What? Let's do this! Like old times!" Scrap said, his eyes blazing.

"You want to find out who did this, or just clean up their mess and hope it doesn't happen again?" I asked as I tapped the top of my Powerbook screen.

"Well, the owners just want the ad redirection to stop - that's why you're here. But I bet we could set a trap for 'em right before they go to manipulate some bits!" Scrappy said as he stood at attention. This was getting way too dramatic for my tastes.

"I thought you'd say that." I replied with a grin.

Part VII

Scrappy looked like a young boy on Christmas morning. He was so excited that we were going to possibly find out who was penetrating his network that he was almost doing a Steve Ballmer-ish monkey dance in the datacenter.

"Let's go over the plan." I said as I waved my hands in the air, trying to get Scrappy to calm down.

Scrappy sensed my displeasure at his monkey dance and quickly walked over to the rack of equipment I was standing in front of.
"First things first, let's verify that my monitoring box is working." I announced as I brought up a serial console to "seeing-eye", a Sun Ultra 1E box that I had neatly placed in the rack next to the firewall. Seeing-eye was a custom-crafted box that did one thing and did it well: snarfed packets off the wire, analyzed them, stored them, performed some type of action based on the traffic (like send the Chief e-mail alerts on his phone) and be as undetectable as possible.

Scrappy had plugged his laptop in outside of the firewall and proceeded to make a telnet connection to the mysterious service running on tcp/2929.

"Beep!" went the console on Seeing-eye. It logged the connection and Scrap's request for a mysql session. Around a minute later, my cellphone beeped with a message containing a brief dump of Scrap's commands.

"Excellent. Now, let's go get that dinner you promised me." I told Scrappy as I listened to my stomach perform a musical rendition of "Feed me dammit!".

Scrap left the office a bit earlier than I did in order to pickup "The Girlfriend[tm]". He really wanted me to meet this girl.
"True love." I said as I laughed to myself. I pointed the car in the general direction of the restaurant and prepared for massive quantities of ingestible calories.

I arrived at the restaurant in record time thanks to my brain communicating properly with my feet. Apparently there was a cerebral coffee shortage and my brain wasn't too happy about it.

The restaurant was rather nice - a traditional steakhouse with all the usual trimmings. The host sat me down in a nice booth, decent lighting, and brought my coffee within a few minutes. I liked this place already.

Scrap was taking his time, so I whipped out my Treo and attempted to catch up on my e-mail and web-surfing habits.

I was right in the middle of winning an auction on eBay when a familiar voice reached my ear.

"Hey Chief! Sorry I.. err we're late. We had some issues at the gas station." Scrappy said as he sat down in the booth next to a rather attractive girl.

"Chief, this is Abby. Abby this is the Chief." Scrap said as I extended my monkey paw towards her. We were in mid-shake when the caffeine from my coffee stirred up some neurons and I suddenly felt a bit sick in the stomach department.

"Abby Abby" I said to myself over and over again, staring at her face and waiting for the neurons in my head to settle down.

The waitress brought us an appetizer, and I politely listened to Scrap and Abby talk about something that I had absolutely no interest in. I started to choke on my crab cake surprise.

"Chief! You OK?" Scrap said as he broke off in mid-sentence from Abby.

I had to do a bit of "Photoshop-ing" in my head, but I knew that Abby was a familiar face. I had met her in Vegas a few years back at Black Hat.

Although when I met her, she was going by the name "DarkAng3l".

Part VIII

"DarkAng3l" was no ordinary chix0r. She made a permanent impression in my memory with a demonstration of her skills at network penetration.

(fade to black, a memory from the Chief's way back machine)

I had joined DarkAng3l and a group of friends for some wardriving during BlackHat. The goal was to locate a seemingly valuable (and protected) wireless network, penetrate, record a quick nmap scan and leave. This was ordinarily something I wouldn't have participated in, but it went back to the old mantra "hero, know thy enemy". [Note: this was not a sponsored event of BlackHat, but the result of a good beer, dinner, and boredom.]We were driving for a little over twenty minutes when another person in the vehicle got a good reading on a network called "hidden". Obviously this name was a misnomer.

The network was fairly well protected aside from the SSID being broadcast - a practice that I discourage to all my clients.

A few minutes later we had identified the access point as a Cisco product. DarkAng3l wasn't saying a thing, simply typing away on her linux-powered HP notebook.

I was peering over the shoulder of the individual who found the network, and saw that a traffic capture was in progress. Apparently this person had come to the conclusion that the WAP was configured with a 64-bit WEP key. Shouldn't take very long to crack.

We were both startled at that point by a loud click and a sigh. I turned to my left to see DarkAng3l putting her laptop in her bag and handing me a floppy disk.

"What's this?" I asked as I stared at the label-less media.

"It's the scan. I win." She said with a creepy half-smile.

I verified the validity of the key, and the results of the scan by duplicating her efforts on my own linux laptop.

I was impressed with her skills and made it a point to get to know her over the next few days before I was scheduled to leave.

She belonged to (and created) a group named "Dark0n3s" that was going to be a hacker-for-hire company. She, along with two other members, were all very well-trained in the "arts".

(End of flashback)

"Chief! Dude, wake up! You're zoning out on us man!" Scrappy said as he waved his chimp paw in front of my face.

"Sorry." I said as I finished off my coffee. "It's been a long day."

(buzzing sound)

My cellphone was vibrating in my pocket. I had received a text message.

"Late for a date Chief?" Scrappy asked.

"You two have fun, I need to go." I replied as I slapped down a few bills to cover my drinks.

"But Chief you" Scrappy moaned as he watched me get up from the table.

I wanted badly to tell Scrap why I was leaving, but I was wary of Abby's presence.

Part IX

This case was developing more curves than Anna Nicole before she discovered TrimSpa. I let the details of the case swirl around in my coffee mug of a brain while I was stopped at a redlight. The drive back to my home had given me a good idea or two from time to time.Scrappy had a linux firewall with what appeared to be a linux kernel module backdoor installed. Scrappy was dating a known hax0r (and a rather cute one too, I might add). We have a method and a suspect, but what of a motive? Was Abby the only suspect? Was she using Scrappy for personal gain? What type of gain? What type of connection was there (if any)?

Once home, I cracked open my trusty Powerbook and performed an nslookup on the IP address that had connected to Scrappy's firewall. Having the entire session sent to my Treo in a few email messages was quite convenient for this type of monitoring.

chimptop:~ chief$ nslookup 210.x.x.x

Server: 192.168.1.254
Address: 192.168.1.254#53

Non-authoritative answer:
x.x.x.210.in-addr.arpa name = x.x.x.210.somecompany.co.th

Wonderful - Thailand. This was going nowhere fast. Gee, I wonder if this server is compromised and simply a backdoor for some mischievous folk?

Chimptop:~ chief$ nmap -sS -O -v 210.x.x.x

Host (210.x.x.x) appears to be up ... good.
Initiating SYN Stealth Scan against (210.x.x.x)
Adding open port 8080/tcp
Adding open port 21/tcp
Adding open port 23/tcp
Adding open port 80/tcp
The SYN Stealth Scan took 13 seconds to scan 1601 ports.
Interesting ports on (210.x.x.x):
(The 1588 ports scanned but not shown below are in state: closed)
Port State Service
21/tcp open ftp
23/tcp open telnet
25/tcp filtered smtp
80/tcp open http
135/tcp filtered loc-srv
136/tcp filtered profile
137/tcp filtered netbios-ns
138/tcp filtered netbios-dgm
139/tcp filtered netbios-ssn
445/tcp filtered microsoft-ds
1720/tcp filtered H.323/Q.931
8080/tcp open http-proxy
27374/tcp open subseven
