Remote operating system guess: Windows Millennium Edition (Me), Win 2000, or WinXP

I sighed in boredom. Another Windows machine with a subseven backdoor in use. What a surprise.

The connection was a dead-end, however the command capture was quite interesting:

mysql -u dbmaint -p -h 10.1.1.100
seckritpasswerd
UPDATE sites.destination SET finaldest = "massivechix^H^H^H^Hpr0nsite.com" WHERE origdest = "legitsite.com";


Let's think about this for a second.

1) Firewall is compromised.
2) Attacker installs backdoor through an LKM
3) Attacker places workable mysql client on firewall (and makes no attempt to hide it)
4) Attacker knows the NEW password to the 'dbmaint' account.
5) Attacker had a type-o in their UPDATE SQL statement

But what is the significance of the TYPE-O?

Part X

(Aside)

My readers constantly amaze me with their abilities to pick out the key parts of a case file that are important and draw some pretty impressive conclusions. As you're about to read, several of you were right on the money...

(/Aside)

It's a good thing that decaf coffee doesn't really mean "without caffeine coffee". I was determined to stay awake while scribbling in my case notebook. I was using a coffee brewing trick I learned in the military when "real" coffee was scarce. Double-brew the decaf, and say "hello" to wake-up juice. I went back to the basics. I drew a timeline in my notebook of the events so far, indicating the systems involved, the players as I knew it, and drew in "theory" bubbles around certain events. (These are helpful to attach motives to people based on events.)

After staring at the diagram for a while and working my way towards the bottom of the super-decaf pot, I decided that I needed to either eliminate Abby as a suspect, or build the case around her. To do this, I would need to play a bit with Scrappy. (What are friends for?) A plan was formed in my head - and a good plan at that.

I dialed Scrappy's cell phone.

*ring*

"Yo! Chief, it's late man - what's up? Why did you take off?" Scrap asked in between loud drags off a cigarette.

"We had another connection to the firewall this evening - I think you need to go into the office, change the 'dbmaint' password again, and consider changing out the firewall. I don't think your employer wants to play this game very much longer." I mumbled into the phone.

"You kidding me? How did they get the new password? We just changed it man! What the f..." Scrap said as I interrupted him.

"Obviously we missed something. Grab your laptop and get over to the office." I said with an impatient yawn.

"No can do Chief, Abby has my laptop. She dropped hers at her apartment and the screen is crack-o-la. I lent her mine." Scrap replied with a dramatic cough. "But... wait... I got that Toshi sitting on the bookcase. I guess I could use that one."

"Hey out of curiosity Scrap - which laptop did you loan her?" I asked - knowing that Scrap has quite a few laptops laying around at Casa De Scrap.

"My SparcBook - you know... the tadpole." he said matter-of-factly. Interesting.

"Scrap, I want you to grab the old Toshiba Satellite laptop in your office and use it to change all the passwords. Then, I want you to swap out the firewall with the freshly built one under your desk. Ok?" I demanded.

Sometimes Scrap needed a push to do the most obvious things. It drove me nuts.

"Yeah, ok, ok... calm down man. I'm on it." Scrap said. "So have you found anything yet?"

"Nothing conclusive." I lied. "And before I forget - why were you guys so late to dinner?"

"Oh, yeah... " Scrap replied with a snort. "Dude, it was soooo wrong. Abby was wanting to check her mail on the tadpole right - so she brings up Netscape and she's like all happy and stuff because we were down by the University, you know - hotspot central - and she gets right on. She's totally digging the tadpole, and kind of impressed by how snappy Solaris is on that bad boy. Then she got all pissed because I had some pr0n sites in my browsing history. It got ugly man."

"Uh, Scrap - you let her use your tadpole logged in as YOU?" I asked as I slapped myself on the forehead.

"Yeah man, it's not like my girlfriend needs a permanent account on my tadpole." Scrap responded, reeking of ignorance.

"Scrap, I'm going to meet you at the office. We need to talk." I said as I looked around for my shoes.

"Uh, ok. About what?" Scrap asked.

"Abby." I said.

The chess game was in motion once again.

Part XI

This case had more twists and turns than my last tax return.

A slight drizzle of rain had started to pour from the clouds overhead as I made my way towards AddaBill. I had diverted myself for a few moments to locate a late-night latte, and was becoming mesmerized by it's sweet aroma as it filled my car.

I took the last few minutes of my drive to collect my thoughts, and to prepare for my discussion with Scrappy. This wasn't going to be the most enjoyable moment of my career.I walked to front doors of AddaBill and saw Scrappy standing outside, huddled in a corner and nursing a cigarette.

"Hey Chief - mission accomplished. Password changed, and the new firewall is in place." Scrap said as he tossed his smoke into a pile of rain water.

"Good work - let's get out of this rain." I said as I motioned Scrappy inside.

I took up residence in a chair next to Scrap's desk and stared at the linux firewall that Scrap had pulled out of the networking rack in the datacenter.

"It's all yours, Chief. You want to take it with you - or you're more than welcome to do your magic on it here." Scrap said with a big toothy grin.

"I'll take it with me." I responded, looking over Scrap's shoulder. "Scrap, I'm a little concerned about your relationship with Abby."

"Why? She's really cool. I don't understand." Scrap said with a look of concern.

"You're breaking one of the cardinal rules of security, bud. You're giving someone else privileged access to your main laptops, which we both know could give her enough information to do a lot of things." I said without missing a beat.

"I'm not sure I understand where you're going here, man." Scrappy said, staring at the ceiling tiles in his office.

"Scrap, you know her background probably better than I do. I've met her before - and I've seen her in action. She is the definitive ch1x0r." I pleaded. "Did it ever occur to you that Abby might have something to do with all the weirdness going on with your little database problem?"

"Oh come on man. Are you serious? Abby isn't like that - you don't know her like I do. She is legit - she's a security consultant now, ya know." Scrap said with a hint of pride. "She's not involved."

"Then you won't mind if I ask to look over your Tadpole?" I asked, looking Scrap straight in the eyes. "I *need* that laptop."

"Hey, that shouldn't be a problem Chief. She should be here any minute. I wasn't about to let her keep my 'pole over night - how am I supposed to get any work done?" Scrappy said with a laugh.

One half-hour later, Abby arrived with the Tadpole under her arm. Abby gave me a rather strange look, handed the laptop to Scrap, gave him a kiss on the cheek and hurried out the door.

"What's her deal? I didn't even get a 'hi'!" I cracked.

"She's flying to Atlanta tomorrow, or maybe it's Miami... I forgot. Anyway, she probably wants a good night sleep or something." Scrap said as he handed me the Tadpole.

"I need to take the Tadpole with me too - you're going to have to make due with the Toshiba until tomorrow evening." I said as I placed the linux firewall under my other arm and made my way to the door.

"Chief! Come on man, can't we do that tomorrow?" Scrap whined.

"Dude, you live in a world of console prompts. Use the Toshiba. Pine works just as well on that box." I joked as I walked down the hallway.

'You're killing me, Chief!" Scrap yelled from his office.

Part XII

The rain was pouring from the heavens faster than Oprah eating at a dessert bar. There I was, sitting in my car outside of my house, watching millions of gallons of water coming from the skies. I was debating whether to leave the linux firewall and tadpole laptop in the trunk of my car and make a run for the house, or brave the storm and move the equipment into the house. Decisions... decisions...I made a compromise with myself - I made a run for the house, and came back to the car with my trusty JumboBrella. I remotely opened the trunk, grabbed the gear with one hand and ran for the house. As luck would have it, I made it through the front door - but the tadpole didn't. I was four paces from the front door when I felt the tadpole slipping out of my grip. Before I could compensate for it's gradual descent towards the ground with my knee, the tadpole had made a beeline for the nearest half-foot deep puddle of water with a suicidal flip from the back of my arm.

Dammit.

What an amateur mistake. I ran outside, plucked the laptop from it's watery grave and ran back to the house. My clothes were soaking wet, and I hadn't even started a fresh pot of coffee to warm myself up. It just wasn't right!

A quick change of clothes later, I inspected the tadpole - now hanging from a clothesline in my office like a pair of worn-out boxer shorts. Water was dripping at a regular pace from every nook and cranny. Not good. My only saving grace was that I had removed the battery from the laptop in the car before I had left Addabill. Well, I really didn't have a choice because Scrap had broken the case holding the battery in. Nice.

I set up a blower fan, pointed it at the tadpole, crossed myself and wished the tadpole the best. I hope the hard drive had survived. Thank goodness they are self-contained.

I turned my attention to the linux firewall.

"What secrets do you have in store for me, my little friend?" I asked it, almost expecting a verbal response. I popped the cover off of the firewall (Scrap wasn't big on using screws on anything - what gives?) and located the IDE hard drive. I snapped a few reference pictures with my trusty Olympus digital camera and proceeded to disconnect the IDE drive and attach it to my good friend Roscoe.

(For those of you that haven't read all my case files - Roscoe is my portable forensic workstation.)

Double-checking that my write-blocker was installed on the IDE chain, I began the imaging process and wandered off to the kitchen to brew some go-go juice.

A few hours later, the laptop was still dripping and my imaging process had nearly finished.

*BEEP*

A friendly console prompt was staring me in the face - I had a nice image of the root ( / ) filesystem of the drive and an image of the SWAP partition. Sweet.

I quickly mounted the root partition as a read-only filesystem using the nifty loopback device, and attempted to have a look around the filesystem.

roscoe$ cd /mnt/firewall
roscoe$ ls -la
total 0
drwxr-xr-x 3 chief chief 102 11 Oct 12:02 .
drwx------ 35 chief chief 1190 11 Oct 10:38 ..

roscoe$

What the...

Did I goof? Did I not image the drive properly? I quickly checked the cables, the write blocker... my dd command... everything was perfect. There was nothing on that filesystem.

And if there was, I suspected it had been deleted or formated.

My patience had worn thin.

I picked up my cellphone and dialed Scrap's number.

*ring*
*ring*
*ring*
*ring*
*ring*

No answer.

Part XIII

I was losing my mind. I was trying very hard not to let my friendship with Scrap interfere with my work, but it was beginning to take it's toll. I was frustrated at the challenges that were being thrown at me left and right (and even more so - the ones I was creating, like the wet tadpole laptop).

I picked up my land line and called Scrap's apartment. If he was screening his calls, he wouldn't know this was me because my land line was blocked - no caller ID.*ring*
*ring*

"Hello?" said Scrap, sounding mildly distracted.

"Scrap, what's going on?" I asked in a most annoyed tone.

"Heh?" Scrap responded.

"I just imaged this firewall, and the drive partitions are blank - empty. How might this have happened?" I asked.

"What do you mean they are blank? I pulled that out of the rack, sat it on the floor and swapped the other firewall in. I didn't touch that thing!" Scrap fired back.

"I want you to come over here right now." I demanded. "I want you to eyeball this thing."

"Alright - give me a sec." Scrap said as he hung up the phone.

I decided to rest for a few minutes and let my mind clear. I had to get back into an investigator mindset and calm down. I was really irritated.

Two cups of finely brewed java later, my doorbell rang.

*dong!*

I opened the door to find a quite drenched Scrappy huddling under the dry safety of my porch.

I motioned for Scrap to join me in my office and I pointed to the linux firewall setting neatly on my lab table.

"Care to have a look there, bud?" I asked.

Scrappy approached the firewall and peered inside. The hard drive was removed and setting next to Roscoe, IDE cable still attached.

"What are you expecting me to see here, Chief? This is my firewall. There's my ID sticker on it - FW-1." Scrappy said, running his index finger along the ID tag on the front of the firewall case.

"You want to explain how that hard drive is wiped clean?" I asked, glancing over at the hard drive sharing desk space with Roscoe.

Scrap approached the tabled and looked down.

"What hard drive? This drive?" Scrap said as he turned the hard drive 180 degrees. "This isn't my hard drive. This is a Maxtor - I only use Western Digital drives in these babies. "

I stared at Scrap like he had just called my mother a derogatory name.

"What do you mean that's not your hard drive? I took it out of the box!" I exclaimed.

"I'm telling you Chief, that is NOT a hard drive that I would use. That model of Maxtor has a ridiculous fail rate." Scrap said as he shook his head.

I disconnected the hard drive and placed it back in the linux firewall, screwing the two screws holding it into the drive bay.

"Here." I said as I handed the case cover to Scrap. "Finish putting this back together." I sat down in my office chair and crossed my arms in my lap.

Scrap popped the case cover back on and slid it neatly into place.

"Got a screwdriver?" Scrap asked, stretching out one arms towards me.

"Why? There weren't any screws holding the thing on when I got it." I replied.

Scrappy put his arm down and stared at the box. He stood motionless for what seemed an eternity.

"You ok?" I asked.

"Chief, you know me pretty well. I *always* screw case covers back on. This case takes four case screws - and one of the holes is stripped - this case cover had three case screws holding it on." Scrap moaned as he sat down on the lab table.

I left the comfort of my office chair and examined the case cover. I opened a filing cabinet drawer and pulled out a baby food jar full of case screws. Two screws into securing the cover and I found that one wouldn't tighten.

"Son of a gun... " I said.

Scrappy continued to sit on the table, head down... thinking intensely.

I glanced over at the tadpole, still hanging from the hastily-fashioned clothesline.

"Hey Scrap, how are your surgical skills?" I asked with a grin.

"Heh?" Scrap said, not lifting his head.

"I need your help with a little surgery on your laptop."

Part XIV

"I need a smoke first." Scrap said as pulled a pack of Newports from his pocket and headed toward my back porch.

My heart was starting to beat a little faster, and I suspected it was from the excitement surrounding the tadpole. Anyone else would blame the coffee, but we all know that the Chief has a high tolerance. I removed the tadpole from the clothesline and placed it on the empty half of my lab table, still warm from Scrap's strategic placement of his arse.

I had just begun to slide the drive door down when Scrap re-entered the office, a blank look occupying his face.

"Ready to do this?" I asked as I slid the drive sled from the tadpole.

"Yeah." Scrap replied as he volunteered to hold the tadpole steady.

Scrap had apparently gotten sick of the small SCSI drive that came in the tadpole and replaced it with an IDE drive equipped with some sly IDE-to-SCSI adapter. Very cool.

I scrounged around in my forensics kit for the proper adapter for the drive, and before I knew it we were in the process of imaging the drive.

The room was getting uncomfortably quiet, so I recommended to scrap that we step out the living room and watch some TV.

A short time later the familiar chime of a console beep alerted me that the drive image was completed. Repeating the same process as earlier, I mounted the partitions and prepared for some serious investigation.

With scrap looking over my shoulder, we went for the obvious - shell history files. Scrap was a bash man, so my attention was drawn to /.bash_history and ~/.bash_history.

We breezed through root's history file (/.bash_history) and saw nothing entertaining. My faith was partially restored in Scrap - he wasn't doing too much work as the root user.

The history file for his user account was a little more... fascinating. Scrap and I stepped through his commands, and analyzed the sequences very carefully... until they abruptly ended.

"I don't get it." Scrap said. "I don't see any commands past where I checked my mail before leaving to get Abby - see, that's where I ssh'd to the mail server... there's where I ran pine... and there's where I handed the 'pole to Abby. "

"How does she usually get her mail?" I asked.

"She's a console gal, man. Otherwise I wouldn't be dating her." Scrap said all too seriously.

I went with my gut and dived into the Netscape history and cache files. Scrap verified all the sites, and even pointed out the pr0n links that Abby was so upset about. We weren't getting anywhere. I then decided to do a comprehensive search of the root partition for strings of interest. A little magic with 'find', 'grep' and 'strings' and we were sailing through thousands of files - and of course, nothing of interest was revealed.

I noticed the number of partitions that we imaged... a root partition, a swap partition, and two others that seemed rather strange. One was relatively small, and the other was the exact size of the root partition.

"Hey scrap, what are these other two partitions?" I asked, pointing to the images files - not yet daring to delve into the mounted versions.

"Uh, that small one is used for suspend/restore - and the other one is my backup partition." Scrap responded.

"Backup partition? How are you backing up your root partition?" I queried. I was almost giddy that Scrap was proving to as responsible as I remembered.

"I have a little script that fires off when I login, and it performs an rsync between the two partitions." Scrap said.

"Wait, you mean when you logged in to check your mail BEFORE you picked up Abby, it made a backup... and then it made another backup when you logged in to give the tadpole to Abby to check her mail?" I asked.

"Right - well, there's a delay of a few minutes at first because it has to figure out what files have changed, but it's pretty darn faster after that." Scrap said.

I wasn't even paying attention to Scrap's words at this point. I had already mounted the backup partition and went straight to ~/.bash_history. A quick SHIFT-G in vi and I was at the bottom of the file.

"Holy Jeezus on a pogo stick." I whispered.

Conclusion

I'm not good at awkward silences. I start to say something, but then I stop because I think someone else is going to say something. I decided that I'd pass the proverbial speaking torch to Scrappy. I was waiting a long time - then I noticed that Scrappy was standing there with his eyes closed.I looked back at the console screen - there in the .bash_history file was the straight dope:

...
telnet 210.x.x.x 27374
ssh mail.chix0rsrus.com
...

"Scrap." I said as I tapped him on the shoulder.

"Huh?"

"So you're telling me that this telnet command is Abby?" I asked, pointing at the screen.

Scrappy sighed loudly.

"Yeah. I guess it is." he replied, closing his eyes again.

"Scrap, the machine at that IP address appears to match what we caught using the backdoor on the firewall. Any ideas?" I asked, smacking Scrap in the arm a few times.

"Yeah, I suppose I have a few." Scrap said. "Let's go outside - I need a smoke."

I followed Scrap out to my Patio, grabbing a fresh cup of Joe from the kitchen.

"I'm sorry." Scrap said as he exhaled a plume of Newport smoke into the atmosphere.

"Sorry for what?" I asked, tapping my finger on my coffee cup.

"Sorry for getting you involved in this." he responded.

"Can I make a guess on what you're about to tell me?" I asked Scrap after a mighty swig of go-go joe.

Scrap nodded as he sat back into the patio chair.

"Abby is every geek's dream girl. She's hot, she's smart, and she has a personality. You got involved with Abby and found geek nirvana. After a few weeks, you started having differing opinions on all things geek. Your relationship turned into a festival of one-upsmanship. How am I doing?" I asked Scrap.

"You forgot to mention her incredible taste in geek boys." Scrap cracked as he flicked a burnt cherry off the end of his cigarette. "But please, please continue."

I elaborated on my theory.

"A series of 'geek olympics' has been going on. She hacks your hotmail account, you socially-engineer a credit-card in her name, she has your electric turned off, you deface her weblog.... am I still doing ok?" I said as I put down my coffee cup and scratched my arm.

"It's like you're reading my mind, man." Scrap joked as he lit another Newport. He was taking my intuition a little light.

"Eventually, you two ran out of ways to best each other. One night, Abby turns her attention to your little server farm at AdaBill. She's so good at not being noticed once she's penetrated your firewall that she decides to liven things up. She wants you to know what she's done. She starts manipulating your link traffic. You see what's going on, but you're unsure of who is doing it. You suspect Abby, but you don't want to ask her - because it might not be. You don't want to mention it to me because, hey - you appear to be getting your geek butt kicked by a chiX0r. So you remain silent." I said, looking back at Scrap for a reaction.

"That's mostly correct." Scrap responded. "I honestly didn't think it was Abby until you showed me the hard drive you took out of the linux firewall. There's no way in hell that I'd use a cheap ass drive like that one. And I knew that the only person who would cover their tracks that well AND that had access to my office would be Abby. She wanted to preserve her hack, and the only guarantee she had was to replace the drive."

I raised an eyebrow.

"Scrap, I need to know where to go from here man. So far I've figured out what has happened, who was responsible, and I gave your rather expensive sparc laptop an unneeded bath. I still owe your employer a report. I can write up my findings and recommendations, or you can go talk to them yourself. It's your call." I said as I sat forward, placing my head in my hands. "What's it going to be?"

Scrap put out his cigarette and leaned forward in the patio chair.

"I'll talk to management. You'll get your check either way. Let's just hope I have a job after tomorrow." Scrap said as he stood up and stretched.

CONCLUSION

Scrap met with the management of Adabill the next afternoon and explained to the three most senior officers of the company what had happened. Adabill hadn't finished putting together a loss estimation from the misguided traffic, but from my exit conference with management I learned that the CFO had guessed around $120k. Adabill made a move that surprised me. They didn't fire Scrap. Scrap paid for the $120k loss in good ol'fashioned humiliation. Adabill had Scrap explain the loss himself at the BoD meeting. Needless to say, the BoD tore Scrap a new orifice and then laughed through his entire presentation. Comments like "she sure schooled you!" peppered the conference room.

Abby was confronted by Scrappy a week later after she returned from a security gig out of town. Abby confirmed my suspicions, however Scrappy left me out of his conversation. I'm not sure if that was a blessing or not. Scrappy and Abby broke up within two weeks citing geek incompatibilities.
(Scrappy won't admit it, but her skills were far more superior than his)
Scrappy is currently employed as a systems administrator for a hosting company. Abby is still a security hired gun. The Chief is still tired and in need of coffee.

(Aside)

This goes to show you that no matter how much work you do in this industry, you haven't seen everything.

What would you have done if you were Scrappy?

What would you have done if you were on the Adabill Board of Directors? Would you have been easier? Harsher?

(/Aside)

Case of the Bandwidth Burglar

Part I

"Is it even scientifically possible for coffee to freeze within a few minutes?" I asked myself as I stared into my coffee cup. What was once an interesting house blend had turned into an iced mocha in a matter of minutes. Then again, I was in Canada.

During the winter time.

Even my blood was freezing.I was perched inside a small caf, enjoying free wireless connectivity and, apparently, an iced mocha. I was meeting a friend of mine, Nelson. Nelson was a fellow geek and had one of the coolest jobs to be had: he worked at a video game company. Nelson was a top-notch systems administrator and always had a plethora of interesting geekish side jobs going on at any time.

"Chief! Your teeth are chattering - welcome to Canada!" Nelson joked as he sat next to me at my table. "Nice Powerbook man - looks a lot like mine." He said as he pulled his own Powerbook from his backpack. "I need some coffee, be right back."

"My teeth aren't chatter-er-ering!" I thought to myself as I browsed a few auctions I was watching on eBay.

Nelson returned with a steaming cup of joe (why was his coffee hot? Is there a trick to ordering coffee in this country?) and cracked open the top to his powerbook. "So, how you liking Canada?"

"It's, uh, nice and pretty close to the north pole from the temperature." I quipped as I scanned the weather applet on my powerbook's desktop. "Jeezus man, it's 7 degrees outside!"

"Yeah, well it's a warm winter this year. So how's business? You working a gig up here?" Nelson asked with a loud slurp.

"Finishing one up, actually. It was mostly a due diligence job - you know, two companies merging that don't trust each other. As the law of hilarity would dictate, neither one of them had adequate security controls in my opinion."

"Hey, speaking of security controls - I just had a case of my own that I solved." Nelson beamed.

"Oh, do tell Sherlock. I have to hear this." I said as I made myself comfortable in my chair.

Nelson pushed back his chair and crossed his legs. This story MUST be good.

"Well, as you might remember I run a small web hosting company on the side from my normal day job as a SysAdmin, mostly so I can host my personal sites and retain some control over the machine. It doesn't make money, but it can be fun. Most of my clients are friends or friends of friends."

I stopped Nelson immediately. "Wait a tick, I don't remember an offer to host any of my stuff!"

Nelson grinned. "Anyway, I get charged based on the amount of traffic I use, so I try to keep tabs on it. For individual sites, I use Webalizer and generate stats every night from cron. But, that doesn't track non-http traffic, so I thought I needed something better."

"Oh man, now I know where all that Canadian pr0n is hosted." I said with a quick ducking motion.

"I won't ask how you know about Canadian pr0n - but I digress. The first attempt was with a nice little app called IPFM (IP flow monitor). It just sits there listening on the network interface and logs the amount of traffic you use to a file. I had it configured to log hourly, then I used another application called bw-ipfm to make nicer looking reports based on it. They worked really nice, and I've been using them for years."

I smiled and joked "Sounds like a good use of open source tools, my man. So when does this start getting good?"

Nelson raised both eyebrows at me, clearly forgetting how much I enjoyed giving him a hard time.

"I gradually started using more and more bandwidth. I could fairly easily figure out the web traffic, and I wrote a perl script that grep'd the mail logs and figured out how much bandwidth incoming mail was using, but there was a large gap. Since those are the two primary services I provide, I was kind of concerned. And I had no idea what I was about to find."

Part II

My heart was doing a pitter-patter dance. Not only had the coffee I ordered come hot, but apparently it was "high octane". Wow - I'm not going to sleep for days!

"Alright, so let me make sure I'm following you here. You have these hosting boxes, and by setting up some cool tools you've found that your bandwidth usage numbers are all out of whack." I said in between sips."You got it. So, I'm thinking at this point that I might have been compromised. There's quite a bit of script kiddy and wanna-be hackers up around these parts - so I ran chkrootkit and thoroughly inspected the machine (even using trusted sources for binaries) to make sure that it wasn't a hacker . Now I have to admit that I was kind of concerned, because it was a 4 year old install of Debian , but I was always pretty good at keeping it up to date. But, what if it was an exploit in the kernel - I might have missed it! As luck would have it, my box was fine and there were no signs that the box had been compromised. The only other thing I could think of was secure shell." Nelson postulated, raising a hand into the air.

"So these hosting customers have shell access to your box as well? The world is their oyster." I said with outstretched arms. "So I have to ask, how were you able to track the shell traffic?"

"Well, I looked into trying to log scp and sftp traffic, but wasn't able to find anything immediately. Later I found that you can get patches for OpenSSH. But anyway, I checked the logs to see who it could be, and spoke to a couple of prime suspects, but they all denied it. " Nelson said.

"They always do."

"Duh - but I figured it wasn't someone being malicious, and they were probably just using it as a way to transfer files back and forth from home or something." Nelson responded as he finished off his coffee.

"That's a pretty good theory. After a clue banana or too, I'm betting that you did more research and found something interesting?" I said, signaling the barkeep for another round of coffees.

"Finally I read an article in SysAdmin magazine by Randal Schwartz where he used OpenBSD's pf - it has this ability to generate totals for traffic based on a rule using labels. He then inserted it into a sqllite database and generated fancy graphs with Perl.

I figured I would do the same, with a few twists. He was running it on the machine he was monitoring, I decided to use a transparent bridging firewall in front of the machine. I also decided to insert it into PostgreSQL instead. Oh, and I did it all in Python."

Now I was really captivated. "I can understand PostgreSQL for the speed, but Python? Are you wielding the holy banana of coders too, now? Impressive!!"

"Hey, Python is cool. Finally I set it up and had it logging for a few weeks (I was busy), then I managed to take some time to go through the data I had collected and find out who it was. First, I did some queries to figure out which days had spikes in traffic. Then I took those days and figured out what type of traffic it was - secure shell! Then I narrowed down when the traffic spikes occurred." Nelson was really into this story.

"So where did the rabbit hole lead?" I asked. "And how did you correlate the traffic to a user?"

"How did I know you were going to interrupt with that? Okay - after I had a one hour time window from the previous day that showed a large amount of traffic sent, I started going through the authlogs on the server itself. I was quite lucky in a way, because there was only one ssh login during that time, and it was exactly when I had seen the traffic in the database." Nelson said.

"And did you know this person?" I asked on the edge of my seat.

Part III

"Ok, ok - enough with the suspense. Out with it man, details!" I demanded.

"You know that we deal with large files at work. Well, this person apparently had a lot of large files too."

"Well, couldn't they have been iso images out of someone's warez collection, pirated movie files or something? There are so many good Canadian films to pirate nowadays." I said, poking Nelson's Canadian button a few more times.

"The user was a customer of my hosting services - and a coworker." Nelson said, his voice growing strangely softer.

"Holy sh. You serious?" I said, eyes wide open.

"Honestly, I wasn't surprised that this person would be tranfering large files. We have some pretty beefy machines in the office, so I figured they were working on a personal project at work and was just scp'ing it up to my machine and then scp'ing it down once they got home." Nelson replied.

I pondered his words for a moment. "Ok, that sounds pretty legit. So where does this go wrong?"

"I started writing them an email telling them that I paid for the bandwidth they were using, and asked if they could pick up a USB drive or something to carry their files back and forth. Just on a fluke, I checked to see if they had already downloaded the files that they had uploaded.

That's when everything changed. I realized that it was files from work - yes, actual intellectual property of work - that they were not allowed to remove from the facility. Now I had a dilemma, this person was a coworker, and I am sure they weren't taking them home for a malicious reason. They probably just wanted to show them to friends or something, right? But alas, it was my job to try to make sure things didn't leave the facility." Nelson said.

"Ah, now that's quite the quagmire to find one's self in. You find out that a coworker is doing something naughty, and the esprit d'duty kicks in. Quite common nowadays from my experience. What did you do?" I said with a puzzled look on my face.

"I did something that I really didn't want to do - something that I think about every day now." Nelson said, staring a whole through me.

Nelson was in neck deep - what DID Nelson do?

(Aside)

Put yourself in Nelson's shoes (in this case, big snow shoes).

What plan of action would you follow?

(/Aside)

Part IV

I could tell during Nelson's accounting of this story that it bothered him quite a bit. I was feeling rather privileged that he was wanting to share this story with me. I felt a little off balance though, because it's usually me recanting my stories to others in hopes of educating the masses.

Nelson moved a bit in his chair, and with a satisfying gulp of joe he continued."Chief, I figured I had two options. I could go to them and explain that I had found the files, and then deal with it myself, or I could go the management and they would reprimand them in some form or fashion. It is their responsibility to do so, right?

I wrestled with this for a while - it made me ill.

I thought about it for a few hours, and I decided to go to management, but proposed that I talk to them, let them know that they weren't allowed to take the files, and have them promise to delete them. Then our management folks could send out a reminder to the other employees." Nelson shared.

I gave Nelson a reassured look across the table.

"There's nothing wrong with that decision man. If you managed that company, I bet you'd really appreciate a trusted employee coming to you with similar findings. So how did management react? In the States they send people to the electric chair for that now." I said without missing a beat.

"Seriously? Isn't that a bit rigid for intellectual property theft?" Nelson wondered.

"Obviously you've never been subpoenaed by the MPAA or the RIAA." I fired back. "Ok, I'm actually kidding. Sorry to interrupt again - what happened next?"

"Great Gods of Gilder, they took it much more seriously than I expected. I had a conference call with the management team where I had to explain exactly how I figured it out, and how confident I was that it was in fact this employee. I imaged the drive of their machine using dd just in case."

I smiled. "You're going to be a forensic investigator yet Nelson. I'm guessing management was freaking out at this point?"

"Well, they scheduled a management meeting the next morning to decide what to do. I was pretty stunned at how they took it, and I couldn't sleep that night. I should add that she was a friend of mine."

Now that was a new bit of information. It was a female coworker!

"Crickies! A fellow employee, a female AND a friend of yours? Nelson, have I ever told you the story about Scrappy and" I trailed off.

Ok, I wasn't going to go there.

(Aside)

What will management's decision be?

How will this affect the relationship between Nelson and his co-worker?

How would you approach this?

Have you had to approach this? Share!

Part V

Nelson was getting more upset as this case was unwound. I completely understood.

"Seriously man, were you getting raked over the coals at this meeting?" I asked.

"I had to go over everything again, and explain things and thankfully my management is fairly technical. They also had a lawyer present just to cover the bases. He asked me a million questions about my business and what kind of contract I had with my hosting clients. I realized that this might not stand up in court, so I was pretty nervous." Nelson said as quickly downed the rest of his second coffee."Well, I can't speak for Judge Judy up here, but if you documented everything and maintained some sort of chain of custody of the evidence, you might have a chance in the States." I said. "But I agree, this is very shaky Nelson."

"I was feeling like total crap, Chief! After the meeting her fate was pretty much sealed. She was going to be terminated. Did I mention that she had a B1 visa, so that meant she would probably have to go back to her home country only a few months after her husband had finally moved to Canada!!!"

"Good grief." I lamented. Now I was getting depressed.

"So a few hours later they called her into the conference room and had a meeting. While she was in there, I had to do my job and disable all of her accounts on the systems and remove her machine from the floor.

I never actually saw her after the meeting, which is probably a good thing. This was probably the most difficult thing that I have ever had to do in my career. I have worked 120 hour weeks, I have stayed up for three days trying to recover critical data from a file server, and I have dealt with hackers and virii. Let me tell you Chief, they are nothing compared to having to carry away a friend's machine after she is fired based on information that I provided." Nelson said, clearly drained from our conversation.

Nelson and I spent the rest of the afternoon discussing happier geek topics and putting a hurt on the caf's bandwidth bill.

Neither of us transferred any large files.

(Aside)

This was a bit different that my past case files, as it was relayed to me by a friend of mine. I hope that while reading this case file, the message was loud and clear.

Doing the right thing is almost always the right thing to do - but it's never easy.

What would you have done in Nelson's place?

Case of the Prying Eyes

Part I

I couldn't keep my eyes open. I had just finished twenty excruciating hours of forensic analysis on a client's hard drive, and my head felt like Dr. Phil's seat cushion (under pressure). I was sitting in a comfortable lounge at my local car dealership waiting for my vehicle to get routine maintenance.

"Why I make these appointments so damn early in the morning I'll never know." I whined to myself. I felt mildly refreshed as I spied a to-go container of Starbucks and a few boxes of Krispy Kreme doughnuts sitting on a nearby counter.
I was half-way through my first cup of Holiday Blend and working on a chocolate glazed when my nemesis, the cell phone, rang at full volume. Not only did I realize that I was now fully awake, but so was everyone else around me.

Oops, sorry folks.

"Chief." I habitually said into the squawking silver box.

"Good morning, sunshine! This is Rick over at Chelsea Healthcare. How are you?"

"Like wrapping paper on Christmas morning man - just waiting to get stepped on." I joked.

Rick and I went way back - he was one of the first clients I ever had and kept in touch on a periodic basis to sample one of the several hundred beer flavors at the local pub. I wasn't in the mood for a beer at 0800 hours.

"Always the joker. Hey, I have a really bizarre situation that I need some help with. We've been doing pretty well handling all of our own security incidents after you put together our incident response plan years back - but we're kind of stuck on this recent happening." Rick said in a serious tone.

"Someone stole the keys to the Coke machine again?" I said, fondly remembering the three days of hilarity that ensued when the Chelsea IT staff couldn't get to Mountain Dew on a regular basis.

"I wish. This actually has to do with a potential customer of ours - an external incident. We're struggling with legal, audit and the rest of the security staff on how to handle this. Let me put it this way, this individual isn't even a customer yet and they are blaming us for stuff already." Rick said in disbelief.

The boggle sound coming from my brain was loud enough that I'm sure the dealership receptionist could hear it. There I was again, bothering people.

"Um, Rick you know I'm not one for riddles, but what exactly are we talking about here?" I demanded, looking around for that magical Starbucks fountain of coffee.

There was a dramatic pause on the phone. I heard Rick cough and he said softly "She is claiming that we assisted in the theft of her identity."

Yikes. I hope they have my vehicle done soon.

Part II

Identity theft is serious stuff. Heck, I live in a city that is darn near the identity theft capital of the world! I knew my case load was light for the next few weeks due to the holidays, so I had to help Rick out.

"Ok, let's talk details when I get there. I'm stuck at the car dealership for a while, but I can head over about lunch time. You want to meet at the usual place for burgers?" I asked, paying attention to the grumbling sound in my gut. It would appear that Krispy Kreme wasn't being kind to my stomach.A few hours later my vehicle was in tip-top condition and I was busy punching the burger place into my navigation system.

"In one quarter mile, make a right turn onto I-999." went the seductive female voice. Wowza. I need to travel interstate more often.

A little over an hour later, I was across town and nearing the burger joint.

"In two tenths of a mile, turn right. Your destination is on your left." went the voice again.

Just in time. I was starving.

I pulled into the parking lot to find Rick sitting on the hood of his ride, his trademark cigar in his mouth.

"Chief! Hurry up - I'm starving!" Rick cried, cupping his hands around his mouth.

A few moments later we were seated in the burger joint, staring at two 1/3 pound burgers with everything. Life was getting better by the minute.

"So Rick, details man. You typically only get me involved when something ugly is going on. Start at the beginning." I said in between bites.

"Well, as you know we launched a major e-commerce initiative a few months ago. Since you have our insurance I'm sure you got the flyer, right?" Rick asked.

"Yep - the blonde lady on the cover was pretty hot." I joked, threatening another french fry with my fingers.

"That's the one. Part of this initiative is to drum up substantial numbers of individual policies. It's been working okay so far. A few weeks ago we had a call from a subscriber that was escalated directly to me. I knew something bad was going down when it hit my desk." Risk lamented.

"Hey, it comes with the territory when you're the CSO, bud. Get over it." I joked. Rick made a truckload of cash, and frequently complained about it.

"Eat your burger Chief. So anyway this customer is a female, and she doesn't even live in this state. Right away, we have a distance issue - we can only talk to her on the phone. Secondly, she says that she went through the application process on our website and used a home phone number that was brand new. She had just gotten the service that same day."

I sat back in my chair. I knew what was coming already.

"She claims that thirty minutes after filling out our application, she received a call on her new home phone number that she hadn't given to anyone but us. The call was from a competitor - well, not really - a broker. They told her that they were aware that she was shopping for health insurance on the web."

Part III

"Rick, give me a minute to digest this - and my burger." I said as I sat quietly, staring at the ceiling.

The scenario was sounding all to familiar, but I didn't want to jump to conclusions.

Chelsea had a potential customer that filled out an application for health insurance on their website. The customer used a contact number that was an hours-old home phone number. The customer hadn't given out this number to anyone but Chelsea. Minutes after submitting the application, the customer receives a call from a health broker wanting to sell her insurance. A quick analysis of the situation let me to think one thing: information interception. But how? Need input!"Where are you at right now, Rick? If you followed the incident response plan that I wrote for you, you should have performed some sort of security analysis on the machines in question, a physical analysis of your network devices and connections, a logical analysis of who had access to the information submitted, etc." I said, putting Rick on the hot seat.

"Absolutely Chief. My team went into action immediately. As a matter of fact, we should head over to the office now so you can talk with the team and guide us through this." Rick suggested. The retainer fee he slipped across the table was quite the motivator. I guess he knew I'd want to jump on this.

I followed Rick back to the office, mesmerized by the cleanliness of my vehicle. What DID they use to clean this interior? It smelled like a mixture of wax and cologne.

Rick escorted me to the security desk where I promptly received a contractor badge with my picture affixed to the bottom of it. I bet they don't take too many pictures of chimp-like creatures on a day-to-day basis around here.

Clue banana in hand, I walked into the spacious conference room and placed my laptop bag in the chair next to me. A few moments later Rick's security and privacy staff milled into the room and took their seats. The staff had grown quite a bit thanks in part to recent HIPAA Privacy and Security regulations. Ah, the government at work. How quaint.

The lights in the room began to dim, and a staff member began an impressive-looking presentation on the incident at hand. Several slides later, I was exposed to some new information - a timeline! I grabbed my trusty Powerbook, popped open textedit (notepad for all y'all windows folks) and started taking more case notes. A summary of the notes looked like this:


09/02 - Customer places call to Privacy Office, files a formal complaint.
09/02 - Privacy Officer reviews complaint, forwards complaint to CSO.
09/02 - CSO reviews complaint.
09/02 - CSO activates incident response team.
09/02 - IRT begins investigation.
09/03 - IRT performs security analysis on all servers involved
09/04 - IRT reports nothing out of the ordinary.
09/04 - IRT performs network device analysis
09/05 - IRT reports nothing out of the ordinary.
09/06 - IRT performs intensive log analysis.
09/06 - IRT begins interviews of staff with access to data.
09/07 - IRT reports nothing conclusive.


A dead end? Why am I always called in when there's a dead end?

Part IV

"We've got a big, fat goose egg." said Paul Verselle, manager of information security at Chelsea. "My team has left no rock unturned, no log unread, no configuration unchecked. That data didn't leave our network."

I smirked... "Paul, you sound pretty confident. And you may be right. The information may have not left the Chelsea network in electronic format. It could have left via a voice call, fax or even a photocopy. Do you have a list of the employees that have direct access to that data? And I need a list of all employees that work in your network group - anyone that has direct access to the telecom hardware around here."

"We're way ahead of you there, Chief." Paul said as he flipped ahead in his presentation. "Here's a list of all employees that have direct access to the data - there are ten of them. The network team consists of 11 engineers, however only 5 have direct access to the datacenter - which is the only practical location for a tap."

"Speaking of taps..." I began, "have you walked every port on your network? No hidden WAPs or hubs laying about under the floor or in the ceiling? Or perhaps rigged as a tap and sent to another port on the LAN?"

Paul made eye contact with his lead analyst.

"Um, yes - yes - and uh no." came a reply from the other end of the table.

"You haven't checked for a rerouted tap?" I asked.

"We didn't even think of that. We'll send a few people back down to inventory the cables again." announced the mysterious voice. The room was so dark I couldn't make out the analyst's face.

"My goal here (and sticking with our plan) is to isolate this incident - if we can eliminate the facility as the source of the leak (if there is a leak) we can move on to more productive activities." I said, standing up from my chair.

I paced around the table to the front where the presentation screen hung from the ceiling.

"What about the potential customer? Are they cooperating? Has she been interviewed? Have there been calls from other places than insurance payers?" I asked in a pretty obvious tone of voice.

Silence.

"You mean to tell me that nobody here is working the 'victim' end of this?" I said as I stared at Paul, then glanced at Rick.

Rick cleared his throat.

"To be honest Chief, we haven't contacted her post-incident because of our legal department. They are still trying to determine how to handle this." Rick said, tapping his fingers on the table in front of him.

"We're losing valuable time here. We need a decision from your legal department on whether or not we should pursue this outside of the company. Has the potential customer said or done anything past filing a complaint?" I asked, motioning to Rick to answer.

"Negative. Not a peep. I'll call a meeting with General Counsel after this meeting and get an answer asap." Rick said, making some notes in his portfolio notepad.

Part V

I've found that for every year that I've aged, I've lost a certain percentage of my patience. Some things in life are worth waiting for (like a tall, hot, steaming cup of freshly brewed coffee from Starbucks) and the needle on the patience meter never moves. Other times, I struggle to not beat people over the head with a clue banana or two.Case in point: Paul's management of this incident. Paul is good "suit" security manager, but lacks a technological understanding of information security. It was very evident in the remainder of the presentation. Note-taking was very poor, there was very little documentation of 'who' worked on 'what', and the timeline was useless as a result.

I left the incident briefing with an extreme lack of confidence in the security management at Chelsea. According to some intelligence from a VP at Chelsea (gathered in the restroom of all places), Rick had been asleep at the wheel for the past year vying for the CIO position. Great - a distracted CSO.

Rick had arranged for me to work in an unused office in the IT department. I had a LAN connection, a phone, and I was about twenty paces from the break room. Excellent.

*ring* The cellphone demanded my attention.

"Chief - Rick here. Can you meet me up on the fourth floor in about ten minutes? I'd like for you to be present when I talk to the GC."

Were Rick's ears burning?

"No problem - on my way." I said as I picked my laptop bag off of the desk and headed to the elevator.

A few moments later I was stepping out onto the lobby of the fourth floor, and not a second too soon. The elevator music was a brain-chilling rendition of the "Friends" theme song as performed by a grade school orchestra (or so it sounded).

I made my way to the office of the General Counsel (that's "head lawyer" in suit-speak) and identified myself to the receptionist.

"Chief, in here." Rick said as he motioned me into a mahogany-covered office.

I had met the GC on my last visit, and he seemed almost surprised to see me.

"Chief! Hello! Have a seat." said Jean-Claude as he sat down in his over-sized office chair.

"Ok Rick, I have reviewed the memo that you sent over. This is quite the pickle sandwich, eh?" Jean-Claude said as he glanced my way.

("Pickle sandwich" is his favorite term to use to describe anything, and no - I haven't a clue as to why.)

"JC, we need a 'go' or a 'no-go' from you on this. Chief would like have the complainant interviewed for more information." Rick pleaded.

"Yes, of course. Ce que! I think our position will be to not interview the complainant. It is my recommendation that we make sure our house is clean and move on." JC said, folding his hands together as he looked at the wall behind us.

"I understand your position, however this could make our investigation much more difficult and we may not come to an adequate conclusion without an interview." I said firmly.

"Chief, I wish I could tell you that it was no problem - but quite honestly, we don't want seconds on this pickle sandwich." JC said, saying something to himself quietly in french.

(This won't be the last time he uses that term - much to my displeasure.)

Our meeting was interrupted by a call on Rick's cell phone.

"Pardon me." Rick said as he answered the ringing box on his belt.

"Yes? Excellent. Meet us in Tony's old office - yes that's where the Chief is working. Thank you." Rick said, closing his phone abruptly.

"Chief, Paul's senior analyst has a CD-ROM that you requested? What's up?" Rick asked.

Part VI

The ball was in motion, and I was using a few pages from "Chief's Classic Play Book".

I met Paul's senior analyst in my office. Thomas was sitting in a side chair with his laptop bag on the floor in front of him.

"Is it Christmas time?" I asked, cracking a smile.

"You tell me, Chief." he quipped as he opened his laptop bag and removed a gold CD-ROM encased in a chain-of-custody bag.
"Thorough... I'm liking this already." I said as I made my entries on the COD bag.

I opened the bag and examined the CD-ROM. It was marked with a single number in magic marker.

"Tracking number." I assumed as I slid the CD-ROM into my powerbook for examination.

The CD mounted flawlessly, and Thomas moved closer to lend some insight as to the CD's contents.

"I followed your directions to the 'T', Chief. This is the web access log archive for the day in question. I filtered using the two methods you asked for. The first shows all access broken out by developer, network monkey, security personnel, etc. Essentially it's every proxy ID we have. The second method was broken out by domain. I also completed a correlation analysis - it's the openoffice document marked 'CORANA'."

"Close the door." I said, motioning to Thomas with a wave of my hand.

I spent the next hour going through the logs with Thomas, stopping frequently to identify user ID's and get explanations of traffic patterns to certain domains.

"Chief, I'm not quite sure of where you're going with this... but if you have a hunch I wish you'd share!" Thomas said as he picked up the phone to ask the receptionist to bring us coffee. Heck, we were a stone's throw from the break room. I had a feeling Thomas was having fun with this investigation.

(Quick Aside)

You've probably already figured this out, but I recruited Thomas in relative secrecy to retrieve several critical pieces of investigative evidence. Only myself, Thomas, Rick, Paul and "Mr Pickle" knew about the request I made.

(/Quick Aside)

Another few minutes of log parsing passed, and a knock at the door could be heard. Thomas opened the door and retrieved two large, 24oz cups of coffee goodness from the receptionist. I was really starting to be impressed with the skills that Thomas had - with information security and coffee selections.

My browsing through the log files came to an abrupt stop. I read the next several lines over and over again. My hunch had paid off big time.

"Uh, Chief... do you feel okay? What did you find?" Thomas asked in a very concerned voice.

"Interesting domain for a database analyst to spend time on - considering that it is banned by the security policy that I wrote a year ago for this place." I said, pointing at the Powerbook's screen with my pen that I was so busily chewing on.

"What domain would that be, Chief?" Thomas asked.

Part VII

Hundreds of years ago, kings built fortresses around themselves to prevent invasions by intruders and, in some cases, the populous from leaving. Chelsea Healthcare had hired me years ago to build such an electronic fortress, designed to withstand Ghangis Khan himself.

As any construction worker will tell you, a structure is only as strong as the weakest part. In the case of Chelsea Healthcare, the weakest part was proven to once again be the human element.

Our story continues...
Thomas was staring at me like a deer caught in the headlights of a Toyota Tundra. He seemed to be paralyzed by curiosity and fear at the same time. I was almost entertained by his blank stare.

"Can I get to the administrative web page for the proxy server from this network?" I asked, waving my hands in front of Thomas.

"Uh, sure. Yeah. No problem. Here's the IP address." Thomas replied as he scribbled an IP address on a sticky pad.

I peered at the IP carefully and typed the address into my Mozilla Firefox browser. Bam! The administrative login page was brought up in mere seconds.

"Thomas, I need you to login to the proxy server so I can perform a quick search of the content filtering database." I asked, sliding the beautiful powerbook across the desk.

Thomas logged in to the proxy server, and slid the powerbook back toward me.

"You're in. Let's see some magic." Thomas joked as he maneuvered behind me for a closer look.

I clicked on the text box marked "domain entry" and typed in the URL I was looking for:


gotomypc.com


"Holy shnikies! Are you serious?" Thomas said under his breath.

After a few seconds, the content filtering database returned the query.


Domain not found. The domain may not be spelled correctly, or the domain may have been removed. Please try your search again.


"Just as I thought." I said as I minimized Firefox. "Anyone with a proxy ID can access that site. I specifically banned that domain a few years ago. I'd like to know why it's not in the database now."

Thomas thought for a moment and took a long drink of his coffee.

"I can tell you how, Chief." Thomas said.

"I removed it myself."

Part VIII

"I beg your pardon?" I asked Thomas as I sat back in my chair. "YOU removed that domain from the content filtering database? Why the hell would you do something like that?"

"It's not what it seems, Chief. About six or so months ago we had a vendor come in that was demoing a 'dashboard' application that the suits upstairs were raving about. The vendor set up their equipment in the boardroom, and unbeknownst to us, needed to access gotomypc.com to run the demo. When they tried to access the site using the temporary proxy ID that we gave them, they were denied access. This delayed the demo by almost twenty minutes, and the suits were furious - including Frenchie." Thomas explained."So I'm going to guess that the suits demanded you allow access to that domain, and nobody ever put the domain back into the content filtering system?" I surmised.

"Yeah. Yeah, that's it. What do we do now? What's the plan?" Thomas asked as threw his empty coffee cup in the trash.

"First, we go hit Starbucks. This coffee is ok, but it has to be decaf. Second, all of the evidence that I've seen so far is circumstantial at best. I think I'm going to talk to Rick and ask him what he'd like to do. Our options are very limited at this point." I replied.

We walked down the hallway on a long trek to Starbucks. My gut was right on the mark so far, even on low-octane coffee.

(Quick Aside)
This is a rough place to be. You have some pretty strong circumstantial evidence against an employee, but nothing concrete. What are your options? These really depend on the client and what their goal is. You should have established the goal in your first meetings with the client. In this case, the goal was to find out how the potential customer's information was compromised and given to an outsider.

Let's summarize where we are so far in this case:

1) We know that a potential customer's information reached a third party by two hypothetical means:
a) Spyware on the customer's computer. We can't explore this avenue due to political and legal reasons.
b) Inside job. Someone at Chelsea is sending out information to a third party.

2) We have established that an employee (a DBA) made a connection to another machine somewhere on the internet via the gotomypc.com service. Gotomypc works through proxy firewalls.
a) We don't know exactly where the other computer was
b) We don't know exactly what the DBA was doing

3) We have a theory - that the DBA has been passing information outside of Chelsea via this service. The recent event (with the potential customer) coincided with a login time in the web logs.
a) We haven't searched too far back in the web logs. How long has the DBA been doing this?
b) We don't have any other recorded complaints of information abuse/theft.

(/Quick Aside)

I called Rick on his cell phone while Thomas drove me to Starbucks.

I explained the situation to Rick in great detail. I was half-way through ordering a Venti cup of coffee when Rick dropped another bombshell.

"Are you sure that the DBA in question was Howard Ness?" Rick asked.

"Positive - the id was hness and the IP address in the web log was assigned to his workstation." I replied.

Rick was silent.

Part IX

"What do you mean he's DEAD?" I blared into the phone. I paused for a moment and realized how stupid my statement sounded.

"Chief, Howard Ness was 61 years old and suffering from an inoperable brain tumor. He died a few weeks before all of this went down." Rick responded.

"I'll call you back." I told Rick as I closed my cell phone.

I sat motionless at my table inside Starbucks, staring blankly at my cell phone.

Was I at a dead end in this case already? Time to regroup.

"Thomas, I'm going back to my home office for the rest of today. Drop me off at my truck." I said, still staring at my cell phone as if I was waiting for it to do a trick or two.

A little over an hour later, I arrived home and was eager to spend some quality meditation time thinking about the events that had transpired today.

I sat down at my desk and opened my folder of requested documents. I was drawn to the organizational chart of Chelsea.

"Howard Ness reported to the Database Development Manager." I mumbled to myself. "The department had three full-time employees. One was Howard, one was the manager, and one... one was Jack Samuelson."

After cross-referencing some HR employment records, it appeared that Howard and Jack had worked together for just under a year, and were situated in neighboring cubes.

Gut instinct took over.

I searched through the last 30 days of proxy logs for the "hness" id and found multiple hits on gotomypc.com.

"Ness is back from the dead!" I said sarcastically to myself.

I then searched for the id "jsamuels", and saw a typically browsing history for a DBA. Hits to microsoft.com, oracle.com, various trade magazines and a couple of sports sites.

Wait. Something wasn't right.

I scrolled back through another window that displayed the "hness" query. The userid was used on a machine with an IP address of 10.1.1.79.

I scrolled back through the window that displayed the "jsamuels" query. the userid was used on a machine with an IP address of 10.1.1.57.

However, for a brief moment in time (two http GET requests), both of the user ids' came from 10.1.1.57.

Mr. Samuelson slipped up.

Part X

"That's what I'm telling you, Rick. This is all circumstantial at best. You'd have a better time prosecuting a pickle for being green." I said to Rick, smirking that I had successfully used a pickle reference in front of Jean-Claude. I was sitting in Jean-Claude's office with Rick, presenting a brief analysis of my case findings and going over my recommendations. In one hand I held my 20-page findings document, in the other a piping hot white chocolate mocha with extra whipped cream. I was well caffeinated and trying to apply the clue banana to this very strange case.

"What about forensic analysis of the workstation?" Rick asked, glancing over at Jean-Claude.

"With your permission, I can do this tonight after everyone has gone home. But you need to face reality here - there may not be much to go on. If Samuelson went to this much effort to populate your customers' data into a system outside the company in near-real time, he's not going to make this easy." I said. "Unless he messes up - twice."

"Twice?" Jean-Claude said as if suddenly awakening from a pickle-induced slumber.

"He screwed up once by accidentally using Ness' ID on his machine. Thomas just scanned Ness' old machine with a port scanner, and it looks like this workstation is mysteriously running a VNC server. It's our theory that Samuelson is initiating a remote session on to Ness' old machine, firing up a browser and initiating the gotomypc.com sessions." I responded.

"Oui, but what about twice? He is going to screw up again?" Jean-Claude said, scrunching his nose a little higher.

"Yes - twice if he thinks he's going to cover up his tracks well enough that I won't find a few crumbs." I said as I sipped the last of my mocha.

"Chief, what's the plan? You have our support to do what you think needs to be done. Fill us in." Rick said as he received a reassuring nod from Jean-Claude.

"I'm going to grab forensic images of both machines tonight, and spend the next day or two in my home office analyzing the data. If Samuelson left me anything at all, I'm going to produce it in my report and hand this case over to you as we previously discussed." I answered as I tossed my Starbucks cup into the trash can.

"ARE you going to find something?" Rick asked.

Part XI

Like Scrappy on most of his blind dates, I was really beginning to regret showing up to this party. I received the proverbial "green light" from Chelsea management to grab the Ness and Samuelson workstations, and was sitting in my cozy bit of Chelsea real estate - on the floor.

"What the hell?" I asked myself, staring at the floor. My coffee buzz was wearing thin, and grumpiness was approaching. After a brief encounter with the delivery girl from the deli next door (15 minutes to deliver a sandwich and a large coffee - impressive!), I walked towards the elevator door.

I inhaled.

The door opened and I stepped inside. Within a few minutes I was stepping out of the elevator and staring at the two mystery workstations in their natural habitat. One was on Ness' desk, the other on Samuelson's desk. Both workstations had a single network connection in a crudely-made junction box that ran through the cube farm.

Out of curiosity, I stepped over to Ness' dek. The LCD screen that sat atop the workstation was turned off. I pressed the "on" button and wiggled the mouse a bit. Seconds later I was staring at... a Windows desktop?

"Eh!" I said out loud to myself in an apparent attempt to locate other nearby Canadians.

This workstation should have been locked through an Active Directory policy setting.

Austin Powers had nothing on me as I snapped about ten pictures of each workstation from every angle I could manage.

Back at Ness' machine, I stared at the system tray. VNC was waiting. Now I couldn't wait to image this machine.

I reached around to the back of both machines, grabbed the power plugs close to the base of the power supplies and yanked. The sound of power supply fans coming to a halt could be heard.

I placed both machines on a nearby mail cart and pushed them into the elevator.

Several hours later I found myself at the monkey crib, coffee brewing, a fresh pepperoni pizza (with extra cheese) smoldering on my dining table, and two workstations having their hard drives imaged by Rosco via Encase.

"Life, it is good." I joked as I bit into the first piece of pie. Heaven.

Time for a nap.

*ring ring ring* went my cell phone. "What time is it?" I thought as I glanced at the clock on the wall. Three hours had passed since my pizza-induced coma began.

"Chief" I said into the phone, rubbing sleep from my eyes.

"No, there is no Jose here. No I'm not lying! Senora, JOSE NO ESTA AQUI, COMPRENDE?" I yelled into the phone. I hate wrong numbers - especially when the same lady calls me every other day looking for her cheating husband.

I wandered into my lab to take a look at the imaged hard drives. I placed the original drives back into sealed bags and marked the date/time on the label. "Think procedure!" I reminded myself.

I attached the image of Samuelson's machine to my forensic workstation and built a case with Forensic Toolkit.

Several hours into the morning (and a pot and a half of premium columbian dark roast) revealed exactly what I thought I would find on Samuelson's workstation. Not a damned thing except for the VNC client executable. Interesting.

I powered down the workstation and peered at the image of Ness's workstation sitting on the workbench. It was calling my name!

I built an FTK case of Ness's drive and began my search. I didn't have to search long.

*beep boop beep beep boop boop beep beep* went my cellphone as I dialed with one hand and held my ego with the other.

"Rick? Chief. We hit the jackpot." I said. "Schedule a meeting with Frency & crew for tomorrow."

"Right. What did you find?" Rick asked impatiently.

Part XII

"I am quite confused." announced Frenchy as I was halfway through my presentation. A quick glance around the conference room revealed that no one was surprised.

"Let me go over this one more time." I said as I restarted the Keynote presentation running on my Powerbook.

"This entire situation revolves around the deceased, Howard Ness. After an analysis of the contents of Ness' workstation, several facts are apparent:
1) Ness had been in financial trouble for quite a long time. Several Microsoft Word documents that were recovered by FTK (Appendix A in your hardcopy reports) show letters that were exchanged between Ness and several creditors. Ness had amassed a personal debt somewhere in the neighborhood of $150,000 for signature loans. A lot of these loans were being used to pay for medical treatments that weren't paid for by Chelsea.

2) Ness had been in contact with two individuals, relationship unknown, via Yahoo Mail. Appendix B shows these mails as web pages that were also recovered in my examination.

Relevant quotes are in bold:


"... I have access to that information but I'm not quite sure what your 'schedule of production' means in your last email..."

"... providing you with 10 people a day will be difficult at best..."

"... I am unable to connect to the machine that you indicated at 203.xxx.xxx.xxx. I am unsure what to do at this point..."

"... payment should be made in money orders only. I have provided you with the PO box address..."

"... bring a partner into the arrangement that can help meet the production requirements..."

"... Sam will be in contact with you regarding his production requirements and abilities..."


Please note that these excerpts are referenced to entire or near-complete emails provided in Appendix C."



Frenchy was rolling around in his seat like a fish thrown on a dock.

"Are you saying then, that Ness and Samuelson were involved in this type of activity?" French asked as he flipped through the Appendices of the report.

I attempted to make eye contact with him and gave an affirmative "Yes, that is exactly what I'm saying - and I believe this report will provide you with the information that you requested."

Frenchy placed his head into his hands.

He kinda looked like a pickle sandwich.

Next update: The Conclusion!

Part XIII

"Chief, can we skip to section 7 where you discuss the technical details? I'm still lost on this part." Rick asked.

"Certainly. Section 7 details a flow of information using a very convoluted, if not inefficient, means of placing Chelsea customer information onto a system that was apparently owned by the two unknown individuals." I began.

"The flow of information went something like this:

Ness was privy to any new insertions into the tbl_new_websignup table of the db_chelsea_mkt database. Appendix G shows some SQL select statements that were recovered from the drive. Now, these commands could have been executed in the normal capacity of his job duties, however it would appear that he kept the results of his queries in Microsoft Word documents on his workstation.

If you compare the recovered documents in the last half of Appendix G with the list of compromised customer data listed in Appendix H, you'll notice that all of the customers who have contacted you in 'H' are listed in 'G'. Could be a coincidence, then again it could be a smoking gun.

Ness connected to gotomypc.com from his workstation to a specific machine on a daily basis outside of the Chelsea network. This machine was identified only by it's IP address - which was recovered from his IE cache files in Appendix I. This is the same IP address indicated in the emails from Appendix B.

If you'll flip back to the recovered MS Word documents, you'll notice one called dtally.doc. Ness was keeping track of which sets of data he was submitting, and what that translated to in dollars. He was getting a mere $50 per submission. And from the same document you'll notice that his 'quota' was 10 a day. $500 a day, seven days a week is $3500 a week, or $14k a month in cash. Very profitable for Ness."


The room was dead silent. Nobody was breathing. Was EMS going to be necessary here?

Frenchy coughed a few times and asked "Eh, now where did Samuelson fit into this?".

"Let's go over that one more time for clarification." I said.


"Samuelson was working with Ness to meet the quota. I have been unable to determine why Samuelson was in 'cahoots' with Ness on this. There were some specific requirements for the people they were submitting, and to be quite honest I haven't been able to locate what those specific requirements were from the forensic analysis of their workstations.

After Ness passed away, Samuelson took the entire operation over. He apparently wanted to keep the 'heat' off of his workstation, so he installed a VNC server application on Ness' workstation, and connected to it from his own. Samuelson was keeping track of his activities the same way Ness was - and he stored the documents on Ness' machine after Ness passed away.

If you look at the file creation date/time stamps on the VNC files, there is two minute difference between when the VNC server was installed on Ness' machine and when the software was installed on Samuelson's machine. Thanks to some quick support from technical services here at Chelsea, we were able to determine that no other machine in the the organization has VNC installed.

I want to point out here that (as I said before) while there is substantial technical evidence to support my theory, you will have to interpret this data as you see fit. I will leave this to your legal beagles.

Rick will have to follow up with his staff on why standard operating procedures were not followed to lock Ness' account and secure his workstation after his death and termination from the company."


Stares of disbelief filled the room.

"So, a dead man has been responsible for sending our data out of the company? What a pickle sandwich this is!" Frenchy said as he closed his portfolio.

I've never wanted to slam my head into a boardroom table so bad.

The Chelsea legal team picked up the ball that I left them and ran with it. The last time I had burgers with Rick, he informed me that Samuelson was let go and they were still debating on a legal recourse. Insurance companies don't like a lot of publicity.

Chelsea stepped up to the plate and informed the affected customers (or in most cases, potential customers) of the information disclosure.

Now if I can just figure out how to program all the local Starbucks locations into my GPS nav system in my truck I'll be all set.

Where is that manual....






Case of the Stealthy Spike

Part I

"And then she walks over to me and says 'Let me guess Scrap, you forgot your wallet AGAIN!" Scrap belted into the other end of our cell phone conversation.

"Let me get this straight man, you're seeing this girl for two months now, you take her to a nice restaurant, you have a nice meal, and then when the bill comes you forgot your wallet?" I asked in disbelief."Yep, and then she reaches into her purse and pulls out my wallet and says 'Not to worry babe, I remembered it for you'. She then pays the bill with my cash and tips the waiter 30%!" Scrap whined in between drags off of a cigarette.

"Exactly how many times did you think the 'I forgot my wallet' thing would work for you? I mean, REALLY?" I said as I let out a loud laugh. "And the funny part is that she figured out your scam and turned it around on you. Brilliant! I need to hire this girl."

"Not funny Chief. Why should I have to pay every time?" Scrap asked.

"This is all very well and interesting man, but I'm driving down the freeway just waiting to hear about this job your guy at the school has for me?" I replied while trying to sound as annoyed as possible.

"Oh yeah, the job. Ok well you know Thom Fong, the IT dude at the school, right? He's the guy you met when I gave you a tour of their new datacenter on campus? Well he has a curious problem with his internal servers - the ones that are only accessible from within the campus network." Scrap said as he blew smoke into the mouthpiece of his phone.

"I'm listening."

"Ok, ok... so somehow a person is getting r00t on all of his boxes and DoS'ing the boxes. They are completely unusable after this person does whatever they are doing." Scrap said. "And I, of course, referred him to you."

"Sounds good. I can be there tomorrow morning after my morning appointment with my doctor. Set it up and be there if you can when I show up." I said, making an illegal U-turn upon spying a Starbucks on the opposite corner of the road.

"No probs man. Manana is my day off. And there's a curve ball to this one." Scrap announced.

"Isn't there always? What kind of curve ball?" I asked.

"He thinks it's an inside job of some sort." Scrap replied.

Here we go again.

Part II

"You're just going to have to cut back on the coffee, Chief. No buts about it." Dr. Berry said as he read my test results. "Your caffeine addiction is playing havoc with your blood pressure and heart rate."

"And I thought that was just my job." I joked. The doc wasn't laughing.
