"Ok, ok. Decaf for me. How... criminal." I said as unstuck myself from the paper on the examination table.

It was going to be a long day.I made my way down the freeway to the school, and fumbled with my cell phone to locate Scrappy.

"Yo Chief! What it is?" Scrap said as he answered his phone amongst a background serenade of noise.

"Where are you man?" I asked.

"I'm at the school. Some kind of pep rally or something going on out here. I'll meet you in the faculty offices. Thom is in building C1 - office twelve." Scrap said as he abruptly hung up on me.

"He must have spotted the next Mrs. Scrap." I joked as the Starbucks cravings began.

This was going to be harder than I thought.

My footsteps echoed through the halls of building C1 as I paced about looking for Thom's office. It wasn't that hard to find as it was right next to the datacenter. How convenient!

"Hey Chief! I'm Thom! Thanks for making the drive." Thom said as he ushered me into his office and located a chair for me to plop in.

"Yo! I brought the coffee man." Scrap said, apparently 5 paces behind me.

"None for me thanks." I said as passed on the java.

"EXCUSE ME?" Scrap said, his eyes as big as recordable CD discs.

"Doctor's orders man. Thom - tell me about what you have going on here." I asked as I changed the subject.

"Well, I prepared some network diagrams for you and a brief description of how the network is put together as reference materials." Thom said.

"Groovy - I love diagrams. So what's happening to your nameservers?" I asked, staring at Scrap's cup of coffee.

"It is very strange indeed. At completely random times, our nameservers take on very heavy loads - so heavy that they stop responding to any traffic at all. We have to take them offline. We look around on them and it would appear that someone is getting in doing something nasty. We just can't tell the how or what. " Thom said as he sat on his desk, narrowly missing a coffee mug full of pens.

"I'd like to examine one of these machines. Have you kept any machines intact after removing them from the network? Scrap tells me you are reformatting, reinstalling, reconfiguring and putting them back into service?" I queried.

"Hmmm. I think we have one machine that has not been put back into service. The attacks have slowed to around once every few weeks. My students don't have the time or the expertise to investigate this kind of nonsense. Hence, the reason I asked you to look at this. I realize that this is probably a bit different and boring to some of the things that you have worked on - at least according to Scrap." Thom replied as he slammed the rest of his coffee. I winced.

"I'll have a look. Is the server still powered or did you shut it down?" I asked as we walked towards the datacenter.

"This machine is still powered on if my memory serves correctly. We just unplugged the network cable because we were in a hurry." Thom said as he pointed to the server in a rack. It was a 1U Dell server, and it was missing it's faceplate. A monitor and keyboard were plugged into the back of the server.

"Apparently you weren't in too big of a hurry - looks like someone made an emergency console connection into this puppy." I joked as I sat at the keyboard.

"That was me Chief. I knew you'd want to look at this baby." Scrap said with a big toothy grin.

I just shook my head. What else had Scrap done? Perhaps it was time to send Scrap out for some cans of 7up.

"I really want to image this thing before we go poking around. However, I would like to run a few tools on the box before we image it." I said.

"Scrap - get plugged in to that isolated switch there - let's plug this baby in and see what responds." I said as I pointed Scrap towards a standalone cisco switch.

Coffee or no coffee, this party was starting.

Part III

I was quivering. The erratic motions weren't from the low temperature in the school's datacenter, but from a lack of artificial stimulants: I was going through Starbucks withdrawals.

*tap tap tap* I quickly looked up the words "withdrawal symptoms" on my PDA.

The definition wasn't surprising:

withdrawal symptoms the unpleasant physical reaction that accompanies the process of ceasing to take an addictive drug.

Well, tell me something that I DON'T know there Webster.

Scrap was fumbling around with a Cisco 2924XL switch that was strategically placed on a table not too far from the target server. The switch was completely isolated - no network connections present. Scrap ran an ethernet connection from his laptop to the switch, and connected the ethernet cable from the server to the switch in a quick 30-second form of interpretive chimp dance. If only we had a crossover cable...

"Thom, can you verify the IP address and network settings for this machine? I'd like Scrap to configure his laptop with similar information so we can get some quality scans done." I asked Thom as I sat down for a moment. The room was starting to spin a bit. I felt... sleepy.

"Sure, I have all that stuff written down. You look like you could use a break. Why don't you go down to the lounge and get something to drink?" Thom suggested as he motioned for Scrap to grab the papers that he was being handed.

"Thanks, that's a great idea. Scrap - when you're locked and loaded, start a port scan. Don't run any of the usual nessus plugins. I just want to look for listeners." I said as I merged into the hallway.

Several minutes later I was seated in the faculty lounge admiring a fresh pot of what appeared to be Folger's Classic. That smell.... it was so.... hypnotizing.

After determining that an 8 ounce cup of life wouldn't hurt me, I quickly poured a mug full and applied liberal amounts of sugar and cream. I had to be 100% to work, and I wasn't going to survive going cold turkey no matter what Dr. Berry thought.

I rested for a few minutes and let the magic java work it's way into my digestive track, and then my circulatory system, and then the nervous system. My cylinders were firing, and my eyes brightened.

The Chief was back.

*ring* *ring*

I reached for my cellphone. Scrap must be done.

"Status?" I asked.

"I'm stumped." Scrap replied, busily tapping on keys.

"And?" I asked more impatiently.

"I can ping all day long. But there's not a single port responding on this box." Scrap replied.

"Hmmm. Not unlike the symptoms described by Thom. " I thought.

"Wait." Scrap cut in to my internal monologue. "What the..."

Perhaps this was going to be interesting after all...





Part IV

"What! What?" I yelled as I walked back into the datacenter. Thom was anxiously peering over Scrap's shoulder.

"I swear man, I just saw something weird. I increased the frequency of my port scan and reduced the number of ports to common services... and every few seconds I get a blip of... THERE! THERE!" Scrap said as he froze his console window.
I squinted at the screen and moved in closer for a better look. I had to keep in mind that sometimes Scrap sees aliens in his bedroom and periodically accuses his socks of plotting against him.

"Ok, I see the results you're talking about. And these only come up every once in a while?" I asked as I scratched my forehead.


Discovered open port 22/tcp on x.x.x.13
Discovered open port 25/tcp on x.x.x.13
Discovered open port 21/tcp on x.x.x.13
Discovered open port 53/tcp on x.x.x.13


This was a new one. Services that reveal themselves randomly. Now I *had* seen everything.

"Whatcha make of this, Chief?" Scrap said as he attempted to connect to a few of the services.

"I'm thinking that..." I trailed off as I watched Scrap in horror.

"Scrap, what the hell are you doing?" I demanded as he was logging in to the server via the console keyboard.

"Watch!" Scrap said as he typed "top" and hit enter.

The server worked for a bit, then returned to the command prompt.

"Huh?" Scrap said as he started to type the command again.

I quickly secured the keyboard and proceeded to scold Scrap like a 6-year old stealing ice cream.

"Dude, we do NOT work on live filesystems - and we do NOT run executables on those filesystems! You may have just screwed us big time." I said as I proceeded to break my own rule and type "cd / && ls -la" on the keyboard.

I had a bad feeling about this.


dns13 #cd / && ls -la
total 0
dns13#


"Hey, where's the filesystem?" Scrap said, almost knocking me out of the way to share my stare of disbelief at the prompt.

"Chief, what's going on?" Scrap asked.

"I'm wondering if we're ever going to know now - but I'll bet a venti house coffee with cream and sugar that your top command was trojaned to erase the filesystem.

My doctor picked a HELL of a week to ask me to kick coffee.

Part V

"Dammit Scrap." I said as I sat down in a chair parked close to the desk. "You can't do stuff like that when a live investigation is in progress. I'm glad you hooked me up with this gig, but you have to let me steer this spooky ship to port. Comprende?" I asked, gazing at the top of Scrap's head. He was staring a hole into the floor.
"Sorry man. Seriously. I had a gut feeling and just went with it." he lamented.

"What now?" Thom said, removing his hands from his pockets. "We don't have any other servers for you to look at that were exhibiting the same behavior."

I collected my thoughts and rubbed my eyes.

"Strategy shift." I blurted out.

"Eh?" Scrap whimpered.

"We need to think about this differently now. We could be dealing with several different grades of digital 'ammunition' here. We suspect the system was trojaned, so the probability that other dns servers are trojaned is pretty high in my betting book right now. We need to find a motive. We need to find some tracks. We need more coffee." I said as I stood up for a painful stretch.

"I can handle the coffee for you guys." Thom replied as he exited the datacenter door.

"Maybe I'll just sit here." Scrap said, still staring at the floor.

"Look, we all make mistakes. This was an expensive one. Learn from it. Let's move on." I said as I walked over to a buzzing rack of servers, all marked "DNSxx". Why a university needed so many DNS servers was a puzzling question - but even better - why were they all located in one physical plant? Unusual from my experience.

"I see 7... 8... 9... 10 servers marked DNS here. They are all in the same network. They are all powered on. This one looks particularly interesting..." I trailed off, pointing to the server on the bottom of the rack marked "DNS PRIMARY".

"Are we going to check it out, or take a picture?" Scrap said as he perked up.

"I want to take that box down." I said under my breath.

"Eh?" Scrap responded.

"I said I want to take that box down - go get Thom. I want to look around on the box, but not while it's running." I said as I made my way out of the datacenter. "I'm going to the car to get my gear. Be back in a second."

"Chief? What's the plan man?" Scrap yelled into the hallway.

"We're going to take a picture." I responded back.

My kind of picture.

Part VI

It was hot. Really hot. The walk out to the parking lot in 105F+ weather was brutal. A slight breeze blew by me as I paced through the parking lot with my equipment bag slung over my shoulder.

"So THIS is what a roast feels like in my convection oven." I thought to myself a I wiped a large band of sweat from my forehead. I was twenty feet from the door of building C1 when I felt the cool breeze of air conditioning hit my face as a student exited the building. Pure paradise."You're going to take pictures of the servers? What good is that going to do us?" Scrap asked as I placed my equipment bag on the floor of the datacenter.

"Not so much a picture as it is a snapshot." I said with a grin. "Let me put this into terms that you'll understand. It's like taking a CAT-scan of your head, then wandering around the images of your cranial cavity looking for brain matter. It's a tough job, but we have hope - so we're sure we'll find something."

"Oh I get it." Scrap said with a serious look on his face. "You're going to make a duplicate of the hard drive in the server, then look at the duplicate for evidence?" Scrap asked.

Apparently he didn't get my joke.

"Precisely. Did Thom go to get his sysadmin kid? What's his name?" I asked, unzipping the equipment bag and removing the contents.

"Uh, I think his name was Jack. Or Jim. No, Jared! Yeah his name was Jared." Scrap said with a scratch of his scalp.

"Alright, when Jared gets here I'm going to ask him to double-check that we can take this server offline without harming the school's network. Once we get the OK, we're going to pull the cord and make an image of the drive." I muttered. "However - I want to get a network traffic sample too. Do you think you can handle putting a network tap in and grab a few hundred megs of traffic here and there?" I asked Scrap as I handed him an ethernet tap.

"I am SO on that man. No worries dude!" Scrap said as he sauntered off to the patch panels located on the other side of the room. Surely Scrap couldn't screw up a simple ethernet tap from this network switch to the core switch - could he?

"Uh, Scrap, don't you want to know WHAT I want captured?" I yelled over to the other side of the room. Scrap tended to use the "shotgun" approach to everything he did, which was quite dangerous in an investigation.

Scrappy wandered back around to my side of the datacenter.

"Oh, you don't want me to capture everything?" Scrap asked as he reached for his cup of cold coffee.

"We start small and work our way up. I want to get some samples of traffic from each of these machines. Are they communicating on ports that we don't know about? Who are they talking to? What are they sending and/or receiving? This is going to be very important, so double-check your capture settings." I demanded as I passed Scrap his notebook.

"Got it." Scrap said while giving me a salute with his left hand.

Meanwhile, Thom had reappeared with his systems administrator Jared. I took a few minutes to introduce myself and to explain to Jared what we were trying to accomplish. Jared was a student in his early twenties, pale as an albino, and apparently still believed in the alluring look of the mullet.

"Uh, I don't think we want to take any of those machines down." Jared said, looking off into the distance. He then proceeded to wander around the rack of servers, carefully examining my equipment and peering at the back of Scrap's head.

Interesting.

"Jared, I really need to image one of these machines as part of my investigative process. Perhaps we could take one of the others down?" I asked politely.

Jared thought for a few seconds and walked back towards Thom. With a quick shrug of his shoulders he addressed my concerns with a long list of technical reasons why each of the DNS servers was required.

I wasn't buying it.

Part VII

"Uh-oh." Scrap mumbled as I walked towards him. "You have that look on your face."

"It's worse than you think. I have that attitude thing going as well." I said as I motioned for Scrap to join me out in the hallway for some privacy.

"Oh man. Is this guy the suspect? You got it figured out already man?" Scrap asked as he nervously searched his pockets for a cigarette that he'd have to go outside in the 105F weather to enjoy."This guy Jared is either trying to royally BS me, or he really has no idea what is going on around here. He just told me that he has one domain being served by each of the servers for DNS load distribution." I spouted off as I nudged the wall with my shoe.

"He what? We both know that is a bunch of sh..." Scrap blurted out as I interrupted him.

"Wait. Wait, wait, wait. Scrap, why would you think you needed to dedicate an entire server to publishing a single domain name?" I quizzed Scrappy.

"Uh, cuz you're a moron?" Scrap responded, sliding that cigarette behind his ear.

"Besides that. If your server is so damn busy doing other things, name resolution is going to be very slow, right? Even for one domain!" I said as I smacked my forehead.

"So Jared really has no idea what is going on, probably logs in every once in a while to edit a zone file, and someone else 0wnz his boxes." Scrappy suggested.

"You're not far off from my own theory. Go grab your laptop and let's look over some traffic captures. I'll go keep Jared occupied." I said as I turned around to enter the datacenter.

"Chief, I have to apologize. I got to thinking about your request, and I completely overlooked the fact that we take... well not on purpose... one of these guys offline all the time when they stop responding. I go to login and the filesystems are destroyed. Weirdest thing ever. Anyways, I can image and prep that machine that you guys have on the table over there, slide it into the rack and we can down that server afterall." Jared said, his eyes looking rather sincere.

"I'll help Jared." Thom volunteered. "We're experts at this by now."

"Deal. I'll leave that up to you, I need to work with my... assistant." I said, trailing off as I walked back towards Scrap's location on the other side of the datacenter.

"Yo man, we got a real head-scratcher here." Scrap announced as I sat down on the datacenter floor next to him.

"Eh? What's your portscan show on that production box?" I inquired.

"No big surprises. I bet this looks familiar, man!" Scrap said. I leaned over his shoulder to read the laptop screen.


Discovered open port 22/tcp on x.x.x.1
Discovered open port 25/tcp on x.x.x.1
Discovered open port 21/tcp on x.x.x.1
Discovered open port 53/tcp on x.x.x.1


"That's consistent with what we saw on the x.x.x.13 box." I said.

"Yeah, but wait until you get a load of this!" Scrap said as he switched virtual desktops on his laptop and scrolled through some ethereal traffic dumps. "Now is that cool or what? Uhh, what is that exactly?" Scrap asked.

I took a deep breathe. I hate being right most of the time.

Part VIII

Scrap was staring at the side of my head so hard I could actually feel my ear growing hotter with each passing second.

"Well? WHAT! What kind of traffic is that, man? I've been a systems administrator monkey for a while now and I've never seen a capture that looked like that." Scrap practically screamed as he gave me a nudge."It would appear that these servers are used for much more than enhancing the education of the students." I cracked as I pointed to the Ethereal window on Scrap's laptop. "Grab packet number 1080. Look at the ASCII view. Look CAREFULLY. What do you see?"

Scrap focused his eyes on the packet capture.


y.y.y.170,x.x.x.1,IP,337,....i......i..E..C..@.@.jJ....D..w.g...............w......v=sQ....GET /uri-res/N2R?urn:sha1:4TSJQULHIUIGQZGWN2OZ4IYFNWBAR67G HTTP/1.1..HOST: z.z.z.119:6348..User-Agent: LimeWire/x.x.x..


"Holy copyright violation on a stick! It's a Limewire session! Peer to peer file sharing, man!" Scrap said with a large grin on his face.

"You got it. And from the looks of these captures and the sheer volume of traffic on this segment, I'd say there's quite a few files being passed from this server." I said as I watched the packet counter climb to a number nearing last month's Starbucks tab.

"Chief, this would explain a lot. I mean, P2P traffic can suck the life out of any network. That dude Jared is either in on it, or completely clueless!" Scrap exclaimed as he peered towards the ceiling. "So what do we do now?"

"We act like a ziplock bag and say zilch to Jared. We need to have a pow-wow with Thom and see where he wants to go with this. Remember, Thom is the client - he's the boss." I said as I saved the packet captures to Scrap's hard drive.

"But we have some serious info here, man. Let's go ask him what's up!" Scrap insisted as he motioned me towards Jared (who thank goodness had his back to us and was twenty feet away).

"Scrap. Take a breath. You're sweating like Al Bundy in a strip club. We're not going to get anywhere with some packet captures. This is raw evidence. We haven't processed it yet. We sit down with the client and get some direction. If you're going to do well in this type of profession, you need to learn patience and restraint." I said as I placed Scrap's laptop under my arm. "Now, let's go!"

Scrap and I wandered towards the door of the datacenter. I waved at Thom to join us as we wandered into Thom's office. Scrap closed the door behind us.

"You're not going to turn on a heat lamp, are you?" Thom joked as he took a set behind his desk. "I'm wearing a good shirt. My wife ironed this baby this morning!"

"Thom, we have an unproven theory on why your servers are spiking and dying. Scrap has collected some interesting packet captures that lead us to believe that those DNS servers in there are actually P2P servers, and they are REAL busy." I explained.

Thom thought for a few seconds and shifted in his chair.

"Somebody has rigged P2P software on these servers? And they are serving what?" Thom asked.

I opened Scrap's laptop and brought up some sample packet captures from our recent capture session.

"Judging from these strings in the packets, I would say music files, movie files, picture files, and some documents." I replied as my finger glided over the LCD screen.

"Dude! They are looking for Iron Maiden! Sweet!" Scrap said, obviously not able to contain his excitement any further.

Thom had a frown on his face that almost engulfed his entire chin. The man was not happy.

"Ok, this obviously can't continue. We are putting the school at serious risk here. We need to take those servers down right now, whether Jared likes it or not. But I want to know how this happened! This is unacceptable! I am going to have a lot of explaining to do to the Dean." Thom said as he leaned back in his chair.

I paused for a moment and made a suggestion to Thom. "Taking these servers offline may cause a service disruption to the campus network. We're going to have to..."

"Chief." Scrap said.

"Not now Scrap, wait a minute." I fired back.

"Chief, you REALLY want to see this." Scrap said as he passed his laptop to me.

Now what had he been working on while we were talking?

Scrap had performed a "whois" command on several of the campus domains.

He was pointing madly at the nameserver records.

"Check it out! There are two nameservers registered to answer for these domains. And you know what the best part is?" Scrap asked.

"Neither of them are in that rack." I mumbled.

Cripes.

Part IX

"Riddle me this, man!" Scrap said with a large grin on his face. "When is it that you have DNS servers that don't really serve DNS?"

"When your DNS servers aren't really DNS servers?" I replied, stating the obvious as we re-entered the datacenter. Jared was nowhere to be seen."Seriously man, this is wild. Now look at the IP addresses of the registered master servers, now look at the network map. The master servers are in that rack right over... there!" Scrap said with a point of his finger to the rack on our right.

I wandered over to the rack and scanned the adhesive name labels on the face of each server. Nothing that appeared to be a DNS server by host name jumped out at me.

"This is like looking for a needle in a haystack." I complained. "There's at least ten servers in this rack, the host names aren't useful, and there's no IP addresses on any of these labels."

I grasped my chin with my right hand and slowed down for a second. I walked around to the rear of the rack and examined the network connections. Above each connector was a factory-installed white sticker with a MAC address label in clear view. Jackpot.

"Scrap, nmap those IP addresses and read me the last few parts of the MAC addresses on both." I said as I maneuvered myself completely behind the rack.

"Roger that, Chief. Okay - the first IP address is assigned to dc:69. The second IP address is assigned to bf:32." Scrap announced proudly.

I scanned down the factory stickers and was not seeing a match until I came upon the last two servers. The last 2 fields matched exactly on both machines.

We had found the mysterious servers.

With Thom's permission, a quick and dirty analysis of the two boxes ensued.

The analysis told me exactly what I expected to hear - these were two real DNS servers!

"Chief, what the hell is going on? This is like a Matrix movie gone terribly wrong." Thom whined as he massaged his tired eyes with his forefingers.

"This is actually excellent news. We can safely remove the questionable servers from the network for examination and not cause a service disruption to the campus network. With your permission, I want to disconnect all the servers immediately and perform a more detailed analysis." I stated as I waved to Scrap across the room.

"Yes! Yes! Let's do this. I want answers to this puzzle now." Thom replied.

Scrap had understood my monkey paw waving and started disconnecting power and ethernet cables from the backs of the suspect machines. Scrap had two cables to go when he suddenly stopped.

"Chief - dude, this machine is going insane!" Scrap yelled, now waving his monkey paws frantically about his head. "Look at the network activity light! It's like a strobe light from the seventies. Listen to that hard drive chatter!"

I crouched down next to scrap and placed my left ear against the front of the server where the hard drives were mounted. I was inches from the machine and could hear the drive chatter over all the other noise in the datacenter. This machine was very busy.

"Uh, oh!" Thom said as he crouched down next to me.

"Oh man, what the heck IS that?" Scrap asked as he scratched his head.

Part X

"Your call, Chief!" Scrap said, his monkey paw firmly grasping the network cable.

I peered over at Thom, raising one eyebrow.

"Thom, do you want answers or do you want us to just clean this up?" I asked.

"Well, we're in this deep already. Let's get some answers." Thom responded with a grin.

I motioned for Scrap to back off from the cables and reached for the "Scraptop". I handed Scrap his laptop and pointed a finger towards the network cable on the back of the spike-ridden server.

"Tap that. Full capture. Let's grab a few gigabytes of traffic and play detective." I said with a slight grin. This was going to be entertaining on many levels.

"Tapping!" Scrap said as he quickly put the tap in place, careful to only disconnect the network cable from the back of the server for a few seconds. After a few quick keystrokes on his laptop, the network traffic scrolled across his screen with blazing speed.

"Where's Jared?" Thom asked as he looked around the datacenter.

"He wasn't in here when we came in. Was he supposed to still be here?" I asked Thom, unaware if Jared was supposed to be in a class.

"I told him to keep his butt in here to answer questions. He has a very small attention span." Thom responded.

"Alright, with the tap in place let's get busy on imaging one of these servers. Scrap, would you mind assisting me with a 'serverectomy'?" I asked.

"Your tonsils hurting, man?" Scrap asked.

I sighed. "Dude, just grab a screwdriver and let's get the first server out of the rack. Don't forget to pull the power cord first."

"Alright, alright. Hey, you brought up your tonsils." Scrap said as he started unscrewing the mounting screws holding the first server to the rack.

I was starting to wonder if Scrap dyed his hair.

A few minutes had gone by and the server was sitting safely on the table in the datacenter next to the server that Scrap had doomed to erasure by his over-eagerness to run shell commands.

"Hey Chief, hand me that bigger screwdriver." Scrap barked as he pointed his paw at a red-handled screwdriver sticking out of my tool bag.

Scrap removed the screws that kept the lid of the server attached and proceeded to slowly pull the lid towards the rear of the server.

"Scrap! WAIT! WAIT DAMMIT!" I screamed as I grabbed the lid of the server.

A sliver of silver wire caught my eye that was somehow attached to the lid of the server. The other end couldn't be seen. I reached into my tool bag to find my trusty penlight for a closer look.

"Dude, it's just a wire..." Scrap joked as he clasped his hands around the sides of the lid.

"SCRAP! WAIT!" I screamed again.

White smoke drifted from the top of the server case.

"What the hell is that?" Thom asked, apparently startled like the rest of us.

"Scrap, I SWEAR TO GOD. If I tell you to do something, or NOT do something - you listen the first time. You do not EVER, EVER remove the case lid to a suspect machine without inspecting it first. I don't know what that is, but if it had been explosives, we could be DEAD. Am I getting through to you?" I said with a stern look on my face.

I was furious.

"Yeah, yes. Yes. I'm sorry man." Scrap replied as he took a seat next to Thom by the table. Both appeared rather stunned as they coughed from the smoke filling the room.

I grabbed my penlight and worked my way around the surface and lip of the lid, waving smoke out of my eyes with my other hand. The smell was very familiar from my days of trying to be a twelve year-old stunt bicycle rider.

It was a smoke mix - and a battery-powered trigger. You'd typically find this type of setup used on remote-controlled toy planes, helicopters, cars, you name it.

I scratched my head furiously.

Why would someone rig a smoke bomb in a server? Physical booby-traps like this are very, very rare in evidence equipment. This was only the second case I had ever seen.

"I'll be right back. I'm going to go drag Jared out of the computer science lab down the hall. This is complete crap." Thom said as he raced out the server room door.

"Chief, do you ever get the feeling that someone just doesn't want anyone messing with these boxes?" Scrap asked as he reached into his shirt pocket for a cigarette.

Do I.

Part XI

"It is a mistake to confound strangeness with mystery. The most commonplace crime is often the most mysterious, because it presents no new or special features from which deductions may be drawn." -- Sherlock Holmes

I needed a breather to clear all the white smoke that was lingering in the air out of my lungs. Scrap needed a cigarette. It was time to take a walk around campus.

Scrap took a few steps towards the door, his eyes looking straight at the ground. Learning lessons the hard way is a real ego killer sometimes.

"Scrap, what's wrong with this picture right now?" I asked as I placed my hand on the exit door, blocking Scrap's exit.

"Huh? Chief, what ISN'T wrong with this picture? Hey man, I don't know where you've been but somebody just smoked us!" Scrap cried as he placed his hands in his pockets.

"No, I mean... look up at the ceiling. This room is equipped with Halon fire suppression. Why didn't it fire off? Look at all the smoke that is still in this room!" I said as I trotted over to the wall where the Halon control panel resided.

I glanced at the control panel and squinted.

"Scrap, this system is keyed OFF. Look! The fire suppression system is turned off!" I said in disbelief. "Why the hell would it be off? Have you ever walked into a production datacenter and seen the fire suppression system off? I mean, when there's not a test or some kind of maintenance going on?"

"Never, man. Never. Might want to bring that up to Thom." Scrap said on his way out the door.

I followed scrap down the hall and out into the heat of the afternoon. I sat down next to Scrap on a bench and watched several students walking towards the next building.

"Scrap, you want something to drink?" I asked as I checked my pockets for some cash.

"Sure. Grab me a Mountain Dew, man." Scrap replied.

I walked along a well-groomed stone path towards the cafeteria. Inside, I quickly located the self-serve drinks. I poured Scrap a Mountain Dew and helped myself to a bottle of Green Tea.

"It's not coffee, but it'll do." I thought to myself as I handed the cashier a few bills.

A few feet away, a group of students sat huddled around a break table with laptops strewn about. One of the students had a beautiful 17-inch Apple Powerbook. I wandered over in their direction for a closer look and took a seat at the table next to them.

"Yeah, and check this out. Star Wars Episode I! I've got a couple of Jackie Chan movies and some serious cartoonage coming down the pipe, babe." one student bragged to the girl sitting beside him.

I leaned over to get a better glimpse of the beautiful 17-inch widescreen display on the Apple Powerbook when a familiar logo caught my eye. A lime, ala Limewire.

"How the heck is he pulling down peer-to-peer files from in the cafeteria?" I wondered.

A quick glance at the menu bar near the top of the screen gave me my answer; an airport icon. The school had a wireless network connection present.

I grabbed my drinks and headed back towards Scrap. My mind was racing. I had an idea.

"Hey, thanks Chief. This will hit the spot." Scrap said enthusiastically as he took a sip of his drink.

"Let's roll back into the datacenter." I said without a bit of hesitation.

Once back in the datacenter, Scrap and I were treated to a familiar pair of faces.

"Chief, I think you know Jared. Jared has an interesting story to share with us." Thom said, nudging Jared forward a few steps.

The room was quiet with the hum of servers and Scrap sucking a few more gulps of Mountain Dew from his cup.

Part XII

"Tell me a story about a man with a secret, and I'll listen long enough to determine if my name is mentioned or not." -- Anonymous

Jared was about as comfortable in his own skin as Scrap in a pair of thong underwear. His eyes shifted back and forth, he was sweating profusely and taking deep breaths.

"We're all pretty confused about this entire situation, Jared." I said as I sat on the table facing Jared.

"Tell them what you just told me." Thom demanded as he made eye contact with Jared.

Scrap slurped up the rest of his Mountain Dew, breaking yet another painful silence in the room.

"Let's start with the nameservers, since that is what brought me here. There is an entire rack of them right here, and there are two unmarked ones in that rack over there. Can you explain to me why the two 'real' nameservers are unmarked and in one rack, and the rest of these nameservers are marked and in another rack?" I asked Jared.

Jared took a deep breath and began speaking nervously.

"There are twelve nameservers total. Two of them are the primary resolvers for the two externally accessible domains of the school. The other ten are resolvers for internal domains only. Departments around the campus have their workstations pointing towards one or more of the ten servers depending on their needs."

I scribbled some notes in my notebook, trying to ensure that all the holes in this strange situation were addressed.

Thom took a step forward towards Jared. "I'd like to know what was causing the load on these machines to spike and render the machines useless? We have lost a lot of man hours rebuilding servers and dealing with staff that can't function without name resolution working."

"The CPU load increases are a side effect of file serving software that is installed on all twelve servers. As the number of requests for files increases, the CPU load increases." Jared replied.

"Might I ask WHY we have file sharing software on all twelve of our nameservers?" Thom asked.

"The machines had no load on them most of the time and the hard drives were barely used. Between the twelve machines we had over half of a terabyte of data storage available, an all of the machines sat on a 100MB ethernet network connection." Jared said, taking some time to think about quantitative amounts before speaking.

"I'm not sure that you answered his question." I interjected.

"Look man, I didn't do any of this. I took over for Marcus last semester and all of this stuff was set up when I got here." Jared snapped back.

"And you didn't think to report any of this, man?" Scrap asked, clearly irritated that he was out of Mountain Dew and eyeing my half-full bottle of green tea.

"Of course I did." Jared replied. "But I had other incentives."

Part XIII

Thom was chewing his cud, clearly agitated over the entire situation. I realized that with Jared spilling the beans and Thom's patience running short, I had to step in and steer the conversations.

"Let's talk about those incentives. Why the deadman switches on the boxes? The smoke bombs? The rigged logins?" I asked.

Jared slowly inhaled. "From what I understand, this is bigger than just Marcus and his friends stealing bandwidth and services on the school's dime. Marcus gave me direct access to the servers to leech anything that I wanted off via secure ftp. The boxes were peering points and used to distribute a lot of 'zero-day' items."

"Zero-day items? You mean like theatrical movies? Software releases? Music files?" I pondered out loud.

"Yeah. Marcus was making quite a name for himself in some circles. Before he turned everything over to me, he seemed a bit nervous when we talked. You know how those association groups are shutting down and prosecuting distro sites and their owners? Well I think Marcus thought he was going to get caught eventually." Jared replied.

"I see. And?" I asked, leading Jared into answering the rest of my questions.

"Right, well I didn't know the smoke charges were there until the first time I had to take a server out of service and re-image it. Ironically enough, all of the images for these servers Marcus made himself, so all of the peering stuff just magically appeared again. Anyway, the first time I popped the cover off of a server I got a face full of smoke and I was freaking out because the detectors up on the ceiling were beeping. I haven't had the fire system on since." Jared admitted.

"You turned off the da..." Thom said, flying off the table.

"Thom, wait. This isn't helping the situation. Let's get all of the facts." I pleaded to Thom as he sat back down on the table with a scowl on his face.

"I got a question." Scrap said, once again breaking the silence. "So, you kind of knew the whole time that re-imaging these machines was just wasted cycles? And then you'd hand off everything to the next guy that took over for you?"

"Well, I hadn't really thought about it that far down the road." Jared said, his eyes aimed squarely at his shoes.

"Ok, I've heard enough. Jared, let's go have a conversation with the Dean." Thom said, motioning Jared to exit through the door.

After the door was closed, I closed my eyes and exhaled. I felt like a train accident.

"Dude, this whole situation is freaking me out." Scrap said, drinking the last of my green tea. "I mean, how much sense does any of this make?"

"I can relate." I said as I rubbed my eyes. "But the sad truth is that this type of piracy isn't exactly new or strange to school campuses. I'm really surprised that things were so lax here. Thom is a pretty sharp guy."

"It's like you always told me, Chief." Scrap said. "People trust the people that work for them, and sometimes they trust them just a little too much."

I brought my bottle of green tea to my lips and attempted to take a drink from a very empty bottle.

"You drank the last of my tea?" I asked in disbelief.

"Hey man, sounds like you're trusting your people too much!" Scrap rattled back.

Sometimes the teacher learns from the student. And sometimes, you have a student like Scrap.

=*=
Epilogue:

Thom went on a blitzkrieg at the school. Law enforcement and several trade associations were notified about the activities of Marcus, Jared and numerous other students.

Scrap scored a major consulting gig with Thom rebuilding the school's DNS architecture since all twelve servers (and numerous other items) were confiscated as evidence.

Lawsuits were brought against several of the students, and they were all kicked out of the university and enrolled into the school of hard knocks.

[NOTE: I apologize for the delay in publishing the conclusion of this case file, however I had to edit it several times for content.]

Case of the Mischievous Minotaur

Part I

"So this is what a vacation feels like?" I said to myself as I stretched out in a pool lounger chair, enjoying the abundant sun light and the scenery around the resort's gigantic pool.

Two years had gone by in a hurry and I was in dire need of rest and relaxation.

"Usted desea otra bebida, Seor Chief?" asked my new friend Pepito as he approached my chair, carefully removing my empty glass from my hand.

"Sounds good Pepito. How about another iced coffee?" I asked politely. Pepito smiled and shook his finger at me.

"Seor, that is your third today!" Pepito announced to all that surrounded the pool. Great, now everyone knows I'm a coffee addict.

I slowly drifted off to sleep and listened to the ocean waves smack against the beach, narrowly missing a few ignorant tourists who refused to move out of the way.

*RING* *RING*

"You've GOT to be kidding me." I moaned as I reached for my cellphone in my gym bag. I didn't recognize the number calling, however my gut instinct told me to answer it anyway.

"Chief." I mumbled.

"Uh, hi! Chief? This is Ronald Krump. I was referred to you as someone that might be able to help me with a problem with my computers?" the caller asked, stunning me with his question.

"Ok. What kind of problem are we talking about? Excel macro not working? Hard drive failure? Screensaver not coming on fast enough?" I said sarcastically. I can't believe I answered this call.

"Well, no. I'm president and CEO of MMM Gaming, you might have heard of us. We're one of the largest online gaming service providers in the world?" Ronald said.

*COUGH* *COUGH*

I nearly choked on my drink.

"Sure, I know of you. What seems to be the problem?" I asked as the dollar signs rotated around my head. Hey, I had to pay for this vacation somehow.

"Our newest MMORPG, Huge Kingdom, is being broken into almost every day. We can't figure out who is doing it, what they are doing, or why they are doing it. We do know that they have deleted customers' characters and have attempted to take over others. We're game programmers and marketers, not security experts. We need some serious help. I hear you're more than capable." Ronald said enthusiastically.

"Well, I think the situation sounds very interesting. You're in San Diego, right?" I asked.

"Correct. I'll have my secretary email you travel information. Can we see you tomorrow morning?" Ronald asked as his cell phone started to cut out.

"No problem. I'll get a flight out tomorrow morning and see you around lunch time." I responded before the line went dead.

"Seor, will there be anything else today?" Pepito asked as he walked up behind me.

"Hey Pepito, what's the weather like in San Diego today?" I asked.

Looks like my vacation was about to end abruptly.


Part II

"I'm sorry Sir, but we're out of regular coffee. Would you care for some decaf?" the flight attendant asked as she reached for the evil pot of low-octane coffee.

"Nevermind. I think I'll switch to Coke." I said as I took the bright red can from her hands. How do you run out of coffee on an airplane? That's like running out of beer during a hockey game.

The flight into San Diego was uneventful, and before I knew it I was in a rental car headed towards MMM headquarters. The weather was beautiful and traffic wasn't too bad.

After a quick check-in with the receptionist and security at the MMM headquarters building, I was escorted to a small conference room that was quite possibly colder than parts of Antarctica.

I opened my equipment bag and removed my prized Apple Powerbook. A quick flip of the screen and it woke from sleep instantly. Several seconds later I was logged in and busily creating case file notes.

The conference door opened briefly to reveal the head of a very attractive female with a smile that consumed the entire lower portion of her face.

"Chief? HI! I'm Lola, Mr. Krump's personal assistant. Mr. Krump will be with you shortly, he's on an international call that should be wrapping up in a minute or two."

I couldn't help but smile back, my eyes partially blinded by the recent glow of teeth bleaching.

"No worries, I have some notes to work on. Can I bother you for some coffee, please?" I begged.

"SURE! No problem!" Lola said with the enthusiasm of a seventeen year-old cheerleader. The door closed and minutes later Lola appeared with a ceramic mug of hot coffee complete with the MMM logo.

"Can I keep this mug? Very cool!" I joked.

"SURE! No problem!" Lola said as she exited the conference room.

I was suddenly under the impression that MMM had developed personal assistant robots. Good grief.

After a few sips of coffee, my brain was awake and processing the information that MMM had sent me via electronic mail.

Item number one was a timeline of events that lead to MMM discovering that their systems were being breached. Item number two was a very nice diagram of the gaming network for Huge Kingdom, and it was quite impressive. Item number three was a one hundred page document describing how Huge Kingdom was designed and implemented. This particular document had "company confidential" stamped on every page in bright red ink.

"Well, at least they have information classification nailed down." I laughed to myself.

As I read the design document I jotted down a very brief (and incomplete) risk analysis of the system. I was barely halfway through the design document when I realized that I had been sitting in the conference room for nearly an hour.

What was keeping Mr. Krump?

The conference room door opened almost on cue, and in came Ronald Krump with two people that I hadn't seen before. You couldn't miss Krump because his picture had been plastered through several trade magazines thanks to the recent success of Huge Kingdom.

"Chief! Hi, I'm Ronald Krump. On my left is our chief architect Steven Hu, and on my right is the project manager for Huge Kingdom, Arlie Brown." Krump said as we all shook hands.

After the usual introductions and jokes about how poor the weather in San Diego was, we got down to business.

We spent the early part of our discussion on the history of Huge Kingdom and what MMM felt their biggest risks were in the online gaming world. Steven gave an excellent thirty minute overview of the technical architecture of the product, and Arlie filled in the gaps where necessary. I now knew more about what made an online game tick than I ever wanted to.

"Ronald, you mentioned that the product is being abused by an unknown party or parties, and to the best of your knowledge they are simply manipulating things within the game, correct?" I asked.

Ronald began to speak with his hands in an enthusiastic manner. "Yes, yes, that's it in a nutshell. I have asked Steven to lead a small group of MMM employees to help you with your investigation. If you need anything, just ask."

"Actually, I do need some help right now." I responded.

"SURE! What do you need?" Steven asked in an enthusiastic manner that seem to be contagious around the office.

Part III

"Dude, you're setting a trap? No fair having fun without me." Scrap said as I heard him take a drag off of his cigarette on the other end of the phone.

"Yep, it's going to get interesting around here. Look, I may need to bring you into this shortly. Clear your schedule." I demanded.

"Aw, man! I hate flying!" Scrap whined as he disconnected from our call. There's just no making that guy happy aside from a carton of cigarettes a week and a new Zippo lighter every Christmas.

I had taken over a small conference room as my work area and was in the process of completing my risk assessment of Huge Kingdom.

"Interesting." I said to myself as I examined the event timeline that MMM had provided me.

Huge Kingdom had one of the largest MMORPG launches in gaming history recently (in terms of advertising dollars spent) and ironically enough, the server disturbances had started to occur within 48 hours of the game launch. Perhaps someone was finding it too hard to play by the rules?

The game network was amazing. Large mainframe computers were the "brains" of Huge Kingdom handling all computation work, statistics tracking, etc. The HK clients were "dumb" and performed no game-critical calculations except for firing the game image onto the player's screen and taking keyboard and mouse commands. Communication between the clients and the servers were encrypted with a strange byte-code method that I hadn't seen before. The encryption technology was called "QuickCrypter" and was a home-grown encryption solution.

I glanced over the server logs regarding every recorded server event and circled some that caught my eye:


June 7th - player X took gold from a chest that was 3000 miles away from him

June 8th - player X had an out-of-bounds conversation with a character 5000
miles away from him

June 9th - player Y complains to technical support that his gold inventory went from 500,000 to 0 in a matter of seconds

June 9th - player Z complains that an expensive magical weapon disappeared from his inventory. Player Z was later killed by Player X who was wielding the very same weapon

Player X always connected from a different IP address.

A few moments later, my eyes widened with disbelief.

Player X had approximately 50 violations a day recorded on the server and played every day.

But why hadn't MMM employees gone through the logs and looked for this information? The programmers had the foresight to include boundary checking in the game. Perhaps this case wasn't going to be very challenging after all.

A knock at the conference room door startled me.

"Chief?" a voice said as the door opened. It was one of the MMM employees assigned to help me with the case, Ken Banobi.

"Hey Ken, what's up?" I asked as I glanced back down at the server logs.

"We're all ready to go, just waiting on you to join us in the room." Ken replied.

"Join you? For what?" I replied, still concentrating on the log files before me.

"Your trap is ready."

Part IV

Ken looked as frustrated as a guy sitting in a bar wearing a "Betty Ford Clinic" hat. I had changed my strategy in the last few minutes before his arrival.

"I don't understand Chief, we're changing our plans? Please explain." Ken asked as he sat down in the conference room.Ken Banobi was "Mr Network" at MMM. Steven Hu had selected him to be my liaison at MMM and to provide me with whatever assistance I may need. Ken was in his early thirties, almost bald, and clearly liked a good beer from his medically diagnosed "dunlop's disease". His belly had not only "done lopped" over his belt, but it looked like it was trying to escape.

"We're going to attack this a bit farther out than I had initially planned." I began. "We're going to get some traffic capture devices in here so we can replay these attacks over and over again until we figure out the method."

Ken was silent, his eyes fixated on the ceiling. "Well, that's fine by me. But I don't have that kind of gear here. We may need to go buy some stuff."

"I have that covered, and it'll be here tomorrow. For now, I want to spend some time with your Human Resources department and do some interviews." I said as I peered back down at my notes.

"No problem. I'll set something up with HR right now for you." Ken said as he exited the room and adjusted his pants. Man, I did not need to see that.

My gut was rumbling, clearly reminding me that I had skipped lunch. I placed all my notes in my travel bag and checked out with the receptionist.

"Oh, sure! You want a Thai place? No problem! Let me write down some directions for you!" said Barbie. Well, I didn't know her real name, but she sure looked and sounded like flight attendant Barbie.

A few moments later and I was patiently waiting for a plate of Pad Thai to arrive at my table. I placed my trusty Apple Powerbook on the table next to my glass of Thai Tea and started transcribing my pages of written notes.

I flipped through a few more pages of server logs that I hadn't completed as a result of my dialogue with Ken when I noticed something intriguing.

Approximately ten days after launch, several players were noted to have advanced weapons in the game. These weapons would take a player several months of constant game playing to accumulate. As I flipped through the logs, the number of players and the variety of weapons increased dramatically. It was almost as if a black market of weapons had sprung up inside Huge Kingdom.

But how?

Steven Hu had made it quite clear to me in our earlier discussion that the path to advancement in Huge Kingdom was very linear, and it was almost impossible to cheat. One of the safeguards that the programmers had designed into the game was the death of players and their possessions. The intent of these safeguards was to prevent bands of "gangs" from finding players with advanced levels and possessions and to keep them from being assassinated.

"Here you go, Sir!" the waitress said as she placed the steaming plate of Pad Thai on my table, narrowly missing my Powerbook with a piece of shrimp that had tumbled off of the plate. I was starving, and proceeded to eat like I had fallen off of the TrimSpa truck on it's way to a bake sale.

I was ten bites into my meal when my cell phone rang. What timing.

"Chief." I mumbled into the phone as I took a long draw of the Thai tea through a straw.

"Dude, this airport sucks!" Scrap whined into the phone. "I just got here and they lost my damn laptop bag!"

I swallowed a rather large piece of shrimp and cleared my throat. "Did the gear make it here okay?"

"Yeah, yeah. I picked it up about five minutes ago. I checked my laptop bag because I brought the jumbo-sized one and they wouldn't let me bring it on the plane."

I chuckled to myself, remembering the gentleman who cleverly stuffed a gym bag the size of a small horse into the overhead compartment on my flight. "I'll pick you up in about an hour. Go get something to eat and we'll wander off to the hotel for some drinks and a briefing session."

"Right on!" Scrap responded. "There's a smoking section out here by the door! Hey, did you solve this thing yet? I need to be in town next week for another gig."

Part V

"So then I turn to the guy and I'm like 'yo, man - you're spitting on me' and he just sits there looking at me like I'm a moron or something!" Scrap wailed as he climbed into my rental car.

"Do you mean to tell me that every time this guy talked to anybody, he was getting little saliva droplets on you?" I asked in complete astonishment.

"Serious man! And I kept telling him! And we didn't even get it worked out until the plane was ready to land." Scrap said, adjusting his seat belt for the long drive.

"Turns out the dude didn't speak english!"

I instinctively rolled my eyes. I walked right into that one!

"What's the plan, Chief? Anything besides sitting on an airplane sounds good to me right now." Scrap asked enthusiastically.

"We're on our way to MMM HQ. I'm going to meet with the director of the human resources department. You're going to meet with the network monkey to install some listener boxes and get us some network traffic to look through." I responded.

"Right on." Scrap said as rolled his window down a few inches and lit a cigarette.

"Scrap, not in the car." I said, fanning the smoke away from my eyes. A car was too confined of an area to be smoking in.

"Dude! It's a rental! Who cares?" Scrap said with a grin as he rolled the window down another few inches, carefully blowing the smoke out on to the freeway.

An hour and half a pack of Newports later, we arrived at MMM HQ. Traffic was unbelievable, but (according to the locals) completely normal for this time of year.

I proceeded to the human resources department, flipping my visitor's badge to Receptionist Barbie.

"Oh, like hi! Were there any problems finding the restaurant I told you about?" Barbie asked with a flip of her hair.

"No problem! No problem!" I said, playfully waving my head from side to side.

She didn't get the joke.

I walked down the hall until I saw the door to human resources. Oh good, another Receptionist Barbie.

"Good afternoon! Can I help you?" she asked with a slow blink of her eyes.

"Yeah, I'm Chief - here to see Erik." I said as I presented her with a business card.

"One moment - have a seat, ok?" she said as she walked down another hall and knocked on Erik's door.

"Mr. Slinkpips will see you now." Barbie said with a Vanna White-ish wave of her arm.

Erik & I took a few minutes to get to know each other, and then I walked down my list of prepared questions.

"In the last year, how many employees have left MMM?" I asked as I placed a check-mark next to the question on my notepad.

Erik reviewed several spreadsheets in a folder placed in front of him and responded, "Two software developers were fired several months ago for non-performance issues. We terminated several facilities staff members after finding them asleep in the office in the morning. And we wondered why our trash never got emptied! Oh, and we let a vice president of marketing go after our department ran a late background check on him and discovered that he had been fired from his previous employer for embezzlement."

My monkey paw was scribbling as fast as it could, dying to catch every word that came out of Erik's mouth. We had several good leads here.

"Erik, is employee access to the MMM network disabled as soon as the employee is let go?" I queried, turning the page in my notebook.

"Hmmm. That's a good question Chief. I usually call Ken Banobi on his cell phone and he terminates all access within a minute. I suppose we should be sending emails back and forth to document this process." Erik said, closing the folder in front of him.

"Probably a good idea." I said with a grin as I left Erik's office. I successfully
dodged Receptionist Barbie on a restroom break and snuck back into my make-shift office.

Moments later, the door to the conference room flew open and a wide-eyed Scrap smiled at me.

"Dude! You have to check this out!" Scrap said, motioning for me to join him.

"What? Where? I'm in the middle of something Scrap." I responded.

"Dude, Ken is IN the game right now and you'll never guess who he's following around?" Scrap asked, his eyes growing wider with every syllable.

"Ok, I give up. Who?" I reluctantly replied.

"A very mischievous minotaur." Scrap said with a grin.

My ears perked with interest.

Part VI

"So that's what they are wearing in Huge Kingdom nowadays." I joked as I watched Ken maneuver his character around a grassy, mountainous landscape.

Ken was shadowing a character resembling a minotaur, straight out of mythology.

The minotaur was, by definition, a half-human and half-creature character wearing not a single piece of wardrobe.

"We're in hot pursuit! Guh guh guh!" Scrap joked in his best Rosco P. Coltraine impersonation.

Sometimes I just want to smack Scrap."We got a hot tip from another player in the game about this minotaur character named 'trotsky'" Ken said as he panned around the area. The minotaur was in the middle of killing several small monster-type characters using some sort of magical flash.

"Lady luck is favoring us today it would seem." I thought to myself.

"Ken, where exactly did this tip come from, and what did they say?" I asked.

"A player that was killed by trotsky sent an email to our support address and reported him. Apparently trotsky approached him in the game and was trying to arrange some sort of a sale involving level 50 magical powers." Ken said as he zoomed in on the minotaur. "To make matters even more interesting, trotsky is one of many names this player has used. His first two names 'lightbringer' and 'godofdeath' should ring a bell with you."

I thought for a moment. "Holy half-price mochas... those are two of the character names that showed up on those exception reports." I exclaimed. "Is he aware that you're following him around?"

"I don't think so. The character I'm playing as is actually a 'debug' character that isn't viewable to other players. We use these players to troubleshoot problems all the time." Ken informed us. "I'm not sure why I didn't think of doing this before."

I watched the screen intently. No matter how many cases I work on, I always learn something new, aside from the many fine Starbucks locations around the country.

"Are you thinking what I'm thinking?" Scrap asked me, his eyes still lit up like the burning cherry of a half-smoked Newport.

"Well, we're not at a strip club, so I'm going to say yes. Sting operation." I replied with a grin. "This works well for drug deals, why not cyber-ware deals? Ken, can you 'un-cloak' your character at some point and approach trotsky?"

"Hell yeah." Ken said. "You want me to do it now?"

"Not right now. Let's treat this as surveillance for a while and take some notes on his behavior." I said as I flipped the page of my notepad.

An hour and a few slices of pizza later, we caught a break. Trotsky approached another player.

"No need for hidden microphones in this game." Ken joked as he hit a key on the keyboard. A transparent console scrolled down over the screen. Ken entered a few debug commands and balloons appeared over the players' heads.

"That is frick'in cool!" Scrap boomed as he moved in for a closer look. I tried to read the balloons and make some notes at the same time.


Trotsky: "Have you found the 'Sword of Summoning' yet?"

Player: "Hell no, I'm not even through my second quest yet."

Trotsky: "I have one for sale. Interested?"

Player: "I have only 200 gold pieces."

Trotsky: "How much cash do you have?"

Player: "???"

Trotsky: "It's for sale on eBay. My id is 'hugekingdomwares'."

Player: "You can do that?"

Trotsky: "Well, I can. I'll prove it right now."

Player: "ok"


Both characters stood motionless.

"Scrap, is the equipment in place?" I asked as I poked Scrap's arm.

"Huh? Uh, oh it's plugged in. Crap I didn't turn capturing on!" Scrap cried as he ran for the operations center.

Balloons appeared over the characters' heads once again.


Trotsky: "Check out your gold."

Player: "Woah! I have 2000 gold pieces."

Trotsky: "Maybe we can make a deal?"


Part VII

"No dice on the recording, man!" Scrap said as he sped around the corner, nearly knocking me down. "We missed whatever just went on, but we'll get anything new! It's dumping to the external firewire drive, so we have lots of bytes to burn."

I motioned for Scrap to approach me and whispered some instructions in his ear."Chief, not on the first date!" Scrap joked as he pulled a pack of smokes from his pocket. "I'll get right on that."

Scrap exited the room with a crisp crackle of his Zippo lighter flinging open. He really wanted a smoke badly.

"Ken, anything else from our balloon buddies on the screen?" I asked, peering over Ken's shoulder.

"Not yet. It would appear that the other player is thinking about Trotsky's offer, or maybe he's taking a bathroom break or something." Ken replied as he increased the view magnification of his character. The technology behind Huge Kingdom was astounding.

"You can take a leak in cyberspace?" I joked, staring intensely at Ken's screen.

"That's one feature I won't be submitting to management." Ken responded.

Within a few minutes, our virtual couple started to communicate again.



Player: "Couldn't I get in trouble for this?"

Trotsky: "No. Trust me on this. Think of me as a God in this game. What I say goes. This place revolves around me!"


Ken almost jumped out of seat.

"No way! No frick'in way! I can't believe he said that!" Ken said as he slammed his fist into the desk. "That egotistical bastard!"

I was starting to think that "project ownership" meant something spiritual to these folks at MMM. Not that it would be a bad thing.

"You say that like you know the fellow with the pointy horns." I said, carefully watching Ken's expression.

"That bastard! It's got to be Duke! Duke Skyscraper! That little prick." Ken exclaimed while making a really nasty "bitter beer face".

"Duke. That was one of the programmers that was terminated from MMM, correct?" I asked.

"Yes, and thank every Deity in heaven for that. Duke was a real piece of work. He worked on the core code of the game, or the 'engine' as we called it. The guy was brilliant, but his ego was so large he had to sit in the chair next to him at meetings." Ken replied.

Several programmers in cubes near Ken's desk could be heard snickering and agreeing with Ken's observations.

"Yo, yo, yo!" Scrap chanted as he once again tried to run into me upon entering the room. Scrap had his laptop in his hand and was busy flipping through PDF documents containing screen shots of web browser windows.

"Ken, call Steven and tell him I want to speak with him immediately. We're going to have an impromptu meeting of the minds." I said as I took the laptop from Scrap's hands.

"A meeting? What about?" Ken asked.

Part VIII

"Let me see if I understand this correctly." Steven said as he paced around the conference room. "You want to approach this 'Trotsky' guy and buy some Huge Kingdom wares from him?"

"Yes." I said. "We need to establish whether or not Trotsky really can do what he claims. After we've established this, we'll move onto the next phase of the investigation." Steven was quiet as he mulled over my words. "I'm going to need to talk to Ronald about this. I'll be back in a little while."

"Understood." I said as I watched Steven leave the conference room.

I grabbed Scrap and motioned for him to walk with me. We left the conference room and proceeded to the Huge Kingdom operations center.

"I want you to look at the capture that was taken during Trotsky's little deal with that player." I said. "Grab Ken and that programmer that was on our contact list."

"Chuck?" Scrap asked with a squint of his left eye.

"That's the one. Break the traffic down for them, don't miss anything. We need to grab any possible artifacts from that traffic." I emphasized as we entered the operations center.

"Got it. You want to go over some of the traffic with me?" Scrap asked as he nervously played with his Zippo again.

"I have something else that needs my attention." I said as I backed out of the operations center doorway. "Remember, find the needle in the haystack."

"Dude, that's a BIG haystack." Scrap said as he sat down in front of his monitoring laptop. "And me without my pitchfork."

I wandered back to the conference room and opened up Scrap's laptop. My eyes grazed over the PDF documents that Scrap had made out of his web browser windows. Scrap had done exactly what I asked him to do. He had found several Huge Kingdom items for sale on eBay, all were for sale by a single seller 'hugekingdomwares'. The seller had a very low feedback score of 23.

Surely this seller hadn't sold 23 Huge Kingdom items already!

A quick flip of the latch on my trusty Powerbook and I was browsing to eBay to do a little merchant research.

I located one of the items that Scrap had found, and then clicked the "View seller's other items".

The item list read like a character's inventory sheet.


S xxxxxxxxxxxx Level 30 Wand of Wonder

S xxxxxxxxxxxx Level 35 Staff of Serpents

S xxxxxxxxxxxx Level 50 Spell of Confusion

S xxxxxxxxxxxx Level 75 Medallion of Murder

B xxxxxxxxxxxx Phoenix Coyotes Jersey Signed Entire Team

S xxxxxxxxxxxx Level 20 Boots of Blunder

B xxxxxxxxxxxx Phoenix Coyotes Hockey Stick Signed Entire Team


Interesting. Trotsky seemed to have a penchant for Phoenix Coyotes signed memorabilia.

"Chief!" Steven said in a firm voice so loud that I jumped in my seat.

"Steven. What's up?" I asked as I scribbled more notes on my notepad.

"Ronald said it's a go." Steven said as he made a 'thumbs up' with his left hand.

Part IX

"Die Elvish scum!" Ken was yelling as he laid waste to a group of small creatures that were attacking his character with swords.

I glanced at Ken's character panel on the screen and admired "Centslayer". He was playing as a level 10 Centaur and apparently enjoying himself.

"I'm guessing that you're out of debug mode and letting the rest of Huge Kingdom know you're here to kick ass and chew bubble gum?" I joked."Yeah baby, and I'm all out of bubble gum!" Ken said, completing my movie reference. It didn't take a second guess to figure out that Ken was a true geek on more levels than computer networking.

"Where's our good friend Trotsky?" I queried while taking a seat next to Ken.

Ken picked up some gold pieces that the Elves were offering to spare their lives and sped off to a portal pad. Portal pads were used in Huge Kingdom to move between "continents" in the game.

"He's in the sand desert recruiting female friends." Ken replied in the middle of a large flash of light as the portal was engaged. "This will only take a second..."

Less than a minute after appearing on the portal pad in the sand desert, Ken found Trotsky amongst a group of Amazon warriors.

"The dude has style, I'll give him that." I commented as I admired the Amazon wardrobe. "I wonder how many of those Amazons are forty-something men sitting in front of their computer in their underwear?"

"You don't want to know, man. Ninety-percent of our players register as males. Do the math!" Ken exclaimed as he zoomed in on Trotsky's location. "There's our buddy!"

Trotsky was having a private conversation with one of the Amazons.

"Ken, can you kick on your magical bugging device or whatever you call that cool balloon monitoring thing?" I asked.

"Say no more." Ken said as he flipped down the developer console and entered in some debug commands. Balloons once again appeared over all the players heads.


Trotsky: "Seriously! $1000 this week alone. I'm making a fracking killing. I'm going to have no problem making it to the all-star game this year."

Amazon: "You are amazing. Am I getting dinner out of this?"

Trotsky: "More than that if you want."

Amazon: "Let's start with dinner."


"Before this turns into a bad episode of 'The Sims', let's approach Trotsky and ask about buying something. Ken, what would be most valuable to a Centaur?" I asked.

"The Shield Of Redemption. It increases almost all of my magic skills and reduces the impact of magic attacks against me by twenty percent." Ken proudly replied.

"Let's buy one." I suggested as I took a piece of paper out of my notepad.

Ken approached Trotsky and initiated chat.


Ken: "Hey, I'm looking for an item. Can you help? I'm kind of new around here."

Trotsky: "Maybe. Whatcha looking for?"

Ken: "My friend is a Centaur also and he has this thing called a 'Shield Of Resumption'"

Trotsky: "You mean 'Shield of Redemption?"

Ken: "Yeah, lol. That's it."

Trotsky: "What a noob. lol. Yeah I have one. What do you have to trade?"

Ken: "I just killed a mess of Elves. I have one thousand gold pieces!"

Trotsky: "I don't take gold. Make me an offer in American dollars."

Ken: "??? You can do that on here?"

Trotsky: "No, I mean we do the deal outside of the game and I give you the shield."

Ken: "I have no idea how to do that."

Trotsky: "You want the shield or not?"

Ken: "How do I know you really have the shield?"

Trotsky: "I'll drop it on the ground over there by that cactus. You can look, but don't touch it. If you grab it, I'll kill you instantly."

Ken: "Sure of yourself?"

Trotsky: "That just cost you 20 life points."


Ken glanced at his character panel.

"Son of a gun. He just drained me 20 points." Ken moaned.

I grabbed Ken's left hand before he could type.

"Hold up. We're going to move things ahead a little faster than planned. Tell him this." I said as I handed Ken some scribbled notes.

"Are you out of your mind?" Ken asked, his eyes as bright as a wizard's fireball spell.

"Oh, I'm dead serious." I replied.

Part X

Ken read the note that I handed him and proceeded to place both of his hands back on the keyboard. He froze, as if in a complete state of shock.

"He's gone! What the hell?" Ken asked as he panned his character around Huge Kingdom. "He just frick'in disappeared!"

"Think we spooked him?" I asked. This wouldn't be the first time that I played my ace card too fast and ended up scaring away the fat cats from the poker table."Dunno. But he's not in Huge Kingdom anymore. Crap!" Ken complained as sunk into his chair. "What's the plan, Chief?"

"We rest." I said. "We're calling it a night for now, it's late. I'll shoot Steven an E-mail when I get back to my hotel room and let him know our progress."

I exhaled deeply and left the room. A few minutes later I was walking into the operations center and disturbed by a strange noise coming from the backside of a server cabinet. As I walked around the cabinet, I was greeted with a pathetic sight. Scrap was sitting on the floor, back pressed up against the cabinet, laptop on his thighs, and snoring so loud that he could be heard over the noise of several Sun E450 servers nearby.

"Scrap!" I said as I nudged his leg with my foot. "SCRAP! WAKE UP!"

Scrap opened an eye and jumped to his feet so fast that he almost dropped his laptop on the floor.

"Sorry man, I was reviewing the traffic with a couple of peeps and I must have drifted off." Scrap lamented as he yawned into his hand. "Are we calling it a night?"

"Affirmative." I responded as I picked up my gear. "Find anything yet?"

"Man, I guess it would depend on how you define 'something'. Chuck and I were pouring over that last dump and weren't having a lot of luck. Ken was over with you, so we weren't able to get his expertise on where some of these network addresses were or what they were for that matter." Scrap replied as he dug through his pockets for his trusty pack of Newports. "And I think I'm out of smokes. Nice."

We loaded our gear into my rental car and headed back to the hotel for some relaxation and room service. I had really lucked out on the suite that I was staying in. It had two queen size beds, a huge bathroom, a patio for Scrap's smoke urges, and high speed internet connectivity.

I was finishing off a sandwich and scribbling away in my notepad when I heard Scrap start typing rapidly on his laptop and start mumbling under his breath.

"What's up?" I asked Scrap as I threw an empty water bottle at his head.

"You know what I noticed when I was reviewing this traffic earlier?" Scrap queried as he chucked the water bottle back at me.

"Was that before you fell asleep?" I joked.

"Nothing. I mean, there really wasn't anything out of the ordinary in the traffic dumps that we isolated. Chuck was scratching his head the whole time." Scrap said as he closed the top of his laptop. "Just doesn't jive, man."

I nursed my water bottle for a few seconds, dedicating some brain computing cycles to the matter at hand. "Scrap, nothing looked out of the ordinary because we were expecting to see something out of the ordinary."

"Duh."

I tapped my water bottle on the desk. "What if we should have been looking for something extraordinary?"

"What?"

"Listen. Think of this as a simple network security problem. If you break into a system, let's say a system that is very useful, and you want to have complete access to that system anytime you want, but you don't want anyone to detect that you have that access, what would your course of action be?" I asked Scrap.

"Dude, that's textbook. You keep exploiting the same vulnerability that let you in, hoping that nobody else finds it. You install a backdoor or something."

"Or..." I began. "You make your traffic look like it belongs there." I said, raising an eyebrow.

Part XI

Scrap threw his water bottle against the wall, nearly knocking the coffee pot off of the table.

"This haystack just gets uglier and uglier, man." Scrap whined.

"Don't they all? I'm going to complete the rest of my interviews tomorrow. I want you to get with Chuck and look at all the traffic captures again. Approach it like you were troubleshooting an application error or something. Make no assumptions about what you're looking for, and the artifacts might just appear in front of you." I said.
"Ok, Indiana Jones. You E-mailing Steven all of this? Ask him to get some bagels or something for the morning." Scrap said as he jumped on his bed. "I'm wiped."

I was still wide awake and in the process of transferring my written notes into case file collections on my Apple Powerbook while simultaneously composing a status E-mail to Steven.


Steven,
An update on today's activities, and an agenda for tomorrow:
...
I need to finish interviewing the rest of the staff, especially anyone associated with the development of Huge Kingdom. Please have Mr. Slinkpips prepare an interview schedule, and keep it confidential.
...
Scrap will need access to Ken Banobi for the entire day.
...
Execution of the sting operation that we discussed will rely on the availability of the suspect character and his willingness to cooperate.
...
I need your permission to pull salary scales on the entire company. I will explain this later.

P.S. Scrap would like some bagels

Chief


I closed the lid of my Powerbook and watched it instantly go into sleep mode. It was time for me to do the same.

The next morning came entirely too fast and found both Scrap and myself a bit sleepy-eyed but eager to continue with the investigation.

"Did you remind Steven to get some bagels, man?" Scrap asked as we packed our gear into my rental car.

"Yes, I did. Good grief, go to the continental breakfast over there in the lobby and get your own bagel." I said, pointing to the lobby of the hotel.

"SWEET!" Scrap said as he ran off. I guess I was packing the car by myself.
An hour later we were walking through the doors of MMM and were greeted by receptionist Barbie.

"HELLO! How are YOU? Glad to see YOU! Would you like some COF-FEE?" Barbie asked in between answering phone calls.

"Sure." I replied as she buzzed us into the hallway that led to our makeshift office.

"Chief! Hey, not to bombard you this early in the morning but our buddy Trotsky is back in the game and he's wheeling and dealing stuff all over the place!" Ken announced, nearly tripping himself as he leapt through the conference room door. "And, we appear to have a new problem."

"Oh no! Steven forgot the bagels!" Scrap said, wincing with every word.

"What..." I began.

Part XII

"The little bastard has friends!" Ken said as he panned around the Huge Kingdom landscape.

We were standing behind Ken and watching the events unfold. Ken was playing as his debug character, invisible to the rest of Huge Kingdom.

"So, all of these friends of Trotsky are selling merchandise too?" I asked.

I had been standing behind Ken for about five minutes and hadn't seen a single deal go down. Ken leaned back in his chair and glanced towards me.

"I only knew that they were his friends when I saw them group over by the Aged Oak over in the forest kingdom." Ken explained. "I crept up on them, opened up the message monitoring and it was quite clear to me that this was some sort of an organized operation."

I raised an eyebrow.

"Ken, tell me you saved a transcript."

Ken brought down his virtual console screen and scrolled through the console messages.

"Paydirt! Yeah, I got it. Hold on." Ken said as he hit a few keys on his keyboard and his game screen shrunk to a 640x480 resolution window.

"Nice." I said.

"Yeah, it's cool. The transcript is over on that printer." Ken announced with a quick point of his index finger towards a large HP Laserjet printer.

I retrieved the transcript from the printer and took a few moments to review it.

The last conversation piqued my interest:


Trotsky: "Yeah, it's awesome man. I can't believe you totally scored on that soloman sword of severance."

PlayerZ: "LOL Let me tell you he was so happy to finally be able to slay the pit dragon, he almost wanted to kiss me."

GigglesME: "Yeah, like anyone would want to kiss you. Fool."
