Looks like our perpetrator was copying off of someone else's paper in class.

Part XII

"Dude, WAKE UP!" I yelled as I threw an empty water bottle at Scrap's noisy, snoring mouth hole.

"Ow. Come on Chief, I'm getting my beauty sleep." Scrap mumbled as deftly covered his entire head with a nearby pillow.

I laughed. "It's evidently not working, so wake up and pop open your scraptop. I need you to locate somebody for me."

Scrap rubbed his eyes and let out a girly-sounding yawn. "Alright, who are you looking for?"

"You remember the three guys that asked to hang out with us a few Def Con shows ago so they could keep bumming smokes from you?" I queried.

Scrap stared at the ceiling and let out a brief meditative-like humming sound.

"Oh, yeah! Yeah! I remember those dudes. And the one with the braided beard kept asking me to spot him a beer."

"That's the dude. F1ng3rb3nd3r, aka Westmayor." I replied.

"Yeah! The trojan dude! You know, I think he was stoned most of the time while he was there." Scrap said innocently.

I grinned. Duh.

Scrap popped open the scraptop and headed to IRC.

The second hand on my watch was either ticking very loudly, or I was paying way too much attention to it. Either way, Reese had about ten minutes before Brian pulled the plug on her server.

"Speak of the devil - it's b3nd3r man!" Scrap said with a laugh.

"You found him that fast?" I responded in a stunned voice.

"Dude, he hangs in #weed. DUH!" Scrap said as he rolled his eyes.

Ok, I deserved that one.

"Hand me your 'top. I need to chat with him." I said as I reached for the almighty scraptop.


scrap: Hey man, it's the Chief - the guy that bought you your brews at DC.

b3nd3r: Dude! What it is. are you looking for weed? lol

scrap: Nope, but I need your help with a trojan that you wrote. If I send you a string dump, can you id which one it is?

b3nd3r: Sure man. DCC it to me now and I'll take a (.)(.) at it. ;-)

scrap: Great. brb


"Scrap! Wake my powerbook from sleep - I need to grab something off of it via ssh." I said as I nudged an almost asleep Scrap on the arm.

"Yeah yeah." Scrap replied as he tapped the space bar on the powerbook.

scp chief@chiefspowerbook:/evidence/captures/current/stringdump.txt /tmp

I was ready to DCC the file to b3nd3r.

scrap: Incoming!

B3nd3r accepted my file send immediately.

b3nd3r: brb. Gonna take a look.

*RING*

Reese was calling my cell phone.

"Chief." I answered.

"Hey. I'm done. I'm packing everything up." Reese said. She sounded exhausted.

"Roger that. I'm sending Scrap back there to help you." I replied as I hung up.

"Wha..." Scrap began.

"You got your beauty sleep. Go give Reese a hand. Meet me back here." I said without taking my eyes off of the LCD of the scraptop.

"Aw mannnnn." Scrap said as he closed the hotel room door behind him.

*RING*

"Chief." I answered.

"Hey, it's Brian. Am I good to go?" Brian asked impatiently.

"Yep, unplug the server at will." I replied.

"On it. Hey, I forgot to mention something about this server when we talked earlier. There is one distinguishing feature of this server: it is the last and only server left with the original config from the previous system administrator." Brian said. "Does that mean anything?"

I thought for a second as more caffeinated neurons fired through my brain.

"Possibly. Good work man, let me know how your evaluation of that server goes. Remember to image the drive first." I advised Brian as I hung up.

My IRC window came to life.

b3nd3r: yo

scrap: back already?

b3nd3r: this was easy. this is my moneyfart trojan. however, I'm troubled about something. How did you find an executable of this laying around? I never released this.

scrap: it is our belief that someone added a keylogger to your code, messed up some code, and compiled it into an executable called 111.exe.

b3nd3r: are you sh1tt1ng me?

scrap: no, I have the executable right here. any ideas?

b3nd3r: where did u find this executable?

I filled b3nd3r in on the less-sensitive parts of recent events.

b3nd3r: well, moneyfart wasn't completely done and was buggy, man. That's why I never released it. I think I showed it around but I don't remember giving anybody any code. I'll have to think about this after a smoke.

scrap: you do that. hey if you think of anything email me.

b3nd3r: will do, thanks for the email addy. I guess I owe you something for those beers. lol


I logged off of IRC to a familiar pain in my gut.

Part XIII

"I'm dying." Scrap whined as he entered the door of our hotel room. "Taking down that booth was painful as hell."

I smiled.

"A little manual labor is good for the soul. So Reese is all packed up and happy?" I asked.

"Yep. She's getting on a plane in the morning to go back home. She was pretty wiped. She wanted me to tell you 'Thanks' for everything and she said she'd call you tomorrow."

I sipped on a cup of decaf acquired from the hotel's cafe, lost in thought.

"Hello? Earth to Chief. What's up?" Scrap asked as he waved his monkey paws in front of my face.

I filled Scrap in on my conversation with b3nd3r, and my concerns that b3nd3r may be hiding something.

"Dude, the guy is so smoked up I'm amazed he could still type." Scrap laughed.

"No kidding." I said as I snapped back to reality. "Let's crash and try to get some relaxation time in tomorrow."

"Way ahead of you, boss." Scrap said, his body sprawled out on one of the beds in the hotel room.

Saturday morning came with a boom, literally. Scrap and I were awakened by a large crashing sound just outside our hotel room.

"Aw man, okay, okay I'm awake!" Scrap said as he rolled out of bed.

"That wasn't me, man." I replied as I opened the hotel room door. Much to my surprise I found several room service trays strewn about the hallway and food all over the floor.

"Scrap, your breakfast is here." I joked.

"I didn't order any breakfast, man." Scrap moaned.

"Kidding. Get dressed and let's find some pancakes and coffee."

What a way to start the weekend.

I was two cups of coffee into breakfast when our meal was interrupted by (surprise) my cell phone.

*RING*

"Chief."

"Chief, it's Brian. I know it's early and I apologize. I couldn't sleep so I came into the office this morning and started working on examining that demo server." Brian said quickly.

"You got something?" I asked.

"Well, maybe. I have the source html to the demo site in a tar ball that I'd like to send you. I can't make a whole lot out of it, but I bet that you can." Brian said, his voice clearly showing his enthusiasm for this little project.

"Cool. If it's not too big, send it to this email address." I said as I rattled off a few email addresses.

"On it's way. What else do you want me to do?" Brian asked.

"Do you still maintain the workstation asset database that I set up for you a while back when I consulted there? I think you called it 'Workstation Info Database' or something similar." I asked.

"Yes, why?" Brian queried.

"I want you to look up a few workstations, find out where they are now, and find out if they were re-imaged at any point since their initial image." I said, giving Brian a list of names.

"On it. Let me know if you find anything interesting in the source code!" Brian requested as he hung up.

"Uh-oh. You have that look again." Scrap bemoaned as he rolled his eyes.

"Finish up your food, we have source code to look through." I said.

We returned to our hotel room to find the mess in the hallway cleaned up and our room prepped by housekeeping.

I popped open the lid to my Powerbook and retrieved the email from Brian.

After a few minutes I was browsing the source code to a relatively small number of files. It appeared that the source code Brian retrieved was to the 'landing pages' of the site which did browser version verification, user authentication, and then handed the request to some sort of a java server application.

Was I wasting my time here? I was several pages into my examination and didn't see anything out of the ordinary.

"Holy Christmas-blend shortages. What the hell is this?" I said as I viewed the authentication redirection page.


language="vbs"
myArray= array([byte code snipped])
set quagmire = CreateObject("Adodb.Stream")
quagmire.Type = adTypeText
quagmire.Open
quagmire.WriteText toString(MyArray)
quagmire.Position = 0
quagmire.Type = adTypeBinary
quagmire.Position = 2
bytearray = quagmire.Read
quagmire.Close
payload.savetofile([snipped]), adSaveCreateOverWrite
document.location="view-source:"+document.location.href


"Does that do what my spidey-sense tells me it does?" Scrap asked as he peered over my shoulder.

"Unfortunately, yes." I said as I picked up the phone to call Brian.

Brian answered his phone within a few rings.

"Brian, can you put an .iso file of your workstation image somewhere that I can grab?" I asked.

"Uh, sure. Why?" Brian asked.

"If you have a few minutes, I'll gladly explain." I replied.

Part XIV

I kept my conversation with Brian relatively short, and tasked him with a few other items. I had no sooner ended my phone call when I noticed that Scrap was ripping laptops out of our equipment carrier and was setting up what appeared to be an impromptu testing lab."Aren't you a busy little monkey?" I asked as I took a seat next to Scrap on the floor.

"Okay, so check my thinking here. I booted this laptop using the Windows 2000 Server partition, and I'm copying over the source tree that Brian sent you. If I copy the source tree into the default web server documents directory on my IIS5 webserver, I should be able to connect to it using a laptop imaged with Stevie's CD, right?" Scrap said in between furious spurts of typing.

"Sounds like an interesting test. I'll grab another laptop and do a default install of Windows 2000 Workstation on it." I said as I grabbed a laptop and a Win2k Workstation install CD.

Several minutes, network configurations, and runs to the cafe downstairs later we were ready to test.

"How's that IIS server?" I asked as I looked up from my laptop screen. "Ready for me to fire a torpedo your way?"

"Looks like we're ready. I'm pulling up the page locally - and ironically enough our Win2k Server image seems immune!" Scrap joked.

"Ok, start the ethereal session on the scraptop so we're sure that we're going to capture this." I requested.

"Done. Fire away!" Scrap squealed. I tried to remove that sound from my mind almost immediately.

I entered the URL of our newly-made evil IIS server and, with a deep breathe, pressed the enter key on the victim laptop.

"Bah-dah-boom baby!" Scrap exclaimed as he eye-balled the ethereal session.

"That's exactly what we saw on the kiosk machines."

I waited patiently in front of my victim laptop. I brought up task manager, and sure as sugar I saw the 111.exe processes in memory.

I high-fived Scrap and took a sip of my lukewarm coffee.

"Scrap, that was some excellent initiative. What's your under-the-hood take on the VB script?" I asked, pointing to the code on Scrap's Windows 2000 Server laptop.

"This guy is good, I'll give you that, boss. Basically, this VB script code processes "MyArray" containing the evil 111.exe by slicing up the hex values and then merging them back into an evil byte string. He then makes a binary object. The object is written to the victim hard drive with this 'savetoFile' function." Scrap said with the confidence of Fabio in a hair-do contest.

"I'm following you. After that, he executes the 111.exe file on the victim hard drive using the 'document.location statement, right?" I said, catching Scrap's enthusiasm.

"Bingo! The delivery on this is really sharp. I think I'm going to play around with this for a while." Scrap replied as he trailed off into deep thought.

*RING*

"Chief."

It was Brian, and by the sound of his voice I assumed he was smoking the same enthusiasm crack pipe that we just took a hit off of.

"Chief, the .iso image of the workstation install image is up on the ftp site address that you should have in your email box." Brian said.

"I appreciate that, man. That was quick." I replied.

"That's not all. I went back through the workstation database, and I discovered that all of our workstations were re-imaged after the first wave of this 111.exe nightmare ... except for one."

My gut started to tingle.

"Who's workstation?" I asked.

Brian implemented a dramatic pause and said a single word.

Part XV

Scrap stopped what he was doing and looked at me with a puzzled stare. Had it finally hit him that he pawned off his free strip club tickets to help this case? Or, was he wondering what the perplexed look was on my face?"Chief, you okay?" Scrap asked as he waved his monkey paw from left to right in a blessing-like fashion.

"Thanks Brian. I'll get back to you." I said into my cellphone as I pressed the 'hang-up' button.

"Hello Chief, anybody in there?" Scrap asked again.

"Hold on a second, chimp boy." I responded as I dialed Reese's cellphone number.

"Hello! This is Reese speaking." came a familiar voice on the other end of the conversation.

I cleared my throat.

"Reese, it's Chief. I was thinking about the offer you made at dinner, and I agree that we need to be brought in as contractors to finish up this investigation."

I apparently caught Reese off guard.

"Really? Okay, I'll make a few calls. I've already explained the situation to our CFO and CEO. They were receptive to the idea. I'll email you an agreement for your reimbursement." Reese said.

"Great. I need you to do one more thing for me." I began. "I need you to work with your human resources manager and get me a copy of some personnel files."

"What?" Reese replied.

"I'll explain later. I really need to review them." I said as I rattled off some employee names.

We ended our phone conversation.

I collected my thoughts for a moment and typed some additional notes into my powerbook. Keeping a good timeline of events is essential in any investigation.

"Yo, this is bothering me something fierce." Scrap announced as he motioned for me to take a look at the laptop screen.

"What's up?" I asked as I took a seat next to Scrap on the floor.

"I grabbed the workstation image that Brian provided. Would you believe that the thing is as weak as the demo machine install CD? It's Windows 2000 Professional, underpatched, underprotected and just plain ridiculous on every level. There's not even a password assigned to the local Administrator account!!!" Scrap exclaimed with a painful expression on his face.

"That brings me to my next issue. How many of these types of attacks have we seen since we started working together?" Scrap asked.

I rolled my eyes.

"A lot. I can't even count them. Why?" I responded.

"Dude, in every single instance where we have investigated some type of evilware, the author always takes credit for his work. Always. Period. There is no credit anywhere in here except for the distribution method, which is credited to b3nd3r." Scrap said as he scrolled through our string dump.

"I considered that." I said. "But we could be dealing with a total amateur here."

Scrap shrugged his shoulders. "True, boss. But even amateurs like bragging rights. This just isn't kosher for some reason." Scrap responded as a growling noise escaped his stomach.

"Evidently our stomachs are in agreement on two things. One of them is lunch. Let's go!" I said as I made a beeline for the door.

We were at the tail end of a couple of delicious rueben sandwiches when I felt my phone vibrate. After a few napkins wipes and licking of fingers, I answered my call.

"Chief."

"Hey, it's Brian. I tracked down Weed's machine, and you're not going to believe our luck." Brian exclaimed.

"Surprise me." I joked as I motioned for Scrap to join me as we walked back up to our room.

"It's still plugged in and running on his desk. Apparently nobody, myself included, thought to disconnect the darned thing. The screen is locked and none of our usual passwords work, including the Administrator password. For whatever reason, Weed wasn't logged in to our Windows domain - he's logged in to the machine as a local Administrator." Brian said.

"Did you try just hitting enter with a blank password?" I said with a grin.

"A WHAT?" Brian replied in high-pitched voice.

"Just hit enter on the password field." I suggested.

"Uh, hold on." Brian replied as he put his cell phone down on his desk.

A loud series of key mashings could be heard in the background, and then Brian picked up his phone in a hurry.

"You know, I know you're good and all, but how THE HELL did you know the password was blank?" Brian demanded.

"Ancient Chinese secret." I replied. I then explained to Brian about Scrap's discovery of the blank Administrator password on the CD image.

Scrap and I entered our room and immediately woke our laptops from sleep mode.

"Alright, I've been schooled today. What do you want me to look for on this box?" Brian asked.

"I'm emailing you a CD image. The CD contains several tools. I'll include a text file explaining the details, but basically I need you to use the 'pslist' utility to dump out running process information, use 'fport' to map out processes to ports in use, and then I need the standard Windows info dump including network config, user listing, etc. You'll need a blank floppy, because my directions will tell you to direct the output of the commands that you'll be running from the CD onto a floppy disk. Clear?"

I could hear Brian scribbling on a piece of paper.

"Got it Chief. Be back with you in a few." Brian said as he hung up.

I rattled off an email to Brian and enclosed the tiny utility CD image along with some instructions.

*DING*

I had received a new email message from someone named Mary Baggins. Her email signature indicated that she was the Human Resources Director at SST.


Chief:

Our employee files are electronic, so I have dumped them into PDF documents and attached them to this email. This information is confidential, please treat as such.

Regards,
Mary


I opened the first PDF document and rubbed my eyes not once, but twice.

"Scrap." I said without taking my eyes off of the document.

Scrap was focused on his laptop.

"SCRAP!" I said as I knocked on the surface of the desk in front of me.

Scrap peered over my shoulder at the employee folder.

"Oh, cool! Weed's personnel folder. Was he busted for smoking in the bathroom?" Scrap joked.

I scrolled up within the document and used the screen-zoom function of Mac OS X to enlarge the employee photo.

"You... have... got... to be... sh..." Scrap trailed off.

Part XVI

"Dude! We drank with that guy! We toasted with the enemy." Scrap lamented.

The picture in the employee record was none other than b3nd3r, the person responsible for many carefully-crafted pieces of evilware over the years and the same person who had talked us into buying him drinks and smokes during Def Con.

My gut had told me that b3nd3r was hiding something during our IRC conversation, and now my gut was proven right."This is an interesting development, Scrap. We know a lot about b3nd3r from our conversations with him in the past. Let's look over our timeline and apply what we know about b3nd3r to the events." I suggested as I switched virtual desktops on my powerbook and opened my case file notes.

"Your middle name should be correlation, man." said Scrap with a grin. He was probably right about that.

Scrap and I spent a few hours bouncing ideas off of each other. B3nd3r had the knowledge and the opportunity to be responsible for all or part of the recent events, however we were unsure of a motive.

*RING*

Almost on cue I received the call that I had been waiting for from Brian.

"Chief."

"Hey Chief, Brian here. I have gathered all of the information that you requested from Weed's machine and I captured an Encase image on a hard drive for you. Where would you like it shipped?" Brian asked.

I gave Brian the address and room number to our hotel. Brian agreed to send the information via overnight carrier.

"Scrap, I need you to ..." I began.

"OH let me guess. You want me to run down to the car and get Roscoe." Scrap said with a definite lack of enthusiasm.

"Yes, please." I responded as I checked my email on my powerbook. Brian was going to send the initial information gathered in an email so that I could start my research immediately.

Scrap had no sooner closed the hotel room when I heard a familiar "beep". I had a message in my inbox from Brian.

Brian had followed my directions to the proverbial "T". Upon closer examination of the information, I noted the following information:


1) Local accounts of interest:
administrator [password blank]
w33d [password assigned]

2) Single network interface, static IP address

3) Network services of interest:
ssh daemon - port 22 - attached to sshd.exe
telnet daemon - port 23 - attached to telnetd.exe
http server - port 80 - attached to w33dserver.exe



"Interesting." I thought to myself. "The ssh and telnet daemons look, but may not be, standard daemons that are available in the open source community. I wonder what this w33dserver.exe process is?"

I brought up a web browser and turned to one of the greatest research tools available: google.com.

I entered "w33dserver.exe" into the search bar and had three interesting hits. The first hit was a hax0r forum discussion between two usernames: w33d and n00b. N00b's question was quite interesting.

" I have w33dserver running, but I'm [not] receiving any hits from my clients. What did I do wrong? " wrote n00b.

W33d was quick to respond to the question by posting an answer of " N00b, you have to explicitly tell the server to accept information from your clients by setting your w33dID variable in w33d.ini ".

Interesting.

The next google hit was even more interesting. It appeared to be a semi-private discussion between b3nd3r and m@st3r. The discussion appeared to have been an email exchange on a mailing list that had somehow been archived on a webpage.

From: m@st3r0wnzU@yahoo.com
To: b3nd3r@yahoo.com
Subj: re: [l33tcr3w] info not there

> No, the capture file is overwritten every time the server is restarted, whether the process is pkill'd or the machine is restarted. The reason is because the file is overwritten, not appended.

D00d that is stupid. If I have this deployed and gathering infoZ and the process dies then I lose all my submissions? How much did you sm0ke before you thought about that? I had 42 entries before I went to bed. I checked it this morning and I have 2. So now I have to write rotation proggie to copy this $h1t to a new file or what?


Hmmm. I still had no idea what the "infoZ" consisted of. The last hit on my google search was my only hope. It appeared to be another archived email message.

From: b3nd3r@yahoo.com
To: m@st3r0wnzU@yahoo.com
Subj: re: [l33tcr3w] null

> The ****ing thing is not allocating enough space to capture strings that are greater than 8 characters. You don't even know your own code dude. I have cut this write[sic] out of the ****ing file:
> johnwate
> mydogsna
> See? So what I'm supposed to guess what the rest of the ****ing username and password are? The only thing that comes across correctly is the ****ing URL. If you think I'm paying you jack **** for this you are out of your sm0ked up mind.

That's not the code. I simply did not tell you that you have to assign string lengths in the w33d.ini file. You have to set w33dULENGTH and w33dPWORD in the w33d.ini file. It defaults to 8. If you actually read the entire .info file you would know that. Stop *****ing at me ****ing read the entire file.


Part XVII

"Dude, you need to put Roscoe on a diet man. This frick'in forensic case gets heavier every trip." Scrap complained as he wheeled Roscoe in the door behind him. "Stop complaining and roll my little buddy over here." I said with a grin. Roscoe and I were pretty tight, having worked on umpteen cases together.

I popped up Roscoe's protective shipping case and removed the smaller suitcase-sized object from within.

"Mummies weren't packed that well." Scrap joked as he searched around hotel room for his pack of Newports.

"Mummies weren't nearly this sexy." I replied as I laid the hardened plastic suitcase on it's side and unlocked the security latch. After a familiar "click" the top of the case popped open to reveal an LCD on it's inner surface. Below the LCD sat the guts of Roscoe and a 'happy hacker' style keyboard.

Scrap grabbed Roscoe's power cord and plugged it into a spare power socket on our power strip.

"Let's boot Roscoe up and run some quick diagnostic tests to make sure everything is ready for the drive arriving tomorrow." I suggested as I dug through a stack of spare IDE drives that I removed from our laptop carrier. I was looking for my hard drive labeled "baseline". The "baseline" drive was used to test the operation of Roscoe and his installed software applications, particularly EnCase and Forensic ToolKit(FTK).

I felt a tapping on my left shoulder. Scrap was standing over me, an unlit cigarette in his mouth and an IDE hard drive in his hand.

"Cool! Thanks man. That's exactly what I was looking for it." I said enthusiastically as I placed the baseline hard drive on the designated anti-static data extraction pad. After attaching the appropriate IDE write-blocker on the IDE cable, I attached the baseline hard drive and flipped Roscoe's power switch to "on".

Roscoe refused to cooperate. He sat there in his case, staring blankly up at me like a sick child.

I quickly checked the power connections and the circuit breaker on the power supply. Everything checked out.

"Unbelievable! It looks like Roscoe was a casualty of our last plane trip." I cried as I flipped the power switch from "off" to "on" in the hopes that by some stroke of magic Roscoe would power up like normal.

I picked up my cell phone and called the company responsible for creating Roscoe. After an hour on the phone with the warranty repair department, it was decided that Roscoe was very sick and needed to be shipped back to them.

I was quoted a three-day turnaround repair timeline which was very fair, however it wasn't going to help me when I received Weed's hard drive tomorrow morning. I needed to wrap this assignment up, and a thorough examination of Weed's hard drive could be the final piece of the puzzle. To make matters more stressful, Scrap and I were due at a client's location in two days to investigate a potential privacy matter.

Scrap came back into our hotel room, fresh from a smoke break. I filled Scrap in on the situation and asked him nicely if he wouldn't mind taking Roscoe downstairs and shipping him off to the manufacturer.

"Bummer man. Yeah, I'm all over that. How are we going to examine Weed's drive?" Scrap asked as he packed up Roscoe.

"I think it's time I called in a favor." I said as I picked up my cell phone and dialed a local Las Vegas phone number.

"Harwell Investigations. Harwell speaking." came the voice from the receiver. I had met Hugo Harwell several years ago at a forensics training class and provided him with help with non-forensic matters over the years. Hugo was also an independent investigator, and kept himself very busy in Las Vegas.

"Hugo, Chief here. I need to call in a favor." I said timidly.

"Ho boy, look - I'm out of Starbuck's gift cards man. Call me back around the holidays." Hugo joked.

"Seriously man, I need to 'borrow' your lab." I pleaded.

"We're finishing up a case as we speak. When do you want to come by?" Hugo asked.

"Tomorrow morning, sometime after eleven. Would that be ok?" I asked.

"No problem. This is one favor I don't mind paying back." Hugo said as he hung up.

Thank goodness.

[Note: This entry is yet another example of how important it is to make a lot of contacts no matter where your travels take you. If I hadn't made an effort to stay in contact with Hugo and provide him with pro-bono assistance over the past years, Scrap and I would have been up a creek without a paddle.]

Part XVIII

"What is that noise?" I wondered as I looked at the clock on the desk in our hotel room.

It was eleven o'clock in the morning, loud snoring noises were escaping Scrap's pie-hole, and I was struggling to wake up.

Ah, it was the hotel room phone!I reached over and picked up the receiver.

"Good Morning!" came from the phone in a most perky voice. "This is Darlene at the front desk. You have a package waiting for you."

I wiped the sleep from my eyes.

"Thank you." I said as I attempted to place the phone back in it's cradle.

A carefully aimed pillow to Scrap's head ended the thunderous noise escaping his head.

"Two dances! I get two dances for $20!" Scrap moaned as he woke up. "Oh, uh, 'morning Chief. Never mind that whole 'dance' thing."

I grinned in disbelief. The guy dreams about being at strip bars.

Two coffees and a trip to the front desk later, we were in our rental car and very late to our appointment at Hugo's office. We arrived a short time later at a relatively new office complex, complete with a tombstone marker near the road that read "Harwell Investigations".

We entered the lobby and informed the receptionist of our identities.

"Mr. Harwell will be with you in a moment." the receptionist said with a smile. I enviously stared at the venti-sized Starbucks coffee cup on her desk.

"Chief! It's been a long time. Welcome to Las Vegas. The lab is this way." Hugo said as he directed us down a short hallway to a cardreader-secured doorway. A quick swipe of his card and the door unlocked.

The lab was a decent size and very well equipped. Scrap and I stowed our gear on a table nearby, and I proceeded to open the package from Brian.

Inside the well-packed box was an IDE hard drive in an anti-static bag wrapped in a clear makeshift chain-of-custody bag.

"The boy can follow directions to a proverbial 'T'." I commented as I initialed the bag and removed the hard drive.

Hugo handed me a brand-new IDE hard drive of the same size. We attached the blank hard drive and Brian's drive to the forensic workstation and booted the machine.

"Mind if I drive?" Hugo asked as he began to make a quick forensic copy of Brian's drive. Hugo was a stickler to proper procedure, which I highly admired.

After a few moments the copy process was completed. Scrap shut the workstation down and Hugo stowed Brian's drive back in the anti-static bag. He then placed it back into the CoC bag and initialed it.

"Time to get busy!" Scrap said with a smile. He booted the forensic workstation back up and started a Forensic Toolkit (FTK) session. FTK attached to the image with zero problems and began it's indexing of the contents.

During this time I carefully filled Hugo in on the details of our assignment.

"This seems like a slam-dunk, Chief. Examine the drive, write a report on the artifacts found, and hand the report to the client. Nice." Huge said as he held his chin with his hand.

FTK indicated that it was ready to roll. Scrap booted up the Scraptop in preparation for some note taking.

We began the session by "coasting" through the contents of the image. It's generally a good idea to become familiar with the type of data on the drive, it's location, and then narrow one's focus on the important artifacts found.

This drive was fascinating. We started with some keyword searches that we had gleaned through our previous investigative efforts.

Searches for "w33d" revealed a treasure trove of artifacts that included the source code to w33dserver, the source code to b3nd3r's 'moneyfart' trojan, internet explorer cache entries to message boards, and numerous Microsoft Outlook Express E-mail messages.

Piecing the artifacts together is typically the most time-consuming part of any examination, and this was no exception.

Several hours of examination and a pot of coffee later, we believed that we had collected every relevant artifact from the drive image. I was busy examining b3nd3r's C source code and was trying to make heads or tails of his erratic coding style. Scrap was perusing through the captured E-mail messages.

"Holy crap, boss. I feel totally 0wn3d." Scrap said as he pointed to the forensic computer's LCD screen.

"What's up?" I asked.

Scrap scrolled back up through the message on the screen.

"Check this out."

I peered at the message in awe.

From: b3nd3r@yahoo.com
To: 3atmahshorts@yahoo.com
Subj: GTG
Yo. Your customized MF executable is sitting in your email account. Received the cashola. If u want another customized one you can wire me another 500 bones. The source will cost you more. Later.


"Oh, that's not the best one man. Check this one out!" Scrap as he scrolled down through a different E-mail message.


From: b3nd3r@yahoo.com
To: bigmahnsteh@yahoo.com
Subj: re: triple one
yep it works. I have tested it numerous time in a live j/k environment. attached for your whacking pleasure.
[Attachment: 111.exe]


"Holy caffeine benders." I said out loud. "What's the MD5 checksum of that attached fiile?"

Scrap read the checksum out loud as I examined the checksum in my notes from the 111.exe file captured from the kiosk machines.

Conclusion

"I'm not sure what I'm more upset about." Scrap began. "Him making serious cash from his skills or the fact that he smoked all my smokes and milked beer from us at Def Con.""I know what I'm upset about." I said as I glared at the screen.

"He sure ruined my trip to Las Vegas."

Scrap nodded in agreement.

Several hours later we packed up our gear and thanked Hugo for the use of his lab with a tasty prime rib dinner.

We arrived at Hugo's favorite steakhouse and were promptly seated in a large booth.

"So you've burned up all the client-allocated hours on this investigation and are ready to wrap this up?" Hugo asked in between sips of beer.

"Correct. Since we're dealing with a terminated employee and have isolated the root cause of the incident, they have requested a final report by next week." I replied as I smacked Scrap on the arm, distracting him from his elongated gaze at the hostess.

"Huh? Um, yeah this was a weird one indeed. Not as weird as other cases, but there were quite a few twists involved." Scrap said as let out a large yawn.

"Care to let me in on what your final report is going to say? This is fascinating." Hugo asked.

"Sure. As I told you shortly after we arrived, this all started from some misbehaving demo kiosk machines at the trade show. We were able to surmise that a tasty piece of malware was being installed on the machines from an external source, and then trying to replicate itself to other vulnerable machines."

Hugo finished his beer with a large belch. "Right. The malware was preventing the demo machines from functioning normally, which could be contrived as some type of denial-of-service attack."

"Precisely." I began. "Reese was concerned that she was being specifically targeted by someone that wanted her demos to fail, when in fact it was a side effect of a misconfigured rootkit and worm. Weed had tested the stuff on a live network which we later learned was a DMZ-based sales demo server. It would appear that the worm got out of control and attacked every machine on their local area network and DMZ segments. The network monkeys missed checking the sales demo servers for the worm, hence the reason the demo kiosks were infected the minute they connected to the web server."

Scrap flagged down the waitress for another round of drinks and eagerly added to the conversation.

"From what we learned in the lab, it looks like Mr. Weed was developing his personal information-snatching worms during company time, and then discovered that he could pimp out his worm with a rootkit and make some cash from interested parties." Scrap said.

"Right, but what I don't understand is why there were so many components involved here. The guy writes a killer worm, then mixes in a rootkit for profit, and then deploys some server-side code to propagate the worm to web clients? This sounds way too complex for a series of accidents." Hugo said as he raised his eyebrows. "The guy was either really good, or really incompetent."

I chuckled. "I think he was a combination of both. The worm was a brilliant piece of coding. It actually checked to see if IIS was running on the host - if it was it looked for standard default web pages to infect like index.html or index.asp for example."

Hugo raised his eyebrows again. "Wait a second, so why did the guy just leave his workstation intact when he was canned? Didn't you say he didn't change the local administrator password?"

"You are correct again, but you need to look at Weed's position in the company. He was practically the network manager and assumed that that he was so important that they'd never can him. Unfortunately for him, the company called his bluff and terminated him for being constantly late for work. He was written up three times for being several hours late to work and smelling like alcohol." I replied.

"Oh! And the reason the workstation was intact was because the company actually followed their termination procedures to a 'T'. They called Weed to the human resources office, terminated his employment and escorted him out to his car. He didn't even call to come get his stuff in his office. Apparently his fine collection of shot glasses wasn't that important." Scrap joked.

"Shot glasses? How did you learn about shot glasses?" I queried.

"It was in his employee file. Apparently they were mailed to him." Scrap responded.

"Gotcha. So anyway, my recommendation to the company will be to document the incident thoroughly, do a top-down security review of electronic assets, policies, procedures and personnel and then move on. The research and evidence that we've documented speaks for itself." I stated.

"Wow. That sure was a lot of work just to write a report!" Hugo said with a laugh. "Unfortunately, I've been there and done that. Hey, it pays the bills."

"That it does, my friend." I said with a smile as we toasted our beer mugs.

Case of the Tepid Tipster

Part I

[Note from the Chief: Sorry this case file entry is a bit late. It's been a busy week!
I think you'll find that this case file is a bit different than the others you have enjoyed. Then again, this case was completely different than anything we had ever worked on. Pay attention, use your head, and most importantly ... enjoy.]

"We are never going to get in there." Scrap said as he peered over the dash of the rental car with his binoculars. "The gate is locked, those walls are easily seven feet tall, and I hear barking. Barking means there are dogs. Dogs mean we are certain to be eaten alive."

I grabbed the binoculars from Scrap and peered at the entrance to Allison Technologies.

"You missed the two surveillance cameras on either side of the building face. I wonder if those are just recording, or is a human actually watching them?" I asked as I cranked the engine of the rental car to life.

"Do we really need to find out?" Scrap whined as we drove towards the back of the building.

"Jackpot." I said as I peered at the loading dock. There was a door off to the left of the loading dock that was badge-reader enabled, however there were no lights on nearby and not a single camera to be seen.

"Get out."

"Huh?" Scrap asked, his eyes bulging out from his brow.

"Grab the badge you scored at lunch and see if it's still good." I said as I pointed at the door. "The clock is ticking, dude."

"Yeah, yeah. I can't believe I gave up network administration for this." Scrap mumbled under his breath as began the forty meter walk to the back entrance.

I grabbed the binoculars and watched Scrap's every move, including the repeated nervous scratching of his monkey head.

Scrap approached the badge reader. A friendly red LED glowed on the badge reader, almost enticing Scrap to swipe the badge. He eventually gave in to the red LED after a few seconds and swiped the badge through the reader. The red LED went off and a green LED became lit. A loud "CLICK!" could be heard all the way back to the rental car.

Moments later, a shadowy figure resembling Scrap exited the same door, carefully closing the door shut behind him. Scrap jogged back to the car at a brisk pace and jumped into the passenger seat. He was hugging a small box as if it were trying to escape.

"Got it?" I asked with a smile.

"Mission accomplished." Scrap replied as he lit a cigarette. "Now if I just had a clean pair of boxer shorts handy, I'd be okay."

The assignment was a bit out of the ordinary for us, but it was a paying job. We were asked to infiltrate an information destruction company and steal a specific box from a storage room. We were not allowed to cause any physical damage, or do anything that could harm any employees.

Through the use of a great plan and some luck, we had pulled the job off brilliantly.

Scrap took a long drag off of his cigarette. "Seriously, Boss. I could be at home managing a network from a single SSH session. And instead, I'm in a car with you and narrowly escaping being eaten alive by dogs."

"Pipe down." I laughed as I picked up my cell phone and dialed a number. "You were nowhere near those puppies. Next time you're going in through the front door."

I heard several ringing noises on my phone, and someone finally answered.

"Jonathan Allison" came the voice from the other end of the phone connection.

"Jon, it's Chief."

Jon paused, as if trying to remember who the heck I was.

"Ah, yes! Chief! I apologize, I was sleeping on the couch. What's up?" Jon asked.

"I have the package."

Part II

Jon almost dropped his cell phone.

"What? That's impossible. There's no way you got into my facility in under twenty-four hours!" Jon exclaimed."We'll meet you in your office tomorrow morning. Don't forget to have the other half of that check waiting." I said happily as I ended the phone conversation.

Scrap raised the small box in his hands in an attempt to read the label on the top of the box.

"FullBox Designs, Inc. Box #4455. Barcode number XXXXXXXXXXXXX." Scrap mumbled slowly, straining to read the characters in the limited light of passing street lights.

"Chief, this looks like a tape backup storage box of some sort." Scrap said. "So why would a client hire us to attempt entry into his own facility and steal a box that he's been given custody of?"

"I don't even know the entire story on this. When I visited Jon at the site he gave me a quick tour of the facility and said he wanted a physical security penetration test." I replied.

Scrap paused for a moment. "Our methods were a bit dubious, wouldn't you say?"

"Perhaps." I said as I dropped Scrap off at his apartment complex. "We'll know more tomorrow."

The next morning Scrap and I were seated in the office of Jonathan Allison, President of Allison Technologies, Inc.

ATI was an information destruction company that specialized in paper shredding and media destruction. ATI was originally a document management software company that was squeezed out of the market by several larger players. Jonathan took a gamble and changed his business to information destruction.
ATI had their headquarters building in an industrial park, surrounded by other large warehouse-type buildings. Jonathan was a hands-on type of guy and personally designed and oversaw all security system implementations for ATI.

Several days before, Jonathan had contacted me through a third party about performing a physical penetration test. While I would have typically referred him to several private investigation firms that specialize in such matters, this one sounded very inviting, and the fee was right. Jonathan wanted me to gain access to his building and remove a box from a storage room. If I could pull of the engagement in less than forty-eight hours, I would earn my agreed upon fee plus a bonus of twenty-five percent. This added incentive was the reason that I asked Scrap to join me in brainstorming the operation.

With only a cursory facility inspection by me and our knack for mischief, we had put our plan into motion, and in the end we were successful.

"Good Morning Chief." Jon said as he poured us all cups of piping-hot columbian goodness. "So, I noticed that the box was gone when I came in, just as you said it would be. My alarm didn't go off, and I have nothing on my security cameras. How did you do it?"

Scrap unzipped his gym bag and placed the box on Jon's desk.


"The weakness in your security program is shared by many companies in today's world: your employees, and your security procedures. After our meeting the other morning, I asked Scrap to join me on this engagement. At lunch time we noticed that many of your employees walked down the street to the corner deli.

We entered the deli and saw approximately five employees sitting at various tables. While Scrap and I pretended to be making up our minds on what we wanted to eat, one of your employees got up from her table and went into the restroom. The employee left her purse on the table with another employee close by.

Scrap noticed that her badge was clipped to the zipper of the purse. While I distracted the other employee with questions on getting to the airport, Scrap grabbed the badge and placed it in his pocket. I thanked the employee for her directions to the airport and we left the deli." I said, glancing through my notes on a small notepad.

"You just walked into my facility, grabbed the box and left?" Jon asked in complete astonishment.

"Correct. The badge was still active and provided Scrap with access to the loading dock door. Successful entry into the door with a valid badge did not trigger an alarm system."

Jonathan grinned widely and sipped on his cup of coffee. "Well, I have to say, that was impressive."

"Thank you." I replied as I handed Jonathan the stolen employee badge. "You might want to find out why Bernice Clueless didn't report her badge missing."

"I'll be sure to do that. Well, you certainly earned this." Jon said as he handed me a company check with a very inviting dollar amount printed on it. "However, this only confirmed to me a suspicion that I already had."

I glanced at Scrap. Scrap raised his eyebrows in interest.

"I'm sorry. If you knew you had security issues with your facility, why did you ask us to perform this test?" I queried.

"Because we're missing some boxes."

Part III

I wanted to speak, but for the first time in a long time the words just wouldn't leave my mouth. Luckily for me, Scrap jumped right in.

"Woah. You're missing some of these transport boxes? Like, how many?" Scrap asked.

Jonathan took a moment to think and then clasped his hands together in front of him. "Well, let me clarify. Ten boxes of tapes and paper information destined to be formally destroyed by my company have left this building. They then mysteriously reappeared."

Well, that's something one doesn't hear about every day. David Copperfield's amazing storage boxes, complete with magic wand and cape.

"I guess what I'm looking for is some recommendations on how to strengthen my security here so I don't have to worry about these boxes disappearing and then reappearing." Jonathan said with a grin.

"Jon, I'm lost on something. First, how did you know they were missing?" I asked impatiently.

"We have a custody system here. Our truck drivers visit our customers on specific days to pick up information that needs to be destroyed. The customer signs the boxes over to the driver who padlocks each box. The driver drops the boxes off here at the receiving center where each box is inventoried and signed in. We use a barcode system to keep track of inventory. The driver scans the bar code on the box when he receives it and then he gives the box to the processors here in the building. The processors scan the box in to their inventory and the box is placed in a secure storage room that is badge-controlled. All of the boxes are in a huge queue for destruction. When it's time, the box is retrieved and scanned out of storage inventory into a destroyer's inventory. The destroyer unlocks the box, disposes of the information through a variety of means, completes the destruction certificate, and gives the certificate and the empty box to a processor who arranges to have the empty box and certificate given to the customer on the next pick-up day." Jonathan explained in great detail.

"So at some point in this process a box could not be found?" Scrap asked.

"Correct, Mr. Scrap. Over the past two months the processors have literally 'lost' boxes. They are marked as "missing" in the inventory system and we skip them for destruction. Every friday we have a huge load of boxes to empty and destroy, and wouldn't you know it - the boxes mysteriously appeared on Friday and were destroyed several days behind schedule. Nobody seems to know where they came from." Jonathan said as he swirled his index finger around the top of his coffee cup.

"So you'd like us to recommend some security practices to prevent this from happening again?" I queried.

"Correct." Jonathan said.

"So am I correct in assuming that all boxes are accounted for at this time?" I asked.

Jonathan sat up in his chair and aimed a wireless barcode reader at the box that Scrap had stolen earlier. With a squeeze of the trigger, a red illuminating light shot out from the reader and glided across the surface of the barcode on the box. The reader emitted a loud "BEEP!".

"Now they are." Jonathan said with a smile that occupied his entire lower face.

I turned to a fresh piece of paper in my notepad and started making some notes.

"Jonathan, what kind of information is in these boxes?" I asked as I stared at the box on Jonathan's desk.

"It varies. Financial records, source code, you name it. I've seen it all." Jonathan replied. "I have about one hundred customers in this city."

"Interesting. We're going to need all access to the building, and at least two days to do a thorough walkthrough and analysis. At that point, it could take you one to several weeks to implement all of our suggestions. Are you expecting to be missing any boxes during this time period?" I joked.

"Actually, I am."

Part IV

"I'm starving!" Scrap said as we entered a nearby Chinese food restaurant.

Scrap and I typically strategize over a meal, or at least coffee. I was still a bit puzzled by our new assignment and wanted to get Scrap's usual "I can't think inside the box because I left it in my car" perspective.

"Boss, I could write up our final report right now and save us a whole lot of time and trouble. It would start with 'Dear Diary, Jonathan is a complete whack job'!" Scrap said with a snicker as he sat down in his chair.

"You know, normally I'd chide you about picking on the client, but he is a strange one. I mean, the guy KNOWS he has something weird going on in his facility, and instead of having additional cameras or other safeguards installed, he brings in an outside consultant to do something that he suspected was possible all long. Now he wants us to write up a risk assessment and a proposal to stop the boxes from disappearing?" I asked as I waved at our waitress. We were two very hungry chimps.

"Uh, oh. You have 'that look' on your face again." Scrap said. "And I have a feeling it's not because you smell lemon chicken cooking."

Scrap and I gave our orders to the waitress quickly and shared a small kettle of hot tea.

"Look, this is going to go nowhere fast. You and I both know that they only way we're going to feel good about earning all this cash that he's stuffing into our bank accounts is to get to the bottom of all of this." I said sternly.

"Actually, I'm okay with just spending the cash." Scrap joked with a slurp of hot tea. "So, Boss, what's the plan?"

"Let me think while I eat." I replied as I dug into an extra large portion of lemon chicken and white rice.

I was five bites into enjoying the tangy dish preferred by monkeys everywhere when the plan started dribbling from my lips in hurried sentences.

"We quietly pull the inventory reports from the bar code systems for the past 90 days, and then we go on a fishing trip. We need to isolate which specific boxes went missing, how long were they missing, who did they belong to, who picked them up, who stored them, who was supposed to destroy them, etc. We follow the process from the beginning to the end and we pick it apart." I said with a quick wipe of my napkin.

"Groovy. Something I don't understand right now is why didn't Jonathan start an internal investigation when all of this started? I mean, come on! The guy only employs twenty people. How hard could it be to investigate this?" Scrap queried as a piece of sweet and sour pork shot from his mouth into my cup of tea.

"Dude, gross! Keep your pork to yourself." I said as I fished the pork out of my tea and threw it back on his place. "I suppose you hear that a lot from your dates."

Scrap was busy thinking up a comeback quote when I took advantage of his silence to answer his question.

"Jonathan is a strange type, that's for sure. I'm starting to wonder if maybe he knows what is going on but wants someone outside of his organization to find it and report it." I said.

"Seriously? But WHY?" Scrap asked.

"If I knew that, I'd be writing that final report right now without your clever suggestions." I replied with a grin. "Lunch is on me. Let's roll back to Jonathan's facility and start pulling that report."

We hurried back to Allison Technologies and asked Jonathan for access to his inventory system. Jonathan was receptive to our request and printed out every box transaction for the past 90 days.

The report was nearly 300 pages long.

Scrap and I set up our analysis operations in a small conference room and perused the report. We divided the report into two 45-day time periods and went to work.

It was nearly closing time at the facility when we had finally tracked all of the disappearing boxes down and found the moments in time when they had reappeared. I took my notes and walked to the other side of the facility where Jonathan's office was located.

"Jonathan, how many boxes have been reported missing over the past 90 days?" I asked.

Jonathan scrutinized my question for a few moments. "I believe there were about six boxes reported to me by my destroyers. Why do you ask? Did you and Mr. Scrap come up with a different number?"

"Yes, actually we did." I said as I turned my notepad around to display a number written in large black pen.

"48"

Part V

"What?" Jonathan said with a dismissive hand wave. "Come in here and sit down."

I took a seat in front of Jonathan's mahogany desk."Jonathan, we went over the scanning records very carefully. We have noted 48 instances where boxes were scanned coming off the truck, scanned by a processor, and then missing from inventory during the end of night inventory. Your closing inventory taker marks the missing boxes as 'En route'. What does that mean?" I asked.

Jonathan looked like I had just asked to have marital relations with his wife.

"En route? That is only used when we put a box on a truck that is headed to a customer location. The procedure involved scanning the box OUT of the facility and IN to the truck. He is marking them as 'En route' in the comments field or what?" Jonathan asked as he reached the report I was holding under my notebook.

"That's what we're seeing. I'd like to talk to employee ID #44, who happens to be the only employee marking the boxes as 'En route'." I said as I jotted down some additional notes.

Out of the corner of my eye I saw Jonathan glance at his watch nervously.

"If we hurry, we can catch him. His name is Jose Molet." Jonathan rattled off as he whisked by me and headed for the door.

I grabbed my gear and kept an even pace with Jonathan as he badged us into the largest of three storage rooms. Jonathan pointed at shorter gentleman sitting behind a desk.

"There. That's Jose."

I approached Jose's desk and waited to make eye contact with him.

Jose was apparently unaware of my presence, aided by the iPod earbuds that were planted in his ears. I faintly detected hearing a strange combination of salsa and mariachi music.

"Jose!" Jonathan said loudly. "HOOOOOO-ZZZZAAAAYYYYYY"

I reached over and popped an earbud out of Jose's left ear. Jose stood straight up, nearly knocking me over.

"Mister Allison! Hello! I was just looking over the inventory reports from yesterday." Jose said . It was obvious to everyone in attendance at Jose's impromptu siesta that he had been sleeping.

"Jose, this is the Chief. He needs to ask you some questions about inventory control procedures." Jonathan said in a slightly irritated tone.

"Of course! Chief, have a seat. I will assist you in any way possible." Jose said as he sat back down, nearly missing his own chair.

Jonathan glared at Jose for a few moments and then walked back towards his office.

"Jose, what can you tell me about these boxes labeled 'En route'?" I asked as I drew Jose's attention to the report in my hand.

Without missing a beat, Jose replied immediately. "Oh, that is easy. Those are boxes that were put on the morning truck."

I was practicing my best 'Scooby-Doo WHATTHEHELLAREYOUTALKINGABOUT' face.

"I beg your pardon? These boxes are on the morning truck? Their contents haven't been destroyed yet." I said.

Jose stared at the report very carefully. He was very quiet.

If I had learned anything in many years of investigation, it was how to recognize the face of someone who wanted to tell me something that they knew they shouldn't. Jose's face was screaming louder than a blond extra on the set of a horror movie.

"Jose, if you know where these boxes are going, I'd really like you to tell me. I won't tell anyone that you told me. Not even Jonathan." I said with a sincere stare.

Jose looked up from the report and looked around the room, almost as if he were scanning it for eavesdroppers.

"Chief, those boxes really are on the trucks and 'En route'."

I sat up in my chair and leaned forward towards Jose.

"I don't understand what you're trying to tell me. The boxes are on the morning truck and 'En route'? En route back to the customer?" I asked

"They are." Jose said with a frown. "After a pitstop."

Part VI

I was feeling a bit dizzy. It wasn't from the coffee I had earlier, but Jose's knack for talking in circles.

"Pitstop?" I queried. "What exactly do you mean by a 'pitstop'?"

Jose became quiet again, nervously tapping on his desk."I mean that the boxes... well, they make a little stop, then they come back, and that's it."

I was losing my patience after digesting that last bit of nonsense from Jose. Two can play at his game.

"So, let me see if I understand this correctly. The boxes are taken off the truck, scanned into inventory, and then put on the morning truck, and then come back and mysteriously end up back in inventory?" I asked.

"Yes." Jose replied.

"Good. And then, the most senior processor on staff is let go for violating corporate policy, however he gets a small confidential severance package for helping identify the rest of the individuals and recovery of any customer assets?" I pondered out loud, staring at the top of Jose's head.

Jose was quiet again.

"I don't want to be in trouble."

I screamed a silent victory yell inside. A crack had formed in Jose's circular logic eggshell.

"You're going to be in trouble no matter what Jose. The tracking logs don't lie. You haven't been able to produce a business reason why these boxes are loaded back onto a truck and disappear, only to reappear later." I said as I continued to stare at Jose. "All of these boxes were scheduled for formal, documented destruction. Why are they being taken offsite?"

Jose stood up from his chair and placed his iPod on his desk, neatly laying the earbuds next to it. He walked towards a storage room and badged himself in.

I followed.

Jose pointed to a row of shelves in the storage room. There were empty places on several shelves where boxes should have been.

"These boxes are scheduled for destruction tomorrow. The missing boxes are on the morning truck." Jose informed me as he jiggled the locks on several boxes on his way out of the room.

"Where's the truck at now?" I asked, following Jose out of the storage room.

"It's backed up to the dock. Everyone has gone home by now. We'll need to have Jonathan open up the lockbox to get into the truck." Jose said as he sat back down.

"You mean I'll need to have Allison open up the lockbox." I replied sarcastically as I realized that Jose was not wanting to attract any more attention to himself than necessary.

"Yep."

I was drunk with questions. What was in these particular boxes? Why were they so valuable? What was being done with the contents?

A few minutes later, Jonathan and I were inside their lockup room and Jonathan opened a lockbox located on the far side of the room.

"We can unlock the truck with these." Jonathan said as he removed some keys from the lockbox and headed toward the dock.

After a few moments we were opening the large roll-up door to the dock and were staring at the back of an Allison Technologies transport truck.

Jonathan inserted the key into the back of the truck, and with several turns opened the back door of the truck. I turned on a small flashlight that I had brought with me and gazed around the interior of the truck.

There were several boxes lined up next to each other along the right side of the truck. I compared the inventory tag numbers on the boxes to the missing boxes from the report. Jose was correct, these boxes were missing from today's deliveries. According to the report, the boxes were from different companies.

Jonathan reached into his pocket and removed a cylindrical looking key.

"What's that?" I asked as I saw Jonathan crouch down in front of one of the boxes.

"A destroyer's key." Jonathan said as he unlocked and opened each of the boxes.

"Well, that's a shocker."

Jonathan motioned for me to look in the boxes.

They were stuffed with high-capacity backup tapes.

Part VII

"Dude, you look frazzled." Scrap said as we sat down in the booth at a nearby restaurant for some well-deserved dinner.

"You have no idea. I am starting to regret taking this job." I replied as I rolled my eyes.
"Already there, man. Time for a recap?" Scrap asked. "When you returned from playing around on the dock you looked like you wanted to pull your hair out."

I rubbed my eyes and let out a chuckle. "I haven't been this frustrated since the time you got us kicked out of that 'entertainment club' in Vegas and you hurled in the rental car."

"Say what?" Scrap asked.

"Nothing. Look, let's analyze what we've seen so far. Jonathan knows that something unusual is going on in his company. Concerned employees have pointed this out to him, yet for some reason he is unable to pinpoint the exact problem or the perpetrators responsible. He brings us in to penetrate his facility, which we do ... no, wait ... which he KNEW we could do, and then acts surprised when he finds out that a lot more of these storage boxes go 'temporarily' missing on a routine basis. We track down a few of these missing boxes thanks to an employee who is scared to death of Jonathan and perhaps other employees, and Jonathan has access to a destroyer's key set, which according to his own policies should not be possible. Only designated employees responsible for material destruction have those keys, and they back each other up. Nobody outside of the destroyer job profile should have those keys. Hell, even the keyholder of the company is a destroyer. The controls were designed well, but there is an obviously poor execution of them here." I whined.

Scrap reached for one of the beers that magically appeared on the table in front of us thanks to an alert waitress. "Don't forget about me almost being dog food, man. It's a good thing we used that badge to go in the back way. So what does Jonathan want to do now? I'm sure he said something to you after you two found those boxes in the back of the truck."

"It's a flippin' goose chase Scrap. Through our investigation we managed to find the evidence that shows that a problem exists and is far worse than Jonathan thought. We have an employee, Jose, who will probably cooperate and point fingers. I told Jonathan that we should do surveillance, leverage Jose's possible cooperation, and discover why boxes only containing backup tapes are leaving the facility. You'll never guess what he said!" I exclaimed.

"He saved money on his car insurance?" Scrap joked.

"He said that he'll think about it. He'll THINK about it. I want to slam my head into a wall." I said as I downed the rest of my delicious malted beverage and signaled the waitress for another round.

"I don't mean to point out the obvious here, boss, but Jonathan appears to either be the most incompetent business owner on earth, or he has a few tassels missing from his bra - so to speak." Scrap said as he made 'coo-coo' images with his hands.

*RING*

My pseudo-drunken conversation with Scrap was interrupted by a unknown number calling my cellphone.

"Chief."

I could barely hear the caller due to a lot of background noise.

"Uh, Chief? This is Jose. I can't lose my job, I have a family to support. I can tell you exactly what you want to know, but you have to go to bat for me with Jonathan." Jose pleaded on the phone.

My eyes widened. Could this phone conversation with Jose get us out of this doomed assignment?

"Jose, I will do everything I can to promote your cooperation with this investigation with Jonathan. You have my solid word on that." I replied.

"I appreciate that Chief. I am glad you gave me your business card before you left. I apologize for acting weird while you were here."

My blood was pumping. "Jose, Jonathan and I found those boxes in the truck just as you said we would. What is on the backup tapes in those boxes that is so important?"

Jose paused.

"Chief, they don't want what is ON the tapes. They want the TAPES."

I anxiously awaited the next round of beers.

Part VIII

"I. Hate. This. Assignment." I said as I smacked my forehead into the table.

"Whoa, whoa there big guy. You're going to spill my beer. So what did Jose tell you?" Scrap asked as he grasped his beer glass with both hands, coddling it as if to prevent losing a drop of the hoppy, golden contents.
"Jose gave me some names, but I'm not sure if I quite understand the tale he was weaving on the phone." I said as I scratched my frazzled hair with a monkey paw.

"Spill it." Scrap demanded as he lit a cigarette.

"According to our little insider, there are two employees primarily involved. Both of the employees are processors, however one has somehow come into possession of a destroyer's key. This is clearly against company policy and completely undermines the established chain of custody procedure." I said in disbelief.

"Nice." Scrap said as he sipped his beer.

"Oh wait, it gets better! The bar scanner that the processors use to check the boxes in and out of the facility displays the customer name. The processors stack certain company boxes in a specific place. The other boxes are placed into the storage rooms in their inventoried places. The remaining boxes are placed on a morning truck by the processors. One of the processors is an 'early bird' and gets to work before the others. He meets the driver on the dock, unlocks the truck, unlocks the boxes, locks the truck and the driver drives away!" I exclaimed.

"No. Way." Scrap said as he accidentally extinguished his cigarette in his beer instead of the ashtray. "Dammit! I hate it when I do that. So what happens to the boxes after they leave the facility?"

I thought for a moment, trying to recollect everything that Jose had shared with me in our phone conversation.

"The driver makes a stop at the other processor's house and unloads the tapes out of the boxes. The tapes are placed into cardboard boxes in the other processor's garage. The driver then makes his other stops for the day and returns with the boxes. The boxes go directly from the truck back into the storage rooms." I said.

"Wait a second. So the inventory controller, Jose, is marking these as being 'en route' which is Allison Technology language for 'still on the truck'. This way they don't appear 'unaccountable', right? Friggin' smooth." Scrap said with a loud belch.

"Exactly. Jose didn't have a lot of the details that I was really looking for, but we do have some leads to go on now." I replied.

"Why do I get the feeling we'll be snooping around Allison Technologies tomorrow to build this case?" Scrap moaned.

The next morning, Scrap and I returned to Allison Technologies and arranged a short meeting with the office manager, Janelle. Jose was only able to give me first names, which I assumed was because of intimidation or he really didn't know.

Jonathan had given us carte blanche access to company records, so Janelle sat us down in front of a workstation and access to their employee records system. Ironically, the very software I was navigating through was the same software that Allison had removed from the market years ago.

I searched for all current employees with a first name of "Tomas", which returned a single record: Tomas Tomason. Tomas had been with the company since the "software days" as Jonathan referred to them. I added the Tomason record to the print queue and proceeded with my next search: Jeffry. A single record was returned.

"Oh this just gets better and better." I said as I laid my head on the desk.

"What now? What's the dude's name?" Scrap asked as he maneuvered behind me for a better look.

Jeffry Allison.

Part IX

"Holy canceled bar tab! You think he's related to Jonathan?" Scrap said as he scratched his eyebrow with a pencil.

"Ya think?" I said as I rolled my eyes. "Janelle? Is Jeffry related to Jonathan Allison?"

Janelle wandered over from her desk and looked at the employee record on my screen. "Oh yes. That is Mr. Allison's brother. He's been here forever."

Scrap quietly chuckled until I fed him an elbow into the ribs.

"Dude, this is pretty messed up right here. So let's see - you have Jeffry, Tomas, Jose and the unidentified driver all in on this?" Scrap said as he rubbed his bruised rib.

"Yep. I think we need to go old school on this." I said as I jotted down the names of all TA truck drivers. "And we're going to need a little professional help."

Scrap and I excused ourselves outside of the TA building. While Scrap lit a cigarette, I scrolled through phone numbers on my Treo looking for an old, reliable friend named Jon Voyte. Jon was a [[private investigator]] that specialized in [[surveillance]] and had helped me out on several previous cases including The Case Of The Heartless Husband .

I selected Jon's number on my Treo and listened to it ring a number of times.

"Jon speaking."

I cleared my throat. "Jon, it's Chief. Is there anyway you could meet me at Allison Technologies tomorrow evening? I know it's short notice."

Jon paused for a moment as he checked his schedule.

"I think I could do that. What's the gig, and how much?" Jon asked. I could hear the smile on his face.

"Standard fee. We have a real cartoon show here to monitor." I said as I described the events of the case.

"What a nightmare." Jon said. "I can deploy all the [[wireless cameras]] you want, and we can place the digital recorder in a vehicle outside. You know me, I can rig anything."

I laughed. "You don't have to brag to me. I like the idea of placing the recorder in a vehicle, I'm not sure how safe it would be in the building. You may have to babysit."

"I'm cool with that. Now let's talk strategy." Jon suggested.

An hour later the plan was formed, and Scrap & I decided to prepare for a bit of impromptu surveillance in the morning.

"Do I need to pick up coffee and doughnuts in the morning?" Scrap said with a
hearty laugh. "This is straight out of a bad police show."

"I have you covered. Just bring your camera, and make sure you get some sleep tonight. No late night IRC chatting with babes!" I demanded while waving my cell phone around.

Tomorrow morning was garage sale time.

Part X

"What was going through Jonathan Allison's head? What, indeed!" I thought to myself after waking up the next morning. Jonathan had asked for daily status reports, and I gave him a brief update that lacked a lot of detail.Scrap and I had planned to arrive at Allison Technologies in the early morning hours before any of the employees arrived for work. Our plan was to keep an eye on the 'morning truck' and see where it went, who was involved, and accumulate some of the missing pieces of this disastrous case.

I left my hotel room before the sun started it's long journey up into the sky. After a quick stop at the holy green bean sanctuary and a small bakery, I headed towards Scrap's apartment. The aroma of freshly brewed java goodness and sugar-encrusted baked goods filled my car.

As I guided my car into the parking lot adjacent to Scrap's apartment, I noticed that he was waiting for me in the usual spot, his camera bag slung over his shoulder.

"Yo. Doughnuts! Sweet. You ready to do this?" Scrap asked in between bites of chewy glazed doughnut.

"As ready as I'll ever be. The truck is scheduled to leave at seven o'clock, so we'll position ourselves across and down the street so we'll have a good view of the perimeter with the binoculars." I replied as I began sipping on my coffee cup.

We reached Allison Technologies in record time, and positioned the car with a view behind the building and across the street. No signs of life were present. I manned the binoculars while Scrap checked the battery life of his camera.

"We have movement." I said as I watched a sedan enter the back gate. I glanced down at the employee records that I had printed out in Janelle's office. There was no mistaking the driver of the car - it was Jeffry Allison.

Jeffry badged into the back door. Over the next thirty minutes, several other employees parked their cars in the rear parking lot and entered through the back door including Tomas Tomason and one of the registered drivers - Pah Manderson.

Scrap glanced at his watch. "Anytime! Come on guys, let's get this dog show rolling."

"Patience, Scrap. This is America. Nobody leaves on time." I joked as I poured myself another cup of Starbucks goodness from the large brown container.

Moments later, Pah approached the cab of the truck and started up the diesel engine. Jeffry walked to the driver's door and had a brief conversation with Pah. Scrap was busy taking pictures.

"Ok, here we go." I said as I watched the AT truck drive down the street. I positioned myself several car lengths back behind the truck.

"Dude, we look like thugs." Scrap joked. We were both wearing sunglasses, baseball caps and jackets.

I cut Scrap's joke session short as the AT truck pulled into a residential neighborhood. The truck drove down several blocks and made an abrupt right turn into a cul-de-sac. I drove by the the cul-de-sac and performed a U-turn, placing our vehicle within eyeshot of the back of the AT truck.

"Who the hell is that?" Scrap asked as he snapped more pictures of Pah opening the back of the truck and patting another man on the back. The stranger had wandered out from the garage in a pair of sweats and a baseball cap, cigarette and coffee in hand.

I aimed my binoculars carefully and focused on the stranger's face. I then rummaged through my pile of employee records from AT.

"Chief, they are pulling boxes." Scrap said as he continued to snap pictures and adjust the focus on his camera.

I peered through my binoculars to see Pah and the stranger taking several boxes from the back of the AT truck and carrying them into the garage. Once in the garage, the stranger was emptying the tapes from the inside and placing them in large cardboard boxes. The empty boxes were returned to the truck.

"Hmmm. Just as Jose described, right down to the boxes being unlocked!" I mumbled. The stranger followed Pah back to the driver's side of the truck and had a brief conversation before Pah climbed back into the cab of the truck, waved, and drove around the inside of the cul-de-sac in an attempt to turn the truck around.

"We're out of here." I said as I placed the car in reverse and left in the opposite direction. "Did you get pictures of the stranger?" I asked Scrap.

"Did I!" Scrap replied. "Dude, I got pictures of his nasty noise hairs."

Well, that was too much information.

Several miles down the road I spotted a local coffee shop called "Empty Mug". Not a very appealing name, but they served coffee.

Scrap and I took up residence at a table outside of the coffee shop. I grabbed us two cups of fresh house blend, and Scrap proceeded to hook up his camera to his laptop.

"Funny - this camera costed me more than the laptop." Scrap commented as he started the picture import process.

I opened my laptop bag and pulled out my folder of employee records. I stared at the faces, trying to make a mental map of their features.

"Okay boss, here's your stranger." Scrap said as he zoomed in on a picture of the stranger having a conversation with Pah.

I looked at the employee records again, dropping most of them on the floor. Scrap began to fidget in his chair.

"Uh, boss. This is impossible, but I swear that's Tomas Tomason!" Scrap exclaimed.

I raised an eyebrow.

"That is impossible. Tomas checked into work shortly after Jeffry and didn't leave the building before the truck." I responded.

It would appear that Tomas had a twin.

Part XI

Naps are perhaps one of an investigator's best friends. Scrap and I had returned to Scrap's apartment for some much needed rest and relaxation, and were both sound asleep. Well, I was trying to sleep during Scrap's snoring rendition of "The Overture of 1812". Scrap had passed out on his couch, while I took up residence in his easy chair.*RING*

"Now where did I put my cell phone?" I pondered as I searched for the source of the electronic ring.

"Chief." I said into my treo as I wiped the sleep from my eyes.

"I'm in town. When do you want to do this?" came a familiar voice from the other end of the cellular signal. It was Jon!

"Well, it's closing in on five o'clock now. Let's plan to meet at Allison Technologies at eight." I replied with a quick glance at the "Coyote Ugly" clock on Scrap's wall.

"Roger that. See you then." Jon said as he hung up.

I heard a stirring sound from behind me. It appeared that Snoralupicus had awoken.

"I feel like crap." Scrap moaned as he reached for his water bottle on his coffee table.

"Too much late night IRC?" I joked.

"No, about this whole 'Tomas' business, boss. Any theories?" Scrap asked with a swig of water.

I had been giving that very topic a lot of thought, and flipped through the Allison Technologies employee files that I had printed out earlier. A quick glance at Tomas's file made me smile.

"Tomas's emergency contact is a 'Jerry Tomason'." I read out loud. "Any bets Tomas has a brother?"

Scrap thought for a moment. "Or a same-named lover?"

That's Scrap, always thinking outside the box.

Eight o'clock came fast, and we were parked outside the rear entrance of Allison Technologies. A white sedan pulled up behind us, and a shadowy figure emerged. Jon had an equipment bag slung over his shoulder, and appeared to have lost his razor.

"Nice beard." I cracked as we shook hands.

"The wife likes it." Jon replied with a grin.

We made our way into the building and surveyed the premises with Jon. Jon was making notes in a notepad and taking measurements.

"Here's my plan." Jon said, referring to his notes. "I'm going to set up wireless cameras here, here, and here placed covertly in the false ceiling tiles.
