We're going to have a 'birds-eye view' of the activities that you were concerned about. I'm going to set up a test unit first so we can make sure that our receiver is going to get enough signal."

"Awesome. What about battery life?" I asked. The units looked very small. I wondered how much power they required?

"We're covered on battery life for twenty-four hours. I have battery packs for everything, man." Jon responded in a confident voice. If Jon said we were covered, then I had no doubts.

Scrap wandered down the hallway and sat the receiver on a storage room table. Jonathan Allison had given us permission to take over a storage room as a base of operations, eliminating the need to keep the receiver outside in a vehicle.

"Hey Chief! I can see the top of your monkey head!" Scrap yelled out the door.

Nice.

Jon finished his installations and tests in record time. We had enough storage space on the receiver for forty-eight hours, much more space than we had battery life.

We thanked Jon for his assistance and made plans to recover the equipment before the weekend, in approximately two days. I locked the storage room door with a set of keys that Jonathan Allison had eagerly provided me. Jonathan assured me there were no other keys to this door. I wanted to believe Jonathan, but if experience had taught me anything, I never believed anyone. I removed a roll of clear marking tape from my pocket and created a transparent seal at the top of the door. This tape was similar to "warranty return" tape that one might find on the box of a very expensive piece of electronic equipment. The clear tape had a hard to see insignia pattern printed on it. If the door was opened before our return, it would be quite obvious, and difficult to 'fix'.

Several hours later Scrap and I were back at Scrap's apartment writing up our activities for the day.

"Hey, this is interesting." Scrap said as he scrolled through a web page on his trusty Scraptop.

"What's that?" I asked, trying to maintain my train of thought.

"You said that Tomas's 'brother' was named Jerry Tomason, right?" Scrap asked.

"Yep. Why?" I queried as my eyes focused squarely on Scrap's chimp-like face.

"Well, according to Google, Jerry is the owner and operator of a computer salvage company about ten miles away." Scrap replied as he turned his laptop to face me. "And you'll never guess what inventory item he seems to have an abundance of?"

Very expensive backup tapes.

Part XII

The weekend arrived with haste. Scrap and I had maintained a low profile during the past few days using our time to create necessary case file documentation, and to theorize about our current train wreck of a case."Come on Chief, he has to know." Scrap said as he pushed a pile of geek magazines off of a nearby sofa cushion to make room for his monkey behind side.

"Know what? That he has a bunch of scheming freaks working for him?" I retorted as I cracked open a fresh bottle of Starbucks coffee-flavored Frappuccino. "Or that his brother is possibly neck deep in doo-doo?"

"That's what I'm saying, man. Jonathan is 'the man' at this company. Nobody can have their head in the sand that deep." Scrap said with a shake of his long, mop-like hair. "He called you in to be the bad guy and do all the dirty work. It's like Miami Vice, boss. You're Sonny, I'm Tubbs and neither one of dress that well."

I laughed quietly. Perhaps Scrap was on to something.

*RING*

"Chief." I said into my cell phone.

"Okay dude, it's Saturday morning. Are we going in to recover my gear?" Jon said impatiently. I had a feeling Jon's wife wanted him back home to take care of his "honey do" list.

"You got it. Meet us down there in an hour?" I asked, motioning Scrap to get our gear ready.

"Check. I need to leave shortly after lunch." Jon said as he hung up.

Apparently Jon was under the impression that I was buying him lunch.

"Did you say something about food?" Scrap said as tossed me my laptop bag.

An hour later we arrived at Allison Technologies to find Jon waiting patiently by his sedan. We marched into the building and approached the storage room where we had left the recording device. I glanced at the doorframe, carefully inspecting my makeshift tamper detector.

It was intact.

I removed the tamper seal, leaving a mess of sticky tape residue on the door's frame. Jonathan would understand.

We entered the room, and Jon sat down in front of the recorder. He opened his notebook and started taking notes on the current date and time. Jon attached a portable monitor to the recorder and started scrolling through the time lapsed images.

"There." Jon said as he pointed to the screen and scribbled more notes. "There's your truck arriving right on time."

The series of events that we then witnessed were exactly as Jose had described. Tomas and Jeffry assisted Pah in unloading the contents of the truck. Some boxes were sorted into a smaller pile towards the left of the screen, the rest were sorted into a larger pile on the right and scanned with an inventory gun. Jeffry moved the boxes on the right side of the screen into a nearby secure storage room. The boxes on the left side were placed back in the truck.

Jon scrolled through some uninteresting footage until he arrived at Jose in the secure storage room. Jose performed some arbitrary tasks on his workstation, and then walked to the back of the truck. He then proceeded to scan the boxes on the truck, and return to the storage room. For the next ten minutes, Jose worked diligently on his workstation and then appeared to go home.

"How much do you want to bet that if we pull the tag numbers on the boxes in the truck and check their status in the inventory system, they are labeled 'en route'?" I said to Scrap with a wink as I removed my cell phone from its carrying case.

"God I hope you're ordering lunch." Scrap joked.

"Nope, I'm calling Jonathan; and I'm about to give him a real upset stomach." I said.

***

Coming up: The Conclusion!

Conclusion

I could hear his footsteps coming down the hall; rhythmic, squeaky, and filled with anticipation. Jonathan Allison rounded the corner and practically leapt into the storage room that we called headquarters.
"Chief, Scrap ... I don't believe that I know this other person." Jonathan said as he extended his hand to Jon.

"Jon is a surveillance expert. The best I've ever worked with." I said as I inflated Jon's already enormous ego another ten p.s.i. "Jonathan, Scrap & Jon have some tasks to do. Can we talk in your office?"

"Certainly." Jonathan replied as he lead the way to his office.

I closed the door to Jonathan's office behind me and created a butt impression on a nearby leather chair.

"You said this was urgent?" Jonathan asked as he folded his arms neatly on his desk.

"Is anything wrong?"

I shot Jonathan my best poker face, my eyes revealing nothing.

"There's very clearly something going on here at Allison Technologies. There is an organized effort to steal magnetic backup tapes placed in your care and resell them on the second-hand market." I began. "And somehow, Jonathan, I think you already knew that."

Jonathan stared at his desk.

"Perhaps."

I raised my voice slightly. "And 'perhaps' you left out several critical facts from this case, like your brother being an employee?"

Jonathan continued to stare a hole through the desk with his incredible powers of concentration.

"You hired me to investigate the disappearance of company assets. I know who's involved, I know what assets are being removed from the premises, I think I even understand their business plan. But what I don't understand is why am I here in the first place?" I asked.

Jonathan peered up at me, obviously aware of his need to 'come clean'.

"Chief, first off, let me say that I now know why you come so highly recommended. In a matter of a week you figured out a situation that took me months to uncover. However, things are much more complex than you may think." Jonathan said quietly as he stood up and walked towards the window in his office.

"Jeffry?" I queried.

"Jeffry. Jeffry is my brother. I love my brother, but he's completely worthless. If it wasn't for me giving Jeffry jobs and bailing him out of jail in his younger years he'd probably be sharing a cell with a car thief right about now. Jeffry is the youngest sibling I have, Chief. Everyone in my family feels sorry for Jeffry, and respects me for giving him a job. However, when I mentioned to my parents that Jeffry was screwing up again and stealing from me, they became upset and told me to overlook his faults. They told me to transfer him to another job and give him another chance." Jonathan lamented, his voice full of disgust.

"You didn't want to be the bad guy in a bad situation. You bring me in as a consultant, and I uncover the great scheme to make money on the side at work." I said.

"Correct. I could terminate Jeffry and his coworkers and not be the bad guy. Most of Jeffry's coworkers are friends of his that I hired as a favor to Jeffry." Jonathan replied.

"What about Jose? Jose was most helpful, and appears to be cooperating with the others out of fear?" I asked Jonathan.

"Jose has worked here a long time, and I know that Jeffry bullies him. Jose has a huge family to support, and Jeffry know that; and he exploits that. He's a good guy, and I plan on taking care of him." Jonathan said as he peered out of the window.

I breathed a sigh of relief. Jose had been cooperating with me under the assumption that Jonathan would seek no retribution against him. This was good news.

I suddenly remembered that I should be reviewing my notes on my notepad and actively engaging Jonathan in conversation, rather than daydreaming.

"My team and I have performed a lot of research and field work in the past week. We know that customer tapes are being removed from your trucks and placed in a garage that belongs to Tomas' brother Jerry. Jerry owns a computer recycling business. My associate, Scrap, visited Jerry's recycle center yesterday and located one of ten tapes that we had tagged with a dye marker. The tape was one of many that we found in the boxes that we opened in the truck earlier in the week. Careful examination of the tape showed that data from one of your customers was present. We're talking one serious exposure of customer data." I said as I flipped through several more pages of notes.

"Yes, you are correct. The guys ... they all knew the procedures here well enough that they knew how to safely get around them. They were targeting companies that shipped us almost brand-new high-capacity tapes for destruction. The tapes were typically in a storage rotation of a year's cycle, from what I could tell. The tapes that they wanted to steal were scanned into the system as received using the driver's gun, and then Jose would mark them as 'en route' in the system so they wouldn't come up missing. The tapes were driven to Jerry's house, and then the boxes were returned with a few tapes clanging around in the bottom. When the tape boxes came back and were checked back in, the destroyers simply opened the boxes, scanned the remaining tapes in the box, and ran them through the destruction machines. Our system always showed the tapes as destroyed. That's what made it so hard for me to track down initially." Jonathan said as he sat back down.

"Well, I can't say this has been the most entertaining goose chase I've ever been on. You have quite the barrel of monkeys here, Jonathan. I hope you have a good attorney on retainer and a strong management team behind you. You have a few customers that aren't going to be happy when they find out that their backup tapes were being sold as second-hand flea market specials." I said.

Jonathan was looking more stressed as I spoke.

"However, my team will have a report complete with electronic media delivered to you on Monday afternoon. I'll send you a bill for the remainder of my fee and expenses." I said as I got up from my chair and wandered towards the door.

"Thanks for all your hard work." Jonathan said as sprang from his chair and shook my hand. "I'm sorry I didn't tell you everything at the beginning of this, but I didn't know if you'd stick around after you heard the whole story."

"No worries Jonathan. You and the rest of your management team will have all the ammunition you need in the reports and video files on Monday. Oh, and Jonathan ..." I said as I opened the door.

"Yes?" Jonathan asked curiously.

I reached into my pocket and tossed Jonathan the Allison Technologies badge and lanyard that Scrap and I had lifted earlier in the week.

"You might want to give this employee back her badge."

***

Scrap and I practically did cartwheels after we left AT for the last time. We were very eager to completely wash our hands of this case. As a very clever reader noted in a comment on our last case file posting, this was a case of family politics. Jeffry was the bad seed, Jonathan wanted to fire him but didn't want the pressure of being the bad guy.

Jonathan, along with his two attorneys, started a marathon of contacting law enforcement, having Jeffry, Tomas, Pah & Jerry arrested for theft and sale of stolen goods, Jeffry, Tomas & Pah were obviously terminated immediately (Jonathan was careful to delete their badge access), and several law suits were filed against AT by customers over the theft of their tapes and potential information disclosure.

New case file next week!

~ Chief

Case of the Leaky Leaf

Part I

"Four hundred clams?" I thought as I stared at the price tag of the combination coffee/cappucino machine. I was wandering around a local department store in desperate need of a new coffee machine.
I had recently taken a much-deserved break from field work. While I had a lot more time to concentrate on life matters, I was realizing quickly that my bank account was starting to look a little pale.

*RING*

A quick glance at my cell phone showed me that I had an incoming call from Scrap.

"What the hell do you want?" I joked. "I'm shopping."

Scrap cleared his throat.

"Boss, you are not going to believe this, but I have a 'live one' here. I'm two days into my gig here at Treesoft, and this job has exploded into something much, much bigger. I'm going to need your assistance. This isn't exactly a small video game developer." Scrap said as he blew cigarette smoke into the mouthpiece of his cell phone. "And you need to get here with a serious quickness."

I closed my eyes and let out a sigh.

"Scrap, I'd love to help but I have a million things going on, a coffee machine to buy, and I just picked up a new X-box game. I'm booked!" I said as I exited the department store and headed for my vehicle.

"Chief, seriously. You need to get on a plane and meet me here tomorrow." Scrap begged.

It was not like Scrap to beg like this. Something must be up.

"Okay, you went to Treesoft to meet with the president of the company and do a risk assessment. That's all I remember. How did this assessment get out of hand?" I asked as I climbed into the driver's seat of my vehicle.

"Let me put it this way, I spent my first day giving presentations to executives. The second day, I was doing interviews with staff members and my cell phone rings. The president and General Counsel of Treesoft wanted me in a boardroom in ten minutes." Scrap said, excitement building in his voice.

"And? AND?" I cried as I maneuvered my way onto the freeway. "Out with it man! What happened?"

Scrap inserted a dramatic pause. "Apparently a customer of theirs sent them some disturbing documents that they found on the internet through a Google search. I looked through some of the documents, and it's everything from company memos to source code!"

"Ah." I thought to myself, "confidential information flapping in the wind of cyberspace."

I put on my turn signal and exited the freeway.

"Scrap, are you thinking network penetration? Unhappy employee? Network gnomes? What?" I asked.

"I'm not really sure yet. News of the leaked documents has already hit some gamer news sites. We need to move fast." Scrap said.

I walked into my house, quickly grabbing my laptop and travel bags.

"I'll be there tonight. I'll call you when my plane lands." I said as I hung up.

With any luck I'd get a seat on the last flight out.


Part II

"Christmas? No, it was Thanksgiving!" I mumbled quietly to myself shortly after my plane touched down. I was trying to remember the last day that I had actually slept more than four hours in a row.


Sleep is the one luxury that most investigators don't get a lot of. During the deepest of slumbers, their minds are constantly working cases. "Did I check all of the slack space on that captured drive? Did I interview all of the maintenance staff? Did I zip my pants up before or after I set that last coffee free?"

After carefully locating all of my carryon baggage, I made my way to the airport's food court. I was in luck; a Starbucks with a chinese food take-out located within fifty feet. After scoring a piping hot cup of java sweetness and a tray of orange chicken, I was on the phone to Scrap.

Well, I would have been on the phone to Scrap if I had brought my spare cell phone battery.

Damn.

I inhaled my chinese food and savored every last drop of my perfect house blend before scampering off to find an electrical outlet to plug my phone in to. I was having no luck until a green-aproned Goddess of the bean stepped in.

"Do you need to plug that phone in, hon?" she asked as she pointed to an empty electrical receptacle behind the Starbucks counter. "Let me hook you up with another coffee."

Great saints of caffeine, I was saved!

I plugged the A/C adapter into my phone and placed a quick call to Scrap.

"Jeez boss, what took you so long? Your plane landed an hour ago!" Scrap whined. The faint sound of traffic could be heard in the background. "I've been circling this airport forever. You know where to meet!"

I thanked my sweet savior one last time with a generous tip in the tip jar and made my way to the arrivals curb.

"YO!" Scrap yelled as he did an impressive power slide into the empty curb in front of me.

Several minutes later we were on the road and headed to Scrap's hotel.

"Details man. What's going on?" I asked impatiently.

"You're going to love this!" Scrap said as he rolled down the window an inch and lit a cigarette. "So, Treesoft has been working on this major new console title for Majorcorp for about year now. Well, one of the reasons I'm doing this risk assessment is because Majorcorp is going to purchase Treesoft."

I looked unimpressed. "Scrap, everyone knows that Majorcorp is going to buy Treesoft."

"Wait! I haven't even gotten to the good stuff yet. A year ago, Treesoft went from two hundred employees to three hundred employees. They started leasing a ton of office space, and they purchased an unreal amount of computing equipment." Scrap said as he smashed his cigarette butt into the ashtray.

"Good grief. You think they are inflating the company to up the purchase price and the perceived value of the company?" I asked.

Scrap laughed. "Hey, I'm not that smart. I didn't figure this out. It was in one of the memos that ended up on the internet. So the Treesoft guys are in a panic. They think the deal is going to cave in, and they want answers yesterday."

"Interesting. So where are you at in your assessment?" I queried as I started taking notes on a fresh notepad.

"I have most of the requested documentation together. They provided that when I walked in the door. I was about a quarter through the interviews when the suits pulled me aside to tell me about the leaked documents. I haven't had time to do anything else since I called you." Scrap said. "Now you know why I wanted you out here fast. This is getting uglier than those dancers in Atlanta that spilled beer on me."

I peered at Scrap through my sleepy eyes. Sometimes I just wanted to hit him.

An hour later, we were camped out in Scrap's hotel room developing our strategic plan. I took a moment to examine the documents retrieved from a website by some Treesoft customers. The website was a bulk file-sharing website called "FFS" or the "Freak'in Filesharing Site" that had a unique revenue scheme. Anyone could upload a file and get a unique URL to share with potential downloaders. However, the downloaders had to pay a monthly fee or they had to wait two minutes before the download would begin; plus, the download speed was throttled.

The documents were interesting. There were five documents total. Three were plain text files containing large amounts of what appeared to be game source code. The other two documents were Microsoft Word documents containing one Treesoft memo each.

The first memo was from the Treesoft CFO to the 'Executive Planning Staff' where he detailed a plan for 'sudden necessary growth' and 'necessary capital expenditures'. The second memo was from a project manager to a Vice President describing a dire situation with their upcoming release. Apparently the development team was several months behind in squashing critical bugs.

The plot thickens.

Discussion of Part II

Continuing our discussion from Part I of this Q/A session, I answer yet more reader questions!


Hill asks: This may have been answered earlier in your blogs, but I only started reading a few months ago. How do you get into this business? What experiance[sic], training do you have? How did you get started consulting, did you work under a mentor first, like Scrap? I'm all ears. And thanks for such an entertaining read.

Answer: This is the #1 question I am asked in the blog and in e-mail. My adventure in this type of business started just before the internet boom of the mid 90's. I had always been interested in computers, and have my father to thank for buying me my first personal computer: a Commodore Vic-20! I checked out every book on computer programming from the local library and got to work. Later in life, I continued my passion for computers and electronics through various learning experiences - and had my first run in with 'unauthorized use of an electronic system'. That's the nice way of saying that I got busted for gaining entry into a certain organization's VAX system through a modem and a username/password that they were nice enough to DISPLAY ON THE SCREEN AT LOGIN. Nope, I'm not making that up. Remember - this is a long time ago before computer security was the topic on everyone's lips.

Fast forward a few years through college, and I'm smack dab in the middle of desert shield/storm as a member of the US Military. Most of my work was in signal intelligence, but I was constantly being pulled away to set up IBM personal computers and 'network the SOB's together!' as my first seargent liked to say. It was at this point that I realized how serious computer security was - and, how to investigate unauthorized usage. This knowledge paid off in spades, as I was able to use my knowledge in other realms within the US military / federal service.

Moving the time wheel forward, I'm out of the military and employed with several internet startup companies. Most startups didn't have security as a line item in their business requirements (or their business plan for that matter). I spent a great deal of time redesigning networks with security in mind, and associating with knowledgeable folks on the internet. I went to every technical certification course I could, and later every security certification course I could afford. During the late 1990's, these types of certifications paid off nicely.

Consulting is a funny business. I started off doing consulting as a side project, and it eventually took over my life at some point - and strictly on a referral basis. However, constant travel and a heavy workload eventually took it's toll on my business and personal life. It was at this point that I decided to hand the majority of the consulting business off to associates (like Scrap) and concentrate my work on a single (albeit large) employer.

I had so many mentors through my journey that I couldn't possibly begin to name them all. I did have one cowboy though who taught me the most important lesson of them all: put your life first, your work second. I encourage you all to read that last part again until it sinks in. =)

I'm sure there will be more details in some sort of a published work eventually ...



Michael Boman asks Have you ever thought about having your casefiles produced as hardcopies? I sure wouldn't mind buying a hardcopy of the best casefiles over a year (for the right price), especially if they were edited to a "Hackers Challenge" kind of format. lulu.com offers on-demand printing so it would not require you to fork up any money up front.

Answer: Are you kidding? I've been working on it for what seems like an eternity. Luckily, most of the work that goes into these case files is 'timeless' so to speak. It's not like I'm writing a book on Office 2003 or anything. =) The book is a spare time project (remember that whole life before work thing?) and to put all your minds at ease - it's about 85% done at my last estimation. Publishing, well - that's a whole other topic. Thanks for the tip on lulu.com.



CBK asks When you're building a casefile do you start with a goal in mind (exposing wireless security) and pull pieces together or do you start with a case and pull bits and pieces in to flesh it out and add things?

Answer: Excellent question from a very loyal reader (yo!). As I'm sure every monkey knows, my writing is very monkey-formula. I start with pieces of cases scattered everywhere in front of me, and I try to piece things together to do two very important things: (1) Educate the reader and (2) Entertain the reader. Let me tell you, #2 is much harder than #1. I do have a goal that I write towards, and sometimes I actually write backwards (as another reader pointed out to me in e-mail recently). 75% of the work that goes into these case files is continuity checking - making sure that I drop clues at the right parts, and wrap them up at the end. I've had several readers ask "Why do you put the surprise stuff in the end like that? How can we solve the case w/o all the data being present?!?". Well, I'll be honest. I don't expect you to - however, it doesn't stop readers like TuxGirl from doing it on a regular basis. Part of the monkey-formula is pulled right out of the Scooby-Doo cartoon (no, I'm not making that up). One of the things that I loved about Scooby-Doo as a child was that there was always this killer revelation at the end that you couldn't have possibly picked up through the story. I'm quite sure that the writers did this to make Fred & the gang seem that much smarter. This is not my purpose. I'm just a monkey - I do it for the sheer hope that when the surprise happens, the *method* being described will stick in your brain, and you'll pull it out down the road on your own case.



Donathan writes I want to know of a case what went bad for you and/or Scrap. One that you couldn't solve, one that your findings/techniques were questioned, maybe the perp of the case went after you personally when you caught them. Basically, when all went down the toilet, how did/do you handle it?

Answer: Ho, boy. We have had some doozies. I have to save some of these for the book, but I'll share a quick summary of one. Scrap and I were tasked with investigating a bookkeeper who was 'cooking the books' at a consulting firm. The partners *knew* she was doing it, but they couldn't *prove* it with hardcore evidence. There were other complications: she was a minority, and played the minority card at every opportunity. The partners knew that unless they had a smoking gun, she would retain a lawyer and quite possibly put their consulting firm out of business. Scrap and I set up video surveillance, key-logged her workstation, and made nightly visits to the office to make forensic copies of her workstation's hard drive. One night while we were in the middle of an imaging session (we're talking 11PM at night), she visits the office with her 300-lb gangsta-looking boyfriend. When she saw what we were doing, we had to think quick. We passed ourselves off as computer repair people. She wasn't buying it. Homeboy had a gun stuck in the front of his trousers. (I'd like to point out that neither I nor Scrap have ever carried a weapon while consulting.) Scrap managed to distract them with some banter while I dialed one of the partners on my cell phone and left the line 'open' praying to all hell that he'd answer and know what I was doing. I lucked out - he figured it out and raced to the office. The rest of the story? Well, you'll have to keep reading the blog. =) I have never had my life threatened, however Scrap has - twice. Maybe you'll all understand why he disguises his voice on the podcasts now.



Case asks a fantastic question: In Leaky Leaf IX the Chief wrote about running an nslookup on the IP address found in the Limewire log:

scraptop:~ scrap$ nslookup 64.xx.xx.xx
Server: 10.0.1.9
Address: 10.0.1.9#53
Name: xx-xx-xx-64.gamersbeatches.net



Chief, although we see in the end that you verified the gamersbeatches.net connection with the corroberating e-mail evididence, were you ever concerned that TreeSoft's nameserver had been altered and was fed you a red herring? Do you ever double-check lookups by using non-internal nameservers?

Answer: It is part of our standard procedure to never trust a DNS server on a local net. Ever. I suppose I could have mentioned this as another lesson in the story - and I'm going to add this to my lessons to add to a future case file. In this circumstance, Scrap used a web browser and verified the DNS response with a well known lookup service. =)



Charlene asks: One thing I'd like to know. I've tried to figure out what was one of the first virii in existance.

I helped clean up one on a CDC 6400 back around 1978.

Answer: Wow! A CDC 6400? I've only read about them in books. =) To answer your question, I would like to refer you to The Computer Virus Timeline at infoplease.com. I'm not sure I could post a better answer than what you're going to read there. For those of you that haven't seen this - it starts in 1949!!!



I hope you've enjoyed this Q/A session. Please, post more questions as comments to this blog entry - you just might get an answer!

Next up - The Conclusion to Lascivious Lawyer !

~ Chief

Part III

The next morning was my introduction to the wonderful world of Treesoft.

"Where did these guys find their lawyers, Microsoft?" I wondered to myself quietly as I scanned several sheets of 8 1/2" by 11" paper with my newly-caffeinated eyes. Scrap and I were seated in a small conference room at Treesoft filling out non-disclosure agreements. Scrap was taking an extraordinary amount of time reviewing the last few paragraphs on the second page of the NDA.

"These guys are pretty serious, man." Scrap said pointing to a paragraph under his thumb that read:

"You acknowledge and agree that due to the unique nature of the Proprietary
Information, any breach of this agreement would cause irreparable harm to
Company for which damages are not an adequate remedy and that Company shall
therefore be entitled to equitable relief in addition to all other remedies
available at law."


I reviewed the paragraph out loud, and then sauntered back towards the beginning of page one.

"Scrap, this is the same NDA that Treesoft employees sign. Interesting."

We had barely finished signing and dating the documents before Treesoft's General Counsel, Ed Notincourt, appeared at the doorway.

"Guys, I have the executive staff assembled next door. Everything okay with the agreements? You ready?"

I handed Ed our documents as we left the conference room and rounded a sharp corner hallway into a much larger conference room.

The conference room was well lit and equipped with every type of presentation equipment imaginable. The executives stood up from behind their side of the large conference room table and we exchanged handshakes and business cards.

"Welcome, Chief! Your associate advised us that you would be joining us due to the recent events." said a very well-dressed man who identified himself as Pete Warginoff, the President and Chief Executive Officer of Treesoft.

"Thank you. I've had a change to catch up with Scrap and review the Treesoft documents that were sent to you. These appear to be rather sensitive in nature." I replied as I took my seat. "How can we be of assistance?"

Pete motioned to the casually-dressed gentleman sitting to his left, John Smackoff. John was one of the original founders of Treesoft and needed no introduction to anyone that had played a Treesoft title in the past five years. He had an almost religious following amongst some hardcore gamers.

"Chief, I've helped build Treesoft into the company that it is today. We started as two people working in my apartment years ago. I have made sure that any employee of Treesoft has a vested interest in the success of our titles and this company. It upsets me greatly to know that an outsider, or perhaps an insider, has passed these documents outside of our company at such a critical path in our future."

Ed cleared his throat removed his gold-rimmed glasses from his face. "We are in active negotiations with Majorcorp to be purchased very soon. The purchase would greatly benefit every employee of Treesoft, as they are all private shareholders of this company. It is our collective belief that someone gained access to our equipment and removed this information with the sole purpose of derailing this acquisition. The timing is just too coincidental to be anything else. We want you to follow-through with what Scrap had originally planned on doing; a risk assessment of our assets. However, we want you to expand this into a full investigation of how the information was retrieved, who retrieved it, and what their true motivation was."

I was scribbling on my notepad in a ferocious manner while trying to maintain eye contact with the executive team. I was hoping that none of them noticed how many times my pen had wandered off of my notepad and marked on their very expensive looking conference room table. Whoops.

The last remaining executive leaned forward in his chair and peered at me over the large smile that had engulfed the lower part of his face. Dave McEww was the Chief Financial Officer of Treesoft, and apparently spent a lot of his salary on haircare products.

"I'm going to send an email to our staff letting them know that you are here as part of the Majorcorp acquisition. You have full access to our resources. If at any time you run into resistance or have any questions, please let me know and I'll take care of you personally."

Somehow, that didn't make me feel any better. Dave was putting off a serious used-car salesman vibe.

"Thanks Dave. We're going to use a 'closing net' process. This means that we're going to start at the physical and electronic perimeters of your facility and network, and then move inward. We will provide you with daily status updates." Scrap said, almost as if he just woke up from a long nap.

Our meeting was interrupted by a knock at the conference room door. An attractive young woman entered the room and presented Pete with a document as she whispered in his ear and left as quickly as she entered. Pete's executive smile turned into a "we're all out of hazelnut creamer" frown as he slid the paper across the table to me.

It would appear that the stolen document count was now up to six.

Part IV

The sixth document appeared to be an 'open issues' list with Treesoft's next big title called "GLOOM". John motioned to me to pass the document to him."This is amazing. Our dirty laundry is getting aired out in the backyard of the internet." John said with an apathetic sigh.

"John, have you or any other member of the management team interviewed your employees regarding the documents? Perhaps a disgruntled employee is slowly releasing these documents in an effort to draw attention to problems within the company?" I asked.

John looked like I had called his mother a moose.

"That's ridiculous! We have a pretty tight-knit group here. If there were internal issues, someone would bring them to my attention. We are very employee friendly here. What hurts one of us hurts all of us." John said in a harsh tone.

Scrap and I excused ourselves from the meeting after discussing some logistical issues with the management team and retreated to the conference room to grab our stowed gear.

"All we need now is a tent." Scrap joked as he unpacked our equipment bags in the last remaining empty office at Treesoft. John had arranged for us to set up shop in an office near the development team.

Our first goal in this investigation was to isolate and contain the breach, if it existed. Scrap had provided me with a diagram of the Treesoft network to assist in my planning.

"According to this diagram, this network is very simple. There is a single connection to the internet via a high speed DSL connection. There is one router, one firewall, and a single core ethernet switch with multiple ethernet blades." I said as I traced my finger along the surface of the Visio document.

Scrap passed me another piece of paper filled with his monkey-scratch scribbling. "Correct, and they are using a NAT scenario to route two RFC-1918 address spaces; 10.0.1.0 and 10.0.2.0. All servers and a few workstations have static addresses on 10.0.1.1-10.0.1.128, and 10.0.1.129-10.0.1.254 and all of 10.0.2.0 appear to be DHCP."

"Alright, Scrap. We're closing the 'net' from the outside to the inside. What's your suggested plan of action?" I asked, testing Scrap's knowledge of our established procedures.

"First, I'm finding out what that attractive girl's name is that brought Peter that sixth document a few minutes ago. Secondly, I'm going to get her phone number. Thirdly, I'm going to ..."

"Scrap." I said, cutting him off in mid-sentence. "The network."

Scrap regained his composure. "Oh, right. The network. Locate all points of egress and ingress, attach a capture box to each point, assess the security of those points with the usual tools. Work backwards from the internet into the network, device by device. Sound like a plan?"

"Correct. We need to go all the way back and hit every server, network device, workstation... basically everything with an IP address. Then what?" I queried.

"I reverse direction, and work from the inside to the outside. What is this, a quiz?" Scrap snapped back as he emptied the last of our equipment bags.

"Just a refresher. I'm going to start my examination of the documents and perform the employee interviews. If you forget how to use nmap, just give me a call." I said with a grin.

Scrap wasn't amused.

I wandered over to the employee break room with my Powerbook and spied a fresh pot of coffee brewing.

"What timing." I joked as I poured a fresh cup of coffee into a nearby styrofoam cup.

I opened up the lid to my Powerbook, entered my password and my desktop sprang to life. Peter had mentioned to me earlier that his assistant, Chandra, would be emailing a zip file containing all six documents. I appreciated that, but I wanted to grab the documents directly from the FFS site.

I scored a break room table near a wall which had an easily accessible network connection marked "Employee Use Only". Ed had given us permission to attach whatever devices were necessary to complete this investigation, and by Joe my Powerbook was one of those devices.

After receiving a 10.0.2.x IP address from the network, I was able to access the internet.

"Ok, so I'm a nosey customer, and I want to research Treesoft. Hello, Google!" I said to myself as my copy of Firefox appeared. I typed in "Treesoft" into the Google search field and immediately received several thousand hits. Most of the search returns were web pages from Treesoft's own website, game review sites, game retailers, and discussion boards.

Thirty minutes later, I saw them.

Part V

I located all six documents on FFS's site. There was no posting time, no poster identification, and nothing else to isolate who could have uploaded these files. I was treated to lots of ads for adult entertainment sites, gambling sites, and cheap pharmaceuticals. "Great." I thought. "I get the same offers in my spam folder."

I clicked on the first download link to download document number one, which was the Microsoft Word memo from Dave to the entire Treesoft staff.


Your download will start in thirty seconds. Registered, paid members don't have to wait! Click here to join today for only $15US a month!


I had plenty of coffee left and a few minutes to kill. They weren't getting my $15.

After going through the same process for the other five documents, I had them neatly arranged in a folder on my Powerbook. I immediately opened up Disk Utility and made a read-only disk image of this folder. I wanted to work with these files in the exact state that I found them.

I had two Microsoft Word documents and four ASCII text files. I dumped the metadata from the Microsoft Word documents first :


Document was created on Windows.
Created : MS Word
Revised : MS Word
Last Author(s):
1 * CS *
2 * CS *
3 * CS *
Summary Information
Title : Memo
Subject :
Authress : EN
LastAuth : CS
RevNum : 4
AppName : Microsoft Word
Created : 01.05.200x, 09:18:00
Last Saved : 01.06.200x, 11:33:00
Last Printed : 01.06.200x, 11:33:00
Document Summary Information
Organization : Treesoft Games


The second Word document had very similar Metadata. I identified CS as being Chandra Smith, Peter's administrative assistant and EN as being Ed Notincourt.

Not a whole lot to go on here.

The three text files of source code appeared to have each line terminated by the familiar ^M control character. Interesting.

*BEEP*

My trusty Palm Treo alerted me to my first round of employee interviews that started in five minutes. I quickly packed up my Powerbook and headed towards a small conference room located near the administration side of the building.

When I conduct interviews in a company, I prefer to start with the 'lowest hanging fruit'. My first twenty interviews were with the the twenty newest employees to the company. None of these interviews were very productive towards establishing new leads for our case. Well, until I talked to my next interviewee; a developer named Eric ManDitt.

The following is a transcript from the last half of that interview:


Chief: Eric, I'm going to show you six documents that have been distributed outside of the company. These documents contain confidential information that has been leaked to unauthorized persons.

Eric: Okay.

Chief: These first two documents are company memos. Look familiar?

Eric: Um, well the first time I saw them was when they were posted to a couple of game sites. I'm too low on the food chain to get stuff like that.

Chief: Fair enough. How about this one? It discusses the schedule of the game you're working on.

Eric: That's familiar. Yes.

Chief: And these snippets of source code. These are from the game you are coding, right?

Eric: Yep. I guess.


At this point, Eric was in deep thought and not really paying attention to my probing questions. He had 'the look', which is usually an indicator that he had something to share.


Chief: Eric, is anything wrong?

Eric: No, not really. It's just kind of weird I guess.

Chief: Weird? What? How?

Eric: Um, well my team would have the necessary access to that source code, but the only person on my team that would have those memos and the project schedule would be our lead programmer, Sven Svenson. It's probaby just a coincidence.


Coincidence, indeed.

Part VI

My eyes were killing me. I had just finished up a marathon of interviews with Treesoft employees and was wandering back to my makeshift headquarters in an empty office. "Yo." said a familiar voice behind me. Scrap entered the office with two venti cups of Starbucks pleasure. "You look like you need a date with the bean queen."

"You could say that." I mumbled. "Dude, I have never seen a company that employs so many robots. These people literally come to work each day, do their job, go home late, and don't really socialize that much. The newest employees were quite friendly, the veterans were very dry."

Scrap smiled. "So much for that culture of caring, eh?"

I noticed that Scrap had plugged his trusty Scraptop into the network and was busily looking through scrolling network traffic.

"You got something?"

Scrap seemed to not hear me. A few moments later he glanced up from his Scraptop.

"I'm trying like hell to figure out their network security policy here. It's not documented at all. If you look at the firewall rules, they block everything on the ingress, but don't block anything from the egress. However, they do use a smart proxy on ports 80 and 443 to track web usage." Scrap said, tapping his pen on the desk in front of him.

"Does the firewall do any port logging in 'ACCEPT' mode at all? Are you telling me they could have people sending information out of the network through any port? That sucks." I said in disgust. "If it is someone inside the network, we're going to have a fun time proving something that happened in the past."

Scrap sat up in his chair. "Hold on to your britches, boss. If the leakage continues, the listener box on the gateway will snag it. Maybe we just need to have some patience?"

I sipped my Starbucks and took a deep breath. For once, Scrap was telling me to calm down.

"You're right. We wait. I have one last interview to do before we jam out of here today. Want to join me while I talk to Sven Svenson?" I asked.

"But of course." Scrap said as we wandered down the hallway and headed towards Sven's office.

knock knock

I knocked on Sven's door, however Sven couldn't hear me. His ears were covered in headphones that were pounding his brain with loud trance music.

"Sven." I said. "SVEN SVENSON!"

Sven looked up from his keyboard and practically fell off his chair. With one swift movement, he removed the headphones from his head and stood straight up.

"Oh, hi! I am Sven. And you are?" Sven asked.

"I'm Chief, this is Scrap. We just need to ask you a few questions as part of a security risk assessment." I replied as I glanced at the notepad in my hand.

"Sure! Okay. This is about that stuff they found on the web, right? Very bad. Very bad." Sven said as he locked the screen on his workstation. "I was very upset to see that. My team wrote that source code, you know."

Sven wasn't a lot of help. Our interview established that he did have the memos stored on his workstation, and he did keep snippets of code laying around on his hard drive. All source code was kept on a CVS server, of which he was the administrator. Sven made it a point to mention several times that no programmers are allowed to email source code around, especially outside of the company.

Scrap and I returned to our temporary office to pick up our things before we headed back to the hotel. I took a moment to check my email, and Scrap was busy staring at the screen of his Scraptop again.

"Chief."

I looked up from my Powerbook.

'What?"

Scrap turned his laptop around. "Remember when we worked that case at that school? The kids that set up the P2P network using supposed DNS servers?"

"Yep. Why?" I asked.

Scrap pointed to an ethereal capture screen, which displayed thousands of connections between the external interface of the firewall and several unknown IP addresses.

Treesoft had some leaky leaves.

Part VII

"They allow peer-to-peer clients on their network? Scrap, where's the network guy? What was his name?" I asked Scrap in a machine gun fashion."Well, boss, like I've been trying to say... nothing is really documented that well. The network guy, errr, Kurt is working on a dying mail server and hasn't given me much time." Scrap responded.

I crumpled up some fancy artwork I was drawing on my notepad and tossed the museum piece into the garbage can. "Alright, I'll go find Kurt. Run back to the wiring closet and tap the inside interface of the firewall. I want to know what machine or machines are serving up that P2P soup. The minute you locate the machine(s), pull their plug(s)."

Scrap rubbed his hands together. "Roger that."

I sprinted down the hall and almost ran John over.

"Woah! Chief! Something up?" John asked as he turned to walk with me.

"I need to talk to your network guy, Kurt. He really hasn't been available much to answer our questions." I said, almost out of breath.

John didn't look happy. "What? I told everyone, especially Kurt, that they needed to be available. Let me take care of..."

"John, seriously... it's okay. I'll find him. Thanks anyway." I said as I opened the door to Treesoft's server room.

John's behavior was very bipolar. One moment he was the happy company man, the next moment he was the only guy not wearing deodorant at a cocktail party full of fashion models. Strange.

I found Kurt curled up next to a large midrange server on the floor. He appeared to be locking the server's external case and about to power the machine back up.

"Hey Kurt, all done?" I asked.

Kurt stood up and towered over me by at least a foot. The man was huge.

"Yeah, I think so. Looks like my RAID controller went south, but I'm hoping that my array is still intact. I guess I'll find out after I hit the power button." Kurt said as he powered up the machine.

"Kurt, real quick... Scrap found some P2P traffic between the internal Treesoft network and the internet. Do you allow P2P clients on the internal network?" I asked.

My neck was becoming stiff from looking up at Kurt, so I took a few steps back.

"P2P? Hell no. We went through this about a year ago. You found some P2P traffic? What machine is it coming from?" Kurt asked as he watched the server scroll POST messages on the server's console screen.

"Scrap is finding that out now. Do you have a moment? We could really use your knowledge of the network." I begged.

"YES! YES!" Kurt screamed as he slammed his huge hands together.

"Wow, I'm glad you're excited about helping." I laughed.

"Nah, my array is fine. Phew. There was a lot of mail on there. Okay, let's go find your friend." Kurt said with a grin.

We wandered down another hall and found Scrap sitting on the floor of the wiring closet, staring at his Scraptop screen.

"Yo." I said as I walked in behind Kurt. "What do you have?"

Scrap looked up from the Scraptop.

"One internal IP address." Scrap replied. "10.0.1.75, and I was about to see who owns that puppy!"

scraptop:~ scrap$ nmblookup -A 10.0.1.75
Looking up status of 10.0.1.75
DELL1234 <00> - P
TREESOFT <00> - P
DELL1234 <03> - P
DELL1234$ <03> - P
SSVENSON <03> - P
MAC Address = XX-XX-XX-XX-XX-XX
scraptop:~ scrap$

Kurt did not look amused.

Part VIII

"Sven? Sven is running P2P on MY NETWORK? Oh, let me take care of this!!!" Kurt said as he brushed by me on the way out the door.Scrap and I hustled after Kurt, fearing for Sven's life.

Kurt made a beeline for Sven's office, only to find an empty desk.

I glanced at my watch.

"It's getting pretty late. Looks like we missed Sven." I said as Kurt sat down in Sven's chair.

"Bah, we don't need him. So help me, if Sven has P2P software installed on this workstation I'm going to remove his hippie sandals and beat him to death with them!" Kurt said with a snarl of his lip.

Kurt wiggled Sven's mouse, and a Windows 2000 desktop appeared on the monitor.

"Now I'm really pissed!" Kurt said. "Sven has been messing with the security settings on his workstation again. All of our workstations should lock after 10 minutes of inactivity."

I made some notes on my notepad and watched Kurt as he maximized a Limewire client window.

"Well my friend, Mr. Sven is going to eat some sandle candy tomorrow morning." Kurt said as he scrolled through Limewire's library lists.

I squinted my eyes and made a cursory observation of the files that Sven downloaded. Every single file was an mp3 audio file.

"What has Mr. Sven been sharing with the rest of the internet?" Scrap asked.

Kurt fussed with Limewire's preferences.

"Good grief." Scrap said as he shook his head. "Almost his entire C: drive is shared out!!!"

I peered at the configuration settings. Scrap was correct. Some key folders that were shared were:


C:\DOCUMENTS AND SETTINGS

C:\TEMP

C:\WINNT

C:\LIMEWIRE

C:\STUFF


"Kurt, can you click on the monitor tab? Can we see what people have downloaded from Sven's workstation?" I pleaded.

"Sure thing." Kurt replied as he clicked on the monitor tab. A huge scrollable list of files appeared on the screen.

We were about halfway through the list, when some familiar filenames began to appear.

As sure as the satisfaction gained from a venti americano at Starbucks, the six files posted to the web were present in the list. All of them downloaded a few days before Treesoft was made aware of the breach.

"Great milking monkeys!" Scrap exclaimed as inched closer to Sven's monitor.

"Chief, we found six documents posted out on the web. According to these upload records, I would guess that at least a hundred .txt, .rtf, .doc, .xls, and .pdf have been downloaded."

I closed my eyes. This couldn't get any worse.

"Uh, dudes? Did you two notice that all of these Treesoft documents were downloaded by a single IP address?" Kurt said with a grin.

A clue.

Part IX

I was scribbling notes onto my notepad faster than Scrap writing phone numbers down at a singles convention. "Interesting. One IP address downloaded all of our 'interesting' documents, and they were all downloaded within about a sixty minute period of time on the same day." I noted. "Looks like somebody found what they wanted."

Scrap wrote the IP address on his monkey paw with an ink pen and disappeared down the hall.

"Kurt, how much of a problem have you been having with P2P software on the network? Have you considered changing the security posture of the firewall to, you know, block outgoing traffic on non-proxied ports?" I asked as I snapped a couple of photos of Sven's desktop and his limewire configuration.

Kurt took a deep breath. Evidently I had hit a sore spot.

"Chief, you should have been here a year ago when I was hired. It was a zoo! Everyone had whatever they wanted on their workstations, there were almost no security controls in place. A large percentage of the programming staff had P2P stuff running day and night on their machines. When you have a small pipe to the internet like we have here, that slows up everything. Sven, here, was one of the worst offenders." Kurt said as he pointed to a picture of Sven on the far wall. "He's a damn good programmer, but has a thing for authority. Ironic that they made him a manager."

"Indeed." I agreed. "So you're controlling the installation of unauthorized software by corporate policy? No controls on the desktop?"

"Yep. I tried to lock them down the Microsoft-recommended way, however the programmers install/uninstall stuff off their workstations all the time. I gave up. I talked to John and Peter one day and they decided to go on the honor system. You see how far that's gotten us." Kurt lamented.

I smiled. "Kurt, you're a systems administrator. You're never going to be able to make every user happy every day. It's impossible." Of course, when your sysadmin is as large as Kurt, you're lucky when you don't get pounded into paste after doing something stupid.

"Thanks. I need to head home and feed my cats. Here's my cell number if you guys need anything." Kurt said as he offered me his business card.

I made my way towards our 'base camp' of an office. Two bankers boxes of HR records greeted me as I unlocked the door.

"And I was worried about not having any bathroom reading later." I chuckled to myself.

I dove into the HR records and selected Sven's personnel record. Amazingly enough, Sven didn't have a single disciplinary action form in his file. It would appear that his earlier P2P misconduct was forgiven with a verbal warning. As a matter of fact, I didn't find a single disciplinary action form in any of the employee files.

"Now THAT is a first." I said as I dropped the last record back into the box. I found nothing to help me generate a motive for the leaked information.

Frustration began to set in.

I was temporarily distracted from my unhappiness by Scrap's footsteps running down the hall and landing in our office.

Scrap was out of breath.

"Chief... you... aren't... going to... believe... this." Scrap panted.

"What, that you need to cut down on the Newports?" I responded.

"No dammit, look at this!!" Scrap said as he handed over his Scraptop.


scraptop:~ scrap$ nslookup 64.xx.xx.xx
Server: 10.0.1.9
Address: 10.0.1.9#53
Name: xx-xx-xx-64.gamersbeatches.net

scraptop:~ scrap$ whois gamersbeatches.net
Registrant:
GAMERSBEATCHES.NET Entertainment, Inc
(DOM-XXXXX)
12351 Third Circle
San Francisco
CA
94XXX US


"Gamersbeatches.net? Scrap, aren't those the guys that were almost bought by Majorcorp a year ago?" I asked as I reached for my Powerbook to do some research.

Scrap was still panting. "I... know... that's why... I wanted... to show you... this."

I brought up Google and quickly searched for several articles on the thwarted purchase of gamersbeatches.net by Majorcorp.

Scrap was busy hacking up a lung.

"That's it! That's right. These guys were knee deep in negotiations and the due diligence caved in on GB. They weren't nearly as valuable as they claimed to be. They went from a game developer to a gaming news site." I exclaimed as I grinned ear to ear.

Scrap had blown the case wide open.

Part X

I couldn't sleep a wink. Scrap and I were up late theorizing about the connection between gamersbeatches.net and Treesoft.Was this just a coincidence that Sven's P2P application shared information that was sensitive to Treesoft? Was it a coincidence that someone at GB just happened to do a keyword search for items that turned up on Sven's drive? If there was an insider at Treesoft trying to do the company in, why not just email the documents home or steal them on a thumb drive? Why go through all this hassle?

Scrap had fallen asleep on the floor of my hotel room and, as usual, was snoring louder than Delta Burke on a lazy Sunday afternoon.

I closed my eyes and struggled to get a few hours sleep. The facts of the case were whipping around in my brain so fast that my eyes were rotating in their sockets. Had I missed a clue? Had I overlooked an obvious fact? Was I making ridiculous assumptions?

"Screw this." I said as I rolled off of my bed and nearly stepped on the Scraptop, perched carelessly on the floor. A quick glance at the clock revealed the time to be 0600 hours.

It was coffee time.

I grabbed my notepad and Powerbook and jumped in the elevator. I was a short walking distance from the temple of the brewed brown bean.

My eyes started to rotate again. The thoughts returned.

I had missed something.

Minutes later I was rushing back up the elevator, laptop bag slung over my shoulder and two venti coffees in my hands.

"Scrap! Scrap! Wake up and clean up. We need to drive over to Treesoft first thing." I said as I handed Scrap his coffee.

Scrap rubbed his eyes. "Dude, I had the weirdest dream. I dreamt that Barbie from our Minotaur case was washing my car and eating a hamburger at the same time..."

I really should work alone.

Several hours later we finally arrived at Treesoft HQ. I unlocked our office door and threw one of the banker's boxes of records at Scrap.

"What gives?" Scrap complained. "Did you switch to espresso or something? Calm down!"

His comments were a whisper. I had zeroed in on the bankers box that I wanted and was feverishly going through all of the current employee records again, one by one.

"You want me to go interview Sven when he gets in? You look a little psycho." Scrap said.

"What?" I snapped back.

"Preoccupied! You look preoccupied." Scrap responded, correcting himself accordingly.

"Fine." I said as I waved him back out the door. I had found what I was looking for.

Scrap entered Sven's office to a familiar sight. Sven was staring deep into his monitor, trance music beating into his ears via headphones.

"Yo." Scrap said as he waved his monkey paws in front of Sven's face.

Sven jumped. Again.

"Scrap! Scrap! Hey, I'm glad you're here. Check out this wicked piece of japanese anime I snagged from some dude!" Sven said as restored a minimized media player window.

"Sven, what gives with the Limewire window? I talked to Kurt last night and he said that P2P software is banned here." Scrap asked in a most sincere voice.

"Aw, Kurt is so anally-retentive about this network. I bet he burps up pearls. I just turn it on for searches. Okay, here's the video!" Sven said as he maximized the video window.

"Seriously man, can I ask you what directories you have shared on your machine?" Scrap queried.

Sven looked confused.

"Uh, my 'stuff' directory. That's all I ever share out. Check it out, I have movies, music, some cool pictures of sheep ..."

Scrap ran around third base and aimed for home. "Sven, can you bring up your preferences in Limewire?"

Without a flinch, Sven clicked through menu options.

"Ya, and?" Sven asked.

Scrap reached towards the sky with his monkey paw and scratched his head.

The only directory shared was C:\STUFF.

Part XI

"I swear, I don't know. I seriously do not know." Sven stammered as he made eye contact with everyone in the conference room.I was playing my hand forward and had decided to conduct an interview with Sven. Scrap and Ed were present in the room, carefully taking notes of the discussion.

"Well, I'm a bit confused Sven. Last night your workstation was unlocked, limewire was running and sharing very sensitive company files, and you don't seem to know anything about this?" I asked as I slid a few photos of Sven's desktop toward him.

Sven examined the photos carefully. His hands were shaking, and his face clearly showed a state of befuddlement.

"Chief, you have to believe me. I know that P2P was banned on the network. I know I shouldn't have disabled the screen lock on my workstation. I most certainly know to never share directories with sensitive stuff in them! I have this exact limewire configuration on my home computer. I only share one directory, and that directory is full of pictures, movies, and other fun things." Sven said.

I stopped my pacing around the room and took a seat directly across from Sven.

"Sven, let's assume that you're telling the truth about this obvious violation of company policy for a moment. Put on your detective hat. If you didn't start that limewire session with the modified sharing preferences, who did? What is their motive? Clue us in here." I said in a calm voice.

Sven started looking at the floor. You could almost hear the squeaking noise from the hamster running around on their wheel inside his head.

"I really try to follow John's philosophy of 'everyone for the company, the company for everyone'. I haven't made any enemies here, and if I have it was completely unintentional."

Ed leaned towards me in his chair and slid a file folder towards me. I was puzzled that Ed chose this time to provide me with more reading material. Scrap sensed that this material was important and proceeded to ask Sven some technical questions about other possible workstation safeguards that Sven had disabled.

With Scrap providing cover, I opened the folder and found a stack of door reports for the Treesoft HQ building. I scrolled down the report for yesterday, and found several interesting entries.

17:30 - MAIN - OUT - KURT
17:45 - MAIN - IN - CONTRACT - CLEAN1
17:47 - MAIN - IN - CONTRACT - CLEAN2
19:30 - MAIN - OUT - CONTRACT - CHIEF
19:30 - MAIN - OUT - CONTRACT - SCRAP
20:15 - MAIN - OUT - ERIC
21:30 - MAIN - OUT - CONTRACT - CLEAN1
21:32 - MAIN - OUT - CONTRACT - CLEAN2


I closed the folder and peered over at Scrap. Scrap knew what this look meant, and ended his questioning of Sven.

It was time to play an ace that I had tucked into my monkey fur.

"Sven, tell me about your relationship with one of your programmers - Eric Manditt." I queried, careful to watch for a reaction.

"Eric? Eric. Yes, we have a history. Eric and I worked together in the past on a lot of games. I wouldn't say that we are friends in a social sense, but we work well here at Treesoft."

"Sven, didn't you and Eric apply for the same job at Treesoft?" I asked, again looking for a reaction.

Sven seemed puzzled at my questions.

"No, no we did not. Well, wait. That is complicated. We both applied for programming positions. We were both hired as programmers. A few weeks after I was hired I was promoted to a management position of 'team lead' which was a serious horizontal promotion, if you know what I mean." Sven replied.

"And how has Eric taken to the role of your subordinate?" I asked.

"Okay, I guess? We have never spoken about the subject."

I flipped over my ace.

"For the record, where did you and Eric work together before?" I inquired.

Sven's expression changed almost immediately.

"Gamersbeatches" Sven replied.

The monkey holds a royal flush.
